    "pages": }\n\n'''Frank Murphy''' (May 15, 1897December 25, 1944) was the 44th .\n\n\nMurphy was born on May 15, 1897, in . In 1920, Murphy moved to . There, he attended the . In 1921, Murphy was a member of .\n\n\nIn 1930, Murphy became an accountant. Under Governor Murphy, Murphy was appointed as state sales tax supervisor. In 1939, he ran unsuccessfully for a seat on the .  In 1940, he was elected as . His electoral success was often attributed to the fact that his name was identical to that of the , to whom he was not related. Murphy served as the 44th Lieutenant Governor of Michigan of from 1941 to 1942. He was a . By January 2, 1941, the Republican majority state senate took the power to appoint committees in the state senate away from Lieutenant Governor Murphy, and took on the power themselves. Murphy asked for unity in his first address to the state senate. \n\nIn 1942, Murphy failed to gain re-election as lieutenant governor. In 1943, he ran in the Detroit mayoral primary election. On October 5, he was defeated by , coming in fifth in the election. \n\nIn June 1944, Murphy pleaded guilty before Circuit Judge  to accepting a $2,500 bribe from two distilleries in exchange for using his influence as lieutenant governor to promote Senate Bill 203 in 1941 which lowered the distilling license fee from $5,000 to $1,000. At the time of his confession, Murphy was very ill. He died before the court could sentence him.\n\n\nMurphy was married to Constance Kirchner. Together they had five children.  Murphy was a member of the . Murphy was .\n\n\nOn December 25, 1944, in , Murphy died due to  which was complicated by heart problems that he had been suffering from for several months. He was interred in  in Detroit.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Eileen Kowall''' (born January 5, 1952) is an American politician, dental hygiene practitioner, and business woman from Michigan. Kowall is a former member of . Kowall is the current county commissioner of .\n\n\nKowall attended Wayne State University. In 1974, Kowall earned an Associate of Arts degree in Dental Hygiene from University of Detroit. Kowall completed the Michigan Excellence in Public Service series.\n\n\nIn 1974, Kowall became a dental hygiene practitioner, until 1989.\n\nIn 1989, Kowall became a business woman as a co-owner, Sales representative and designer of Accurate Woodworking, Incorporate in Waterford, Michigan, until 2004.\n\nOn November 4, 2008, Kowall won the election and became a  member of  for . Kowall defeated Mark Venie with 66.60% of the votes. On November 2, 2010, as an incumbent, Kowall won the election and continued serving District 44. On November 6, 2012, as an incumbent, Kowall won the election and continued serving District 44. Kowall defeated Tom Crawford and Scott Poquette with 62.79% of the votes.\n\nKowall's husband, , serves in the , making them the first married couple to serve in the Legislature at the same time in 25 years ( and Colleen House were the last). Eileen was known to be more conservative than her husband .\n\nIn November 2014, Kowall won the election and became a county commissioner of  for District 6. In November 2018, as an incumbent. Kowall won the election and continued serving as a county commissioner of  for District 6. Kowall's term will expire in December 2020.\n\n\nKowall's husband is . They have two children. Kowall and her family live in Waterford Township, Michigan.\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*  \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Gary Woronchak''' is an American politician and newspaper editor.\n\nBorn in , Woronchak graduated from  and was the editor for the Dearborn Press & Guide and managing editor of the Daily Tribune in . He served in the  from 1999 to  2004 and lived in . Woronchak then served on the  Board of Commissioners, starting in January 2005 until December 2018. He was Chairman of the Commission from 2011–2018. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''John Burley Swainson''' (July 31, 1925 – May 13, 1994) was a Canadian-American politician and jurist who served as the 42nd  from 1961 to 1963.\n\n\nSwainson was born in , Canada. He moved to , at the age of two, with his family.\n\nHis father, John A. C. Swainson, of , was a Democratic  for Michigan in 1964 and an alternate Michigan  to the .\n\nHe was captain of his high school football team and an .\n\nSwainson served in the  during World War II with C Company,  of the  and lost both legs by amputation following a  explosion November 15, 1944, near , . He was awarded France's '''', the  with two battle stars, and the , all before his twentieth birthday. After months of convalescence and rehabilitation at the  in , Swainson learned to walk upright and unassisted.\n\nSwainson received a B.A. from , where he also met and married his wife, Alice Nielson. She accompanied him to the , where he received a  degree in 1951. While there, he was elected student president of the law school.\n\n\nSwainson was elected to the  from the  in 1954 and was reelected in 1956. In 1958, when  was elected to the , Swainson succeeded Hart as the  under Governor . When the long-serving and popular Williams announced he would not seek re-election in 1960, Swainson decided to enter the race. He did so despite being pressured by influential  members, including Williams, not to run in deference to three-term , . Swainson won the primary against the party favorite, largely due to strong support from labor unions.\n\nOn November 8, 1960, Swainson narrowly (1.28% margin) defeated  Paul D. Bagwell, a  professor, in the . As a result, the 35-year-old Swainson became the youngest governor of Michigan in the 20th century.The \"Boy Governor\", , elected at 24 in 1835, was younger. He was also the state's second foreign-born governor. , who succeeded Swainson, was the third and was born to US citizens residing in Mexico and was thus a US citizen from birth but was born out of the US.  was the fourth and was also born in Canada.}}\n\nSwainson's  was . His opponent in the Democratic primary, Hare, continued to serve as  until 1971.\n\nDuring his two years in office, a tax was secured on the usage of telegraphs, telephones, and leased wires; court procedures and medical care for the elderly were improved, legislative pensions were excluded from both local and state taxes; and taxes on liquor, beer, and cigarettes were raised to fund educational programs.\n\nWhen the  (which spans the  between Port Huron, Michigan, and ) was paid off, Swainson used an executive order to cancel the $0.25  that had been collected. \"\", he effectively cancelled his own father's \"$6,115-a-year toll-collector's job,\" which John A. C. Swainson held since 1957.\n\nHe appointed the first African American to sit on the Michigan Supreme Court.\n\nIn 1962, Swainson was defeated by Republican , the chairman of the , who had never before held elected office. The win was attributed in part to Romney's appeal to independent voters, as well as to the increasing influence of suburban Detroit voters, who, by 1962, were more likely to vote Republican than the heavily Democratic city. (It also marks the only time in US history that a governor born in Canada was replaced by one born in Mexico.)\n\n\nOn June 23, 1963, Swainson accompanied the Reverend ,  , and approximately 125,000 people on a \"Walk for Freedom\" march down Detroit's . The same year, he was also a member of  from Michigan.\n\nHe served as Michigan Circuit Court judge of the 3rd Circuit from 1965 to 1971 and as a justice of the  from 1971 to 1975. In 1975, he was accused of accepting a $20,000 bribe from a felon, who was seeking review by the Supreme Court. He was found not guilty but was convicted of  over his testimony to the . As a result, he resigned from the Supreme Court, was sentenced to 60 days in a minimum-security facility, and lost his license to practice law for three years.\n\nThe criminal charges derailed his expected run to replace retiring  . There are pundits who maintain that he was the \"victim of an overzealous prosecutor.\"\n\nHe later became an antiques dealer and became president of the Michigan Historical Commission. In the later years, he often represented the state at the Detroit Highland Games and apologized for not wearing a kilt: \"I don't have the legs for it.\"\n\nHis life's journey was described as being an inspirational story of personal redemption: \"By 1985, his reputation was restored when he was appointed president of the Michigan Historical Commission. (Michigan Supreme Court. Michigan Reports: Cases Decided by the Supreme Court of Michigan. Rochester, N.Y.: Lawyers Co-operative Publishing Co., 1949 - 1998, Vol. 419.)\"\n\n\nAt the age of 68, Swainson died of a heart attack in , and he is interred there at Oak Grove Cemetery. His wife, Alice, died on September 5, 2004, in Manchester at 77.\n\nDuring his life, he was a member of , , , , , , , and . In the Boy Scouts, Swainson was an active leader of the local  lodge and served as secretary.\n\nThe Michigan Historical Commission established the Governor John B. Swainson Award in 1996 to honor him for his love of history and as one of the few public officials to have served in the legislative, executive, and judicial branches of state government. The commission presents the award to state, county, or municipal employees who have contributed to the preservation of Michigan history even if such activities are not part of their primary job responsibility. Swainson's last public office was president of the Michigan Historical Commission as an appointee of Governor .\n\nHis papers are 75.1&nbsp;ft, collected at the  at the University of Michigan. Particularly represented are documents regarding research, public policy, and programs concerning  and the .\n\nSwainson was honored by an official portrait painted by Dorthea R. Stockbridge. The portrait was dedicated at a Special Session of the Michigan Supreme Court's Special Session. The portrait hangs on the fourth floor of the .\n\nHanging in the  on the second floor 'Hall of Governors' is \"his gubernatorial portrait [that] is notable for appearing unfinished.\" It is said to be one of the most unusual portraits, a portent that Swainson's political career was not yet finished. The Republican legislature even authorized the painting of a more traditional replacement, which has not yet been accomplished.\n\nAt the dedication of his judicial portrait, Swainson said he left the final judgement of his public career to history.\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* Named a 2010 \"\" by the .\n*\n*\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Nancy Jenkins-Arno (née Jenkins)''' (born June 2, 1964) is a former member of the Michigan House of Representatives from the , which covers most of .\n\nJenkins has a bachelor's degree from  and a master's degree from the . She worked as a title representative and then on the staff of state senator  before being elected to the state house in 2010. From 2017 through the present, she has worked as director of development for Hudson Area Schools. She is currently running for re-election in the 34th House District.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Kristy Pagan''' (born September 5, 1982) is a  politician from  who represented the  in the  from 2015 to 2020.\n\nPagan attended Plymouth-Canton Community Schools,  and .  After working in the  office of U.S. Senator , she returned to Canton to start a small business. In addition, she worked at .\n\nPagan's community involvement includes the Canton Community Foundation Board of Directors as well as the Advisory Council for the STEM program at Canton High School.\n\nIn 2015, Pagan was appointed to serve on the House Appropriations Committee.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Daisy L. Elliott''' (November 26, 1917 – December 22, 2015) was an American politician and realtor from the .\n\n\nElliott was born '''Daisy Elizabeth Lenoir''' in , and resided in . She was a delegate to the 1961–1962 Michigan Constitutional Convention from Wayne County's 4th district, which resulted in .\n\n\nA , she represented Wayne County's 4th district in the  from 1963 to 1964, , which replaced Wayne County's 4th district, from 1965 to 1972, and Michigan's 8th district from 1973 to 1978. She was an unsuccessful candidate in the primary for the  5th district in 1978. then regained her old seat in the Michigan House in 1980. In politics, Elliott was nothing if not persistent: she was defeated five times in the primaries for State Representative (the 1st district in 1950, the 11th district in 1954, and the 4th district in 1956, 1958 and 1960) before finally winning in 1962.\n\nWhile serving in the Michigan State House of Representatives, she co-authored the , which passed in 1976, with .\n\nIn April 1982, Elliott was arrested for possessing a stolen 1977 . She was defeated by  in the Democratic primary that year, and, after numerous appeals, had her conviction upheld in 1984. She served sixty days in jail before being released in June 1985.\n\n\nShe was a member of Democratic Party,  (NAACP), , and .\n\n\nShe died on December 22, 2015, aged 98, at DMC Sinai-Grace Hospital in Detroit. She is interred at  near the Rosa L. Parks Freedom Chapel.\n\nIn 2016, she was inducted into the . On June 30, 2020, the Lewis Cass Building in Lansing was renamed the  in honor of Larsen and Elliot.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Jocelyn Benson''' (born October 22, 1977) is an American academic administrator, attorney, and politician serving as the 43rd  since 2019. A member of the , she is a former dean of , a co-founder of the Military Spouses of Michigan, and a board member of the Ross Initiative in Sports for Equality. Benson is the author of ''State Secretaries of State: Guardians of the Democratic Process.''\n\nIn , Benson was elected as the Secretary of State in Michigan, securing the position with an 8.9 percentage point margin over Republican Mary Treder Lang. This victory made her the first Democrat to hold the office since 1995. She was reelected in , defeating Republican  by a margin of 14 percentage points, setting a record for the largest margin and vote share among statewide candidates that year. \n\n\nBenson graduated '''' from  in 1999, where she founded the now-annual Women in American Political Activism conference and was the first student to be elected to serve in the governing body for the town of . She subsequently earned her master's in  as a  at , conducting research into the sociological implications of white supremacy and neo-Nazism.\n\nPrior to attending law school, Benson also lived in , where she worked for the  as an , researching white supremacist and neo-Nazi organizations. Benson has also worked as a summer associate for voting rights and election law for the , and as a legal assistant to  at .\n\nBenson received her  from , where she was a general editor of the . From 2002 to 2004, she served as the Voting Rights Policy Coordinator of the Harvard , a non-profit organization that sought to link academic research to civil rights advocacy efforts, where she worked on the passage of the federal .\n\nUpon graduation from Harvard Law, Benson moved to Detroit to serve as a  to the Honorable  on the  for the .\n\n\nBenson was appointed dean of  in December 2012 at the age of 35, becoming the youngest woman to lead a top 100 law school in United States history.\n\nAs dean she established two \"marquee\" programs: the Levin Center at Wayne Law, chaired by former United States Senator  (D-MI), and the Program on Entrepreneurship and Business Law, which helps aspiring business professionals in underserved communities participate in the economic revival of Detroit.\n\nPrior to being appointed Dean in 2012, Benson was the associate director of the Damon J. Keith Center for Civil Rights, where she started the Michigan Allies Project, an effort designed to track hate incidents throughout Michigan and provide legal support for victims.\n\n\nFrom 2016 to 2018 Benson served as CEO of the Ross Initiative in Sports for Equality (RISE).\n\n\nIn 2012, Benson joined with three military spouses and family members in Michigan to create Military Spouses of Michigan, a network dedicated to providing support and services to military family members and veterans in Michigan. In January 2013, the group was selected to represent the state of Michigan in the Presidential Inaugural Parade, the only group of military spouses to receive that honor.\n\n\nIn 2011, Benson was selected to serve with retired U.S. Supreme Court Justice  on the national board of directors of iCivics, Inc., a nonprofit created by Justice O'Connor to improve civics education throughout the country. In addition to serving as an appointed member of the 's Standing Committee on Election Law, she is also the founder and current director of the Michigan Center for Election Law, which hosts projects that support transparency and integrity in elections. In 2011, the center hosted Michigan's first \"Citizens' Redistricting Competition\", providing an opportunity for Michigan citizens to access software and draw their own redistricting maps for the state.\n\nBenson developed and supervised three statewide nonpartisan election protection efforts in Michigan in 2007, 2008 and 2012.  During the 2008 election, she was called to testify before the , where she called on  to ban the use of foreclosure lists to challenge voters' eligibility on .Shawn Wright,  ''The South End'', March 3, 2009 She is a frequent commentator on voting rights and election law on local news and radio broadcasts.\n\nIn 2007, Benson worked with several groups to successfully keep a Secretary of State branch office open in . The , under then-President , concluded that the closure of the office would violate the .\n\n\n from   in January 2023]] \nIn March 2010, Benson published her first book, ''State Secretaries of State: Guardians of the Democratic Process''. The book highlights best practices of  from throughout the country and seeks to inform voters about how secretaries of state across the political spectrum can work to advance democracy and election reform. After working with secretaries of state from around the country while researching the book, she was inspired to run for the office in her resident state of Michigan. She lost to Republican candidate  by a margin of 51 percent to 45 percent.\n\nOn October 27, 2017, Benson announced her second candidacy for Michigan Secretary of State. She was elected on November 6, 2018, defeating  Mary Treder Lang, becoming the first Democrat to serve since  left office in 1995. In 2022, Benson secured her party's nomination uncontested and went on to win the general election with 56% of the vote, defeating Republican candidate candidate .\n\nBenson has gained national prominence, making frequent appearances on cable news shows, appearing on the cover of '''' magazine alongside fellow election officials, and testifying before Congress about the challenges election workers have encountered in recent years.\n\n\nThroughout her tenure, Benson has implemented reforms in the Secretary of State's office, including filling vacancies, expanding online services, installing over 150 new  stations, and seeking state funding for additional mobile offices. She significantly increased the proportion of services conducted outside of branches, reaching about 60% of transactions online, by mail, or at self-service stations as of May 2021, up from about 25% in 2018. In April 2021, Benson announced that appointment-only visits to secretary of state offices would become permanent.\nDespite criticisms calling for the reintroduction of walk-in services, Benson defended retaining the system even after the , highlighting the benefits of next-day appointments for urgent matters and the overall reduction in wait times, providing a more efficient process.\n\n\nIn the year of her election, Michigan voters approved a  allowing  voter registration and unrestricted . Benson's office oversaw the implementation of these changes. During Benson's tenure, in 2019, the Election Modernization Advisory Committee was established. Comprising 27 local and national experts, the committee played a pivotal role in shaping  and was considered a key component of Michigan's preparation for the 2020 elections. She also established an Election Security Commission consisting of 18 experts in  and . The commission, funded by a federal election security grant and facilitated by state employees, aimed to enhance election integrity.\n\nSince 2020, Benson has emerged as one of the prominent state-level advocates defending American elections. Prior to the 2020 presidential election, Benson identified  across the state with the lowest participation rates and visited them to understand how she could assist residents in exercising their . Want Better Elections? Choose Better Elections Officials |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/16/opinion/voting-rights-elections-secretary-of-state.html |access-date=2023-10-15 |issn=0362-4331}} She has advocated for and enacted initiatives to streamline the registration process, maintain accurate , and increase the number of eligible voters. Benson facilitated voter registration by allowing online registration in advance with approved identification and in-person registration on Election Day. In 2020, amid the COVID-19 pandemic, she initiated the distribution of  well in advance of the election and spearheaded the state's inaugural campaign to enlist and train a new generation of . Benson mailed absentee voter applications to all 7.7 million Michigan registered voters for the August primary and November general election, citing the need for equal access and health protection during the COVID-19 pandemic. The effort was funded by $4.5 million in federal coronavirus relief funding from the . In June, she initiated a platform enabling registered voters to apply for an absentee ballot online, using their  and last four digits of their . Voters were also allowed to submit a scanned, signed copy of their absentee ballot application via email. Benson also played a role in developing an online ballot-tracking tool for absentee ballots.\n\nBenson's administration has worked on improving voter education for students in high schools and colleges statewide, a factor in Michigan achieving the highest youth  in the 2022 election, where 18 to 29-year-olds participated at a rate of 37%, surpassing the national average of 23%, according to Tufts University's Center for Information and Research on Civic Learning and Engagement. In August 2019, she initiated the Collegiate Student Advisory Task Force to address challenges that could hinder the voting capabilities of young citizens. Her administration has collaborated with local clerks and colleges, such as the 's robust early voting site, and has engaged in programs like MI Vote Matters with high schools, facilitating convenient voting for students and encouraged voter registration among 17- and 18-year-olds.\n\n marked a historic turnout, exceeding 5.5 million voters. Benson credited the achievement to prioritized voter education, enhanced accessibility and a surge in absentee voting, with 3.1 million registered voters choosing to cast their ballots by mail. She has upheld the integrity of the 2020 presidential election in Michigan and has refuted unfounded allegations of voter fraud from former President  and has stated that the attempts to  ultimately resulted in the . Local elections in May also achieved a \"record-breaking turnout,\" with 25% of registered voters participating, of which 99% voted by mail or in a drop boxsignificantly surpassing the 10-year average turnout of 12% in local May elections.\n\nIn preparation for the , Benson, alongside other Democratic leaders, has collaborated on the Democracy Playbook, a set of over 40 recommendations by the NewDEAL Forum aimed at enhancing election systems nationwide, with a focus on election integrity, voting access, and civic engagement. In July 2023, she confirmed that federal prosecutors interviewed her for \"several hours\" in March as part of the ongoing criminal probe into efforts to overturn the 2020 election. While not divulging specific details, Benson highlighted the investigators' focus on the impact of misinformation on election workers' lives and threats. Benson is an advocate for stricter penalties against those who harass election workers and for increased funding to support elections. She aims both to explicitly prohibit and to enhance penalties for threatening election officials, ',' and pressuring them to violate the law. She has highlighted legislative goals that involve tightening rules on  signature gathering, holding accountable those who mislead voters, and securing more funds for municipalities to conduct elections.\n\n\nAs Trump voiced concerns about potential election fraud associated with absentee voting, his criticism particularly targeted Benson's mailing effort. He called Benson a \"rogue Secretary of State\" Bridge Michigan |url=https://www.bridgemi.com/michigan-government/michigan-gop-lawmakers-claim-jocelyn-bensons-absentee-ballot-mailings-illegal |access-date=2023-10-16 |website=Bridge Michigan |language=en}} and initially threatened to withhold federal funds for coronavirus relief, but later retracted his threat. Court rulings affirmed Benson's legal authority to mail absentee ballot applications to all registered voters in Michigan in 2020, while the state auditor discredited Republican claims of fraudulent ballots from deceased voters, highlighting that the 2,775 problematic votes represented only 0.02% of the 11,725,897 votes cast in the eight reviewed elections, with 98.5% of these few votes being cast by electors who died within 40 days of the elections. On December 7, 2020, reportedly armed  demonstrators gathered outside her home, echoing Trump's election fraud claims. The demonstrators chanted and made threatening demands to overturn Michigan's election results, linking the incident to broader efforts by Trump and his legal team to challenge the election outcome. No arrests were made and police confirmed that there were no breaches of criminal law throughout the demonstration. Benson faced death threats for her role in overseeing the 2020 election. In January 2020, a 72-year-old man was arrested after evidence was found in his home related to violent threats he directed at Benson. In December 2022, she stated that threats from election deniers that started in 2020 had not ceased. In May 2023, she claimed in an interview that after the election, Trump suggested she be tried for treason and possibly executed, an accusation he denied. In October 2023, a 60-year-old man from Detroit was sentenced to 15 months of probation after threatening to kill Benson and Michigan Governor .\n\nBenson's efforts to modernize and expand access to elections have faced legal challenges, with GOP officials claiming the mailings are illegal and could result in fraudulent activities, although the decision was compliant with the Michigan constitution and upheld in court. Michigan GOP lawmakers, such as Benson's predecessor , criticized her for using COVID-19 relief funds to mail absentee ballot applications to all registered voters. Republicans argued that the move could compromise election security and lead to voter fraud. Despite disputes and claims of potential fraudulent activities, experts argued that the multiple verification requirements in place make a significant increase in fraud unlikely. In response to concern over applications reaching dead or relocated individuals, Benson has contended that the mass mailing aids in identifying and removing inactive or deceased voters, and emphasized the long-standing signature verification measures as safeguards against fraud.\n\nBenson has been named in multiple lawsuits. In October 2019, she was specifically named in a lawsuit filed by Priorities USA, a Democratic group, over the elimination of absentee votes due to disparities between a voter's signature and other filed documents with election officials. In November, the group targeted her in a lawsuit challenging the state's automatic registration law and alleging undue burdens on young voters' constitutional rights. In March 2021, Michigan’s Court of Claims ruled against Benson, saying that although the instructions' content did not breach election law, she had not followed the appropriate procedural measures while providing guidance to clerks on verifying signatures on absentee ballots. In September 2022, the Election Integrity Force and others sued Benson and Michigan’s governor, , in a bid to decertify the 2020 election. Controversies also arose during Benson's administration regarding the Michigan Bureau of Elections' guidance on signature matching for absentee ballots in the lead-up to the 2020 presidential election. The guidance, maintaining the presumption of a valid signature, faced legal scrutiny, and in March 2021, State Court of Claims Judge  ruled that such instructions should be issued as an administrative rule. The court found the process used to send the content to the clerks did not follow the state Administrative Procedures Act, prompting the Bureau to undergo the APA rulemaking process, which is now in effect.\n\nIn a September 2023 opinion piece for '''', Benson argues that secretaries of state, including herself, shouldn't unilaterally decide Trump's eligibility to serve as President under the 14th Amendment of the U.S. Constitution, and emphasized that the courts, particularly the , are the appropriate forums for such determinations. Benson subsequently released the list of candidates to be listed on Michigan's Presidential Primary 2024 ballot. The list included Donald Trump.\n\nIn November 2023, Trump's legal team sued to prevent Benson from excluding him in Michigan's . The lawsuit argues Benson lacks authority to disqualify him under the , seeking an injunction against barring him from the ballot. Despite Trump's request for confirmation, Benson's reported silence adds uncertainty. The dispute traces back to a Free Speech for People lawsuit, asserting Trump's Capitol riot involvement violates Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.\n\n\nAiming to address the state's 2015 ranking as the lowest in the U.S. for ethics and transparency, Benson has advocated for ethics reforms and emphasized the need for transparency in the state's government in the wake of various scandals. She has aimed to enhance citizens' understanding of influence in , with financial disclosures as a starting point and the possibility of addressing  accounts.\n\nIn March 2021, Benson introduced a legislative agenda called \"From Worst to First\" to enhance , coinciding with . The proposed measures included expanding the  to cover the  and Legislature, requiring personal  from elected officials, demanding more frequent campaign disclosures, and tightening regulations to prevent secret and foreign money in Michigan elections. In 2023, she criticized inaction from legislators, describing the state's  and  laws as \"far, far behind\" other states.\n\n\nA long-distance runner, Benson averages two full s per year. She has completed twenty-three full marathons since 2005, including races in New York City, Honolulu, San Francisco, Washington, D.C., Florence, Venice, Chicago and Philadelphia. She completed her 18th marathon representing Team Red White and Blue in Rome, Italy. She completed her second  in 2016, and became one of a handful of women in history to complete the Boston Marathon while more than eight months pregnant.\n\n\nBenson was among several high-profile Democratic officials viewed as potential contenders for the 2024 U.S. Senate race in Michigan to take the seat of retiring Senator . Benson announced that she would not enter the race in March 2023 and said she would instead be focused on protecting democracy and elections in Michigan in her role as Secretary of State. She is considering a run for the open Michigan Governor's seat in 2026.\n\n\n'''' named her one of Michigan's \"Most Influential Women\" in 2016 and in October 2015, she became one of the youngest women in the state's history to be inducted into the , second only to . In 2022, Benson was named as one of five recipients of the  for her efforts to protect democracy. \n\nOn January 6, 2023, Benson was awarded the  by President Joe Biden, for her \"undaunted and unflinching\" work in performing \"exemplary public service to advance free and fair elections.\"\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|years=2019–present}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Ian Kyle Conyers''' (born October 28, 1988) is an American politician and businessman who represented the  of  in the  for one term. \n\nConyers sat on the Economic Development & International Investment, Energy & Technology, and Banking & Financial Services Committees in the State Senate. He was minority vice chair of the Transportation Committee.\n\n\nConyers was born in 1988 and raised in . His father's family has lived there since his great-grandfather, John Conyers Sr. moved there from rural  as part of the . His grandfather, William Conyers, was the younger brother of Congressman , who retired in 2017 after setting a record for longevity in Congress.\n\nIan Conyers attended . He graduated from , where he obtained a B.A. in government. While at Georgetown, Conyers played football and joined the Kappa Chi chapter of  fraternity. Conyers also earned a Master's degree in urban and regional planning from Georgetown. While in Washington, DC, he worked on the Anacostia waterfront redevelopment, a multi-year, public-private effort.\n\n\n\nOn January 27, 2016, Conyers filed to run in the Democratic Party primary election for Michigan's 3rd State House District.\n\nOn April 13, 2016, Conyers filed to run in the Democratic primary election to fill the remainder of the term for the vacancy in Michigan's 4th State Senate District. Candidates were running to replace , who had resigned from office amid a domestic violence scandal. In the primary, Conyers won a nine-candidate race with 34.52% of the vote. In the General Election, Conyers defeated Republican Keith Franklin with 76.55% of the vote. He entered office in November 2016 for the remainder of the term; at 28 years of age, he was the youngest state senator in Michigan's history to that date.\n\nConyers was assigned to the Economic Development & International Investment, Energy & Technology, and Banking & Financial Services committees in the State Senate. He served as minority vice chair of the Transportation Committee. His term ended December 31, 2018.\n\n\nIn late 2017 his great-uncle, Congressman , was the subject of several allegations of sexual harassment by former staffers. In November, the House Ethics Committee initiated an investigation into the allegations and John resigned on December 5, 2017. He endorsed his son, John Conyers III, as a potential successor. Ian Conyers announced his intention to run for the seat on the same day, saying that John had encouraged him to run privately. Conyers later tweeted, then deleted, pictures of John Conyers III, then underage, with alcohol. Conyers added the caption asking the media to take \"a thorough look at all candidates\". On January 19, 2018, Ian Conyers formally announced his candidacy for the 13th Congressional District vacancy.\n\nAfter Republican Governor  held the seat vacant for over one year the election was announced as a double primary in which one contest was to finish the unexpired term of John Conyers Jr. and a second concurrent election was to hold the office from 2018 until 2020. Detroit city council president Brenda Jones won the partial election,  narrowly won the full term by 800 votes.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''David Henry Crowley''' (September 5, 1882December 21, 1951) was a  lawyer and politician.\n\n\nDavid H. Crowley was born on September 5, 1882, in , to parents Daniel Crowley and Margaret Crowley. In 1905, David earned a LL.B. from the .\n\n\nIn June 1905, Crowley was admitted to the . Crowley served as  Prosecuting Attorney from 1909 to December 1912. Crowley served as Assistant Michigan Attorney General from January 13, 1913, to November 1, 1916. Crowley served as er from November 10, 1916, until his resignation in January 1917. Crowley resigned to practice law in  as a member of the law firm Monaghan, Monaghan, O'Brien & Crowley, which later became Monaghan, Crowley, Reilly & Kellogg and then became Monaghan, Crowley, Clark & Kellogg. Crowley served as special counsel for Detroit in public utility matters from 1918 to 1933. On April 1, 1935, Crowley was elected as a regent member of , a position he served in from 1936 to 1943. After the resignation of Michigan Attorney General , Crowley was appointed by Governor  to fill the vacancy. In 1936, Crowley tried to keep his position as attorney general, but was defeated in the election.\n\n\nOn August 17, 1909, Crowley married Nina C. Barrett in . Together, they had two children. Crowley was a member of the , the , and the .\n\n\nCrowley died on December 21, 1951, in . He was buried at .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Yousef D. Rabhi''' (born June 9, 1988) is a former member of the  who also served as the Democratic Floor Leader. He represented , encompassing the majority of , from 2017 to 2023. He replaced , who was term limited. He is a member of the .\n\n\nRabhi was born in  and raised on the North Side of Ann Arbor. His father is a mechanical engineer and his mother a longstanding community activist. His mother's involvement in the Ann Arbor Democratic Party, as well as his grandfather's history of labor organizing in  inspired Rabhi to pursue a career in public service.  Rabhi is of  descent on his paternal side.\n\nRabhi attended Blossom Home Preschool where he was exposed early to environmental protection through the Adopt-A-Stream program. After graduating from  in 2006, Rabhi attended the  and graduated with a Bachelor of Science in Environmental Science with a specialization in urban planning and ecosystems management.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\tIn 2010, while still attending the University of Michigan, Rabhi was elected to the Washtenaw County Board of Commissioners, earning over 75% of the vote to defeat Republican candidate Joe Baublis.\n\nHe won his primary election by two votes.\n\nThe commissioners elected Rabhi to serve as chair of the Board's Working Sessions.\n\n\nFollowing the redistricting completed in 2011, Washtenaw's districts shrunk from eleven to nine. Unopposed in the Democratic primary, Rabhi was elected as commissioner for District 8, which comprised most of the same area as the former District 11. Rabhi won 77.75% of the vote, succeeding again over Republic candidate Joe Baublis.  His fellow commissioners elected Rabhi to serve as chair of the Board.\n\n\nAfter winning 82.22% of the vote, Rabhi was reelected in 2014 to serve as District 8's county commissioner; the Board elected him to serve as vice chair.\n\n\n\n\n\nRabhi announced his candidacy for Representative for Michigan's 53rd District in September 2015. The seat was left vacant by Democrat Jeff Irwin who was term limited. Irwin - alongside a majority of local elected officials like Ann Arbor Mayor Chris Taylor and the entire Ann Arbor City Council – endorsed Rabhi's candidacy. Rabhi ran on a platform that sought to secure \"a healthier Environment, a resilient Economy, a strong Public Education system, and Equity for all\".\n\n\nIn the August 2016 Democratic primary, Rabhi won over 85% of the vote over candidate Steven Kwasny. In the November general, Rabhi secured 80.26% over the vote, defeating Republican candidate Samuel Bissell and Green Party candidate Joseph Stevens.\n\n\nThrough his six year tenure as a county commissioner, Rabhi served as chair of the Board's Working Sessions, chair, and vice chair. During his time as  chair, Washtenaw County balanced a four-year budget for the first time in its history. Under Rabhi's leadership, the Board was also able to secure stable 10-year labor agreements and earn the County's first AAA Bond rating.\n\nRabhi also spearheaded many community development programs, including the creation of the first Municipal ID program in the Midwest and the establishment of the Washtenaw Dental Clinic, which serves uninsured and Medicaid eligible patients.\n\nAs a county commissioner, Rabhi served on many different boards such as committees and commissions covering public safety, public works, solid waste management, transportation, regional cooperation, human service funding, land preservation and food policy.\n\n\nRabhi was sworn into the  in January 2017. He serves on the House Committee on Appropriations. He serves on the House Appropriations Subcommittees on Higher Education, Community Colleges, and Department of Environmental Quality. He also serves as the minority vice chair on the Appropriations Subcommittee on the Department of Environmental Quality. During his second term, he is serving on the Committee on Government Operations, the House Fiscal Agency Governing Committee, and the Legislative Council.\n\nRabhi has campaigned for the shutdown of  (a petroleum pipeline that crosses the ) asserting the 65-year-old pipeline is likely to spill.\n\nHe opposed revisions made to the Michigan Public School Employees Retirement System in 2017 which shifted state educators' pensions into  plans.\n\nRabhi has also backed legislation supporting immigration rights and , and .\n\nRabhi was elected Democratic Floor Leader for the 100th session of the Michigan Legislature.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* https://housedems.com/rabhi\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Tom Casperson''' (July 20, 1959 – November 29, 2020) was an American businessman and politician from the State of . He formerly served as a  member of the , representing the , which includes much of the . He previously served in the , representing the .\n\n\nCasperson was born in , in 1959. He graduated from  in 1977. He worked in his family's log trucking business, Casperson and Son Trucking, for 25 years, and owned the business for ten years. He was married to Diane Casperson, with whom he had four children.\n\n\n\nCasperson served in the  from 2003 to 2008. He was the vice chair of the House Transportation Committee and was a member of the Agriculture and Resource Management; Land Use and Environment; and Veterans Affairs and Homeland Security committees. He then served in the  from 2011 to 2018 representing much of the .\n\nAs state senator, Casperson voted against the passage of  laws in 2012.\n\nIn 2013, while on a radio talk program, Casperson said he was not sure President  was born in the United States.\n\n\nOn May 14, 2008, Tom Casperson filed over 1700 petitions with the Secretary of State, formally launching his bid for Congress for the  as a Republican against incumbent Democrat . That support translates into designating Casperson as the candidate that gathered the most support among all the candidates that have filed for the First Congressional District. Following his announcement of candidacy on March 17, Casperson traveled the entire District, covering all 31 Counties, and secured petitions from each county within the District.\n\nAccording to the Federal Election Commission (FEC), Casperson reported total campaign finance receipts of $102,059 as of July, 2008 - of which three quarters of that amount was donated by individuals, one eighth from Political Action Committees (PAC) and one eighth the candidate himself loaned to his campaign. As of July the two other Republican contenders for the 1st Congressional District seat had not filed financial reports with the FEC. (Under the Federal Election Campaign Act only candidates who have raised (or spent) over $5,000 are required to file financial reports.) Rep. Bart Stupak, (D) Menominee, reported to the FEC $730,541 in total receipts; of which the majority was contributed by PAC's. Roughly three-eighths of the congressman's contributions came from individuals.\n\nAccording to the FEC, Americans for Constitutional Enforcement (ACE) of Iron Mountain, the Michigan Farm Bureau PAC, the National Electrical Contractors PAC, the Michigan Infrastructure and Transportation Association Federal PAC, the MILEAD Fund, and several Republican candidates and groups constitute Casperson's PAC support. Stupak has 16 pages of PAC's listed in his FEC report. PAC's supporting Stupak include numerous communications giants like AT&T, Alltel, Time Warner, Motorola, Sony, Universal, Verizon and Viacom. (Stupak chairs the Oversight and Investigations subcommittee of the U.S. House Commerce Committee - which conducts investigations and oversight of the telecommunications industry.) In the November 2008 election, Casperson was defeated by Stupak.\n\n\nCasperson died from  on November 29, 2020.\n\n\n*'''2008 campaign for Congress'''\n**Tom Casperson (R), 33%\n** (D), 65%\n*'''2006 campaign for State House'''\n**Tom Casperson (R), 55%\n** (D), 44%\n*'''2004 campaign for State House'''\n**Tom Casperson (R), 68%\n** (D), 31%\n*'''2002 campaign for State House'''\n**Tom Casperson (R), 51%\n** (D), 48%\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

He represented the , which includes , , , , , ,  and  Counties.\n\nAfter leaving the state legislature, Allen served as a senior policy advisor for the , Department of Military and Veterans Affairs, State of Michigan. He served as the Michigan state director for  during the .\n\nAllen was a candidate for the U.S. House of Representatives from  in 2010 and 2016, but lost the Republican primary both times.\n\n\nBorn in , Allen is a moved to , at a young age. After graduating high school he attended . From there he completed his education at  in , where he earned a bachelor's degree in Finance. He then returned to his hometown and began a job at his family's menswear business, Captain’s Quarters, located in downtown Traverse City. He has served in the  with the rank of E4 specialist and is a member of the . Allen has also remained active in his community. As an  he continues to help out with scouting activities, serving on the President Ford Executive Board and counseling merit badges.\n\n\nPrior to becoming a senator in 2002, Allen served as a member of the  for the  from 1999 to 2002. In 2016, Allen signed the  , committing to opposing tax increases.\n\nOn November 6, 2017, the  announced the appointment of Jason Allen as the new state director for  in Michigan.\n\n\nAllen unsuccessfully sought the Republican nomination for Congress in the 2010 primary election, losing by fifteen votes out of 70,996 total votes cast. Allen chose not to request a recount, saying he did not want to put either the party or the district through the lengthy and costly process.\n\nHe ran in 2016 for the Republican nomination for the open congressional seat.     "pages": }\n'''Paula Zelenko''' (born January 12, 1957) is a Michigan politician who formerly served as 's mayor and a member of the  .\n\n\nIn 1991, Zelenko was elected to the Burton City Council, serving until 2001. She was then elected to the , serving the  until 2006. Zelenko returned to the Burton City Council in 2008 and served until December 2010. The council had pre-selected Zelenko prior to Smiley's resignation date. In 2019, Zelenko announced she would not seek a third term as mayor. On November 18, 2019, Duane Haskins was sworn in as Zelenko's successor.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n|children      = 4, including \n|father        = \n|education     =  (, )\n|signature     = John Dingell Signature.svg\n|allegiance    = United States\n|branch        = \n|serviceyears  = 1944–1946\n|rank          = \n|battles       = \n|module        = \n}}\n\n'''John David Dingell Jr.''' (July 8, 1926 – February 7, 2019) was an American politician from the state of  who served as a member of the  from 1955 until 2015. A member of the , Dingell holds the record as the  in American history.\n\nBorn in , Dingell attended , where he earned a Bachelor of Science in chemistry in 1949 and a  in 1952. Dingell began his congressional career by succeeding his father, , as representative for  on December 13, 1955. A longtime member of the , Dingell chaired the committee from 1981 to 1995 and from 2007 to 2009. He was  from 1995 to 2015. Dingell was instrumental in the passage of the , the Water Quality Act of 1965, the , the , the , and the , among other laws. He also helped to pass the . Dingell was one of the final two  veterans to have served in Congress; the other was  Representative .\n\nDingell announced on February 24, 2014, that he would not seek reelection to a 31st term in Congress. His wife, , successfully ran to succeed him in the . President  awarded Dingell the  in 2014. Dingell left office on January 3, 2015.\n\n\nDingell was born on July 8, 1926, in , the son of Grace (née Bigler) and  (1894–1955). His father was the son of  immigrants, and his mother had  and  ancestry. The Dingells were in Colorado in  for Dingell Sr.'s . The Dingell surname had been Dzięglewicz, and was Americanized by John Dingell Sr.'s father.\n\nThe family moved back to Michigan, and in 1932, Dingell Sr. was elected the first representative of Michigan's newly created 15th District. In Washington, D.C., John Jr. attended  and then the  when he served as a page for the U.S. House of Representatives from 1938 to 1943. He was on the floor of the House when President  gave his famous speech after the bombing of . In 1944, at the age of 18, Dingell joined the . He rose to the rank of second lieutenant and received orders to take part in the first wave of  in November 1945; the Congressman said that President 's decision to  saved his life.\n\nDingell attended  in Washington, D.C., receiving a Bachelor of Science in chemistry in 1949 and a  in 1952. He was a lawyer in private practice, a research assistant to U.S. District Court judge , a congressional employee, a forest ranger, and assistant prosecuting attorney for  until 1955.\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 1955, Dingell's father, John Dingell Sr., died. Dingell, a Democrat, won a special election to succeed him. He won a full term in 1956 and was re-elected 29 times, including runs in 1988 and 2006 with no Republican opponent. Dingell received less than 62% of the vote on only two occasions. In  when the  swept the Republicans into the majority in the House of Representatives for the first time since 1954, Dingell received 59% of the vote. In  when the Republicans re-took control of the House of Representatives, Dingell received 57% of the vote. Between them, he and his father represented the southeastern Michigan area for 80 years. His district was numbered as the 15th District from 1955 to 1965, when  merged it into the -based 16th District; in the primary that year, he defeated 16th District incumbent \n\n in 1955]]\nIn 2002, redistricting merged Dingell's 16th District with the  and western -based 13th District, represented by fellow Democratic Representative , whom Dingell also bested in the Democratic primary. The 15th District for the  included Wayne County suburbs generally southwest of Detroit, the  and  areas in Washtenaw County, and all of Monroe County. For many years, Dingell represented much of western Detroit itself, though Detroit's declining population and the growth of its suburbs pushed all of Detroit into the districts of fellow Democratic representatives, including . Dingell always won re-election by double-digit margins, although the increasing conservatism of the mostly white suburbs of Detroit since the 1970s led to several serious  challenges in the 1990s.\n\nDingell announced on February 24, 2014, that he would not seek re-election to a 31st term in Congress.\n\n\n]]\nDingell was sworn in as a member of the U.S. House of Representatives on December 13, 1955.\n\nDingell was instrumental in the passage of the , the Water Quality Act of 1965, the , the , the , and the , among others. He also helped to pass the .\n\nDingell was generally classified as a moderately liberal member of the Democratic Party. Throughout his career he was a leading congressional supporter of ,  measures and traditional  policies. At the beginning of every Congress, Dingell introduced a bill providing for a  system, the same bill that his father proposed while he was in Congress. Dingell also strongly supported 's managed-care proposal early in his administration. In October 1998, President Clinton began a  appearance \"by thanking Senator  of West Virginia and Congressman Dingell for their steadfast support of Medicare and their participation in our Medicare Commission.\"\n\nOn some issues, though, Dingell reflected the values of his largely Catholic and working-class district. He supported the  until 1971. While he supported all of the  bills, he opposed expanding school desegregation to Detroit suburbs via . He took a fairly moderate position on abortion. He worked to balance clean air legislation with the need to protect manufacturing jobs. As well, in the early 1980s, he was a prominent politician who used \"\", blaming \"little yellow men\" for domestic automakers' misfortune, further fostering anti-Japanese racism in Detroit and contributing to the environment that led to the , an American man of Chinese descent killed in the Detroit suburbs by two autoworkers who mistakenly thought he was Japanese.\n\nAn avid sportsman and , he strongly opposed , and was a former board member of the . For many years, Dingell received an A+ rating from the NRA. Dingell helped make firearms exempt from the 1972 Consumer Product Safety Act so that the  had no authority to recall defective guns. Dingell's wife, Representative Debbie Dingell, introduced legislation in 2018 to remove this exemption from the law.\n\n\n wrote of Dingell in 2002:\n\n\n\nDingell was  from 1995 to 2015.\n\nOn December 15, 2005, on the floor of the House, Dingell read a poem sharply critical of, among other things, , , and the so-called \"\". Along with , in April 2006, Dingell brought an action against  and others alleging violations of the  in the passing of the . The case ('''') was ultimately dismissed for lack of .\n\nAfter winning re-election in 2008 for his 28th consecutive term, Dingell surpassed the record for having the longest tenure in the history of the House of Representatives on February 11, 2009. In honor of the record, Michigan Governor  declared February 11, 2009, to be John Dingell Day.\n\nDingell was one of the final two  veterans to have served in Congress; the other was  Representative .\n\nDingell left office on January 3, 2015. As of that date, Dingell had served with 2,453 different U.S. Representatives in his career. Dingell served in Congress for more than 59 years, retiring as the longest-tenured member of Congress in the history of the United States. His wife, , successfully ran to succeed him in the .\n\n\nA longtime member of the , Dingell chaired the committee from 1981 to 1995 and from 2007 to 2009.\n\nDingell was well known for his approach to congressional oversight of the executive branch. He subpoenaed numerous government officials to testify before the committee and grilled them for hours. He insisted that all who testified before his committee do so under oath, thus exposing them to  charges if they did not tell the truth. He and his committee uncovered numerous instances of corruption and waste, such as the use of $600 toilet seats at . He also claimed that the committee's work led to resignations of many  officials, and uncovered information that led to legal proceedings that sent many  officials to jail.\n\n with  in 2006]]\nAfter serving as the committee's ranking Democratic member for 12 years, Dingell regained the chairmanship in 2007. According to '''', he had wanted to investigate the  Administration's handling of port security, the Medicare prescription drug program and 's energy task force.  magazine has stated that he had intended to oversee legislation that addresses  caused by carbon emissions from automobiles, energy companies and industry.\n\nDingell lost the chairmanship for the  to Congressman  of California in a  meeting on November 20, 2008. Waxman mounted a challenge against Dingell on grounds that Dingell was stalling certain environmental legislation, which would have tightened something that could be detrimental to the  that constitute a major source of employment in Dingell's district. Dingell was given the title of Chairman Emeritus in a token of appreciation of his years of service on the committee, and a portrait of him is in the House collection.\n\n\nIn the 1980s, Dingell led a series of congressional hearings to pursue alleged scientific fraud by  and Nobel Prize-winner . The 's fraud unit, then called the , charged Imanishi-Kari in 1991 of falsifying data and recommended that she be barred from receiving research grants for 10 years. She appealed the decision and the  appeals panel dismissed the charges against Imanishi-Kari and cleared her to receive grants. The findings and negative publicity surrounding them made David Baltimore decide to resign as president of  (after Imanishi-Kari was cleared he became president of the ). The story of the case is described in ' 1998 book ''The Baltimore Case'', in a chapter of 's 2004 book '''', and in a 1993 study by , updated and reprinted in his book ''Challenges''.\n\n\nFrom 1991 to 1995 Dingell's staff investigated claims that  had used samples supplied to him by  to fraudulently claim to have discovered the . The report concluded that Gallo had engaged in fraud and that the NIH covered up his misappropriation of work by the French team at the . The report contended that:\n\n|sign=|source=}}\n\nThe report was never formally published as a subcommittee report because of the 1995 change in control of the House from Democratic to Republican. Other accusations against Gallo were dropped, and while Montagnier's group is considered to be the first to isolate the virus, Gallo's has been recognized as first to prove that this virus was the cause of AIDS.\n\n\n at the 2011 Ypsilanti Independence Day Parade]]\nDingell was a member of the .\n\nDingell opposed raising , which he helped to write in the 1970s. Instead, he indicated that he intended to pursue a regulatory structure that takes  and oil consumption into account. In a July 2007 interview with , he said \"I have made it very plain that I intend to see to it that CAFE is increased\" and pointed out that his plan would have  (CAFE) standards increased tantamount to those in the Senate bill recently passed. In November 2007, working with House Speaker , Dingell helped draft an energy bill that would mandate 40% increase in fuel efficiency standards.\n\nIn June 1999, Dingell released a report in which the  cited concurrent design and construction was the reason for production of high levels of explosive  gas. In a statement, Dingell asserted that \"mismanagement by the  and  led to an extraordinary, and pathetic, waste of taxpayer money. All we have to show for $500 million is a 20-year delay and the opportunity to risk another $1 billion to make a problematic process work.\"\n\nIn July 2007, Dingell indicated he planned to introduce a new tax on carbon usage in order to curtail greenhouse gas emissions. The policy has been criticized by some, as polling numbers show voters may be unwilling to pay for the changes. A '''' editorial claimed that vehicle emissions standards that he supported will not yield any substantial greenhouse gas emissions savings.\n\nAs one of his final votes, Dingell voted against the  on November 13, 2014.\n\n\nDingell was closely tied to the , as he represented , where the  of , , and the , are headquartered. Dingell encouraged the companies to improve . During the , Dingell advocated for the  the companies received.\nDuring the electoral span of 1989 through 2006, intermediaries for the aforementioned corporations contributed more than $600,000 to Dingell's campaigns. Dingell also held an unknown quantity, more than $1&nbsp;million in 2005, in assets through General Motors s and savings-stock purchase programs; his wife, Debbie Dingell, is a descendant of one of the Fisher brothers, founders of , a constituent part of General Motors. She worked as a  for the corporation until they married. She then moved to an administrative position there.\n\n\n's ]]\n* ''''''\n** \n** \n**  (''ex officio'')\n** \n** \n**  (''ex officio'')\n\n\nDingell was Catholic. He had four children from his first marriage to Helen Henebry, a flight attendant. They married in 1952 and divorced in 1972. Dingell's son, , served in the  and has served as a judge on the Michigan Third Circuit Court.\n\nIn 1981, Dingell married Deborah \"Debbie\" Insley, who was 27 years his junior. In November 2014,  won the election to succeed her husband as  for . She took office in January 2015. She is the first non-widowed woman to immediately succeed her husband in Congress.\n\nDingell had surgery in 2014 to correct an abnormal heart rhythm, and the next year had surgery to install a pacemaker. He was hospitalized after a fall in 2017. On September 17, 2018, Dingell suffered an apparent heart attack and was hospitalized at  in Detroit.\n\nIn his later years, Dingell became an active Twitter user, and earned over 250,000 followers for his witty and sarcastic posts attacking Republicans, particularly . He earned the nickname \"the Dean of Twitter\".\n in 2018.]]\nIn 2018, Dingell was diagnosed with , which had . He chose to forgo treatment, and entered . Dingell died on February 7, 2019, at his home in . On the day of his death, Dingell authored a column discussing his \"last words\" for the country; the column was published in ''''.\n\n\nDingell received the  Humanitarian Award from Wayne State University in 2006.\n\nPresident  awarded Dingell the  in 2014.\n\nThe , named in his honor and signed into law on March 12, 2019, permanently reauthorized the  and established multiple areas of land protection.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Gary Richard Glenn''' (June 16, 1958 – July 27, 2023) was an American politician and activist who was a member of the  for the , from 2015 to 2018, as a . He campaigned to prohibit compulsory union membership or financial support as a condition of employment.\n\nHe was also president of the  of Michigan, an organization that the  has recognized as a homophobic hate group.  In his role with the American Family Association, he coauthored a 2004 amendment to the state constitution which defined marriage as solely between one man and one woman, until it was overturned by the U.S. Supreme Court's 2015 decision in ''''.\n\n\n\n\n\nAs executive director of the Idaho Freedom to Work Committee from 1980 to 1986, he led a successful effort to enact a state  prohibiting collective bargaining agreements that require membership in or financial support of a labor union as a condition of employment. For his leadership of a 1986 statewide ballot campaign in which Idahoan voted to keep the law, Glenn and actor  were named co-recipients of the \"Freedom Fighter of the Year\" award by the Center for the Study of Market Alternatives, a free market think tank located at the College of Idaho.\n\nIn 2011, Glenn was a founding board member of the Michigan Freedom to Work coalition, which successfully advocated similar legislation in that state.\n\nIn 2015, the National Right to Work Committee gave him its Senator Everett M. Dirksen Award for advocacy of the Right to Work principle.\n\n\nGlenn enlisted in the  during the  buildup in 1990 and served eight years in the Reserves and , including with the 1/183 Attack Helicopter Battalion in Boise, Idaho, and the 1460th Transportation Company headquartered in Midland, Michigan. He was named \"Honor Graduate\" of both Basic Combat Training and Advanced Individual Training, earned two Army Reserve Component Achievement Medals, and was honorably discharged at the rank of Sergeant in 1998.\n\n\nIn 1999, Glenn became president of a recognized hate group, the American Family Association of Michigan, an organization dedicated to \"preserving traditional Judeo-Christian family values, opposing Internet pornography in public libraries and special \"protected class\" status based on homosexual behavior or cross-dressing.\" The organization campaigned in support of a  to define marriage as \"the union of one man and one woman\"; the measure was .\n\n\n\nGlenn ran in the , campaigning against marriage and adoption by same-sex couples. He was finished in last place out of four candidates in the Republican primary, after unofficially dropping out. The winner, , lost to incumbent Senator  in the general election.\n\n\nGlenn was elected to the  in November 2014, representing the 98th House District, comprising the cities of Auburn, Linwood, Midland, and Pinconning, the village of Sanford, and thirteen suburban and rural townships in Bay and Midland counties.\n\nDuring the 2017–18 legislative term, he served as Associate Speaker of the House Pro Tempore and as chairman of the House Energy Policy Committee. He also served on the House Communications and Technology, Insurance, and Military and Veterans Affairs committees. During the 2015–16 session, he served as vice chairman of the House Energy Policy Committee and on the House Commerce and Trade, Military and Veterans Affairs, and Tax Policy committees.\n\nGlenn was reelected in 2016 with just over 60 percent of the vote. The Republican House Caucus elected him Associate Speaker of the House Pro Tempore, and he was appointed by the Speaker of the House to serve on the seven-member Committee on Committees, which recommended the chairs and membership of each House committee, and to serve as one of three Finance Co-chairmen of the House Republican Campaign Committee.\n\nGlenn drew attention for his conservative voting record. He received a 100 percent score from –Michigan and from the state chapter of the .\n\nHe won the  \"Award for Conservative Excellence\" for the most conservative voting record in the Michigan House in 2015, 2016, and 2017.\n\nIn 2016, he was named \"House Member of the Year\" by the Associated Builders and Contractors of Michigan and received NFIB's \"Guardian of Small Business\" Award.\n\nIn 2017, he was named \"House Member of the Year\" by the Michigan Propane Gas Association.\n\nIn 2014 and 2016, the Abolitionist Roundtable, an organization of conservative African-American radio talk show personalities in the metro Detroit area, named him the recipient of its annual \"Champion of Liberty Award\" for his work towards economically and socially conservative policies.\n\n\nGary Glenn and his wife Annette moved from  to 's Williams Township, in order to run in the August 2018 primary for the 31st District state Senate seat, comprising Bay, , and  counties. He received 41% of the vote, losing to former state Rep. Kevin Daley with 59%. The state's two regional monopoly utility corporationsConsumers Energy and Detroit Edisonspent an estimated $1.2 million in \"dark money\" advertising against Glenn, who as chairman of the House Energy Policy Committee had advocated eliminating their monopoly powers and allowing customers to buy electricity from competing energy providers. Glenn's wife, Annette Glenn, succeeded him as representative for the 98th district in the state House.\n\n\n\nGary Glenn was a member of Midland Baptist Church, and was a founding board member of the new Midland .\n\nGlenn and his wife Annette were married in 1983, and they had five children and nine grandchildren.\n\nGlenn was diagnosed with stage 4 metastatic prostate cancer in January 2016, which showed indications of recurrence in 2018 and 2021. He died on July 27, 2023, at the age of 65.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
