    "pages": }\n\n'''Rick Baxter''' (born July 18, 1979) is an American businessman and politician from .  He currently is the Chief Operating Officer (COO) of Baxter Machine & Tool Co., Inc. in .\n\nBaxter's previous positions have been the chairman of the   Party, the Business Development Director for his family's company Baxter Machine & Tool Co., Inc. in , district director for Congressman  (R-MI) (2007),   State Representative in the  (2005–2006), County Commissioner for  (2003–2004), and holding several positions, most recently as Chief Financial Officer (CFO), for Baxter Machine & Tool Co., Inc. (1997–2004).\n\nBaxter is a member of a local  congregation where he has taught a Bible class and has served as their Treasurer since 2005.  He has also been a guest preacher at his and other churches.  Rick Baxter is a graduate of  in  (1997) and received his Bachelor of Arts degree (BA) from  in  (2003).\n\n\nBaxter's first campaign was in 2002 when he ran for the Jackson County (Michigan) Commission.  He defeated the two-term incumbent  county commissioner in the primary and went on to win the seat, unopposed, in November.\n\nIn 2004, Baxter ran for an open seat for State Representative.  He defeated two other Republicans in the primary. Baxter won a very tight general election, winning by 358 votes out of a total of 37,714.\n\nAs State Representative Baxter had 14 bills signed into law.  In the summer of 2005 he published a controversial article in the Wall Street Journal titled \"How to Skin a Wolverine.\"  The article caught the ire of then Governor  who labeled his views \"treasonous.\"  During both years in the Michigan House he was rated by Inside Michigan Politics as \"The Most Conservative Freshman\" in the Michigan Legislature, rated second Most Conservative in the entire State in 2006.\n\nFor his next re-election, Baxter won the primary with over 65% of the vote but went on to lose his re-election bid in the general.  Both parties combined spent almost 1.5 million dollars in this race that year.\n\nIn 2008 Baxter ran for the open seat of Jackson County Treasurer, but lost the election in November.\n\n\nBaxter served as chair of the Jackson County Republican Party from 2007 to 2008.  During that time he was credited for fundamentally reorganizing the local party, rewriting their by-laws, consolidating their committees, and removed prominent inactive members with active new ones.  He secured  as the keynote speaker for the party's major fundraiser of the year, the Lincoln Day Dinner, an event that raised over $20,000, well over double what any preceding event had raised.\n\nIn 2008 he has started to organize the Party to work more closely with candidates, at all levels, to share costs, strategies, and resources.  In June 2008, Baxter resigned his position as chair to run for Jackson County Treasurer.\n\nIn 2008, Baxter was awarded \"Republican of the Year\" by the Jackson County Republican Party.\n\n\nBaxter's business career started after he graduated in 1997 from Lenawee Christian School in Adrian, Michigan.  He began working in the summer of 1997 as a CAD Tech/Accounting Assistant and worked his way up to Chief Financial Officer (CFO) in 2003.  He left the company at the end of 2004 to become State Representative.\n\nIn October 2007, he left his position as district director for Congressman  to rejoin the family business as their Business Development Director.  In this position he handled Baxter Machine's business development, sales, and customer relations.\n\nIn November 2008 he founded Driven Motors, a used vehicle dealership based solely online.  The business grew from there and added a physical presence in Jackson by the summer of 2010.  In late 2010, Driven Motors added a vehicle repair facility for both its dealership and open to the public.  By early 2011, the company doubled its capacity and doubled its staff.\n\nBy 2014, Driven Motors has grown to offer vehicle sales and financing, auto salvage, auto repair, and auto detailing.\n\nIn July 2014, he returned to his family's business, Baxter Machine, as its Chief Operating Officer (COO) after his brother, holding a similar position, left the company.  In 2015 he sold off his remaining interest in Driven Motors.\n\n\n*'''2008 Jackson County Treasurer General Election'''\n**Rick Baxter (R), 44.9%\n**Karen Coffman (D), 54.5%\n*'''2006 State House (64) General Election'''\n**Rick Baxter (R), 47.4%\n**Martin Griffin (D), 52.6%\n*'''2006 State House (64) Primary Election'''\n**Rick Baxter (R), 65.3%\n**Bob Ross (R), 34.7%\n*'''2004 State House (64) General Election'''\n**Rick Baxter (R), 49.8%\n**Martin Griffin (D), 48.8%\n**Bob Ross Write-In, 1.3%\n*'''2004 State House (64) Primary Election'''\n**Rick Baxter (R), 44.3%\n**Bob Ross (R), 28.8%\n**Jon Williams (R), 26.8%\n*'''2002 Jackson County Commission (05) Primary Election'''\n**Rick Baxter (R), 40.2%\n**Alan Miltich (R), 32.4%\n**Judy Reynolds (R), 23.0%\n**Trish O'Shea (R), 4.4%\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Roger grew up on a beef and dairy farm and graduated from Beal City High School. He then attended  before starting a 24-year career at . Hauck currently serves as minority vice chair of the Senate Regulatory Affairs Committee and as a member of Health Policy, and Energy & Environment committees.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Padma Kuppa''' (born August 10, 1965) was a member of the  from the , which encompasses the cities of  and , from 2019 to 2022. She was the first Asian immigrant and Hindu to serve in the .\n\nKuppa is a  by trade and a community organizer. She has served as President of the Troy Historical Society, which oversees the Troy Historic Village, and is a founding member of the Troy-area Interfaith Group. She is  in , , and .\n\nIn 2022, Kuppa unsuccessfully ran for the  in the new 9th Senate District following the decennial  process.\n\n\nKuppa was born on August 10, 1965, in . In 1969, her father began attending  on , as a graduate student, and later became a post-doctoral fellow. Her mother also went back to school and eventually earned a  in biology from Stony Brook and was a post-doctoral fellow at  and .\n\nIn 1970, during her parents' studies in the , Kuppa and her family moved to Long Island where she began attending kindergarten. When she was 15 years old, Kuppa and her family returned to India, unlike most immigrants of the era. Kuppa recalled of her parents' decision: \"That move was very difficult. I did not think or behave as an Indian. I was Indian on the outside and American on the inside.\" She has also said of this time in her life, \"I didn't feel at home. I had an American accent, I had an American attitude. And so I think that it wasn't just the best age to move, to shift cultures.\"\n\nReturning to India with her family in 1981, Kuppa finished high school at  and later graduated from Regional Engineering College Warangal (now ). Kuppa was the first woman to earn a degree in  from the university.\n\nIn 1988, Kuppa returned to the United States to attend graduate school at Stony Brook University, her parents' alma mater, as a foreign student. In 1998, Kuppa and her husband moved to .\n\n\nKuppa is a founding member of the Troy-area Interfaith Group, as well as the local Bharatiya Temple's Outreach Committee. She has served as a board member and advisory board member of the Women's Interfaith Solutions for Dialogue and Outreach in Detroit (WISDOM). She became board president of the Troy Historical Society, which oversees the Troy Historic Village, in October 2018.\n\nKuppa worked with  as a mechanical engineer and project manager for over five years. She later worked as a business analyst at . Kuppa served on the City of Troy's Planning Commission from 2015 to 2018, having been appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council. She was later elected to serve on the city's Zoning Board of Appeals from 2017 to 2018.\n\nIn 2018, Kuppa was elected to the . She assumed office in 2019 for the 100th Michigan Legislature, representing , which encompasses the cities of  and . A Democrat, Kuppa defeated Republican Doug Tietz in the general election, earning 51.3 percent of the vote versus 48.7 percent for Tietz. Kuppa's predecessor, term-limited Republican , attended her swearing-in ceremony. During her first term, Kuppa was named Assistant Whip for her caucus. She was also selected to serve on the Energy Committee and the Local Government and Municipal Finance Committee.\n\nIn 2020, Kuppa won re-election against Republican Andrew Sosnoski in the general election. She earned 55.04 percent of the vote to Sosnoski's 44.96 percent. For the 101st Michigan Legislature during her second term, Kuppa was selected to serve on the Tax Policy Committee and Rules and Competitiveness Committee, in addition to returning to serve on the Local Government and Municipal Finance Committee. She was also selected to serve as an alternate member for the Michigan Legislative Council. In 2021, Kuppa received the  Public Policy Award for her work with the disability and business communities.\n\nIn 2022, Kuppa unsuccessfully ran for the  in the new 9th Senate District following the decennial  process.\n\n\nKuppa resides in , with her husband, Sudhakar Tadepalli. They have two children.\n\nKuppa is  and a member of the Bharatiya Temple of Metropolitan Detroit. She is  and speaks , , and ; the latter of which is the most spoken minority language in the district that Kuppa represents.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nBROKEN LINKS:\n\n\n\n-->\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Harry Francis Kelly''' (April 19, 1895 – February 8, 1971) was an American politician. He served as the 39th  from 1943 to 1947.\n\n\nKelly was born in , one of nine siblings born to Mary Agnes (Morrissey) and Henry Michael Kelly, a lawyer. Both of his parents were Roman Catholics of  descent. Kelly spent a year assisting his father in his law office before enrolling at the , where he received a law degree from  in 1917. He served in the  during World War I, was wounded and lost his right leg in the , where he also earned the  with palm leaves.  Upon his return to the United States, Kelly joined the American  drive.\n\nAfter the war, Kelly established a career in public service. He served as the state's attorney for , from 1920 to 1924. During that time, his father moved to Detroit to represent  in Michigan.  Harry followed when his term as state's attorney ended, joining his father and younger brother Emmett to form the law firm of Kelly, Kelly, and Kelly.\n\nIn 1929, Kelly married Anne Veronica O'Brien, and they had six children together, including actor .  The following year, he became the assistant prosecuting attorney for , where he served until 1934.\n\n\nKelly was selected by Governor  to head the Detroit area Liquor Control Commission. Fitzgerald later asked him to run for , which Kelly did.  Kelly was elected, serving from 1939 to 1943. When Fitzgerald died suddenly and Lieutenant Governor  took the governorship, Dickenson turned to Kelly for assistance, and for approximately two years Kelly acted as chief counsel and confidante to Governor Dickinson.\n\nIn 1942, the Republican party turned to Kelly as a candidate for governor, and on November 3, 1942, he defeated incumbent  governor  in the general election to become .  In 1944, while governor, he served as a delegate to the  which nominated  for U.S. president.. The Political Graveyard. Retrieved on September 30, 2011.  He was elected to a second two-year term in 1944, and during his four years in office, the state government was reorganized and a grand jury was convened to examine misappropriations in the legislature.  Also during his tenure as governor, Kelly appointed  and  as Regents to the University of Michigan. The '''War Governor''', as he was nicknamed, declined to run for re-election in 1946.\n\n\n\nAfter serving out his second term, Kelly returned to private practice until, in 1950, the Republican party again asked him to run for governor again.  He lost a close race to Governor , by only 1,154 votes. Kelly was declared the winner in the initial vote count, but Williams requested a recount that found several counting errors and reversed the election's outcome.\n\nIn 1954, he was nominated by the Republican party to a seat on the .  He was elected, and served  from 1954 to 1971.\n\n\nKelly died at the age of 75 in . He is interred at Holy Sepulchre Cemetery of .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Johnson''' (born August 19, 1958) is an American politician who served as a member of the  from the  from 2019 to 2022.\n\n\nJohnson was born on August 19, 1958, in the city of . She graduated from . She was certified as a paralegal by the American Institute for Paralegal Studies. She earned an associate degree from  and a bachelor’s degree in business management from .\n\n\nJohnson ran for office in the Michigan House of Representatives five times before being elected on November 6, 2018, as the representative from . Since 2013, Johnson has hosted the radio show, ''StandUp Now with Cynthia A. Johnson''. Johnson currently serves as Chaplain of the Michigan Legislative Black Caucus. During the beginning of her term, Johnson served on three committees: the Families, Children, and Seniors committee, the Agriculture committee, and as the Minority Chair of House Oversight.\n\nOn December 2, 2020, Johnson appeared on a House Oversight Committee panel, which heard testimony from  and four other witnesses in regard to alleged election fraud in the . Johnson disputed the claims of fraud. After the hearing, Johnson received voicemail lynching threats. Johnson posted a video in response to these threats, in which she warned supporters of President  to \"Be careful. Walk lightly\", further stating that \"And for those of you who are soldiers, you know how to do it. Do it right. Be in order. Make them pay.\" , chairwoman of the  found this video to be threatening to members of her party. On December 9, 2020, Michigan House Speaker , in a statement supported by Speaker-elect , removed Johnson from all three committees she had been a part of, because of the video's contents.\n\nJohnson was disqualified from running in the 2022 Democratic primary for her re-election in the newly drawn , as she did not submit required campaign finance paperwork.\n\n\nAround 1975, Johnson was married to Wallace F. Hoskins Jr. Johnson is a .\n\n\n\n\n\n*  at \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Michael J. Shirkey''' (born December 5, 1954) is an American  politician who served as a  member of the  and as a member of the . He was first elected to the House in 2010 and to the Senate in 2014. His district, the , covered all of , , and . From 2019 to 2023, Shirkey was the majority leader of the Michigan State Senate.\n\n\nHe has a bachelor's degree from  and a master's degree from the . Shirkey worked for  for 13 years before starting his own engineering company. Shirkey founded the -based assembly machine manufacturing company, Orbitform.\n\n\nIn May 2020, Shirkey appeared onstage at an American Patriot Council rally in Grand Rapids, Michigan with William Null and Adam Fox. In October 2020, William Null, his twin brother, Michael Null, Adam Fox, and 10 other men were charged in a plot to kidnap and kill Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer.\n\nIn early April 2020, Shirkey criticized Governor  for extending a \"\" order until the end of April. Shirkey opposed face mask requirements in Michigan.\n\nIn November 2020, Shirkey stated that he would not attempt to appoint a slate of electors in the  that would vote for President , following Trump's loss in the . Trump invited Shirkey and several of his Republican colleagues to the White House following Shirkey's statement. Shirkey and several of his colleagues in the  met with Trump on November 20, 2020. Shirkey and others issued a statement following the meeting in which they stated that they would \"follow the normal process\" of certifying the state's election results.\n\nOn December 23, 2020, Shirkey tested positive for . He believed he was exposed to the coronavirus on December 19. On December 21, Shirkey attended 's farewell speech at the . Shirkey characterized his COVID-19 illness as him having fought against the \"Chinese flu army\"; his remarks were criticized as xenophobic.\n\nIn April 2020, Shirkey's business, Orbitform, received  in Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) loans. In January 2021, Orbitform received another  in PPP loans, for a total of $3.5 million. During this time, Shirkey led the Michigan Senate to block allocation of $4 billion in federal COVID reliefs funds for food and rental assistance. Although Shirkey claims to not be involved in the day-to-day management of his company, several of his family members (including son David Shirkey, grandson Karter Fannin, and Mark Shirkey) are employed at Orbitform in management positions.\n\nIn February 2021, Shirkey alleged that the  was a \"hoax\", that it was \"staged\", and that supporters of Donald Trump did not carry it out.\n\nIn a February interview with radio station , Shirkey alleged that dead people voted in Michigan in the 2020 elections, a claim that has been denied by others. In 2021, Shirkey led efforts  in the Michigan Senate by Republicans which according to the GOP are aimed at  securing elections in Michigan, Democrats and other critics  have called these efforts by Republicans a push to restrict voting rights.\n\nIn April 2021, Shirkey accepted an invitation to meet with militia leaders. During the meeting in Grand Rapids, Shirkey told the militias, \"We need you now more than ever to continue to train\" and \"to stand up and test that assertion of authority by government\".  The Associated Press described the event \"Michigan’s GOP leadership has for the first time in memory bestowed legitimacy on its state’s militia, long relegated to the shadows\" and indicative of the rightward shift of the Michigan GOP after the 2020 elections.\n\nShirkey was ineligible for re-election in  due to term limits.\n\nIn his farewell address to the Senate, Shirkey claimed that \"the surprise attack of an insidious virus\" was \"one that we were not prepared for, but one that was most certainly planned,\" embracing the unproven theory that COVID was a designed attack by China. He also suggested a series of \"little-g gods\" like climate change, gun control, digital currency, child sacrifice, and \"trans-whatever\" are part of a broader push to \"achieve a one-world government\" and \"one-world religion.\" He also took aim at the World Economic Forum, arguing the non-governmental lobbying organization is behind a push for “the elimination of sovereignty,” and that, \"It's becoming glaringly apparent COVID was just the beginning of the forces that will test the very fabric of our freedoms, independence, our sovereignty, our values, and even our God-given rights.\" According to the Anti-Defamation League, adherents of the \"\" conspiracy theory \"warn that 'global elites' will use the pandemic to advance their interests and push forward a globalist plot to destroy American sovereignty and prosperity.\" He also shared an anecdote about noticing warmth in a Senate bathroom and reaching his hand into a Senate toilet to test the water temperature. He said, \"I put my hand in it, and it was hot water. So I went back to the office and said, 'Please, get a hold of maintenance staff around here and ask them why taxpayers are paying for hot water in our toilets.\"\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Rebekah Lynn Warren''' (born November 25, 1971) is a former American  legislator from , who represented the  of the  from January 1, 2019 until January 1, 2021. She was elected to this position on November 6, 2018, beating Republican opponent Bob Baird, 74% to 26%. Previously, she served two terms as State Representative for , from 2007 to 2010, and two terms in the Michigan Senate, from 2010 to 2018. She was arrested for drunk driving and fleeing police in a motor vehicle on December 26, 2019.\n\n\nWarren was raised in , and attended the , majoring in political science. In 1993 she joined the staff of State Representative Mary Schroer of Ann Arbor, Michigan and later that of State Representative Hubert Price of .  From 1999 to 2006 she was the executive director of NARAL Pro-Choice Michigan, the state affiliate of .\n\n\n\nShe was elected to a two-year term in the  in 2006 and was subsequently reelected in 2008. Warren chaired the House Great Lakes and Environment Committee since and sat on the Judiciary Committee, the Tax Policy Committee, and the Oversight and Investigations Committee. She also co-chaired the Michigan BioTech Caucus with Republican Senator .\n\n\nWarren is a  Democrat, subscribing to tenets of social equity, environmental conservation and liberal fiscal policies.\n\n\nWarren is an ardent supporter of gender equity and has championed abortion rights.  In 2005 she was recognized for her leadership by the  of Michigan with their annual Millie Award.  NOW of Michigan named her \"Legislator of the Year\" in 2009.\n\nShe has sponsored or cosponsored legislation to prevent pay discrimination, provide emergency contraception, extend family medical leave to adopting parents, and provide support and protections for sexual assault survivors.\n\n\nEnvironmental issues topped Warren's agenda in the state legislature in 2007–2008.  She championed the passage of the  and associated legislation to govern withdrawals of the state's groundwater.  The  touted the package as \"the most important accomplishment to come out of the Michigan legislature this year.\"\n\n\nWarren and mother-in-law  introduced legislation in 2009 to provide free college tuition for Michigan residents by raising the state income tax.\n\n\nIn 2010, Warren competed with fellow Democrat  for the Democratic nomination for the   seat to succeed .  Five days before the primary election, an article in a Michigan newspaper revealed that ads for Byrnes and attacking Warren were financed by The Great Lakes Education Project, a Political Action Committee (PAC) funded in part by Republicans Dick and . The Great Lakes Education Project (GLEP) lobbies for choice, accountability and quality in education and assists candidates that support education reform. Warren defeated Byrnes in the primary election with 55.7% of the vote.\n\n\nUntil 2017, Warren was married to  Commissioner Conan Smith and was the daughter-in-law of .\n\n\nOn the evening of December 26, 2019, Warren was arrested in Auburn Hills, MI, on suspicion of DUI. Police had received several calls in relation to an apparently impaired driver at approximately 11 p.m. Police  footage showed Warren's Jeep driving erratically and colliding with the right wall of northbound I-75 before continuing on. When finally stopped, Warren told police she was on her way home to Ann Arbor. She also told the arresting officer that she had consumed 2-3 glasses of wine \"just a minute ago\" and subsequently failed a field sobriety test administered at the scene.\n\nWarren refused to take a  test and was taken by police to McLaren Hospital in Pontiac where testing showed her blood alcohol level was .21, almost triple the legal limit. Police dashcam footage showed Warren telling police at the scene \"You understand there's going to be a moment where we're both going to be on TV\", adding \"I'm elected. I'm a senator. This is going to be the most famous arrest you've ever made.\"\n\nOn February 18, 2020, Warren pled guilty to a reduced charge of misdemeanor driving while intoxicated. On May 27, 2020, Warren was sentenced to one year of probation and 10 days of community service. She did not seek re-election in the 2020 election, and was succeeded by fellow Democrat .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* '''Official Michigan Senate Site'''\n*, '''Official Campaign Site'''\n* profile\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Sanford A. Brown''' (May 18, 1909June 26, 1986) was a  politician.\n\n\nBrown was born in , on May 18, 1909.\n\n\nBrown served as  from 1955 to 1965. Brown was the last Michigan State Treasurer to be elected, as the position was changed to an appointed one after his term in the office. In 1956 and 1964, Brown served as an alternate delegate to the  from Michigan. In 1964, Brown ran unsuccessfully as for the  seat representing the . In 1968, Brown ran unsuccessfully for the  seat representing the .\n\n\nBrown married Mildred Maxine Harder. Together they had two sons.\n\n\nBrown died on June 26, 1986, in Bay City. Brown was interred at New Bay Port Cemetery in .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n}}\n'''David Bing''' (born November 24, 1943) is an American former professional  player, businessman, and politician who served as the  from 2009 to 2014. He is a member of the .\n\nAfter starring at , Bing played 12 seasons in the  (NBA) as a  for the  (1966–1975),  (1975–1977), and  (1977–78). During his career, he averaged over 20 points and six assists per game and made seven  appearances, winning the game's  in 1976. The Pistons celebrated his career accomplishments with the  of his #21 jersey. In addition, he was elected to the  and named to the  and the .\n\nBing founded Bing Steel, a processing company that earned him the National Minority Small Business Person of the Year award in 1984. Soon the business grew into the multimillion-dollar Detroit-based conglomerate, the Bing Group, one of the largest steel companies in Michigan.\n\nBing entered Detroit politics as a  in 2008, announcing his intentions to run for mayor in the city's  to finish the term of , who had resigned amid a corruption scandal. After winning the primary, Bing then defeated Interim Mayor  and was sworn in as mayor in May 2009. Later that year, Bing was re-elected to a full term. However, he lost most of his power to Detroit's emergency manager , had numerous health problems, and suffered approval ratings as low as 14%. Bing thus did not seek  and was succeeded by politician and businessman .\n\n\nBing was born November 24, 1943, in Washington, D.C., to mother Juanita, a housekeeper, and father Hasker, a  and  for the local  church. He was the second child of four living in a two-bedroom, one-story house in the northeast part of town. In his childhood, Bing received the nickname \"Duke\" from his father, because, according to Bing, he always \"wanted to be top dog.\" He suffered a traumatic eye injury at age five, when, while playing with an improvised  he constructed with two sticks nailed together; Bing tripped and accidentally poked his left eye with a rusty nail. The family could not afford emergency surgery, leaving the eye to heal on its own and diminishing his vision thereafter.  Bing's father also suffered a severe head injury during the boy's childhood. While working a construction site, a brick fell four stories onto his head, causing a brain clot. The episode led young Bing to promise himself that he would never work in such a profession.\n\nIn athletics, Bing played basketball, but older children often told him he was too small for the game.  However, he played well, triumphing over such older and bigger children as future  musician , who, after not performing well on the court, chose to sing on the sidelines. Bing and Gaye forged a friendship, which continued later in life. Despite his basketball play, Bing, a fan of the  and , focused primarily on , the neighborhood's preferred game.\n\nDespite his fuzzy vision, he excelled in baseball at , where he enrolled in 1958. Nevertheless, the school's head basketball coach William Roundtree encouraged him to revisit basketball. Roundtree became a fatherly figure to Bing, who decided to join the team. He developed into a double-digits per game scorer, noted for his  and knack for driving to the basket. He continued also to compete in baseball into his senior year, but was forced to choose between it and basketball when a scheduling conflict between two tournaments arose. Though he felt he was better at baseball, Bing opted for basketball, believing it gave him a greater chance at a full-ride college scholarship, well aware of the path taken by  forward , a Spingarn alum. At the tournament, Bing led his team to victory and earned MVP honors. All in all, in high school, Bing was a three-year letter winner, all–Inter High, all-Metro, and all-East member. In 1962, he was featured in  and made the All-American Team.\n\n\nBing attended , where he was once roommates with . He led the  in scoring as a sophomore (22.2) in 1964, as a junior (23.2) in 1965, and as a senior (28.4) in 1966. During his senior year, Bing was fifth in the nation in scoring and was Syracuse's first consensus All-American in 39 years. He was also named to '''' All-America First Team and was named Syracuse Athlete of the Year.\n\nIn his three-year varsity career at Syracuse, Bing averaged 24.8 points and 10.3 rebounds, with 1883 total points and 786 total rebounds in 76 games.\n\n\n\n,  1975]]\nBing's playing style was somewhat unusual for the time.  As a lean, athletic and explosive , he functioned as the playmaker distributing the ball, but also did more shooting and scoring than most others who had this position.  At one time a joke about him and his backcourt partner, , was that it was a shame they could only play the game with one ball at a time.\n\n\nIn 1966, after being selected 2nd overall in the  by the , Bing scored 1,601 points (20.0 points per game), and won the 1967  while also being named to the . The next year, he led the NBA in scoring with 2,142 points (27.1 points per game) in 1968.\n\nOn November 23, 1968, Bing recorded a triple-double of 39 points, 16 rebounds and 10 assists in a 127–128 loss to the Baltimore Bullets.\n\nBing sat out 2½ months of the 1971–72 season due to a detached retina incurred from a preseason game against the , playing in only 45 games that season. While with the Pistons, he played in six s (1968, 1969, 1971, 1973–1975), and was named to the  in 1968 and 1971.\n\n\nAfter leaving the , Bing went on to spend his next two seasons with the , for whom he was named an NBA All-Star once more in 1976, this time winning the game's MVP Award.\n\n\nHe played his final season with the , averaging 13.6 points. He then retired at the conclusion of the .\n\nOverall, in his NBA career, Bing averaged 20.3 points, 6.0 assists and 3.8 rebounds in 901 games over 12 NBA seasons, scoring 18,327 points with 5,397 assists.\n\n\nBing was awarded the  in 1977.\n\nBing was elected to the  in 1990.\n\nBing was named one of the  in 1996.\n\nBing was inducted into the  in 2006.\n\nBing was named one of the  in 2021.\n\n\nBing is the godfather of . In 2020, Bing published his autobiography titled 'Attacking the Rim'.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAt age 22 with an NBA contract worth $15,000, Bing was rebuffed by the  on getting a mortgage to finance a home. This led Bing to work at the bank during the offseason, holding jobs in the teller, customer relations, and mortgage departments.\n\nImmediately after retiring, he worked at a warehouse of the  processing company Paragon Steel and was paid $35,000. He left after two years, after stints in the company's shipping and sales operations.\n\n\nIn 1980, Bing opened Bing Steel with four employees in a rented warehouse from $250,000 in loans and $80,000 of his own money. Losing all his money in six months, the company shied away from manufacturing to focus on being a middleman. With  as their first major client, the company turned a profit in its second year on revenues of $4.2 million. By 1984, Bing was awarded by President  the National Minority Small Business Person of the Year. By 1985, Bing Steel had expanded to two plants with 63 employees posting revenues of $40 million. Company assets were sold off in 2009.\n\n\nBing Steel transformed itself to the Bing Group, a conglomerate with headquarters located in Detroit's North End. The company, among other things, supplies  to the  industry.\n\nAt the , Bing received the  Achievement Award for his work after his NBA career.\n\n\nBing was an early political supporter of . However, Bing was among the first Michigan business community leaders to urge the resignation of Kilpatrick from his office as mayor of Detroit when scandals emerged surrounding Kilpatrick. Kilpatrick resigned as mayor in September 2008.\n\nBing led Detroit's effort to receive the rights to host the . In November 2002, Detroit lost to . Detroit's weak spot was considered to be its smaller number of hotel rooms.\n\nIn January 2009, on , Bing received the  Sports Legacy Award. The award honors King's legacy as a leader of the , by acknowledging athletes who have made significant contributions to civil and human rights and who helped establish a foundation for future leaders in  careers.  The honor was to be presented during the  show of the game between the  and the Detroit Pistons in .\n\nBing volunteered in the  program.\n\n\n VP Tony Brown,  CEO Yann Delabrière, Michigan Governor , Rush Trucking CEO Andra Rush, U.S. Senator , and Bing]]\n\n\nOn October 16, 2008, Bing announced that he would be a candidate for  in the  to finish the term of Kwame Kilpatrick, who had resigned as part of a  agreement after being charged with the crime of . Bing finished first in a 15 candidate non-partisan primary on February 24, 2009. On May 5, 2009, Bing was elected with 52.3% of the vote, defeating interim mayor , who received 47.7%. Bing had only moved to a residence within city limits shortly before his campaign for mayor. Bing had previously resided in suburban .\n\nBing was reelected to a full term on .  Bing's inauguration for his full term was held at the .\n\n\nIn comparison to his predecessor Kwame Kilaptrick, Bing opted for a more low-key presence as mayor and opted to forgo enjoying many of the benefits to which the mayor was entitled. Bing additionally forwent accepting salary as mayor during at least his first year as mayor. Bing did not shy away from making decisions that were unpopular.\n\n\n at the  in 2011]]\n\nWhen Bing took office, the city was suffering significant economic trouble and its government was suffering major fiscal trouble. The city was suffering a $30 million budget deficit. The city also had overall accumulated $332 million in deficit, more than $15 million in long-term liabilities. The city government's fiscal troubles persisted under Bing, with Detroit suffering increased budget deficits during much of his tenure. However, by the time he left office, the city's deficit had decreased by $7 million from where it stood when he assumed office.\n\nIn 2011, Bing proposed that the city's next budget include a $4 million decrease in funding for  staff, and fund new hires for the city's fire department. In mid-2011, Bing ed the budget passed by the City Council, claiming its cuts were excessive and could be to the detriment of the services of the city's police and fire departments. The City Council's budget made $50 million more in cuts than Bing's initial proposed budget had made. Bing's budget proposal was for $3.1 billion in spending. The City Council overrode this veto in an 8–1 vote. The city's 2012 budget made a 20% decrease to the city's fire department. This has been seen as having a detrimental effect on the city's ability to handle fires, including . In mid-2012, the fire department announced 164 layoffs. In 2013, Bing proposed a $1 billion budget, a $300 million decrease from the previous year's budget.\n\nBy the time he was reelected to a full term, Bing had dismissed more than 400 city employees and had ended 16 out of 51 contracts that the city had with s. Bing faced protests by unions during his mayoralty. By the end of his mayoralty, Bing had eliminated 1,000 positions in the city government, a 9% decrease to the municipal workforce. Additionally, many city employees faced decreased , decreased , and even s. Bing also d many roles of the city government. The city's public health department was replaced by the Institution for Population Health . The workforce-development department was replaced by Detroit Employment Solutions, a . Management of payroll and benefits for city employees was also outsourced.\n\nThe city enjoyed new private development over the course of Bing's tenure. This included both the opening of new es, an investment of $198 million by  in its Mack Avenue Engine Plant (which created 250 new jobs), and significant development in the city's downtown by businessman .\n\n\n]]\n\nBing proposed the idea of demolishing neighborhoods and decreasing city services. Bing spoke of his intention to depopulate neighborhoods, including through forcible means such as . This was controversial among city residents. Bing sought to incentivize residents to relocate from largely depopulated neighborhoods so that those neighborhoods could be demolished and the public services could be consolidated to more densely populated areas of the city. Past mayors had made pledges to demolish abandoned homes but taken little action to do so. Under Bing, the city took action to demolish abandoned homes, reporting in early 2013 to have demolished 6,700 since Bing took office. However, the city still had tens of thousands more abandoned homes. Bing's program of demolishing abandoned homes was controversial with some city residents. Aiming to repopulate certain neighborhoods, in early 2011 Bing began a program to give $150,000 in grants to assist in renovations of foreclosed homes in select neighborhoods. Hoping to encourage members of the city's police force to reside within city limits, Bing only required police officers to place a mere $1,000 in order to acquire abandoned residences and be eligible for renovation grants.\n\nBing launched the Detroit Works Project (later renamed Detroit Future City), an effort to create a 50-year outline for the city's future. The project was intended to create a community-planned vision for how the city would manage its problems. The city government underestimated how many citizens would attend community meetings. Controversy arose during the process, when Bing publicized his intention to depopulate certain neighborhoods by forcibly relocating residents to denser neighborhoods. The public anger at this threatened the project.\n\nBing sought to fix the city's broken s, which were considered a serious problem. In 2012, Bing persuaded the state legislature and governor to create the Public Lighting Authority of Detroit and dedicate utility and income tax revenue for the $185 million in bonds for this purpose. Bing appointed a lighting authority board, which then signed a contract with  to repair the city's streetlights. However, the contract did not take place until early 2013, by which time Bing had left office. Bing's successor  built upon Bing's efforts to repair the city's streetlights to significant success. It has been noted that, due to Bing being out of office when the work was carried out, he has not received much public credit for it.\n\n\nDuring Bing's tenure, there was trouble within the . This included instability in leadership, with the city cycling through four different police chiefs during Bing's less-than-5-years in office. While he gave no explicit reason for the firing, it was speculated that Bing dismissed the first police chief of his mayoralty, , both due to the  that resulted in the  and due to Bing's dissatisfaction with Warren's pursuit of media exposure through participation in  shows such as ''''. Even as crime in large cities was declining overall in the United States, Detroit saw its  rate rise to a 20-year high in 2012.\n\n\n (far left) and Secretary of the Navy  (center left) at the 2011 naming ceremony for ]]\n\nEarly into his mayoralty, Bing began pursuing a renovation of , the city's main . Renovation occurred while Bing was mayor, taking place under the management of a new cooperative governing authority for the convention center.\n\nBing established the city's Active and Safe Campaign  to raise funds for public safety initiatives, as well as raise funds for recreational programs and enhancements to the city's recreation facilities.\n\nBing made an unpopular proposal to decrease city bus service on Sundays. This never came into fruition.\n\n\nOn March 1, 2013, Governor  announced that he would appoint an emergency manager for the city of Detroit due to the city's fiscal troubles, making Detroit the United States largest city's to be placed under emergency management. Bing had, in the years prior, warned that this was a possibility, and expressed his desire for the city to avert such a situation. The placement of the city under emergency management deprived Bing of much of his mayoral authority. Bing declared that while he opposed emergency management, he was willing to work collaboratively with the emergency manager that would be appointed.  was soon after appointed to the emergency manager role. Many in the city criticized Bing for not being more resistant to emergency management.\n\nIn July 2013, before Bing left office, Detroit became the largest city in United States history to declare municipal . This was the decision of emergency manager Kevin Orr. Many criticized Bing for not doing more to fight this move by Orr.\n\n\nIn addition to losing authority to the emergency manager, Bing suffered numerous health problems, and had seen approval ratings as low as 14%. Bing announced on May 14, 2013, he would not run for reelection to another term in .\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n*  \n* \n* \n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Robert Morrison Gosselin''' (1951-2023) was a conservative  politician in  and is an Oakland .\n\n\n\nGosselin was born in  and attended . He attended, but did not graduate from , where he studied . He is also a licensed , licensed  and licensed heating contractor.\n\nHe is married to Jan Gosselin and has three children.\n\n\n\nGosselin was elected to the   in 1993. He served until 1997.\n\nIn 1998, he was elected to the  to represent the then- which included portions of  and Troy. He was re-elected to the same seat in 2000. In 2002, after his district was consolidated into Troy and , he ran for and lost a  seat against incumbent Shirley Johnson in the 13th District. In 2004, Gosselin again sat in the Michigan House, this time representing the new .\n\nIn 2006, Gosselin became a candidate for County Commissioner in the 13th District which includes the southern portion of  Rochester Hills and a northern  portion of Troy with a portion of . He unseated a moderate Republican incumbent, , in the primary. He handily won his general election bid for that seat. According to the Oakland Press:  \nHowever, with Gosselin term-limited out-of-office, the younger Knollenberg became the Republican nominee for State House in 2006, defeating Mike Bosnic in the August 2006 primary. Bosnic, who also ran in 2004 in a three-way race against Gosselin, was endorsed by Gosselin in 2006. Despite Gosselin's endorsement, Knollenberg won by 7%, or roughly 700 votes, over Bosnic.\n\n\n\nGosselin has achieved a reputation of being a conservative who appeals to the  as well as a strong  bloc of Oakland County politics. As such, he has gained the reputation of challenging establishment mainstream, , and liberal Republicans. This was the case in his 2002 bid for the State Senate as well as his 2004 House election.\n\nGosselin has traditionally supported a strong relationship between State Government and . He has sponsored various legislation to place the words \"In God We Trust\" and the  at the  in . In support of this legislation, which failed, but ultimately won by putting them in the Lansing Capital thru House Resolutions HCR 0056 of 2002 and HR 0024 of 2005. Gosselin traveled the state with fellow Republican Representative  with the 2.6-ton granite tablets involved in the . Gosselin holds the controversial belief that the  does not deliberately dictate a  and instead is a mere protection of all religious beliefs.\n\nConsistent with his conservative philosophy, Gosselin also strongly opposes . In the legislature he supported bills that would make it illegal to coerce a woman into having a legal abortion, requiring ultrasounds to be shown prior to abortions, to prohibit physicians and health facilities from accepting prepayment for abortions, and to establish a \"Choose Life Fund,\" funded with revenue from the sale of a \"Choose Life\" specialty license plate.\n\nDespite his interest in government regulation of abortion and association of government with religion, Gosselin has maintained significant support for and from libertarians. For instance, he endorsed libertarian  for City Council in Troy. This is because of his strong opposition to state and local regulations, taxation and benefits. While in the legislature, he voted against every single budget citing overspending in State Government. He was the author of a package of legislation known as \"Michigan Citizens First,\" which cut welfare benefits from illegal immigrants. He consistently favored substantial cuts to government welfare programs.\n\nHowever, with Gosselin term-limited out-of-office, the younger Knollenberg became the Republican nominee for State House in 2006, defeating Mike Bosnic in the August 2006 primary. Bosnic, who also ran in 2004 in a three-way race against Gosselin, was endorsed by Gosselin in 2006. Despite Gosselin's endorsement, Knollenberg won by 7%, or roughly 700 votes, over Bosnic.\n\n\n\nIn 2006, Gosselin initially ran for the Michigan Senate against fellow State Representative . Many state political observers were anticipating a lively free-for-all between these two. This prediction was based upon the open animus between former Senator Shirley Johnson and Gosselin. Gosselin accused Johnson, who is a moderate Republican, of accepting donations from a pro-Gay group. He also attacked her position on abortion. Johnson actively worked for Marty Knollenberg's 2004 campaign against Gosselin. A joke between many observers was that if Gosselin were to win the Republican nomination, Johnson would endorse the Democrat, and one Republican insider seriously acknowledged this possibility.\n\nWhen  , son of Congressman  and nephew of  , entered the race, however, Republican leadership became concerned. Former Michigan Senator and fellow Troy State Representative  was coaxed by the  to run for the 13th District seat, as they believed he was the only one with the name recognition and fundraising ability to retain the seat in the general election. When Pappageorge entered the race, Gosselin dropped out.\n\nPappageorge defeated Taub in the primary in August 2006 by a two-to-one margin. He narrowly defeated Andy Levin in one of the closest and most controversial state senate races in November, by a margin less than that of the vote totals accumulated by the Green Party candidate.\n\n\n\n|- style=\"background-color:#E9E9E9\"\n!     "pages": }\n\n'''Mai Hlee Xiong''' (born December 19, 1984) is a  businesswoman and politician currently serving as a  member of the . She previously served on the . In April 2024, Xiong won a special election to fill the vacant  in the Michigan House of Representatives.\n\n\nXiong was born in the  in the  of  to a  family. At the age of 3, Xiong's family moved to  after being accepted into the  as refugees. Due to having extended family in , Xiong and her siblings spent a lot of time in the area while growing up.\n\n\nIn 2003, Xiong was accepted into the  in . During her studies, she moved to  and interned at . Xiong graduated in 2007 with a  in Graphic Design.\n\nXiong later graduated from the Michigan Political Leadership Program (MPLP) at . She is also a graduate of the Senior Executives in State and Local Government program at .\n\n\nIn 2017, Xiong founded the brand Mai&Co, an apparel company inspired by traditional  clothing. She is fluent in the  and helps as a language interpreter for a translation and interpretation organization.\n\nXiong serves as a volunteer Board Member of the Macomb Food Program, a  working to raise funds and feed the hungry in . She is also a coordinator for Adopt-A-County Road, a program where participants help maintain roads by cleaning up trash and litter.\n\nIn August 2020, Xiong challenged incumbent Macomb County Commissioner Marvin Sauger in the Democratic primary where she finished in first place with 37.3% of the vote. Xiong later won the general election in November with 54.5% of the vote.\n\nDuring her first term, Xiong led the commission in appropriating $300,000 for the 2023 budget to go towards the county's food pantry distribution program. Xiong also worked to increase funding for Turning Point, a nonprofit intended to support victims of  and . In addition, she also worked to secure funding for Martha T. Berry, a county  that works with the .\n\nIn 2022, Xiong was re-elected to a second term with 56.7% of the vote.\n\nIn 2023, Xiong challenged  City Clerk Sonja Buffa. Despite making it through the primary, Xiong lost the general election with 46.2% of the vote.\n\nIn 2023, , a ,  after being elected mayor of Warren. Xiong announced her candidacy for the special election and won the Democratic primary in January 2024. She later won the general election with 65% of the vote.\n\nIn November 2024, following court-mandated , Xiong sought re-election in the new 13th district and won the general election for a full term with 50.6% of the vote.\n\n\n\nXiong and her husband, Adam, met in 2008 before getting married in 2011.     "pages": }\n\n'''Joel Gougeon''' (born January 13, 1943) was a  member of the  from 1993-2002 representing the  (then , , , , and  counties). He previously served as a member of the Bay County Board of Commissioners.\n\nGougeon received a mechanical engineering degree in 1966 from what was then the  by co-oping at the Saginaw Malleable Iron Foundry. After five years in the , Gougeon and his brothers formed Gougeon Brothers, Inc., which manufactured sailboats, epoxy adhesives, and wind energy blades. The methods first developed by the Gougeon brothers using West System epoxy have become the standard techniques taught in colleges the world over for building boats using epoxy. He was also a member of a number of civic organizations, including as a past president of the Bay City Lions Club and as a founder of the Bay County Crime Stoppers.\n\nFirst elected in a special election in 1993 to succeed  after he was elected to the , Gougeon later won two full terms in the . He served on the appropriations committee. After his retirement from the Legislature, Gougeon served as a lobbyist for . Gougeon is also a member of the , the , and the .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Marshall Laverne Bullock II''' is an American politician, serving as a  member of the  from 2019 to 2023, and currently serving as the  Director of Government Affairs.\n\nBullock was born and raised in Detroit, and is a member of  and an . He attended  and the , graduating with a Bachelor of Arts in Human Services. Bullock has worked in public health and juvenile justice, and served in the Detroit Mayor's Department of Neighborhoods from 2014 to 2016, working directly with constituents to address concerns. Bullock advanced to the Director of Community and Political Affairs, a position he held until his election to the State Senate.\n\nIn the , Bullock won by a wide margin against his Republican opponent, Angela Savino. In office, he served as Chair of the Michigan Legislative Black Caucus.\n\nMichigan's legislative maps were redrawn in 2021 with data from the , and Bullock's district changed substantially. Bullock and fellow Michigan Senator  were drawn into the same district, District 8. Bullock's new district represented only 15% of the population of his former district, to McMorrow's 40%. McMorrow won the primary by a wide margin.\n\nAfter leaving the Michigan Senate in 2023, Bullock returned to the administration of Detroit mayor  as Director of Government Affairs. In this position, he advocates for the city's interests at the state and federal levels.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

In 2022, he ran for election to the  in the 30th district, narrowly losing to incumbent . He resides in Grand Rapids, Michigan with his wife, Melissa LaGrand, and four children: John, Issac, Helen, and Julia.     "pages": }\n\n'''Patrick Vincent McNamara''' (October 4, 1894 &ndash; April 30, 1966) was an American politician. A , he served as a  from  from 1955 until his death from a stroke in  in 1966.\n\n\nPatrick McNamara was born in , , to Patrick Vincent and Mary Jane (née Thynne) McNamara, who were  immigrants. The oldest of eight children, he received his early education at public schools in his native town. He attended the local high school for two and a half years before transferring to the  in , where he learned the trade of . In 1916, he began working as pipe fitter and foreman at the . He then played semi-professional  from 1919 to 1920.\n\nMcNamara moved to , , where he worked as foreman of a construction crew for the Grinnell Company. He then married Kathleen Kennedy, with whom he had two children. Mary Jane (1922) and Patrick (1925). His wife died in 1929. He then married Mary Mattee in 1930. He then served as job superintendent for R.L. Spitzley Company (1922–1926) and general superintendent of H. Kelly Company (1926–1930).  From 1930 to 1932, he took extension courses at the  in . He was maintenance foreman at a  plant (1931–1934) before joining the Donald Miller Company. In 1937, he became president of Pipe Fitters Local 636, a position he held until 1955. He also served as vice-president of the Detroit chapter of the  from 1939 to 1945.\n\nDuring , he served as rent director of the  in Detroit from 1942 to 1945. He then joined the Stanley-Carter Company, where he served as superintendent of construction, customer contact man, head of labor relations, and vice-president.\n\nIn 1946, McNamara made his first venture into politics with a successful campaign for an unexpired term on the . He won twenty-one of the city's twenty-three wards, and served until 1947. From 1949 to 1955, he was a member of the .\n\n\n and First Lady  meeting with Senator Patrick V. McNamara.]]\nIn 1954, McNamara challenged former Senator  for the  nomination for a seat in the . He was given little chance of defeating Moody by most political analysts, but won the nomination after Moody died two weeks before the primary election. He faced two-term  incumbent  in the general election, during which McNamara criticized  's economic, labor, and  farm policies. In November, he narrowly defeated Ferguson by a margin of 51%-49%.\n\nMcNamara was reelected over  in 1960, serving from January 3, 1955, until his death in . In the , he became the first chairman of the . He also chaired the  in the  and .  The 1959 committee hearings which Pat McNamara called on the subject of the health of the elderly began a public debate which led to the creation of .\n\nMcNamara died of a stroke at  on April 30, 1966, aged 71, and was interred in  in Detroit.\n\nMcNamara was a member of . The  in Detroit was named for him.\n\n\nMcNamara donated his archival papers to the , where they are open to the public for research. The bulk of materials relate to his time in the Senate and his work on the Public Works Committee (chairman, 1963–66), Labor and Public Welfare Committee, Select Committee on Improper Activities in the Labor or Management Field, Select Subcommittee on Poverty, and the Special Committee on Aging.  Subjects covered include problems of the aged, civil rights, atomic energy, education, taxes, public works, federal highway acts, and labor. Correspondents include all major political figures of the period and many labor leaders.\n\n\n*U.S. Congress. McNamara, Late a Senator from Michigan''. 89th Cong., 2nd sess., 1966. Washington, D.C.: Government Printing Office, 1967.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Brenda Lawrence''' (née '''Lulenar''';  born October 18, 1954) is an American retired politician who served as the  from  from 2015 to 2023. A member of the , Lawrence served as  of , from 2001 to 2015, and was the party's nominee for   in 2008 and for  in . Her congressional district covered most of eastern , including downtown, and stretched west to take in portions of , including , , and Lawrence's home in Southfield.\n\nRedrawn into the , Lawrence did not seek reelection in 2022, and retired from Congress upon her fourth term's expiration in 2023.\n\n\nLawrence grew up in Detroit's northeast side, on Lumpkin Street. She was raised by her grandparents after her mother died when she was three years old. She attended local schools, graduating from Detroit's . She then earned her  in public administration from .\n\n\nLawrence had a 30-year career with the , advancing to work in human resources. In the early-1990s, as an active member of the  at her children's school, she sought and earned a seat on the Southfield Public Schools . She served as president, vice president, and secretary of the board.\n\n\nLawrence got more deeply involved in local affairs. In 1997, she was elected to serve on Southfield's City Council, and in 1999 she was elected council president.\n\nIn 2001, Lawrence defeated longtime incumbent Donald Fracassi for the mayor's office, becoming the city's first  and first female mayor. She was reelected in 2005 without opposition. As mayor, she was invited by the  in 2008 to represent United States mayors in testimony about the mortgage crisis and its effect on American communities. She returned to Washington later that year to lobby Congress for a bridge loan for the .\n\nLawrence served as a Michigan delegate to the . As a  at the , she endorsed   for  in June 2008.\n\nShe successfully sought a third term as mayor in 2009, defeating former Councilwoman Sylvia Jordan with nearly 80 percent of the vote.Official Election Results Certified by the Southfield City Clerk She was reelected to a fourth term unopposed in 2013.\n\n\n\n\n\nIn May 2008, Lawrence announced her candidacy for Oakland County Executive. She was unopposed for the Democratic nomination to unseat the longtime  incumbent, . Patterson won reelection 58%-42%. Lawrence's challenge to the polarizing Patterson was identified as the strongest challenge he faced in his six elections for County Executive. \n\n\n\nLansing Mayor  named Lawrence as his running mate in his bid for . She was formally nominated as the Democratic candidate for  at the  convention in August 2010. They campaigned around the state promoting a \"Main Street Agenda\" with emphasis on their shared backgrounds as mayors.\n\nAs with the national election results, the 2010 general election in Michigan saw strong turnout and enthusiasm by Republican voters. Political pundits attributed the losses by Democrats, in part, to voter reaction to President Obama and term-limited Democratic Governor . The Democratic gubernatorial ticket lost to Republican nominees , a businessman, and , a State Representative, 58%-40%. No statewide Democratic candidates were successful in 2010.\n\n\n\nIn late 2011, Lawrence announced she would be running in the newly redrawn . The district had previously been the 13th, represented by freshman Democrat . It was redrawn to take in a large slice of Oakland County, including Southfield. Clarke's home in Detroit was drawn into the neighboring 13th district, but he opted to follow most of his constituents into the 14th.\n\nIn the Democratic primary, the real contest in this heavily Democratic, black-majority district, Lawrence faced incumbent representatives Clarke and , both of whom lived outside the district, and former State Representative Mary D. Waters. Peters won with 47%, to Clarke's 35%, Lawrence's 13%, and Waters's 3%. Peters went on to win the general election.\n\n\n\nIn May 2013, Peters announced that he would not be running for reelection in 2014. He instead  the U.S. Senate seat being vacated by retiring Democrat . On January 23, 2014, Lawrence announced that she would run for the 14th district for the second time.\n\nLawrence was the first candidate to submit signatures to the state in order to be on the August primary ballot, doing so in March. Other candidates that filed for the Democratic nomination were former Congressman Hansen Clarke of Detroit, State Representative Rudy Hobbs of Southfield and teacher Burgess D. Foster of Detroit.\n\nDuring the course of the campaign's contribution reporting, Hobbs raised a total of $607,806, Lawrence $383,649 and Clarke $173,124; Burgess reported no contributions to the Federal Election Commission, indicating that he raised or spent less than $5,000. Michigan Congressman Sander Levin's Political Action Committee, GOALPAC, also spent hundreds of thousands of dollars to help elect Hobbs, who was previously employed on Levin's congressional staff.\n\nLawrence won the Democratic Party nomination on August 5, 2014, with 36% of the vote to Hobbs's 32%, Clarke's 31% and Foster's 1%. She took the most votes in Oakland County, carrying Southfield, Pontiac and Oak Park, as well as Royal Oak Township. Although it was expected that Clarke would convincingly win the portion of Detroit within the district, where he lives and had previously held public office, Lawrence was competitive in the city and won more votes than all other candidates from voters who cast their ballot on Election Day in Detroit.\n\nAs the Democratic nominee for Congress, she faced Republican nominee Christina Conyers of Detroit in the November general election. But Conyers withdrew from the race and Christina Barr of Pontiac was chosen as the Republican nominee. The district has a history of voting heavily for Democratic candidates. Also facing off against Lawrence in the November election was Libertarian Party nominee Leonard Schwartz of Oak Park and Green Party nominee Stephen Boyle of Detroit. Lawrence won with 78% of the vote, Barr took 20%, Schwartz 1% and Boyle 1%.\n\n\n\n\n*\n**\n*\n**\n**\n**\n\n\n*\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* Congressional Former Mayors' Caucus\n*\n\n\nDuring the 2022 redistricting cycle, Lawrence's 14th district was eliminated as Detroit's congressional districts were radically reshuffled. While redistricting did create an open, heavily Democratic , the reshuffle combined with several deaths in Lawrence's family led to speculation that Lawrence would opt not to seek reelection. On January 4, 2022, Lawrence announced that she would retire, becoming the 25th Democrat to do so that cycle.\n\n\nLawrence was married to McArthur Lawrence prior to his death in 2023. They were high school sweethearts, having met outside the Midway Market corner store where he worked on Detroit's east side. They bought their first home on Detroit's northwest side. They had two children and a granddaughter.\n\nProfessionally, Lawrence worked for the federal government for 30 years in the United States Postal Service. She started as a letter carrier and later worked in human resources management; she retired in 2008. Lawrence's husband is a  retiree from .\n\n\n*'''2016 Election for Congress, Michigan 14'''\n\n*'''2014 Election for Congress, Michigan 14'''\n\n\n*'''2014 Democratic primary for Congress, Michigan 14'''\n\n\n*'''2013 Election for Mayor of Southfield'''\n\n\n*'''2012 Democratic primary for Congress, Michigan 14'''\n\n\n*'''2010 Election for '''\n\n\n*'''2009 Election for Mayor of Southfield'''\n\n\n*'''2008 Election for Oakland County Executive'''\n\n\n*'''2005 Election for Mayor of Southfield'''\n\n\n*'''2001 Election for Mayor of Southfield'''\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* official U.S. House website\n* campaign website\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n|term_start          = January 3, 2015\n|term_end            = January 3, 2019\n|predecessor         = \n|successor           = \n|office1             = \n|term_start1         = January 10, 2007\n|term_end1           = January 12, 2011\n|predecessor1        = \n|successor1          = \n|state_senate2       = Michigan\n|district2           = \n|term_start2         = January 8, 2003\n|term_end2           = January 12, 2011\n|predecessor2        = \n|successor2          = \n|state_house3        = Michigan\n|district3           = \n|term_start3         = January 13, 1999\n|term_end3           = January 8, 2003\n|predecessor3        = \n|successor3          = \n|birth_name          = Michael Dean Bishop\n|birth_date          = \n|birth_place         = , U.S.\n|death_date          = \n|death_place         = \n|party               = \n|spouse              = Cristina Bishop\n|children            = 3\n|education           =  () ()\n|website             = \n}}\n'''Michael Dean Bishop''' (born March 18, 1967) is an  attorney and politician who was the  for  from 2015 to 2019. He is a member of the . He previously served in the  from 1999 to 2003, and the  from 2003 to 2010 where he served as .\n\nBishop lost his reelection bid in the  to Democratic nominee .\n\n\nBishop graduated from , and graduated from  in 1989. He received a  from . Bishop worked at the law firm of Booth Patterson until 2002. He later became a senior attorney at Simon, Galasso & Frantz. Bishop is also a licensed  and has owned two local real estate businesses, Freedom Realty, Inc. and Pro Management, Inc. Bishop is a member of the , , , Bar of the Supreme Court of the United States, Oakland County Bar Association, Michigan Association of Realtors, and .\n\nBishop served on the Municipal Law and Business Law committees of the Oakland County Bar Association and is a member of the National Association of Sportsmen Legislators. Following his time in the Michigan Legislature, Bishop worked as chief legal officer for International Bancard Corporation and taught at . Prior to his election in the , Bishop unsuccessfully campaigned for a  position in 1996.Demas, S. ; domemagazine.com, March 16, 2009; retrieved March 21, 2017.\n\n\n\n\n\nBishop served in the Michigan State House from 1999 to 2002 representing the 45th District, which covered much of the same territory where his father, Donald Bishop, had served. During his four-year tenure in the Michigan House, he served as vice chairman of the Commerce Committee.\n\n\nBishop was elected to the State Senate in 2002 to represent the , a seat which had previously been held by his father. He served until  prevented him from seeking re-election in 2010. Before his time as majority leader, Bishop was chosen to be chairman of the Banking and Financial Institutions Committee and vice chairman of both the Gaming and Casino Oversight Committee and Judiciary Committee.\n\n\n\nBishop was the Senate Majority Leader from 2007-2010.\n\nAt the State Republican Party Convention in 2010, Bishop unsuccessfully bid for the Republican nomination for . He ran for Oakland County prosecutor in 2012, but lost to Democratic incumbent Jessica R. Cooper.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nOn November 4, 2014, Bishop defeated Democratic challenger Eric Schertzing for Michigan's 8th congressional district.\n\nBishop was sworn in on January 6, 2015. Shortly after being sworn in, he voted for  as Speaker.\n\n\n\nBishop successfully ran for re-election in 2016. He ran unopposed in the Republican primary. Two Democrats, actress  and Linda Keefe, filed to run in the Democratic primary election. Gilbert later withdrew. Gilbert was replaced with Democratic challenger Suzanna Shkreli late in the race in July, 2016.\n\n\n\nBishop ran for re-election but lost to Democratic challenger .\n\n\n*''''''\n**\n*''''''\n**\n**\n*''''''\n**\n**\n\n\n* \n* \n*\n\n\n\n\nBishop has voted to ban abortions after 20 weeks and has co-sponsored legislation which states that life starts at conception.\n\n\nBishop disapproves of the ACA and voted to repeal the  in 2016.\n\n\nBishop has called on the  to stop the killing of kittens after being tested on for research.\n\n\nBishop supports gun rights and the , receiving a A/A+ rating from the .\n\n\nWhen Bishop was Majority Leader of the Michigan Senate, a bill to create the  as a companion to the  came to him for determination to put it to the Senate floor for a vote. Corporate interests were strongly in favor of the bill, which would partner with Canada to pay for the bridge. Bishop opposed the bridge and did not bring the legislation to a floor vote, saying there were \"too many outstanding legal issues and the legislation is too important to push a lame-duck vote.\" Bishop had received campaign donations from , owner of the rival .Behnan, C. , livingstondaily.com, October 19, 2014; retrieved August 31, 2016. Governor , a Republican, found another way to make the deal and the project continued without Bishop's support.\n\nBefore being elected to the U.S. House of Representatives he vowed to vote to block the Gordie Howe International bridge. The ''Livingston Daily'' reported \"A proposal for the federal government to fund a U.S. customs center has stalled. If elected, Bishop said he wouldn't support federal funding of the customs center.\"\n\n\nBishop, a resident of , is married and has three children. He is a .\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''William Isaac Robinson''' (August 21, 1975 – March 29, 2020) was an American attorney and politician who served in the  as a member of the  from 2019 to 2020.\n\n\nWilliam Isaac Robinson was born on August 21, 1975, in  to , an activist and politician. In 1998, Robinson earned a  from the  and  from the  in 2001.\n\n\nRobinson became a law clerk for . In 2003, Robinson became a political director of Michigan  Joint Council #43 until 2010. In 2012, Robinson started his own law firm.\n\n\n\nRobinson's mother represented the  in the Michigan House of Representatives from 2013 to 2019. After his mother was prohibited from seeking a fourth term due to term limits, Isaac was part of a crowded field in the Democratic primary to replace her. He won the Democratic primary against thirteen other candidates and easily won in the Democratic-majority district in the general election.\n\nIn February 2020, he  Senator  for the  for the . Robinson also served as vice chair for Sanders' Michigan campaign in the Democratic primary. He was a member of the Detroit chapter of the .\n\nWhile in the House of Representatives, Robinson served on the Tax Policy, Commerce and Tourism, and Regulatory Reform committees. During the  Robinson supported legislation that would temporarily suspend evictions, foreclosures, and shutting off utilities for ninety days and drafted legislation that would have removed waiting periods for unemployment benefits.\n\n\nOn March 29, 2020, Robinson was taken to Detroit Receiving Hospital due to breathing problems and later died. Robinson's death is suspected of being caused by  infection. He was 44 years old. Following his death, he was praised by Governor , Michigan State Attorney General , Michigan House Speaker , Michigan House Minority Leader , and Congresswoman .\n\nRobinson was succeeded as representative by .\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n*  \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Prior to his election to the House, Wentworth worked for the  and was a member of the .\n\nAfter graduating from high school, Wentworth joined the . He spent five years as a military police officer and completed a tour in South Korea. Wentworth earned his bachelor's degree from  in Florida and his master's degree in leadership from .\n\nPrior to being elected to the Michigan House, he was the East Central Michigan Regional Coordinator for the Michigan Veterans Affairs Agency.\n\nFollowing the  where the GOP caucus maintained its 58–52 majority, Wentworth was selected by his Republican colleagues to serve as Speaker of the House for the 2021-22 legislative sessions, to succeed the term-limited .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
