    "pages": }\n\n'''Cornelis Piet''' \"'''Pete'''\" '''Hoekstra''' (; born October 30, 1953) is a Dutch-American politician who served as the  from January 10, 2018, to January 17, 2021. A member of the , he previously served as the  for  from 1993 to 2011.\n\nBorn in the , Hoekstra immigrated to the United States as a child. In 1992, Hoekstra ran for the U.S. House, defeating thirteen-term incumbent  in the Republican primary and  opponent John H. Miltner in the general election. Hoekstra was the chairman of the  from 2004 to 2007. He was a candidate for governor in , but came in second to  in the Republican primary. Hoekstra was also the Republican nominee for the  in 2012, losing to Democratic incumbent  in the .\n\nIn July 2017, Hoekstra was nominated to be  by President . This nomination was confirmed by the  on November 9, 2017, and Hoekstra was sworn in as U.S. Ambassador on December 11, 2017. He took office on January 10, 2018. He left office on January 17, 2021.\n\nOn January 20, 2024, Hoekstra was elected chair of the .\n\n\nHoekstra was born Cornelis Piet Hoekstra in , Netherlands. He moved to the U.S. with his parents at the age of three, and Anglicized his name to '''Peter Hoekstra.''' He graduated from  (Holland, Michigan) in 1971. He received a  in  from  in 1975 and an  from the 's  in 1977. He then joined office furniture maker  and remained there for 15 years, eventually becoming vice president of marketing.\n\n\n\n\nIn 1992, Hoekstra made his first bid for public office in the 2nd District. The district, previously the 9th, had been represented for 26 years by , longtime chairman of the . Hoekstra rode his  across the district, charging that Vander Jagt had served in Congress for too long; Vander Jagt had won his first election in 1966, when Hoekstra was 13 years old. He scored a monumental upset, winning by almost six percent. Hoekstra dominated the district's more populated southern portion; Vander Jagt's margins in the northern portion, his longtime base, weren't enough to close the gap. This primary win was  in a district reckoned as Michigan's most Republican district; the GOP has held the district for all but four years since it was created in 1873. Hoekstra later defeated  John H. Miltner and  Dick Jacobs in the general election, with 63% of the vote. Hoekstra continued to ride his bicycle across the district every summer, and biked across the state for his gubernatorial campaign.\n\nWhen he was first elected, Hoekstra initially pledged to serve no more than six terms (12 years) in the House. However, in 2004, he announced he would break that pledge and seek a seventh term. In 2006, Hoekstra's Leadership PAC (the Mileage Fund) raised nearly $160,000 in Political Action Contributions from contributors including the , Michigan Credit Union League, and Little Planet Books.\n\nHoekstra faced no significant opposition in the Republican primary or in the general election (as in his previous five reelection campaigns) and went on to secure his seventh term. Shortly after the primary, he was named chairman of the Intelligence Committee, succeeding , who became .\n\n\n\nHoekstra had no primary opponent. In November he was opposed by the  candidate Kimon Kotos, who was also his 2004 opponent. Hoekstra defeated Kotos 183,518 votes to 87,361 votes.\n\n\nHoekstra ran for re-election in 2008 against Fred Johnson, associate professor of History at . He beat Johnson by 215,471 to 119,959 votes.\n\n\nHoekstra had a conservative voting record, consistent with the conservative nature of the 2nd congressional district. He opposed abortion rights, opposed expanding health care benefits for children, opposed gay adoption rights and gay marriage, and voted against paid parental leave for federal employees. However, he also opposed amending the  to prohibit .\n\n\nHoekstra consistently opposed  during his tenure, earning an A rating from the . In 2005 he voted to prohibit product lawsuits against gun manufacturers. In 1994 he voted against the .\n\n\nHoekstra was a proponent of the claim that the Saddam Hussein regime in Iraq possessed weapons of mass destruction (WMDs), and held onto this belief even after no WMDs were found in the wake of the Iraq invasion. In 2006, Hoekstra made headlines by announcing at a press conference in the Capitol that  had been located in  in the form of 500 s. However, the weapons in question were defunct munitions, manufactured prior to the 1991 Gulf War and which had been scattered throughout Iraq. The media had already reported on these munitions when Hoekstra made his announcement that the weapons had been discovered. Hoekstra's insistence that the Hussein regime possessed weapons of mass destruction were disputed by both  officials, the , and the intelligence community.\n\nOn November 3, 2006, '''' reported that a website created at the request of Hoekstra and   was found to contain detailed information that could potentially be helpful to those seeking to produce s. The website was shut down on November 2 following questioning by ''The New York Times''.\n\nAs of September 17, 2007, some news outlets reported that the Congressional committee Hoekstra had overseen had created \"erroneous\" and \"misleading\" reports about Iran's nuclear capabilities. \"Among the committee's assertions is that Iran is producing weapons-grade uranium at its facility in the town of Natanz. The IAEA called that \"incorrect\", noting that weapons-grade uranium is enriched to a level of 90 percent or more. Iran has enriched uranium to 3.5 percent under IAEA monitoring.\"\n\n\nDuring the ,  were discovered by the U.S. military.  In March 2006, the U.S. government, at the urging of members of Congress, made them available online at its  website, requesting Arabic translators around the world to help in the translation.  On April 18, 2006, about a month after the first documents were made public, Hoekstra, chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, issued a news release acknowledging \"minimal risks,\" but saying the site \"will enable us to better understand information such as 's links to terrorism, weapons of mass destruction and violence against the Iraqi people.\" He added: \"It will allow us to leverage the Internet to enable a mass examination as opposed to limiting it to a few exclusive elites.\"\n\nIn early November 2006, the entire set of documents was removed. Media reports stated that the website was taken offline because of security concerns regarding the posting of sophisticated diagrams and other information regarding nuclear weapon design prior to the .\n\n\nOn December 27, 2009, Hoekstra commented on reports that , who had allegedly tried to set off a  on  on December 25, 2009, had subsequently confessed to being trained and equipped in Yemen.\nHoekstra called for a halt to the repatriation of .\n\n\nHoekstra was a founding member of the Congressional House  in 2010.\n\n\n* ''''''\n** As ranking member of the full committee, Rep. Hoekstra may serve as an ''ex officio'' member of all subcommittees\n* ''''''\n** \n** \n\n\n* Founding chairman of the Education Freedom Caucus\n* Founding chairman of the Congressional Caucus on the Netherlands\n\n\n\nIn December 2008, Hoekstra said he would not seek re-election to his U.S. House seat in 2010, and instead campaign to be Michigan's governor. Hoekstra joined , the Oakland County Sheriff and former state senator, former  president , State Senator  and Michigan Attorney General  as 2010 Republican gubernatorial candidates. In the primary, held on August 3, 2010, Hoekstra finished second to Snyder.\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nHoekstra was suggested as a possible challenger for Democratic incumbent  in the , but he initially declined to run. Hoekstra later changed his mind and decided to challenge Stabenow in the election. On August 29, 2011, Hoekstra was endorsed by Republican Michigan Governor Rick Snyder, and on September 23, 2011, Hoekstra was endorsed by  .\n\nHoekstra faced Stabenow and four third-party candidates in the general election. On November 6, 2012, Hoekstra was defeated by Stabenow, receiving 38% of the vote.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nHoekstra targeted Democratic incumbent Debbie Stabenow with a television ad which ran statewide during the . The 30-second ad, created by Republican advertising consultant , opened with the sound of a gong and the image of a Chinese woman (played by 2012 Miss Napa Valley Lisa Chan) riding a bike alongside a rice . The ad sarcastically accused Stabenow of contributing to the U.S.' spending problem, with the woman thanking \"Michigan Senator Debbie Spenditnow\", in , implying Stabenow has earned China's gratitude for making the U.S. economy \"very weak\" while China's \"get very good\".\n\nThe commercial included a link to a Hoekstra campaign website with statistics about federal spending, decorated with images of Chinese flags and currency and using a stereotypical  font. In the  code on Hoekstra's site, the woman in the ad is identified as \"yellowgirl\". A statement released by the Hoekstra campaign said the  code was mistakenly shortened from \"yellowshirtgirl\".\n\nAsian-American groups called the ad \"very disturbing\", and two of Hoekstra's GOP opponents,  and Gary Glenn, questioned whether Hoekstra was the right candidate for Republicans to support. The ad was criticized by , former aide to  , a member of the , and U.S. Senator .  of '''' called it the \"most revolting ad\". The  denounced the ad as an \"unnecessary .\"\n\nThe ad proved costly for Hoekstra; several polls reported him losing ground to Stabenow in a head-to-head match-up.\n\nHoekstra initially stood by the ad, claiming it hit Stabenow \"smack dab between the eyes\" on the economy.  However, on February 10, 2012, Hoekstra shut down his controversial Chinese-themed website and phased in a new TV commercial in place of his original ad.  American Values super PAC, an Asian American group, claimed credit for the scrub shortly after the group's launch of an online viral ad condemning Hoekstra.\n\nOn February 16, Chan apologized for her involvement in the ad. In a statement on her  page, she said the role was \"not in any way representative of who I am\" and \"absolutely a mistake on my part.\"\n\nDespite the controversy, Hoekstra won the Republican primary. He lost to Stabenow in the general election.\n\n\nIn February 2011, Hoekstra joined the government relations group and  law firm , and was named a visiting distinguished fellow at the conservative  , concentrating on education reform.  In 2014, Hoekstra left Dickstein Shapiro to join one of its rivals, .\n\nHoekstra joined 's Investigative Project on Terrorism in 2014 as a  Senior Fellow, specializing in national security, international relations, global terrorism and cyber security.\n\nHoekstra published his first book in October 2015, ''Architects of Disaster: The Destruction of Libya'' with Terri Blumenfeld.\n\nIn an interview with NPR's Robert Siegel on December 10, 2014, Hoekstra said he disagreed with the recently released .\n\n's KFile reported that Hoekstra in 2016 accused  of ties with the . A 2016 ''''  gave that claim \"four \". CNN also stated that Hoekstra was a frequent guest on a talk show hosted by , an anti-Muslim conspiracy theorist based in Washington.\n\nOn March 11, 2017, Hoekstra said that , , and other leakers of government materials, having illegally released classified information, were traitors and should have taken their evidence to the intelligence committees of the U.S. Congress for proper investigations.\n\n\nOn July 24, 2017, President  nominated Hoekstra to be . He was confirmed by the Senate on November 9 via voice vote and sworn in by Vice President  on December 11, 2017. He took office on January 10, 2018.\n\n\n\nLater that December,  U.S. correspondent Wouter Zwart questioned Hoekstra about inaccurate claims that he had made in November 2015 at a panel titled \"Muslim Migration into Europe: Eurabia come True?\" hosted by the  that the Netherlands had \"\" and that politicians and cars were being set on fire in the country due to . Hoekstra told Zwart that he had never said such things, saying, \"we would call it . I never said that.\" Zwart then played the clip in which he made those remarks for his viewers. Later in the interview, Hoekstra denied that he denied it, saying \"I didn't call it 'fake news'. I didn't use those words today.\" On December 23, Hoekstra issued an apology on , writing that he \"made certain remarks in 2015 and regret[ted] the exchange during the '''' interview\".\n\nOn January 10, 2018, during his press conference after presenting his credentials to King , Hoekstra said that he did not want to revisit the comments made in 2015. Despite repeated questions from Dutch reporters regarding these comments, Hoekstra refused to talk about these statements and refused to answer further questions.\n\nOn January 11, 2018,   said that in 2015, Hoekstra \"made comments that should not have been made\", that \"the State Department does not agree with those statements\" and \"that is not the language we would use.\" He added that the \"comments were wrong and don't reflect the U.S. view of the Netherlands\". One day later, in an interview with Dutch newspaper '''', Hoekstra finally retracted his statement about the presence of \"no-go zones\" in the Netherlands where cars and politicians are being set on fire, saying: \"Looking back, I'm dismayed that I said it. It was an incorrect statement. It was just wrong.\" He further claimed that he could not recall how he got to the statement or what it was based on, saying: \"I've mixed up countries. I was wrong, and I don't know how that could have happened. I do know: it was wrong.\"\n\n\nIn September 2020, a group of Dutch officials demanded answers from Hoekstra in response to reports that he had hosted a fund-raising event at the U.S. embassy for the far right Dutch political party , a potential violation of international law. This is not the first time Hoekstra has been associated with the far-right party. In May 2020, Hoekstra was interviewed by party leader  on the party's video channel and he was also a guest speaker at the party's conference in November 2019.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n*  ''IPT (Investigative Project on Terrorism)''\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n()|years=}}\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Vicki Barnett''' (born July 8, 1954) is an American politician who served as a member of the  from 2009 to 2014, representing the . A member of the , Barnett served as the mayor of  from 2003 to 2007 and from 2019 to 2023. Barnett was the unsuccessful Democratic nominee for Oakland County Executive in 2016.\n\n\nVicki Barnett was born on July 8, 1954, to a  family in , .  She received a  from the  in 1983, and later received her  in Business Administration in 1991, also from the University of Michigan-Dearborn.  She has worked as an investment consultant at LPL Financial in  since 1999, and is a licensed accident, life, and health insurance agent.  Barnett married her husband, attorney Mark Steckloff, in 1981, and together they have two children,  and Jordan. She belongs to the Roosevelt Group of the Greater Detroit Chapter of Hadassah, an American Jewish volunteer women's organization.\n\n\nBarnett was elected to Farmington Hills City Council in 1995.  She served two four-year terms in this position until 2003, when she was elected Mayor. She served as Mayor for the maximum two consecutive two-year terms, through 2007.\n\nIn 2008, she announced her intention to run for the , which was left open by the retirement of longtime Democratic legislator , who could not run for re-election due to term limits.  Barnett was unopposed in the Democratic primary and faced Republican Paul Welday in the General Election.  Barnett's popularity as Mayor led to a 60%-40% victory over Welday.\n\nIn 2010, Barnett retained her seat with an even stronger showing against Republican Chris Atallah, garnering 61% of the vote.  Barnett was thereafter named House Minority Whip.\n\nBarnett won her third and final term on November 6, 2012, by her largest margin, over Republican Bruce Lilley.  Barnett received almost 62% of votes cast in Farmington and Farmington Hills.\n\nFacing term limits, Barnett announced in late 2013 she was running for the Michigan State Senate's 14th District, but narrowly lost a three-way race in the Democratic primary election to the incumbent State Senator Vincent Gregory, who received 34.68% of the vote to Barnett's 34.28%.\n\nIn 2016, she was the Democratic candidate for Oakland County Executive against six-term incumbent Republican , where she garnered 46.1% of the vote, the highest any Democratic candidate had ever received against Patterson.\n\nIn 2019, she again successfully ran for Mayor of Farmington Hills, where she now serves. She was reelected in 2021.\n\n\n\n*'''2008 Election for State House'''\n**Vicki Barnett (D), 60%\n**Paul Welday (R), 40%\n*'''2010 Election for State House'''\n**Vicki Barnett (D), 61%\n**Chris Atallah (R), 38%\n*'''2012 Election for State House'''\n**Vicki Barnett (D), 61.6%\n**Bruce Lilley (R), 38.3%\n*'''2016 Election for Oakland County Executive'''\n**L. Brooks Patterson (R), 53.5%\n**Vicki Barnett (D), 46.1%\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Tommy Brann''' (born December 23, 1951) is an American politician from Michigan. Brann is a  member of  from . \n\n\nThomas Michael Brann was born on December 23, 1951. Brann's father is John Brann, a former restaurateur. He graduated from East Grand Rapids High School. He is a third-generation resident of Kent County. He is of Irish Descent. \n\n\nBrann is the owner of Brann's Steakhouse and Grille. At 19, Brann started his first restaurant business. Brann is the author of Mind Your Own Business. After  and  criticized the film '''', Brann banned the two from visiting his restaurants, describing their criticism as \"hateful\" against the  and military sniper , who was portrayed in the film.\n\n\nOn November 6, 2016, Brann won the election and became a  member of  for District 77. Brann defeated Dana Knight. In 2018 and 2020, as an incumbent, Brann won the reelection served House District 77.    \n\nOn October 10, 2021, Brann co-sponsored House Bill 5444.\n\nBrann supported   during the  in 2022. In the , Brann was defeated by  in a race form representing .\nBrann is currently running against State Representative John Fitzgerald in the 2024 Election racing for the 83rd District which spans from Wyoming to Grand Rapids.\n\n\nBrann is married to Sue Brann for 50 years, whom he met through his restaurant, according to his website. He describes himself as an Independent Republican. He is currently running in the 2024 83rd District against John Fitzgerald. \n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Monique Owens''' (born February 21, 1984) is an American politician and convicted criminal who served as the mayor of  from 2019 to 2023. She previously served on the Eastpointe City Council from 2017 to 2019 and was the first  to serve in either office. She was unseated in the 2023 mayoral primary.\n\nHer tenure as mayor was controversial and included a lawsuit alleging that she violated residents' First Amendment rights and a criminal conviction for making false statements on a grant application for her business. Residents also objected to police reports she made against critics, her failure to file financial disclosure statements, her heated tirades against residents and other officials during meetings, and her lack of support for the LGBT community.\n\nOn September 28, 2023, Owens pleaded no contest to a misdemeanor charge of making a false statement. The case, which was originally charged as felony false pretenses, stemmed from a COVID business relief application which stated that her business was 51 percent or more owned by veterans and had 100–249 employees. After paying $10,000 in restitution to the victim, she was sentenced to six months of probation, 100 hours of community service, and $725 in court costs.\n\n\n\nOwens started her career as a clerical employee with the  and later served as a 's deputy for 11 years. The Wayne County Sheriff's Office suspended Owens in 2010.\n\n\nOwens moved from  to Eastpointe in 2010.\n\n\nIn 2017, Owens was elected to the Eastpointe City Council, the first African-American to serve as councilperson in the city.\n\nEarlier that year, the U.S. Department of Justice had filed a lawsuit alleging that the city's election of council members at-large violated the . The lawsuit was settled after Owens was elected to council and resulted in the city using ranked-choice voting for council elections beginning in 2019.\n\n\nOwens was the only council member to vote \"no\" on the city's Pride Month resolution in 2019, saying that Eastpointe has \"always accepted everybody\". After becoming mayor, she voted against similar resolutions in both 2020 and 2021. Owens did not attend the council meeting where the 2023 Pride Month resolution was voted on.\n\nAs mayor, Owens attended a Feb. 2020 speech by  which included anti-LGBT remarks.\n\n\n\nIn 2019, incumbent mayor Suzanne Pixley did not file to run for re-election. On November 5, 2019, Owens was narrowly elected mayor with 32.5 percent of the vote in a five-way contest. She received 19 more votes than runner-up Mike Klinefelt.\n\n\nIn July 2021, Owens applied for a poverty exemption from property taxes on her home in Eastpointe. The Eastpointe Board of Review later granted the mayor a 100 percent exemption from property taxes in 2021.\n\nIn 2022, Owens applied for a tax exemption again, but the Eastpointe Board of Review denied the exemption for 2022 on the grounds that her income exceeded the guidelines for a poverty exemption. Owens appealed the board's decision to the Michigan Tax Tribunal, which in February 2023 issued a judgment upholding the city's denial of the exemption. Paperwork submitted by Owens to the tribunal claimed that her annual income was less than $12,000. Judge Patricia Halm, however, noted that the testimony and evidence considered by the tribunal showed income of $43,695. Tax records reviewed by the ''Macomb Daily'' shortly after the decision showed that Owens owed $3,378 for summer and winter 2022 property taxes. On Feb. 28, 2023, Owens's 2022 property taxes were paid via two separate credit cards, according to city records.\n\nIn 2023, Owens applied for the tax exemption a third time. The board of review denied the request.\n\n\nIn 2021, Owens applied for the full-time city manager position in . In September, the city extended Owens a conditional job offer, which she accepted on September 30. Owens expressed her intent to remain mayor of Eastpointe while working as city manager of Harper Woods. The following day, the mayor of Harper Woods announced that Owens did not meet the conditions of the contract. As a result, Owens did not receive the job.\n\n\nIn October 2021, Eastpointe Community Schools board member Mary Hall-Rayford criticized Owens for her behavior at the Michigan Military Technical & Historical Society Museum. ''The Macomb Daily'' reported that Owens brought someone to tour the museum during hours when it was closed to the public and that she entered areas that were restricted to museum employees only. The museum is privately owned and operated but leases a building from the city. Museum staff also complained that Owens violated the museum's policy prohibiting beverages near the exhibits and that she refused to comply when reminded of the rule. MMTHS board member Wendy Richardson said that she filmed Owens' visit using a cell phone due to legal concerns. Owens objected to the recording and alleged that museum staff had violated her rights by filming her.\n\n\nIn Eastpointe's 2021 general election, Owens endorsed Shenita Lloyd and Michael Jones for city council. Both candidates were defeated by Cardi DeMonaco, an incumbent, and Rob Baker, who had previously served a partial term on the council.\n\nThat same day, voters also approved a city charter amendment requiring the city to hold a mayoral primary if more than two candidates run for mayor in the same election.\n\n\nThe Eastpointe City Council voted 3-1 to censure Owens at its April 5, 2022, meeting.\n\n\nOwens filed on April 15 to run for the Republican nomination for state senate in the 11th district. Four days later, she withdrew from the Republican primary and filed to run in the Democratic primary in the same district.\n\nOn June 18, Owens attended the opening ceremonies of Cruisin' Gratiot, an annual car cruise hosted by a nonprofit in Eastpointe. As the ceremonies ended, Owens approached the microphone and spoke to the crowd against the organization's wishes. Harvey Curley, an 80 year-old longtime Cruisin' Gratiot board member who is also a city councilman, then confronted Owens. She later reported the incident to police, alleging that Curley had assaulted her. The Macomb County Sheriff’s Office dismissed the case.\n\nOwens also filed for a personal protective order against Curley. On September 23, 2022, Macomb County Circuit Court Judge Rachel Rancilio denied Owens’s request, saying in her decision that no evidence was taken at the hearing that would demonstrate that Curley is dangerous.\n\n'''' endorsed Owens in the primary. '''' endorsed her opponent in the primary, citing Owens' \"oddly malleable\" values and expressing concern that she may switch her party affiliation again.\n\nOwens lost the Democratic primary election to  by a nearly two-to-one margin.\n\n\nDuring the 2022 state senate campaign, Owens claimed in a Ballotpedia candidate survey that she had a bachelor's degree in political science. The Macomb Daily, however, reported that she had a bachelor's degree in criminal justice.\n\n\nIn 2022, Owens was named as a defendant in a federal lawsuit alleging that she violated the civil rights of four constituents by interrupting or censoring their remarks during public comment time at council meetings.\n\nAt the council's September 6, 2022, meeting, Owens repeatedly interrupted and talked over residents during the public comment section of the meeting, objecting that speakers may not discuss a police matter involving Owens and another council member, Harvey Curley. The city's attorney advised the council that they may not restrict a speaker's subject matter, except for racial accusations and similar remarks. When Owens continued to interrupt subsequent speakers and raise her voice, all four council members walked out in protest, leaving Owens alone at the table and effectively ending the meeting.\n\nOn November 9, 2022, the  filed suit in the  in Detroit, naming Owens and the City of Eastpointe as defendants. The lawsuit alleges that Owens violated the First and Fourteenth Amendment rights of four residents who attempted to speak during public comment periods at meetings by shouting them down, berating them, and otherwise preventing them from speaking. In addition to the three plaintiffs who attempted to speak during the public comment period of the September 6 meeting, a fourth plaintiff alleged similar treatment during a March 2022 meeting. The lawsuit further alleged that Owens frequently uses her authority “to suppress dissent and criticism by interrupting and shouting down members of the public who criticize her or raise subjects she finds personally embarrassing”. The lawsuit's stated purpose is to “stop Mayor Owens’s abuse of authority”.\n\nOn December 8, 2022, a federal judge issued a preliminary injunction, which the City agreed to, prohibiting Owens from shouting down speakers or restricting the subject matter of their remarks. The order is to remain in effect until the case is resolved or the court orders otherwise.\n\n\nOn December 13, 2022, the Eastpointe Board of Ethics voted 3-0 (with one abstention) to verify a resident's ethics complaint against Owens which alleged that she had failed to file annual financial disclosures required under the city's ethics ordinance. At the time of the complaint, Owens had not filed a disclosure form since 2017.\n\nOn January 30, 2023, the Ethics Board directed the city manager to issue a formal letter to Owens requesting that she submit her annual disclosure statements for 2021 and 2022 within 30 days. The board was unable to take action for missing disclosures prior to 2021 due to the ordinance's statute of limitations.\n\n\nOn March 9, 2023, Owens was arraigned on a felony charge of false pretenses in 41B District Court. The Macomb County Prosecutor's Office alleged that she fraudulently applied for a COVID relief grant for her business and received $10,000 from the program. Owens is accused of fraudulently stating that her business was 51 percent or more owned by veterans and had 100–249 employees. The warrant authorization request stated that Owens “has never served at any capacity in any of the armed forces, and according to state unemployment records has zero employees other than herself\".\n\nOwens waived her right to a preliminary examination and on July 17 was bound over to the 16th Judicial Circuit Court for a July 31 arraignment.\n\nOn September 28, 2023, Owens pleaded no contest to a misdemeanor charge of making a false statement. As part of the plea agreement, she was required to pay $10,000 in restitution to the victim. Sentencing was originally scheduled for October 10 but was delayed until November 9. In response to remarks made by Owens at sentencing, Judge Jennifer Faunce questioned the defendant's remorsefulness and suggested that she was grandstanding. Owens could have received a sentence of up to one year in jail but was ultimately sentenced to six months of probation, 100 hours of community service, and $725 in court costs.\n\n\nOwens faced three challengers in her 2023 bid for reelection. She was unseated in the primary as she failed to win a place among the top two vote getters. She received 14.1% percent of the vote. Mike Klinefelt and Mary Hall-Rayford, one of the plaintiffs in the civil rights lawsuit against Owens, proceeded to the general election.\n\nIn the general election, Klinefelt defeated Hall-Rayford. Klinefelt succeeded Owens as mayor on November 13, 2023.\n\nIn her final speech as mayor, Owens compared herself to Jesus and complained of being abandoned by people who had supported her.\n\n\nMonique Owens lives in Eastpointe and has two children.\n\nOwens is a Christian. She said in a 2021 city council meeting that she does not celebrate Christmas.\n\nIn 2022, Monique Owens authored a children's book titled ''Mom, What's a Mayor?''\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }
  }

    "pages": }\n'''John Edward James''' (born June 8, 1981) is an American businessman, combat veteran, and politician serving as the  from  since 2023. A member of the , he was the party's nominee for  in  and .\n\nIn , James declared his candidacy in Michigan's redrawn 10th congressional district. He defeated Democratic nominee Carl Marlinga by a narrow margin.\n\n\nJames was born in , in 1981 and grew up Baptist in the  neighborhood of . He graduated from the Catholic  in 1999. He graduated from the  (West Point) in 2004, and served eight years in the , participating in multiple tours of duty in  as an  pilot. Two of his West Point classmates are fellow congressmen  and . He attended the  and became Ranger-tabbed as a captain.\n\nJames received a master's degree in  from 's  and an  from the 's .\n\n\nIn 2012, James joined James Group International, where his father, John A. James, was the CEO. James Group is a global  management service company; James became its director of operations, and eventually became president of James Group International and CEO of its subsidiary, Renaissance Global Logistics. Renaissance Global, based in Detroit, was the recipient of a $1–2 million  loan during the .\n\nJames was named one of ''Detroit Business Journal's'' 30 in their 30s of 2012, and '''''s 40 under 40 of 2014. He served as a board member of the Michigan Council for Future Mobility, Michigan Minority Supplier Development Council and National Veteran Business Development Council. He serves on the Detroit Workforce Development Board.\n\n\n\n\n in September 2018]]\nIn September 2017, James entered the  primary for the  in an attempt to unseat three-term incumbent  , as well as become Michigan's first African-American senator. Despite musician and Michigan native  publicly toying with the idea of running for the seat for months, the primary came down to James and  businessman and former Wayne County commissioner Sandy Pensler. James was endorsed via  by   on July 27, 2018, eleven days before the primary. James won the nomination with 55% of the vote.\n\nOn November 6, 2018, Stabenow defeated James, 52.3% to 45.8%.\n\n\nIn late November 2018,  reported that Trump was considering nominating James to become the , to replace Ambassador , who previously announced that she was planning to leave the Trump administration by the end of 2018. James reportedly met at the  with Trump,  , and  . He was ultimately bypassed for the position. Trump announced he would appoint , the  and a former television reporter, to succeed Haley, but Nauert was never nominated and announced in February 2019 that she was withdrawing from consideration.\n\nAfter Nauert's withdrawal, Trump again considered James for the ambassadorship, but eventually nominated   for the post.\n\n\n\n\nBecause the election margin in the 2018 Senate race was smaller than expected, James became a front-runner for the Republican nomination to take on Michigan's other incumbent Democratic senator, , in the .\n\nAs well as being recruited to take on Peters, it was reported in June 2019 that the  was recruiting James to challenge freshman Democratic U.S. representative  of .\n\nOn June 6, 2019, James announced that he was seeking the Republican nomination in  to take on Peters. Michigan was one of two states in which an incumbent Democratic senator was seeking reelection during 2020 in a state won by Trump in , the other being . Although the Associated Press called the race for Peters on November 4, 2020, James refused to concede, which Peters termed \"pathetic.\" James initially insisted that the election had not been administered fairly. He established a joint legal fund with the  to challenge the results. James claimed there was \"ample evidence\" for an investigation, but offered none. He raised $2 million after the election as he sought to challenge the election results, and he unsuccessfully attempted to block certification of the results of the election, which he lost to Peters by 1.7% of the vote, which was much closer than originally projected. James conceded on November 24 over social media, congratulating Peters.\n\nDuring his campaign, James pledged to give 5% of his campaign contributions to charity. The James fundraising committee reported about $46.12 million in total contributions for the 2020 election and has given more than $2.36 million to charities following through on his pledge.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nJames won the Republican primary in the 2022 election in . He defeated Democrat  in the November general election.\n\n\n\nAs of the , James is a member of the following committees.\n\n*\n** (Vice Chair)\n**\n*\n** (Chairman)\n**\n*\n**\n*\n\n\n in Israel, November 12, 2023]]\nDuring his 2018 Senate campaign, James ran on a typical Republican platform, describing himself on his campaign website as \"a pro-life, pro-, pro-business conservative.\" He emphasized his desire to defund  and compared '''', the  decision legalizing abortion, to \".\" He opposes the , does not believe employers should be able to fire workers due to their sexual orientation, and opposes the legalization of recreational marijuana.\n\nJames says he wants to repeal and replace the  (Obamacare), which he has called \"a monstrosity.\" According to ''The Detroit Free Press'', James was careful not to take a position on the  seeking to immediately strike down the entire ACA as unconstitutional. When pressed in a September 2020 interview, he said he was against the ACA lawsuit without a replacement plan in place, but did not criticize Republicans for pushing the lawsuit.\n\nJames supported  in the . He later became a Trump supporter, and  in 2018 that, if elected to the Senate, he would back Trump \"2,000%.\" During his 2020 campaign, James accepted Trump's endorsement and campaigned alongside him. James has not been publicly critical of Trump or his actions. During a meeting with black faith leaders, James was asked whether he disagreed with Trump on anything. James said, \"Everything from cutting Great Lakes funding to '' to speaking ill of the dead. I mean, where do you want to start?\" In a leaked audio recording of a meeting with African American leaders in Michigan, James was asked why he hadn't publicly criticized Trump. He said he thought it was better to be silent in public in order to gain access to Trump. James said, \"Donald Trump doesn't need less Black folks around him, he needs more,\" and that his goal was \"achieving equity and equality for our people, not standing up on Twitter and condemning folks.\" During the campaign, Democrats sought to tie James to Trump, while James has said his candidacy was not a referendum on Trump.\n\nDuring his 2020 campaign, James declined to take specific positions on a number of policy questions, including how the  would be protected from the impact of a , whether the Senate should vote to confirm a new  justice to fill the vacancy created by the  before or after the 2020 presidential election, and whether he thinks  should be renamed.\n\n\nJames married his wife, Elizabeth, in 2012. They have three sons. When James was still dating Elizabeth, he had an encounter with police at a mall in a suburb of Detroit in which the officers drew their guns on him; James believes that if Elizabeth had not been beside him, he might have been killed. He has also expressed his fear of being killed whenever police pull him over for a .\n\nJames is a .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  official U.S. House website\n* \n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n()|years=}}\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Tim Moore''' (born April 26, 1967 in ) is a   from the  of . Moore served in the  from the  from 2005 to 2010. He resigned in August 2010 to become principal of Farwell Elementary School. Before running for office, he ran the family auto part store in . He earned a business administration degree from  in 1989.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n|children            = \n|profession          = \n|website             = \n|party               = \n|alma_mater          = \n|religion=\n\n|nickname           = \n|allegiance         = \n|branch             = \n|serviceyears       = \n|rank               = \n|unit               = \n|commands           = \n|battles            = \n|awards             = \n}}\n\n'''Frederick Moulton Alger Jr.''' (August 3, 1907January 7, 1967) was an American politician and diplomat.\n\n\nAlger was born on August 3, 1907, to parents Frederick Moulton and Mary Eldridge Alger in . He was a grandson of .\n\n\nAlger served in the  during .\n\n\nAlger unsuccessfully ran for the position of  from  in . He received 34.4% of the vote. Alger served as the  from 1947 to 1952. In , Alger ran in the Michigan gubernatorial  primary unsuccessfully. Alger was the Republican nominee in the , but was again unsuccessful.\n\n\nAlger was appointed to the position of  by President  on May 26, 1953. The presentation of his credentials occurred on July 22, 1953. The termination of mission occurred on March 27, 1957.\n\n\nAlger married Suzette de Marigny Dewey in 1929. He was widowed in 1963. Later in the year, he married Katherine Sutton. Alger was a member of a number of organizations including the , the , the , , , and was a . Alger was .\n\n\nAlger died on January 7, 1967, in .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

He was inaugurated in the Michigan Senate on January 1, 2015 and left office on January 1, 2022. A , he represented  in the Senate and before that represented  in the House, and is from .\n\n\n\nState Representative Jim Stamas was elected to his second term in the Michigan House of Representatives in November 2010, representing portions of Midland and Saginaw counties. Stamas is a former two-term Midland County commissioner. He was a Midland Township trustee from 1997 to 2004. He served on the boards of the Midland Downtown Development Authority, Midland Downtown Business Association, and Midland County Planning Commission.\n\nOn June 14, 2012, Stamas moved with the House Representative leadership to bar two fellow Representatives from speaking on the floor. One, Representative  (D - West Bloomfield) was denied speaking time after, during a debate regarding a restrictive anti-abortion bill, she made the remarks, ''\"...Mr Speaker, I'm flattered that you're all so interested in my vagina, but 'no' means 'no'.\"''  According to , spokesman for the Republican Majority, \"Majority Floor Leader Jim Stamas determined Brown's comments violated the decorum of the House.\" Michigan State Representative  (D - Onondaga) was also barred June 14 from introducing an amendment to the same proposed anti-abortion bill that would ban men from receiving  procedures unless sterilization were necessary to save a man's life.\n\n\n\nStamas is the owner and former general manager of Pizza Sam's, the eatery in Midland the Stamas family has owned for nearly 50 years. Prior to running the family business, Stamas was self-employed as a realtor and was project manager at .\n\nStamas holds a bachelor's degree in business administration from  and an associate degree in business management from .  Stamas served in both the  and the . Jim and wife, Marsha, have been married for more than 35 years, and have a daughter and a son.\n\nHis brother, , served in the state House and Senate.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Sara Cambensy''' is an American politician who served in the , representing the , and is a member of the . Prior to her election to the state legislature, Cambensy served on the  City Commission and the Marquette Planning Commission and was the director of adult and continuing education for Marquette Community Schools.\n\n\nCampbensy is a lifelong resident of Marquette, in . She has two degrees from , a bachelor's degree in education earned in 2002 and a master's degree in public administration in 2011.\n\n\nIn April 2017, Cambensy announced her campaign to seek the Democratic nomination in the 109th District in the Michigan House of Representatives, to succeed three-term state Rep. , who was term-limited and was running for .\n\nThe 109th district seat became vacant on May 9, 2017, when Kivela committed suicide just hours after his second drunken driving arrest during his five years in the House. On May 18, 2017,   announced a special election to fill the remainder of Kivela's term, with a special primary election on August 8, and the special general election on November 7, 2017. On May 23, Cambensy announced that she would run in the special election as well. She won the Democratic primary, taking 36 percent of the vote, winning by just 133 votes in a four-person field. She then won the special general election to finish the last 14 months of Kivela's term, defeating Republican nominee Rich Rossway and  candidate Wade Roberts, receiving 57 percent of the vote. She was sworn in on November 28, 2017 and served in the state House until she was  in 2022.\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Benny Nelson Napoleon''' (September 10, 1955 – December 17, 2020) was an American attorney, law enforcement officer, and politician who served as the  of  from 2009 to 2020. A member of the , he previously served as the chief of the Detroit Police Department, and was also a candidate for the office of  in the .\n\n\nBorn in  in 1955, he was one of seven children of his mother Betty and father Harry Napoleon, who was a minister. Napoleon graduated from . He earned a bachelor's degree from the  and  from the .\n\n\nNapoleon entered the  in 1975. He was also a member of the Detroit Police basketball team that played in international police tournaments in  from 1978 to 1980. He served as Detroit Police Chief from 1998 to 2001 under . In 2004, he was made Assistant Wayne County Executive, and in 2009, he became Wayne County Sheriff.\n\n\n\nA , Napoleon entered , announcing his intentions to run for mayor in the city's  to replace , who announced he would not seek re-election after the appointment of an emergency manager for the city. During the primary campaign, he referred to himself as a \"businessman with a badge\". Napoleon placed second in the primary despite his most serious competition, former Wayne County Prosecutor and Detroit Medical Center CEO  having to run as a write-in candidate, and lost the mayoral race to Duggan on November 5, 2013.\n\nIn 2017, Napoleon was wiretapped by the FBI as part of a corruption investigation. No charges were ever filed on Mr. Napoleon.\n\n\nIn November 2020, it was announced that Napoleon had tested positive for  during the . He was admitted to a local hospital on November 21 and placed on a . On December 17, after various sources reported that Napoleon had died, his family released a statement on  that Napoleon remained in stable condition. Napoleon died later that same day.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n| relatives =  (brother)\n| children = 4, including \n| education =  () () ()\n| module              = \n}}\n\n'''Sander Martin Levin''' (born September 6, 1931) is an American politician who served in the  from 1983 to 2019, representing  (numbered as the  from 1983 to 1993 and as the  from 1993 to 2013). Levin, a member of the  from , is a former ranking member on the ; he was Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee from 2010 to 2011. He was the older brother of former  , and is the father of former Congressman , his successor.\n\nIn December 2017, Levin announced that he would retire from  at the end of his current term, and not seek re-election in . His son Andy was elected on November 6, 2018, and took office in the , which commenced on January 3, 2019.\n\n\nLevin was born in Detroit, Michigan, the son of Jewish parents Bess Rachel (née Levinson) and Saul R. Levin. He graduated from  in Detroit, received a bachelor's degree from the  in 1952, a  in international relations from  in 1954, and a law degree from  in 1957. Afterwards, he developed a private practice in Detroit.\n\n\nLevin was named chairman of the  Democratic Party in 1962. He was elected as  for the  in 1964, defeating Republican George W. Kuhn.\nLevin served in the position until 1970. Following the 1967 resignation of  chairman , Levin was elected state party chairman on December 17. He resigned his position as minority  the following January. He served as Senate minority leader from January 1969 to January 1970, when he resigned to run for governor.\n\nHe made unsuccessful campaigns for  in  and , both times losing to  . He was a Fellow of the  in 1975. From 1977 through 1981 he was assistant administrator of the .\n\n\n\n\nIn 1982, incumbent Democratic U.S. Congressman  decided not to run for re-election, instead making an unsuccessful run for governor. Levin won the Democratic primary in  with 49% of the vote, which at that time included northwestern Detroit as well as parts of Macomb and Oakland counties. Levin subsequently won this 1982 general election with 67% of the vote. He typically won re-election with at least 56% of the vote since then, exceptions being 1992 and 1994 elections. After the , his district was renumbered as the 12th district and lost its share of Detroit. In 1992, he narrowly defeated businessman and  veteran  53%-46%. In a 1994 rematch, Levin again defeated this same opponent, during the midst of the , 52%-47%. Then again in 1996, Levin defeated Pappageorge by a larger margin in a third rematch 57%-41%. In 1998, Levin won re-election against Republican nominee Leslie A. Touma, 56%-42%. In 2000, Detroit Metro area businessman Bart Baron gained the endorsement of the  Union, but Levin still managed to win re-election with 64% of the vote. The 2000s redistricting added heavily Democratic  and Mount Clemens to the district, and he won re-election in every election with at least 61% of the vote since.\n\n;2012\n\nAfter redistricting, Levin's district was merged with the 9th District of fellow Democrat .  The district retained Peters' district numberthe 9thbut geographically was more Levin's district. Peters opted to run in the newly redrawn . This effectively handed the Democratic nomination to Levin. While he lost Southfield to the 14th, it picked up the rest of Royal Oak, as well as Oak Park,  and , among other locations. It was no less Democratic than its predecessor, and Levin breezed to a 16th term with 61.4 percent of the vote.\n\n\n*  (former Ranking Member)\n**  (Ranking Member)\n** \n\nLevin took over as chairman of the Ways and Means committee on March 4, 2010, when  of New York stepped aside in due to a number of ethics violations. Levin served as chairman until January 2011 and ranking member until the end of 2016.\n\nLevin was a member of the  and the .\n\n\n\n\nAs a member of Congress, Levin was a supporter of . He supported the , and said that Israel, the region, and the world would be more secure under the Iran nuclear deal.\n\n\nHis wife of 50 years, Vicki Schlafer, died on September 4, 2008. They had four children: , Jennifer, Madeleine, and Matthew and ten grandchildren.\n\nIn a private ceremony in July 2012, Levin married Pamela Cole, age 61, a  psychology professor who studies emotional development. They met through his late wife Vicki. Cole and Levin worked to create a fund in her name for young professionals researching early childhood development.\n\nLevin comes from a family that has long been prominent in Michigan politics. His younger brother  was the state's senior Senator until his retirement in January 2015. His uncle, , was a federal judge. His first cousin  was a  justice, after serving as a  judge. Another first cousin, Joseph Levin, was a candidate for the U.S. House of Representatives. His son  was an unsuccessful candidate for the  in 2006, but in 2018 was elected to succeed him in the United States House of Representatives.\n\n\n\n|+ : Results 1982–1990\n! Year\n!\n! He was a member of the .\n\n\nMike Simpson received his high school diploma at . After high school the Representative attended college for some time.. Project Vote Smart. Retrieved on 2008-05-14.\n\n\nMike Simpson was a veteran who served in the  from 1980&ndash;1986. After high school Simpson joined his family's business and was an entrepreneur and business owner until his death.\n\n\nIn 2006 Mike was elected state representative in Michigan's 65th house district after having run in the same district in 2004 and in US House District 7 in 2002.\n\n\nHe was a member of all five local business chambers in the 65th District; Jackson Area Chamber of Commerce, Eaton Rapids Area Chamber of Commerce, Brooklyn-Irish Hills Chamber of Commerce, Grass Lake Regional Chamber of Commerce and the Onsted Area Chamber of Commerce.\n\nHe was a member of the Brooklyn Area Kiwanis Club, the Michigan Farm Bureau, the American Legion Post 252, the National Rifle Association and the Michigan Fraternal Order of Police Lodge 70.\n\n\nAt the time of his death Simpson served as a member of the House Tourism & Natural Resources Committee, the House Commerce Committee, and the House Insurance Committee.  Additionally, Mike was the Majority Vice-Chairman of the House Health Policy Committee, a standing member of the National Conference of State Legislators, National Health Policy Committee, and a member of the Board of Directors for the Michigan Center for Rural Health.\n\n\nSimpson had been ill with a rare  known as light-chain deposition.     "pages": }\n\n'''George Alvin McManus Jr.''' (December 12, 1930 – June 21, 2024) was an American politician who was a  member of the , serving from 1991 to 2002.\n\n\nMcManus was born on December 12, 1930 on the , just north of . The salutatorian of  in Traverse City in 1948, McManus went on to receive both a bachelor's and a master's degree from . He later served as the extension director for the institution in  for 25 years. McManus was also a fourth-generation .\n\nMcManus was a trustee of  for 20 years, and a director of the college's foundation. He also served on the Grand Traverse Area Catholic Board of Education.\n\nDuring his time in the Senate, McManus sponsored the Michigan Groundwater and Freshwater Protection Act and played a key role in protecting family farms from property tax increases.\n\nMcManus received an honorary doctorate of agriculture from  in May 2003. \n\nMcManus died in  on June 21, 2024, at the age of 93.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Christine Morse''' (born 1973) is an American  politician from . She was elected to the  from the  in . She was then elected to represent the  in .\n\n\nMorse was born in  in 1973. Morse earned a  from  and then a  degree from .\n\n\nMorse worked as an attorney from 1999 to 2002. Morse has served as the  Commissioner representing the 9th district since 2018. In her campaign for the  seat representing the , Morse was endorsed by former United States President . Morse is the first Democrat to win the 61st district since it was re-established as a Kalamazoo County seat in 1993. Morse was sworn in as state representative on December 11, 2020 and assumed office on January 1, 2021.\n\nIn the , she was elected in  due to redistricting.\n\n\nMorse is married and has three children. Morse is a cancer survivor.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''James Lower''' (born April 10, 1989) is an American politician who has served as a  member of the  representing the  since 2017. Lower previously served on the , was the Village Manager of , and was the campaign manager for 's state senate campaign in 2010.\n\n\nLower was elected to the  Board of Commissioners in 2010, becoming one of the youngest elected officials in Michigan and the board's youngest member as a 21-year-old. In 2012, Lower ran an unsuccessful campaign for Ionia County Clerk. In 2014, Lower accepted a job as the Edmore Village Manager, earning an annual salary of $45,000. He resigned from this job after 18 months when he announced his candidacy for the .\n\nMichigan state representative  was term limited out of the 70th District House seat in 2016. Lower announced his candidacy for the seat in January 2016 and won the 2016 election with 63% of the vote, beating  candidate Ken Hart and  candidate Michael Anderson.\n\nIn December 2018, Lower sponsored a bill during the lame-duck session which would make it harder to get signatures for ballot initiatives. ''The Detroit Free Press'' noted that the bill came \"on the heels of three successful ballot proposals that were overwhelmingly approved by voters... but were opposed by many Republicans.\" The bill would require that a ballot initiative cannot get more than 15 percent of total signatures from any one of Michigan's 14 districts. Lower said that the intention behind the bill was to \"get more transparency in the process and more input from voters.\"\n\nDuring 2019-2020 legislative session, Lower sponsored 15 bills of which only three became law. Lower was the only sponsor of a bill which eased restrictions on sex offenders, eliminating the requirement that they appear in person to update information and eliminating school safety zones which had previously prohibited sex offenders from living within 1,000 feet of a school.\n\nLower lives in  with his wife Kristen and two young children.\n\nIn May 2019, Lower announced that he was challenging independent U.S. Representative  for  in the . He withdrew from the race in November 2019. On December 7, 2020, speaker-designate  announced that he had hired Lower to be a strategic advisor on his staff beginning in January 2021.\n\nDuring the 2020 elections, Mr. Lower drew criticism that he was accepting unlawful payments through a shell company \"Eureka RDC\" in exchange for his endorsement.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Walter H. North''' (January 31, 1933 – October 31, 2014) was a  member of the  from 1995 through 2002. He was also an assistant to  , and comptroller and executive director of the .\n\nNorth was born in Missouri to Robert and Mary North on January 31, 1933. Raised in , North was a standout student and star basketball player in high school. He received a scholarship to , but a hand injury prevented him from playing in college. After three years in the , North returned to WMU and was awarded a business degree. He married Sally, his high school sweetheart, in 1953.\n\nHe made an unsuccessful run for the  in 1964. North then became an assistant to the state treasurer and, in 1966, was appointed comptroller of the . He was named the authority's executive secretary in 1982, a role he held until 1993. While involved with the authority, North helped grow the annual Labor Day Bridge Walk.\n\nNorth was elected to the  in 1994, representing the  for two terms. An advocate for those less fortunate, his accomplishments include new medical clinics on  and  islands, a new  post in St. Ignace, and various projects for the .\n\nNorth's grandfather, , was a circuit court judge in  for 22 years and a justice of the  for 25 years, including four (1929, 1936, 1944, 1952) as chief justice.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Glenn S. Anderson''' (born February 8, 1954) is a politician from the  of . A , he has served on the  since 2016. He was previously member of the  from 2007 to 2015 and the  from 2001 to 2007. In the , Anderson challenged  member  in a , after Conyers lost part of his district to  after the .\n\nAnderson lives in  with his wife Gail, where they have lived for over 37 years.  They have two adult children, Melissa and Kyle, and two grandchildren, Mackenzie and Logan.\n\n\nBefore entering public service, Anderson was employed by  and has been a member of the  since 1972.  He has also been a licensed  since 1979. Prior to his election to the Senate, Anderson represented Michigan's 18th District in the  for six years. Before beginning his tenure in the legislature, Anderson served as Councilman for the City of Westland for nine years.\n\nOver the years Senator Anderson has been active in a number of local organizations, including the Churchill High School PTA, Western Wayne NAACP, Westland Jaycees, Goodfellows, Rouge River Rescue, and Westland Hockey Association. Senator Anderson's focus as a legislator centered on ending bullying in schools, protecting children, strengthening consumer protection and state government transparency and reform of the redistricting process. Anderson was chosen as \"Legislator of the Year\" by the Michigan Association of Chiefs of Police, the Police Officers Association of Michigan, and the Michigan Hemophilia Association. In addition, he has been recognized by numerous other organizations for his legislative work including the Michigan Association of School Psychologists and the Michigan Municipal League.  Anderson is also an alumnus of the National Conference of State Legislature's Bowhay Institute for Legislative Leadership Development and Toll Fellowships.\n\nAnderson was a member of  and the Council of State Governments Great Lakes Caucus throughout his legislative career. In 2014, Senator Anderson was invited by the British Embassy, along with four other state legislators from across the United States, to see first-hand the efforts of the United Kingdom to combat global warming.\n\nAnderson left the State Senate on January 1, 2015, due to term limits.\n\nIn January, 2016, he was sworn-in as a member of the  after the Commission's members voted to appoint him to the 12th district seat which had been vacated by Richard LeBlanc. He was elected to a full term in 2016.     "pages": }\n'''Terri Lynn Land''' (born June 30, 1958) is an American politician who served as the 41st  from 2003 to 2011. A member of the , Land was elected to the  in 2012. She was the Republican nominee for the  race in Michigan, losing in the general election to  . Land currently serves on the Board of Governors of .\n\n\nLand was born in . She grew up in , graduating from Grandville High School, and attended  in , where she received a Bachelor of Arts in political science. In 2009, Land was awarded an honorary doctorate degree from .\n\n\n\n\nIn 1980, Land joined the Grandville Planning Commission. At age 23, Land ran for the , unsuccessfully challenging incumbent Democrat Jelt Sietsema. From 1992 to 2000, she was the elected  of , Michigan's fourth-largest county. In 2000, with Governor 's encouragement, Land ran unsuccessfully for the .\n\n\n\n\nIn , Land became Michigan's 41st , defeating Detroit-based attorney Melvin Hollowell 55%-43%, and took office on January 1, 2003. She and her husband contributed more than $1.9 million of their own money to her 2002 and 2006 Secretary of State campaigns.\n\nThe ''Grand Rapids Press'' editorial board praised Land for her technological transformation of state services, including updates to computer systems; expansion of Web services; consolidation of branch offices and \"expanded hours in new, larger locations\"; and changes that for the first time allowed Michigan customers to pay fees with credit cards and renew license plate registrations through self-service stations. The ''Press'' editorial board wrote that, over the opposition of some Republicans, Land \"advocated measures that would expand participation at the polls, including , no-reason absentee voting and early registration for young voters.\"\n\nIn 2005, Land's office announced an effort to use the  to reduce potential voter fraud by removing names of voters who had died, moved out of Michigan, or changed their names. A '''' investigation found that 33,000 people were removed from the rolls, while Land's office said 11,000 voters were removed. The  (ACLU) took Michigan to court over the removal of voter names. The ''Times'' pointed out that similar problems were seen in other states, as \"Republican and Democratic election officials ... struggled to interpret new federal laws, such as the Help America Vote Act.\" In October 2008, a federal judge ruled that the national  had been violated and six states, including Michigan, were ordered to stop removing names from voter rolls. A spokesperson for Land's office told the ''Detroit Free Press'', \"If you're eligible to vote, you will be able to cast a vote on Election Day\".\n\nIn , Land was reelected, defeating  Clerk , 56%-42%. After serving two terms, the maximum allowed in the state, she was succeeded by Republican .\n\n\n\n\nAfter exploring a bid for Michigan governor in 2010, Land decided not to run in June 2009, instead endorsing . She ran for  on a ticket with Bouchard the following year, but lost in the Republican primary.\n\n\n\nOn June 3, 2013 Land announced her candidacy for the  in . She ran unopposed in the primary and faced Democratic congressman  in the general election.\n\nAccording to an early analysis by the '''', the U.S. Senate election in Michigan was considered one of the top 10 Senate races of 2014. Land outraised Peters throughout the campaign. Her largest independent backer was , which spent $3.6 million in support of her candidacy.\n\nIn 2014, Land gave $3 million to her own campaign, saying, \"You can't ask other people to invest in you if you don't invest in yourself.\" In her federal financial disclosure form, she had not listed any bank accounts or other assets in her control worth that much. Her campaign said that it had mistakenly failed to disclose a joint account she had with her husband. A '''' review of financial disclosure forms showed Land and her husband had assets worth $35 million in 2014, with $1.5 million belonging to Land, and that \"candidates may typically tap liberally into joint accounts with their spouses.\"\n\nIn May 2014, Land gave a speech at the Mackinac Policy Conference, a three-day event that many of the state's top business and civic leaders attend, which she read from notes. Following her speech, Land was swarmed by reporters and, unable to articulate a response to a question, pushed their microphones away, saying, \"I can't do this.\"\n\nLand was endorsed by the entire Michigan Republican delegation, as well as former congressman , and the .\n\nHer campaign was weighed down by various missteps and her reluctance to make public campaign appearances, particularly after the event in May. Peters opened up a consistent lead in the polls beginning in September. The Republican establishment effectively gave up on Land's campaign the following month. In the November 4 general election, Land received 41.3% of the vote to Peters's 54.6%.\n\n\n\nIn September 2020, Land filed a lawsuit against Secretary of State  for allowing votes postmarked before Election Day to be counted after Election Day.\n\n\n\nIn September 2020, the Michigan Republican Party was required by law to withdraw its nomination of Diane Dunaskiss for the  Board of Governors due to Dunaskiss's failure to pay a 2018 campaign fee. In an emergency state committee session, Land replaced Dunaskiss as the party's nominee. On November 3, 2020, Land was elected to an 8-year term on the board of governors.\n\n'''2020 Michigan Fake Electors Case'''\n\nAs revealed by documents from the Federal Government retrieved via a FOIA request, Terri Lynn Land was listed as a fake elector for Donald Trump during the 2020 presidential election, but declined to attend, and was replaced by Ken Thompson.\n\n\nLand married Dan Hibma in 1983. They live in  and have two children. According to financial disclosures, Land and her family have assets worth at least $34 million.\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n()|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Vera Bea Rison''' (February 14, 1939 – August 31, 2015) was a  member of the  from 1997 through 2002.\n\nBorn in , Rison received her high school diploma from the Mott Adult Night School. She worked at Genesee Memorial Hospital from 1969 to 1990, and was elected to the  Board of Commissioners in 1986, serving for ten years. Considered one of the  most fervent champions, Rison was also director of human resources at the Amy Jo Manor housing complex, a member of the Genesee County Community Mental Health board, the Genesee County Substance Abuse Services board, and the Jobs Central Workforce Development board. In 1994, she received the  Civil Rights Human Rights Award.\n\nFor her dedication, the Vera B. Rison Women's Shelter of Hope and Vera Rison Library were named in her honor.\n\nRison became the first House member in recent memory to forgo any committee assignments when she did so in the 1999–2000 session.\n\nDue to  and , Rison became , and later in life she was forced to largely leave the political scene. Rison died August 31, 2015, at her home in .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Paul Scott''' (born 1982) is an American  from . A member of the Michigan State House of Representatives, Scott was recalled on November 8, 2011.\n\n\nScott graduated from Grand Blanc High School in 2000.    He received his bachelor's degree from the , studied in a master's of public policy program at , and received a  degree from the .\n\n\nScott ran for the  State  in 2008.  He first faced off against pilot James B. Swenor and businessman Vince Lorraine in the Republican  and won with 41 percent of the vote.  He then stood against Michael J. Thorp in the general election and defeated him.\n\nAfter one term as State Representative, Scott ran for the Secretary of State nomination in 2010 but lost the nomination at the Republican State Convention to .  In 2010, he won reelection to the  of the Michigan House of Representatives, defeating Art Reyes.\n\nScott was one of roughly 20  elected officials targeted for recall efforts in 2011, primarily by voters and interest groups opposed to changes in state education funding mechanisms, taxation of some retirement income and opposition to .  Voters and the , opposed to Scott's actions as the chair of the House Education Committee, launched a  effort against him. After recall supporters collected enough signatures to put the recall on the November 2011 election  in his district, Scott launched a legal challenge against the recall, but the appeal was denied unanimously by the Michigan Supreme Court.  On November 8, 2011 Scott was recalled.\n\n\n\n\n \n \n \n\n\n \n \n \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Sherry J. Gay-Dagnogo''' (born January 30, 1967) is a current Detroit School Board Member elected citywide and a former  member of the  who represented the . The 8th House District includes portions of Northwest Detroit, including the Bethune, , Castle Rouge, College Park, and  communities. In January 2020, Gay-Dagnogo announced that she was forming a political committee to explore the possibility of running for Mayor of Detroit in 2021.\n\n\nGay-Dagnogo is former Vice President, of the North Rosedale Park Civic Association.\n\nIn 2019, a house owned by Gay-Dagnogo was professionally demolished without her permission and without planning permission. The circumstances surrounding the demolition were initially unclear. Gay-Dagnogo had previously sought quotes from local contractors concerning a potential demolition, but decided to renovate it instead. In October, construction debris from the house were discovered in a landfill in Wayne County, twenty-one miles away from the location of the house. A few days later, the owner of a local trucking company self-identified as the responsible party.\n\n\nAs of 2018, Gay-Dagnogo has not sponsored a bill that has been signed into law.\n\nIncumbent State Rep.  defeated Gay-Dagnogo in the 2012 House District 8 Primary Election for the Michigan House of Representatives. Gay-Dagnogo was re-elected in 2014 and 2016.\n\nIn 2018, Gay-Dagnogo ran for the House of Representatives after  resigned in December 2017 amid allegations of sexual harassment. She later withdrew.\n\nDuring a reception celebrating Black History Month in February 2020, Gay-Dagnogo lobbied President  to grant clemency to . Kilpatrick, former mayor of Detroit, was convicted of extortion, bribery, and conspiracy in 2013 and sentenced to 18 years in prison.\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n*https://www.followthemoney.org/\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

He served as Speaker of the House during the 40th Legislature.\n\nAdams was born in August 1866 to George and Margaret Adams. At age 6, the family moved to a farm in , where he attended school, and again, six years later, the family moved to a farm in . Adams' father was a distant relative of  and . He taught one term of school at age 17, later becoming employed by Hopkins & Lyon in . Adams taught himself in the law and, after moving to  in 1892, was admitted to the bar in 1894.\n\nAdams' re-election in 1898 was not without controversy as he was opposed by Governor  and members of his own political party. His election as Speaker in 1899 was similarly fraught, and described as \"one of the most bitter and determined fights ever witnessed.\"\n\nAdams served as a delegate to the convention which drafted the 1908 .     "pages": }\n'''Timothy Bledsoe''' (born June 18, 1953) is a politician and college professor from the  of . In 2008, he was elected as a  to the , taking office in 2009 and serving until 2012.  He represented the , which was located in  and included the cities of , , , , , , and a small portion of . He previously served as a political science professor at .\n\n\nTimothy Bledsoe was born on June 18, 1953, in . He graduated from Lakeside High School in Lake Village in 1971. He received a B.A. in Political Science from  in 1976. In 1978, he received an M.A. in Political Science from the . He received a Ph.D. in Political Science from the  in 1984.\n\nAfter receiving his Ph.D., Bledsoe began teaching political science at the , where he taught until 1989. In 1989, Bledsoe moved to  and took a job teaching at , where he taught until elected to the State House in 2008. Bledsoe has written several books on the study of urban politics, including ''Careers in City Politics'', and ''Urban Reform and its Consequences''. He is married to Dr. Mary Herring, also a professor at Wayne State. They have one daughter, named Daisy, and are members of Christ Church Grosse Pointe in .\n\n\n\nTim Bledsoe was a precinct organizer for Democratic Presidential Candidate  during the . In 2006, he unsuccessfully challenged sitting State Representative  for his seat in the State House.  Bledsoe ran again for the 1st District in 2008, when term limits required Gaffney to step down. Bledsoe won the 2008 Democratic Primary that also included Harper Woods mayor Kenneth Poynter with nearly 55% of the vote. He faced Republican Mary Treder Lang in the general election. He defeated her with 57% of the vote.\n\n\n*'''2008 election for State House'''\n**Tim Bledsoe (D), 56.78%\n**Mary Treder Lang (R), 43.22%\n*'''2008 Democratic Primary election for State House'''\n**Tim Bledsoe (D), 54.92%\n**Kenneth Poynter (D), 38.12%\n**Edward Ruedemann (D), 3.51%\n**Ronald Diebel (D), 3.46%\n*'''2006 election for State House'''\n**Ed Gaffney (R), 52%\n**Tim Bledsoe (D), 46%\n*'''2006 Democratic Primary election for State House'''\n**Tim Bledsoe (D), 49%\n**Je Donna Dinges (D), 29%\n**William Miller (D), 21%\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

She was a member of the Detroit City Council from 1993 to 2009 and served as a Wayne County Commissioner from 1987 to 1990.\n\nTinsley-Talabi was first elected to the State House in  to the 3rd District and re-elected in  to the  following .\n\nShe has received over 100 National and Local awards received for leadership in the area of Substance Abuse Prevention and Community Service including: United States Office of Drug Czar Presidential Award, National Council on Alcoholism Detroit and Vicinity 2 time award recipient, Scenic America National Award for Beautification State of Michigan House Resolution, and Partnership For a Drug Free Detroit Leadership Award 2 time recipient.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''David Alan Trott''' (born October 16, 1960) is an American attorney and retired politician who served as the  from  from 2015 to 2019. He is a member of the .\n\n\nTrott was born in 1960. He graduated from  in 1978, and obtained a bachelor's degree from the  in 1981. He graduated from the  in 1985, receiving his . Trott was a member of the  Village Council from 1987 to 1988.\n\n\nTrott was the chairman and CEO of Trott & Trott PC, which represents banks and lenders in homeowner foreclosure and bankruptcy litigation. He is the owner of Attorneys Title Agency LLC and its subsidiaries. Trott is also the co-owner of Dietz Trott Sports & Entertainment, and owns Trott Recovery Services. He has served as chairman and CEO of NDeX, and been affiliated with Detroit Legal News Publishing, the U.S. Foreclosure Network, and . Trott's legal career and impact on the community was profiled by the '''' on May 18, 2014.\n\nTrott has served on the boards of the , On My Own, the , The Community House, and the Karmanos Cancer Institute. He is a partner of 23 energy companies. He was a candidate for the  Board of Trustees in 2012.\n\nTrott chaired the  Lincoln Day Dinner, a Republican fundraising event. He was a major donor to the  and the presidential campaigns of  and .\n\n\n]]\n\n\n\n\nOn September 4, 2013, Trott announced his candidacy for , challenging incumbent freshman Congressman . Former Michigan State Senate Majority Leader Mike Bishop, Wayne County Commissioner Laura Cox, former Congressional candidate Rocky Raczkowski, and Republican Committeewoman  were announced as his campaign co-chairs. The Michigan Chamber of Commerce and the  endorsed Trott's campaign, joining more than 350 other individuals and elected officials.\n\nOn May 27 Michigan Information and Research Service published the results of a Republican primary poll for the 11th Congressional District that showed Bentivolio at 33% to Trott's 21%, with a large portion of the district undecided.\n\nTrott enjoyed a significant advantage in resources over his opponent throughout the campaign, with more than $1 million in the bank following the first quarter of 2014 to Bentivolio's $130,000. According to Federal Election Campaign filings, Trott personally contributed over $2,400,000 to his own primary run and outspent the incumbent approximately 20:1. He defeated Bentivolio in the August 5 primary. Bentivolio tried to initiate a write-in campaign for the November general election against Trott and Democrat Bobby McKenzie, but that effort failed.\n\n\n\n\nTrott won reelection with 53% of the vote against Democrat Anil Kumar, who had 40%, Libertarian Jonathan Ray Osment with 3%, and Independent  with 4%.\n\nIn September 2017 Trott announced that he would not run for reelection in .\n\n\n*''''''\n*''''''\n**\n**\n*''''''\n**\n**\n\n\n* \n*\n*\n*\n\n\nTrott supported  programs, supported and introduced gun control legislation, and was supportive of the Supreme Court's decision on same-sex marriage. He was critical during his second term of President Trump's policies on foreign affairs, trade and immigration.\n\n\nTrott supported President 's 2017  to impose a temporary ban on entry to the U.S. to citizens of several Muslim-majority countries, saying, \"Until we can adequately vet these refugees and ensure the safety of all Americans, I support President Trump’s executive order to stay refugees from these terror-prone countries.\"  Trott recently expressed regret during a speech in Northern Michigan that he supported some of President Trump's policies on refugees.\n\n\nOn May 4, 2017, Trott voted in favor of repealing the  (Obamacare) and to pass the . He publicly called Trump \"unhelpful on health care.\"\n\n\n\nOn March 18, 2017, Trott held a town hall meeting. Topics discussed included the repeal and replacement of the  funding for social programs, and whether Trump's tweets were a good strategy. After the town-hall meeting, Trott and his aide, Stu Sandler, were caught on a  stating \"We're going to take that part where they're booing funding for the military and I'm going to get somebody to write a story and we're going to promote the shit out of that\", adding \"It's un-American crap.\" Review of the tape shows that the booing begins after Trott said the American military was \"the weakest it's ever been\" rather than related to military funding.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
