    "pages": }\n'''Gretchen Demarest Driskell''' (born October 1, 1958) is an American politician, , and  from the  of . A member of the , she served in the , representing the . Before her time in the Michigan legislature, she was the first female mayor of , a position she held for 14 years.\n\n\n\n\nDriskell challenged  incumbent  for the 52nd  district (northern and western an Washtenaw County areas outside ) in . She defeated Ouimet, receiving 26,646 votes (52.9%) to his 23,609 (46.8%). In , Driskell defeated Republican nominee John Hochstetler, receiving 20,849 votes (56.2%) to his 16,265 (43.8%).\n\n\n\n\nIn February 2015 Driskell announced that she would challenge Republican incumbent  for . In a March 2015 Inside Michigan Politics/Revsix/Change Media poll, Driskell led Walberg 42%-37% with 21% undecided. In a September 2015 Harper Polling poll, Walberg led Driskell 49%-32% with 20% undecided. Driskell was endorsed by former Republican governor , who also endorsed .\n\nIn the general election, Driskell lost to Walberg, who received 55% of the vote to Driskell's 40%.\n\n\n\nIn December 2017, Driskell announced she would run against Walberg again. She faced a challenge in the Democratic primary from Steve Friday, a progressive grassroots activist from . Driskell won the nomination easily. She lost to Walberg again, 54% to 46%.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  campaign website\n* (archived)\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

He was a member of the , representing the , from 2011 to 2017. He was term limited out in 2017.\n\n\nOutman was born on December 15, 1963, in . He grew up in . Ginster won the Republican nomination, and was in turn defeated in the November 2008 general election by , the first Democrat to hold the seat since 1932. Outman ran again in 2010 and defeated Huckleberry. Outman was elected to two additional terms in the state House, in 2012 and 2014. His campaign manager in 2012 and 2014 was , who  in 2016 was elected to the state House from the 70th district, after Outman was term-limited out.\n\nIn 2012, Outman voted in favor of a \"\" that barred labor unions from collecting fees from workers represented under . Medicaid expansion was supported by almost every Democrat, but Republican members were split, with a little more than half voting no and the rest voting yes. In 2014, Outman voted against a compromise bill to increase Michigan's  to $9.25 an hour by 2018. The bill passed the House on a 76&ndash;34 vote and the Senate on a 24&ndash;12 vote, and was signed into law by Governor .\n\n\nHe was ineligible to run for reelection to the House in 2016 due to , and was hired as a legislative staffer (district liaison) by Republican state Senator  at the end of 2016.     "pages": }\n'''David W. Coulter''' is an American politician serving as the County Executive of ,  since 2019. A member of the , Coulter previously served as the mayor of  from 2011 to 2019, and as a member of the  from 2002 to 2010.\n\n\nCoulter was raised in , and attended St. Joan of Arc Grade School in the city. He graduated from  in . Coulter earned a bachelor's degree from . In 2007, Coulter completed 's  program for Senior Executives in State and Local Government as a  LGBTQ Victory Institute Leadership Fellow. He is openly gay.\n\n\nCoulter has worked as a civil engineering draftsman and school teacher. He was employed for thirteen years by , served as the executive director of the Michigan AIDS Fund  and director of external affairs for the  Foundation.\n\nCoulter was elected to the  in 2002, defeating a 20-year incumbent by 86 votes. He served four terms on the Commission (2002-2010), also serving as Democratic minority leader. He left the seat to run for a  seat in the 14th district in 2010, but lost in the primary to . Coulter was appointed Mayor of  in January 2011 after his predecessor resigned. Coulter was then elected to the two-year position in November 2011. He was re-elected in November 2013, defeating his predecessor and two other challengers. He ran unopposed to win re-election in November 2015 and 2017.\n\nCoulter created the Mayor's Business Council in 2012, helping lead to a period of increased business and economic growth in the city.\n\nIn 2013, Coulter, along with Congressman , undertook a challenge in which they spent less than $4.50 a day on food. They did so to protest cuts to . The following year, Coulter became the first mayor in Michigan to perform same-sex marriages.\n\nOn August 16, 2019, the Oakland County Commission voted to appoint Coulter to serve out the remainder of Oakland County Executive  term as County Executive following Patterson's August 3, 2019 death from pancreatic cancer. Coulter ran for a full term in the position in the November 2020 election, and defeated county treasurer  in the Democratic primary. He then won the November general election over former  Senator Mike Kowall, becoming the first elected Democratic county executive.\n\nCoulter is seeking a second full term as county executive; he will face Republican businessman Nik Gjonaj in the 2024 election.\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nhttps://www.friendsofdavecoulter.com [Dave Coulter website]\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Alexander Joseph Groesbeck''' (November 7, 1873 – March 10, 1953) was an American politician who served as  and the 30th .\n\n\n\nGroesbeck was born in , the son of  Sheriff Louis Groesbeck and his wife Julia (Coquillard) Groesbeck. Groesbeck attended the public schools of , and of , where his parents resided for two years with their family. Groesbeck wanted to become a lawyer from an early age, and undertook the study of law in the office of an attorney at . He went on to earn a  degree from the  at  in 1893. He was admitted to the  that year and set up practice in Detroit where he rapidly gained the \"respect, goodwill and confidence of his colleagues, because of his close conformity to the highest ethical standards of the profession\".\n\n\nGroesbeck's entrance into state politics came in 1912  he led efforts to select a delegation to the  favoring the renomination of  . Groesbeck also actively led the party faction supporting Taft in the . That same year, Groesbeck was elected the , serving until 1914. In 1914, he was a candidate for , but lost in the Republican  to . In 1916, Groesbeck was elected , and was re-elected in 1918.\n\nAs reported in '''', Attorney General Groesbeck supported a call for  to run for the  as a . This vision drew opposiotion from many other Republicans.\n\nIn 1920, he won the Republican primary election for governor and defeated Democrat and former governor  in the . After being re-elected in 1922 and 1924, Groesbeck lost to  in the 1926 Republican primary election.\nIn 1924, he was a delegate to the Republican National Convention, which chose President  to be re-elected. \nIn addition to Groesbeck's political work, he was one of the builders of the Flint-Saginaw  Railway.\n\nAt the , he was instrumental in 1922 in selecting  to be the successful Republican candidate for the  seat left vacant by .\n\nIn 1925, Groesbeck vetoed legislation that would have created a . '''' magazine reported:\nForgetful of the state poets of republican Athens, the Governor's historical knowledge led him to describe the bill as \"a reversion to monarchical customs\" which \"has no place in a republican form of government.\"\nDuring his six years in office, the state's highway growth continued, prison reform measures were sanctioned, state titles for automobiles began, and state government was restructured and consolidated.\n\nHe was defeated in the 1930 Republican primary election by .\n\nGroesbeck is recognized as an important \"road builder\" in Michigan, being the first governor to champion the use of  and \"take Michigan out of the mud.\"\n\nIn 1924, he opposed a ballot initiative (sponsored by the Public School Defense League) to require attendance at  and outlaw ; this placed him at odds with the position of the then increasingly popular , which supported the opposing candidate, James Hamilton.\n\n\n, Detroit]]\nGroesbeck was later appointed chairman of the Michigan , and served from 1941 to 1944. Also in 1944, he was a delegate to the  which nominated for U.S. president, , who would lose to the three-term President  in the general election. He was also a member of the , the  and the , and in club circles was well known as a member of the  and the .\n\nGroesbeck's gubernatorial papers are kept in the Archives of the State of Michigan.\n\nHe died in Detroit and is interred there at .\n\nGroesbeck Highway () was named for the governor, both because of the local prominence of the Groesbeck family in Macomb county and Oakland County and because of his strong support for building roads and highways in Michigan.\n\nHe is memorialized by a state historical marker in the City of Warren.\n\n\n\n\n\n* (East Lansing, Michigan: ) ; .\n*Woodford, Frank B. (1962) ''Alex J. Groesbeck Portrait of a Public Man'' (Detroit: ) 1st Edition. Hardcover. . 366 pp.\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Kevin Elsenheimer''' (born August 21, 1965) is an American judge, lawyer and politician from  and a former minority leader of the . He is the former Director of the Michigan Workers' Compensation Agency and deputy director and Senior Deputy Director of Michigan's Department of Licensing and Regulatory Affairs (LARA). He served in the cabinet of Michigan  as executive director of the Michigan State Housing Development Authority (MSHDA). He was appointed 13th Circuit Court Judge by Governor  in January 2017.\n\n\nElsenheimer was born and raised in . He and his wife live in East Bay Township, outside Traverse City, Michigan. He is the son of former Grand Traverse County Commissioner, the late Arthur C. Elsenheimer.\n\n\nElsenheimer graduated from Traverse City Central High School and then attended Northwestern Michigan College, where he received an Associate of Arts degree. He then earned a Bachelor of Arts degree from Michigan State University in 1987 studying psychology, History and Philosophy. Elsenheimer continued his education at Wayne State University Law School where he obtained his  degree.\n\n\nElsenheimer served as assistant prosecuting attorney for  and as a member of the Bellaire Public Schools Board of Education for a term-and-a-half, from 1998 to 2003. He later stepped down to run for the Michigan Legislature.\n\n\nAntrim County Prosecuting Attorney Charles H. Koop hired Elsenheimer as an assistant prosecutor in 1994. As an assistant prosecuting attorney Elsenheimer handled over 30 jury and non-jury trials. Two years later Elsenheimer formed a law firm with former elected Antrim County Prosecutors James G. Young and Bryan E. Graham. The law firm focuses on representation of municipal entities. At the firm Elsenheimer tried matters in circuit courts throughout Michigan, argued several cases in the Michigan Court of Appeals, and practiced in both the Michigan Supreme Court and US Supreme Court. Elsenheimer lost election to the 86th District Court to Judge Michael Stepka in 2010. On January 18, 2017, he was appointed 13th Circuit Court Judge for Antrim, Grand Traverse and Leelanau counties by Governor Snyder, replacing retired Judge Philip E. Rodgers, Jr..\n\n\nWith the retirement of Rep. Ken Bradstreet due to term limits, Elsenheimer filed to run for  in 2003. He defeated several opponents in the Republican primary, including John Ramsey, the father of the late Jon Benet Ramsey. He was elected to a 2005–06 term in the fall general election defeating Democrat Jim McKimmy 62%-38%, and was re-elected to two additional two-year terms before retiring in 2010 due to term limits.\n\nDuring the 2005–06 term Elsenheimer was elected by the Republican caucus to serve as Associate Speaker Pro Tem. He served as the Assistant Minority Leader during the 2007–08 term, and as Republican Minority Leader during the 2009–10 term. Elsenheimer left Republicans in majority in the Michigan House following the 2010 elections picking up a net of 21 seats for his party.\n\nWhile serving in the majority during the 2005–06 term Elsenheimer had 19 bills signed into law. Notably, working with State Senator Jason Allen, he passed Heidi's law, PA 564 of 2006, which allowed use of prior drunk driving convictions in charging decisions regardless of the number of years that passed since the convictions. The law is named in honor of Heidi Steiner who lost her life to a drunk driver in Antrim County.\n\nElsenheimer also drafted and passed Michigan's Unified Zoning Act, PA 110 of 2006.\n\n\n\nAs Director of the Michigan Workers' Compensation Agency from 2010 to 2015, Elsenheimer oversaw the enactment of sweeping legislative reforms to Michigan's 100-year-old workers compensation statute. The reforms were signed into law by Governor Snyder in 2011. As a result, Michigan has experienced a 39% reduction in pure premium workers compensation insurance costs saving employers an estimated $390 million in premiums since 2011.\n\n\n\nAs Chief Deputy Director and deputy director of Michigan's Department of Licensing and Regulatory Affairs (LARA), Elsenheimer's reports included the Workers' Compensation Agency, the Michigan Liquor Control Commission (MLCC), and the Office of Regulatory Reinvention (ORR), among other administrative entities. During his tenure, the ORR marked the net reduction of over 1500 obsolete, redundant or unenforceable administrative rules.\n\n\n\nElsenheimer was appointed executive director of MSHDA in 2015, and left to take an appointment to the 13th Circuit Court. In 2016 the state housing authority reduced operational expenses by $500,000, lowered personnel costs, coordinated policies which led to a 15% drop in veterans' homelessness in Michigan, and restructured or refinanced almost $780 million in housing debt leading to more than $30 million in gross savings.\n\n\n\nGovernor Rick Snyder appointed Elsenheimer 13th Circuit Judge for Grand Traverse, Antrim and Leelanau counties in January 2017. He ran unopposed and was elected in 2018 and in 2020. The Michigan Supreme Court named him Chief Judge of the 13th Circuit Court, and the Antrim, Grand Traverse, and Leelanau Probate Courts for a term beginning in 2020.\n\n\n\nNorthwestern Michigan College named Elsenheimer an Outstanding Alumnus in 2017. In 2016 he was named Outstanding Public Official by Habitat for Humanity of Michigan. Elsenheimer is a Rodel Fellow with the Aspen Institute, and a BIILD Fellow with the Council for State Governments. He was named outstanding legislator by the Michigan Association of Planners, the Michigan Manufacturers Association, the Michigan Grape/Wine Institute, and the Michigan Chiefs of Police. In 2009 he was named the most effective Republican legislator in the Michigan House by MIRS.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*  profile\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }
  }
}

    "pages": }\n\n'''Deb Cherry''' (born August 19, 1954) is a former  member of the , representing the  until she was elected  treasurer in 2010. Her district included parts of  and  counties. Previously she was a member of the  from 1995 to 2000. Her brother  was the  of Michigan, and her nephew  has been in the Michigan Legislature since 2019.\n\n\nCherry received a Bachelor of Science degree from  and earned a  from .\n\n\nCherry's interest in politics began in high school when she joined a non-partisan student group. She also served on the Genesee County Commission for six years, where she represented the 3rd District, and was Commission Chair for 3 years.     "pages": }\n\n'''Thomas Read''' (May 28, 1881 – April 7, 1962) was a  politician from  who served in the  including as its Speaker during the 50th Legislature, as the  under , as a member of the , and as .\n\nBorn in , of English and Scottish ancestry to Thomas and Jane Read on May 28, 1881, Read was either a candidate for or served in nearly all state-level offices in Michigan (he was never a candidate for or elected ). He was a candidate in the primary for  in 1924, losing to , and 1940, losing to .\n\nRead was a presidential elector for Michigan in 1928, casting a ballot for , and a delegate to the  in  which nominated  (who eventually lost to . Senator  of Michigan was a candidate for the nomination at that convention.\n\nRead died after surgery at a hospital in  in 1962. The elementary school in his hometown of  is named for Read.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Kate Segal''' (born February 16, 1975) was a State Representative for the  (in the  of ), which covers much of  and includes the cities of , Springfield and , and seven townships: Albion, Bedford, Clarence, Convis, Lee, Pennfield, and Sheridan.\n\n\nFor the 2013-2014 session, Segal was selected to serve as the Democratic vice chair of the House Insurance Committee and will also serve on the House committees on Health Policy and Michigan Competitiveness. State Representative Kate Segal |access-date=2013-02-05 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130411035924/http://062.housedems.com/news/article/segal-to-serve-as-democratic-vice-chair-of-house-insurance-committee |archive-date=2013-04-11 |url-status=dead }} Segal was previously the House Democratic Floor Leader for the 2011-2012 .\n\nAs a State Representative, Segal stated that some of her priorities were to focus on making health care more affordable and accessible to all  residents, creating an environment that is inviting to the businesses that will create good-paying jobs for the workers of , and improving schools to provide Michigan students with a quality education from an early age.\n\nPrior to being elected to the , Segal served on the Calhoun County Board of Commissioners from 2002 to 2008, serving as chairwoman in her final term. Segal is deeply involved in the community and has volunteered with a number of groups such as the United Way, the Urban League of Battle Creek, the Comprehensive Senior Care Corporation, the Junior League of Battle Creek and the Region IIIB Area Agency on Aging Advisory Council. She was also a founding member and past chair of the Calhoun County Health Plan, which is now called Community HealthCare Connections.\n\nSegal is a graduate of , where she received a  in , with a concentration in public policy and urban affairs. She lives in  with her husband, Mike, and their daughter, Elise.\n\n\n\n'''2013-2014 Legislative Session''' \n\nInsurance - '''''Democratic Vice Chair'''''\n\nHealth Policy\n\nMichigan Competitiveness\n\n'''2011-2012 Legislative Session'''\n\nAgriculture\n\nHealth Policy\n\nInsurance\n\nHouse Fiscal Agency Governing Board\n\n'''2009-2010 Legislative Session'''\n\nHealth Policy - '''''Vice Chair'''''\n\nInsurance\n\nNew Economy and Quality of Life\n\nUrban Policy\n\nPublic Employees Health Care Reform\n\n\nOn May 21, 2009 the Michigan House of Representatives passed House Bill 4930, a bill sponsored by Segal, which modified Michigan's tax code to create a tax exemption for Duncan Aviation, a Battle Creek company specializing in the interior customization of new aircraft.  Without the modification, Duncan Aviation would have transferred more than one hundred jobs from Battle Creek to its sister facility in Nebraska.  By working closely with Republican Senator Jason Allen, the legislation was signed by Governor  on June 23, 2009 and became Public Act 53 of 2009.  Public Act 53 of 2009 was Segal's first bill to be passed into law.\n\nDuring the 2009 Michigan budget negotiations, Segal made the Michigan Youth ChalleNGe Academy (MYCA) one of her top priorities for future funding.  The MYCA is a voluntary, quasi-military program run by the National Guard.  The program is designed for at-risk youth who have either dropped out of high school or are at risk of dropping out.  Segal advocated for full funding of the program throughout the budget process, but applauded the efforts of the bi-partisan School Aid conference committee for providing partial funding, $642,300, in its compromise budget.  In an effort to save the MYCA, Segal launched an online , hosted a rally at the Capitol, and lobbied her fellow legislators for support.\n\nOn November 25, 2009, the Michigan Youth ChalleNGe Academy announced that it would remain operational through at least 2010.\n\n\n*'''2012 General Election for State Representative - Michigan's 62nd District'''\n\n\n*'''2010 General Election for State Representative - Michigan's 62nd District'''\n\n\n*'''2008 General Election for State Representative - Michigan's 62nd District'''\n\n\n*'''2008 Primary Election for State Representative - Michigan's 62nd District'''\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n\n'''Kathy Angerer''' (born November 16, 1957) is the deputy director of the . She was formerly the City Manager, Director of Community & Economic Development, and Director of Community and Governmental Affairs for the city of  (2013). Prior to that, she was Executive Director of Government Affairs at  Michigan from 2011-2013. From 2005-2010, she served as  State Representative in the , representing the  which covers parts of  and . During her final term ending in 2010, she served as the Majority Floor Leader of the .\n\n\n\nAngerer grew up in , and is a lifelong Monroe County resident. She graduated from St. Mary's Academy in Monroe; attended . and is a graduate of Eastern Michigan University. She has five adult children. Prior to serving as State Representative, Angerer was the Communications Director for the Dundee Community Schools, where she successfully worked with a coalition of parents, teachers, and administrators to pass a millage expanding the size of Dundee High School.\n\nAs a legislator, Representative Angerer was noted to author legislation brought to her by residents of her district. Two such examples include her legislation to fix problems with railroad crossing inspections and to expand the Michigan Promise Grant program. She also authored legislation creating a statewide Patient Safety Organization to which all state hospitals must report adverse effects for the purpose of learning from mistakes and improving patient safety. One of her biggest priorities as a State Representative was legislation requiring insurance companies to cover treatment for children with , which while unsuccessful while she was in office, she continued to be a strong leading advocate towards final passage in 2012.\n\nFor the 95th Session of the Legislature in 2009, Angerer was elected by her colleagues to be the Majority Floor Leader. She had served as the Assistant Floor leader during the previous sessions.\n\nEarly in her service, Angerer was named Legislator of the Year by the Michigan Pharmacists' Association, the Hemophilia Foundation of Michigan, the Michigan Agri-Business Association. She was named as a Public Policy Health Champion in 2008 by the Michigan Department of Community Health.  The Southwest Lake Erie Chapter of Waterfowl U.S.A. named her as Outstanding Sportsperson of the Year for 2009. In 2010, she was named Legislator of the Year by both the Michigan Association of Chiropractors and the Michigan Distributors and Vendors Association.\n\n\nAngerer was elected to the State House in 2004, beating incumbent  . The race was one of the most expensive in Michigan in 2004, with over $500,000 spent between the two candidates and parties. Pundits credited Angerer's win with a strong door-to-door campaign which began in March of that year. Milosch was criticized for making statements against the .\n\n\nAngerer was the lone  running for State Representative in the district. She once again faced Republican Matt Milosh in the general election, and she was reelected. Again, Angerer's win was attributed to aggressive campaigning. She had also developed a strong reputation for delivering good service to her constituents as she visited more than 11,000 resident's homes during the campaign \"off-season\" to become aware of their concerns and help them with any state government-related issues. Angerer bested Milosch in the general election, outspending him nearly three-to-one.\n\n\nAgain, Angerer was unchallenged in the Democratic primary. She beat Republican challenger  in the November election. Moynihan was the surprise winner of the Republican primary, who ran a rather unconventional campaign. He refused to speak directly to the media and maintained a spartan website. As such, this race was seen by pundits to be heavily one-sided and led to Angerer improving on her vote-totals for the third straight election.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nKathy was appointed as the Interim City Manager on July 11, 2017, in a meeting that involved much yelling and disagreement between council members. Her appointment was a point of contention on the Hamtramck Council. On August 7, 2018, in the primary election, a City Charter Amendment was adopted, changing the way the City Manager is appointed. Speculation as to whether this was written to specifically accommodate Angerer or whether it was written to open up the broader City Manager search was unsure.  Artists and residents handed out flyers encouraging voters to vote against the proposal, saying it would give the council too much power to waive eligibility requirements.\n\nOn August 28, 2018 at the regular Hamtramck City Council Meeting, a resolution was brought forth for \"Approval of Appointment of Kathleen Angerer as Hamtramck City Manager\" At 7:48pm, two council members, Andrew Perrotta and Andrea Karpinski, exited the meeting in protest, in order to break quorum. There was no action due to lack of quorum, and Kathy Angerer was not appointed as permanent City Manager.\n\nJust within the Open Meetings' Act Time Frame, public comment and the resolution to appoint Kathy Angerer were added to a Special Meeting Agenda for Friday evening August 31, 2018 at 7 p.m. This happened to be the evening of one of the largest annual festivals in Hamtramck, a holiday weekend, and during famed local \"Queen of Soul\" 's funeral,.\n\nAs summarized by the Metro Times: \"When the majority of the city council turns away from the fresh air and sunshine of public debate, concocts their plans in private, and then uses special meetings, narrowly controlled information, and lock-step voting to push an agenda, this is precisely the environment in which rumors not only flourish, they can’t be effectively quashed.\"\n\nOn November 26, 2019, the Tuesday before Thanksgiving, Kathy Angerer's employment contract was amended by Hamtramck City Council at a regularly scheduled meeting. The legislation proposed, Resolution 2019-110 Resolution to Amend Employment Agreement of Kathleen Angerer, was added to the agenda at the last minute. Changes to the contract include a $5,000 salary raise and severance pay equal to two years of salary (her previous contract included a severance of three months' salary). Councilmembers Karpinski and Perotta questioned why this item was added to the agenda with more than a year remaining in Kathy's previous contract. The resolution passed, with Aye votes from Councilmembers Almasmari, Miah, Musa, Al-Marsoumi, and Mayor Majewski and Nay votes from Councilmembers Perotta and Karpinski.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Kristina Karamo''' (born 1985 or 1986) is an American politician and former poll watcher who served as the  of the  from 2023 to 2024. Karamo was the Republican Party's nominee in the , losing to incumbent   in a landslide. She is commonly seen as being .\n\nKaramo is a staunch proponent of many debunked conspiracy theories, including  that  won Michigan (and the national presidential election) in .\n\n\nKaramo received an associate's degree from . She graduated from  with a bachelor's in communications and media studies. She graduated from  with a master’s degree in .\n\nAs of 2017, she has served as an instructor of Career and Professional Development at . \n\n\nKaramo was a member of the  State Committee. She ran for the 10th district of the  in 2018, which covers the city of , but lost in the Republican primary.\n\n\nKaramo was a poll watcher in the . After  lost the election to , she began repeating Trump's false claims that there had been . She alleged illegal votes were included in the count. She stated in an affidavit that she had \"personally witnessed\" irregularities in vote counting during her time as a poll watcher. After the , she called it a , saying that \"this is completely  posing as Trump supporters...anybody can buy a  hat and put on a t-shirt and buy a Trump flag”.\n\n\nKaramo was the party's nominee in the . She framed her platform as based on family values and religion, including a religious objection to abortion.\n\nTwo weeks before election day, she filed a lawsuit in which she alleged ballot \"mules\" had cast illegal ballots and that there were concerns with voting machines, attempting to throw out s from Detroit.\n\nKaramo lost to incumbent Democrat  by 14 percentage points, the largest margin of defeat for any statewide Republican candidate that year, but she refused to concede the election. Hers was also the worst performance for a Republican Secretary of State nominee since .\n\n\nIn 2023 Karamo was elected to lead the . Karamo was the first Black woman to chair the state party.\n\nIn March 2023, Karamo faced widespread criticism and condemnation for defending a social media post by the Michigan Republican Party which compared recent  bills passed by the legislature to the . Karamo defended the comparison and refused to apologize or take down the post. In a contentious press conference, Karamo argued that people get “way too offended” and said it should not be controversial to \"point to history\". Several prominent Michigan GOP officeholders and officials, the Republican Jewish Coalition, and numerous others have condemned the comparison and Karamo’s defense of the post. \nOn January 6, 2024, the party voted to oust her as chairperson of the Michigan Republican Party after criticism for the lack of fundraising and other financial problems. Karamo has refused to recognize her ouster, claiming the meeting where she was voted out was \"illegal\". The  contradicted Karamo's claims and stated their initial review of the removal indicated that she was \"properly removed\". Karamo was officially replaced on February 14, 2024 by . Kent County judge Joseph Rossi ruled on February 27 that her removal was \"valid.\"\n\n\nKaramo is a resident of  and is a divorced mother of two children. She was married to Adom Karamo; the marriage ended in 2014 with a divorce. In an October 2021 court record first published by '''', her ex-husband Adom Karamo claimed that she had threatened to kill herself and their daughters in a car crash. Karamo denied these allegations, saying they were an attempt by her ex-husband to \"exploit the fact that [she is] a public figure, using it as leverage to change the custody agreement he became dissatisfied with\".\n\nKaramo believes that  is real and may be transferred through sexual relations. She has also said that abortion is  and a  practice,\nthat pop stars such as , , , , and  are tools of  recruiting their followers into , and that  is a ritual to summon demons. Karamo is also a fan of , yet criticized one plot line centered on communicating with deceased ancestors, saying, \"Satan, again, he's so crafty... It is so important to know that you're not communicating with no ancestors. Sweetheart, you're communicating with demons.\"\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Daniel S. Paletko''' (December 21, 1950December 29, 2020) was an American politician who served as mayor of , from 2004 to 2020.\n\n\nPaletko was born on December 21, 1950. Paletko graduated from . Paletko earned a BA from the , an MBA from the , and an MST from .\n\n\nPaletko formerly worked as a  and a financial manager at . Paletko first got involved with politics by attending  city council meetings. Paletko served on the city council from 1974 to 2002. On November 5, 2002, Paletko was elected to the  where he represented the  from January 8, 2003, to 2004. In January 2004, Paletko was appointed as the mayor of Dearborn Heights after the retiring of former mayor Ruth Canfield, and Paletko resigned from the state house to take this position. At the time of his death, Paletko was the city's longest serving mayor.\n\n\nPaletko had two daughters. Paletko was a member of the . Paletko attended and ushered at St. Linus  Church in Dearborn Heights.\n\n\nPaletko died in office from complications of  on December 29, 2020, during the . He was 70 years old. The Dearborn Heights City Council President Denise Malinowski-Maxwell became interim mayor after Paletko's death. Paletko was succeeded by Bill Bazzi, Dearborn Heights' first  mayor. Paletko was interred at  in Dearborn Heights on January 4, 2021.\n\nOn April 29, 2021, Dearborn Heights Mayor Bazzi, along with other city officials, in celebration of , planted an  tree in memorial of Paletko. A plaque erected at the base of the tree is dedicated to Paletko and his tenure as mayor. Police Corporal Carrie Hatten, Fire Marshal Max Mitts and Firefighter Jammal Faraj organized a memorial golf outing for Paletko on June 18, 2021.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Gary N. Click''' (born December 29, 1965) is an American politician, the  state representative from its 88th district. He won the seat in 2020, after incumbent   left it to run for the , defeating  Chris Liebold 62.9% to 37.1%.\n\n\nClick earned a Bachelor of Religious Education from  in 1990. In 2006, Click became a pastor to the Fremont Baptist Temple and has held that position ever since. He has worked in ministry for over 30 years and claims to have served many aspects including youth ministry, bus ministry, writing, radio, Christian education, and lobbying Congress on behalf of churches and Christian schools. He has also served as a chaplain for law enforcement and in hospice care.\n\n\n\nClick opposes abortion. In 2022, Click and seven co-sponsors introduced a bill titled \"The Personhood Act\" which would ban abortion state-wide from the moment of conception. In 2023, Click criticized Ohio's  which would create a constitutional right to abortion in Ohio, calling it \"worse than \".\n\n\nClick opposes LGBT rights. Click also emphasized his view that God provided a specific plan for the family. \n\nClick has called gender-affirming care for minors \"child abuse\". In 2022, Click introduced a bill that would ban gender-affirming care for minors in Ohio. After amendments weakened the bill, he held it up to introduce a stronger bill in the next general assembly. He introduced House Bill 68 in February 2023, which would ban sex change procedures  for minors as well as ban men from competing in women's sports. The bill passed the legislature in December 2023, but was vetoed by Governor . In January 2024, the legislature overrode DeWine's veto thereby making the bill law. However, on April 16, 2024, a judge temporarily blocked the law from taking effect. On August 6, 2024, a judge overturned the injunction and allowed the law to take effect immediately. The plaintiffs immediately announced an appeal.\n\nIn January 2024, in a conversation about trans healthcare with several Republican legislators, Michigan State Rep.  asked, \"If we are going to stop this for anyone under 18, why not apply it for anyone over 18? It’s harmful across the board and that’s something we need to take into consideration in terms of the endgame.\" Michigan State Rep.  and Gary Click did not express agreement with that sentiment.\n\nIn October 2024, Click expressed opposition to a  poll which attempted to measure Ohio voter's support for transgender rights and other political issues. Click objected to the poll using the term \"gender identity\" in the questions, saying that \"There is no such thing as gender identity ... You are either male or you are female.\"\n\n\nClick met and married his wife Nanette while in college. They have four sons, Nathaneil, Zachary, Garrison, and Micah and four grandchildren. Click and his wife reside in Vickery, Ohio.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Aric Nesbitt''' (born January 25, 1980) is an American politician serving as a member of the , representing the , which includes most of , Central , Northern  and  &  in . He serves as the  of the  and previously served as President pro tempore. He received the Distinguished Alumnus of the Year Award from Hillsdale College for being a conservative reformer. He previously represented the  in the  and served as the  Commissioner from 2017 to 2018.  Nesbitt was elected in November 2010 to the , served three terms, and served as the House Majority Floor Leader and chair of the House Committee on Energy & Technology. He is a member of the  and resides south of  with his wife, Trisha, daughter, Catherine, and son, William.\n\n\nNesbitt grew up on a six generation family dairy & grape farm in Porter Township, just south of Lawton in Van Buren County. He is the middle of five children, with two older brothers and two younger sisters. He said this taught him the values of hard work, self-government, and independence. His father served three tours in  and came back home to run the family dairy farm. He served as a page in the  during his junior year of high school and was a delegate to the American Legion Boy's Nation between his junior and senior year of high school.\n\n\nNesbitt graduated from Lawton High School in 1998, the same school as his father and grandfather. During his senior year of high school he was dual enrolled at .  He earned a B.A. in economics from  December 2001 and later earned his master's degree in international business from , NHH.\n\n\n\n*'''2023–Present'''\n**Senate Minority Leader\n**Minority Vice-Chairman, Government Operations Committee\n*'''2019–2022'''\n**Senate President Pro-Tempore\n**Chairman, Regulatory Reform Committee\n**Chairman, Appropriation Subcommittee on Licensing & Regulatory Affairs and Insurance & Financial Services\n**Chairman, Advice & Consent Committee\n**Vice-chairman, Finance Committee\n**Vice-chairman, Joint Select Committee on the COVID-19 Pandemic\n**Member, Appropriations Committee\n**Member, Government Operations Committee\n**Member, Energy & Technology Committee\n**Member, Insurance & Banking Committee\n*'''2015–2016'''\n**House Majority Floor Leader\n**Chairman, Energy Committee\n**Member, Elections Committee\n**Chairman, Michigan House Republican Campaign Committee\n*'''2013–2014'''\n**Chairman, Energy and Technology Committee\n**Member, Commerce Committee\n**Member, Tax Policy Committee\n**Member, Insurance Committee\n**Chairman, Michigan House Republican Campaign Committee\n*'''2011–2012'''\n**Vice Chair, Government Operations Committee\n**Member, Energy and Technology Committee\n***Chairman, Subcommittee on Natural Gas\n**Member, Tax Policy Committee\n**Member, Education Policy Committee\n\n\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Warren Cleage Evans''' (born December 30, 1948) is an American law enforcement official, lawyer, and politician serving as the  of  since 2015. Evans is a member of the . Evans served as Wayne County Sheriff from 2003 to 2009 and the chief of the  from 2009 to 2010. He was an unsuccessful candidate in the .\n\n\nEvans began his career in law enforcement as a deputy with the  in 1970. Evans rose through the ranks of the department, serving as Undersheriff, the department's second-in-command officer from 1987 through 1991. Evans became the director of administration for the Wayne County Board of Commissioners in 1991 and created the Wayne County Department of Community Justice and served as its director from 1992 to 1997. He rejoined county government in 2001 as chief of Special Operations for the Wayne County Prosecutor's Office in 2001 and was named sheriff in 2003 and was elected to full terms in 2004 and 2008.\n\n\nOn July 6, 2009, Evans was named as the 39th Chief of Police of the  by  , replacing James Barren, who Bing had fired the previous Friday.\n\nEvans was asked to resign by Bing just over a year into his tenure in July 2010. Bing did not give specifics why he asked Evans to resign but said \"a combination of things\" were met with disapproval, and the department was \"compromised in some of the decisions he made.\" Speculation over Evans' desire to be a reality TV star and a relationship he had with a subordinate in the department contributed to his removal.\n\n\nEvans ran for mayor of Detroit in  caused by the resignation of  in September 2008. Evans came in fourth in the primary, taking just over 10 percent of the vote, Bing and then-interim Mayor  advanced to the general special election in May.\n\nEvans announced in April 2014 that he was going to seek the Democratic nomination for Wayne County Executive, challenging 3-term incumbent . Evans easily won the Democratic primary in August 2014, taking 46 percent of the vote in a ten-person field. Evans defeated Republican nominee John Dalton in the general election.\n\nAfter running unopposed in the Democratic Primary, Evans defeated Republican challenger Denis Curran to win a second-term as County Executive in November 2018.\n\nWarren C. Evans most notable accomplishment during his career was his ability to turn a 52 million deficit into a 121 million dollar surplus within 4 years. \n\nDuring his second term (2022), Detroit Metropolitan Airport Authority voted unanimously to name a terminal after him. (Warren C. Evans Terminal)\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Sarah Roberts''' (born December 9, 1974) is an American politician from the state of .  Since 2009, she has served in the . A , Roberts represents the , which is located in eastern  and includes the city of  and , as well as the small portion of  that is located within Macomb County. Prior to being elected in 2008, Roberts represented Northern St. Clair Shores in the Macomb County Commission.\n\n\n\nSarah Roberts was born on December 9, 1974, in Michigan to Helen and Charles Roberts. She graduated from the , receiving her bachelor's degree in 2000. She served as a community organizer for  of Macomb County from 2003 to 2005. She worked in the communications department of the House Democratic Caucus in the Michigan State House of Representatives from 2005 to 2006 before being elected to the Macomb County Board of Commissioners.\n\n\nIn 2006, Roberts announced her candidacy for the Macomb County Commission.  She ran for the 24th District, located in Northern St. Clair Shores. The 24th district, which leans Democratic, was being vacated by Democrat Peggy Kennard. Roberts defeated Republican Richard Doan by a large margin.  She served on the commission for two years before being elected to the State House of Representatives.\n\nIn January 2008, Roberts filed to run as a Democrat for the 24th State House District, which was being vacated by Republican , who was barred from running for re-election due to term limits. She faced seven other Democrats in the primary election, but still carried 63% of the vote. The 24th District is a narrow district that runs north-to-south along . It includes the city of , , and a small portion of , and is normally a battleground district, although it historically favored Democrats (prior to Jack Brandenburg, the seat had been held by a Democrat going back to the 1970s). In the general election, Roberts faced Republican Bryan Brandenburg, an unsuccessful candidate for Macomb County Commission and son of then-current Representative Jack Brandenburg.\n\nThe race for the 24th District was one of the most competitive in Michigan. The state Democratic Party alone invested over $220,000 in the race, an unusually high number for a state house race. The race featured a large amount of negative campaigning, including adds that raised questions about four incidents involving Brandenburg in which the police investigated but no charges were filed, including an assault accusation at a party. On election day, Roberts emerged narrowly victorious by just over 1,000 votes, or about 2%. President Obama carried the 24th District by a similarly narrow 51.5%-46.4% margin.\n\nRoberts took office on January 1, 2009. She sits on the Education, Energy and Technology, Great Lakes and Environment, and Military, Vet. Affairs, and Homeland Security Committees.\n\n\n*'''2008 campaign for State House'''\n**Sarah Roberts (D), 49.4%\n**Bryan Brandenburg (R), 47.1%\n*'''2006 campaign for Macomb County Commission'''\n**Sarah Roberts (D), 59.2%\n**Richard A. Doan (R), 39.2%\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Michael Lahti''' (born 1945) is a politician from the State of . A , Lahti served in the  representing the , which is located in the  and includes all of , , , , ,  and  in .\n\n\nLahti was born in  on October 10, 1945 and graduated from Hancock High School. He graduated from  in 1967. A year after he graduated, Lahti opened a  agency in Hancock. Lahti was a small business owner and real-estate developer, owning private and commercial lands all across the .  Lahti lives in Hancock with his wife, Sharon Lahti.  He has six children, 15 grandchildren and 1 great-grandson.\n\n\nLahti was elected to the Hancock area School Board in 1994, where he served for seven years.  Also in 1994, he was appointed to the  board of trustees, where he served for 13 years.  In 2000, Lahti was elected to the Houghton County Commission as a Democrat.  He served as chairman of the Commission for 6 years.  In 2006 he announced his intention to run for the State House seat District 110, being vacated by Democrat Rich Brown.  The 110th District is located in the western portion of the  and is one of the largest in the state.  Lahti easily won the Democratic Primary, and went on to face Republican Dave Schmidt in the General Election.  He won 64% to 34%.  He was easily re-elected in 2008 with 70% of the vote.\n\nIn 2010 Lahti ran for the  in the 38th district, which includes the western Upper Peninsula. Lahti lost to former state representative Tom Casperson.\n\n\n\nSince leaving the House in 2011, Lahti has returned to the real estate profession. He has also been re-appointed to the Board of Trustees of Finlandia University.\n\n\n*'''2010 election for State Senate'''\n**Tom Casperson (R), 56%\n**Mike Lahti (D), 44%\n*'''2008 election for State House'''\n**Mike Lahti (D), 70%\n**John Larson (R), 30%\n*'''2006 election for State House'''\n**Mike Lahti (D), 64%\n**Dave Schmidt (R), 34%\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Adam Frederick Zemke''' (born June 4, 1983) is a former member of the . He represented  in  from 2013 to 2018.\n\n\nZemke was born and raised in . His parents, Debra Lehto and Frederick Zemke, divorced when he was a toddler. He spent much of his childhood in , attending Haisley Elementary, Forsythe Middle and Pioneer High schools in the  district. He also attended  in New Jersey while his then-stepfather, Dr. Trevor Wooley, worked at the  in . Adam has one brother, Cameron Wooley, and a sister, Michelle Zemke&mdash;both younger.\n\nAfter high school, Zemke enrolled in and attended , studying  and obtaining undergraduate and master's degrees in this field. In spring 2005, Zemke served as the commencement speaker for his graduating class of the .\n\n\nZemke's family has deep roots in Washtenaw County. His father's family first emigrated to Ann Arbor and settled on Spring street in the early 1890s. They are of German ancestry. While in Ann Arbor, Zemke's great grandfather owned and operated The Orient, a well-known \"\" pool hall and barber shop on the corner of North Main and Ann streets. \n\nIn 1935, his grandfather Frederick \"Fritz\" Zemke left the  to start a business out of his parents' Spring Street garage, operating vending machines and jukeboxes in local establishments. This business, called Zemke Operated Machines, is run by Zemke's father and has remained in continuous operation to this day.\n\n\n\n\nWhile in college, Zemke was a member of the  team, something that he frequently discusses as being impactful to his educational experience. He participated in this program and was involved in the design, build, test and racing of the 2005, 2006, 2007 and 2008 vehicles. He served as project manager for the 2006 and 2008 vehicles, the latter of which placed 4th at the Formula SAE West competition in Fontana, CA.  At the 2006 Fontana competition, Zemke made a connection with  that led to Mr. Leno inviting the MSU Formula SAE Team to his Big Dog Garage in Burbank, CA for an exposé on the Formula SAE competition. Zemke remains a strong supporter of Formula SAE, serving as Presentation Event Captain and a member of the organizing committee for the competition held annually in Michigan. He also served on the board of trustees for the SAE Foundation, helping to encourage STEAM educational experiences for pre-K through high school students in classrooms all over the country.\n\n\n\nFollowing the completion of his master's degree, Zemke joined Demmer Corporation as a project lead engineer in their machining division. He worked on projects predominantly in the defense and commercial aerospace industries. A year after joining the company, Zemke was promoted to Program Manager, where he was one of two engineers tasked with helping to grow Demmer Corporation's presence in the private plane and commercial aerospace markets.\n\nDuring a company trip to Wichita, Kansas, Zemke and his colleague visited a factory where production had slowed significantly during the recession. Upon asking what contributing factors were to the production decline, workers discussed that following the media coverage of the automotive hearings in the United States Senate where CEOs who flew on private planes were chastised by senators, many corporations cancelled their private plane orders.\n\n\n\n\n\nAfter a failed run for the Washtenaw County Board of Commissioners in 2010, Zemke ran for the 55th district in the Michigan House of Representatives in 2012  a seat that was held by Republican   who declined to run due to changes in the district boundaries following the 2011 reapportionment. Zemke faced  Trustee Andrea Brown-Harrison in the Democratic primary election, where he won with 62% of the vote. He then faced Republican former Milan Mayor Owen Diaz in the general election where Zemke won the election with 64% of the vote. He was re-elected in 2014 and 2016, serving until he was term limited. Zemke won the election with over 69% of the vote.\n\n\n\nIn 2015, Michigan Democratic Leader  selected Zemke and  to serve as chairpersons for the 2016 House Democratic campaign team and Representative  (D-Lansing) as chairperson of the 2016 House Democratic finance team. Representative Faris later resigned from her position. In his role as campaign chairperson, Zemke drove his 1998   approximately 30,000 miles around the state helping Democratic candidates campaign for the .\n\n\n\nAt the start of the 99th (2017–18) Michigan legislature, Zemke ran for election to become Chair of the House Democratic Caucus for the two-year term that comprises the 99th session of the Michigan House of Representatives. He won this election on January 12, 2017 and began the position immediately.\n\n\n\nIn 2021, Zemke was appointed as chair of Ann Arbor's Council of the Commons, an advisory body to the city council tasked with implementing a 2018 change to the city charter to develop the roof of an underground parking structure as a park rather than the previously planned housing development. Other initial members included  and .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

He is a former member of the , first elected in  and re-elected to a second term in  and a third term in . He graduated from  in 1999 before attending , from which he graduated in 2005 after studying  and . He is a  who also has been a . He lives in , in the state's Upper Peninsula.Tim Alberta, , ''The Atlantic'' (June 30, 2021).\n\n\nMcBroom was formerly a member of the  . From January 2011 to 2016, McBroom was a member of the ; he was not eligible to seek reelection due to . In 2015, McBroom was the chairman of the special House committee that considered disciplinary proceedings against state Representatives  and .,  (CBS News)/Associated Press  (September 11, 2015). Gamrat, along with a majority of the special committee, recommended the expulsion of both members. Gamrat was expelled, while Courser resigned after it became clear that the chamber had the votes to expel him.\n\nMcBroom was elected to the  in November 2018, with 54.4% of the vote, defeating Democratic nominee .Jonathan Oosting, ,  ''Detroit News'' (February 15, 2019). He took office in January 2019. McBroom succeeded term-limited incumbent Republican . Immediately upon taking office, he hired Casperson as his constituent relations and .Jonathan Oosting, ,  ''Detroit News'' (February 15, 2019). Casperson died in 2020.\n\n\nIn the ,  defeated , and  by more than 150,000 votes. Trump sought to , in part by falsely claiming that he won Michigan.Allan Smith, , NBC News (March 20, 2024). Trump's lies was rejected by multiple courts and by the . As chair of the Senate Oversight Committee, McBroom led an exhaustive investigation into the 2020 election in Michigan. In June 2021, after an eight-month investigation, his committee issued a final report debunking Trump's claim of a \"stolen\" election. Regarding the , McBroom told the , \"They were wrong. And other people followed them when they shouldn't have.\" However, McBroom refused to comply with a subpoena issued by the , saying that he had no relevant information and viewed the subpoena as an infringement of Michigan's sovereignty.Ben Orner, , ''Mlive'' (June 17, 2022). The Michigan committee's report was, however, entered into the January 6 Committee's formal record. Trump disparaged McBroom for failing to support his false election claims. Nevertheless, McBroom endorsed .\n\n\nMcBroom has called for rolling back environmental regulations. In 2022, McBroom introduced a resolution opposing proposals to designate four areas within the  (the Ehlco area, Trap Hills, Norwich Plains, and ) as s. An opponent of federal protections for the , McBroom denounced a 2022 decision by federal judge who determined that the  had violated the  by removing protections for wolf populations in the  and parts of the West without adequate grounds. McBroom also opposed the 's proposal to add some lands on the decommissioned , near the , to the , saying that he believed that listing on the register could halt the  project, which McBroom supports.Sarah Cwiek, , Michigan Public (September 29, 2022).\n\nIn 2023, McBroom signed a letter in support of the proposal to build the  oil pipeline tunnel under the .  The same year, McBroom voted against a clean-energy and  bill that created a  (with a requirement to achieve 50% by 2030&ndash;2034 and 80% by 2035). The bill passed the state Senate on a 20&ndash;18 party-line vote.\n\n\nIn 2023, McBroom voted against legislation to expand the  to protect against discrimination in housing, employment, and public accommodations on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity; in a floor speech against the bill, McBroom contended that it would \"create impossible-to-resolve conflicts for churches, individuals, employers and employees.\"\n\nIn 2020, McBroom sponsored legislation that allowed most one-time  offenders to obtain  of their criminal record from a judge. The bill passed both chambers by wide margins; in January 2021, Governor  ed the legislation.\n\n\nMcBroom is married and has children. He is a . He plays the  and directs the Norway City Band.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Frank Foster''' is a  politician from the  of . He was a member of the , representing the . Foster was elected in 2010 and 2012, but was defeated in the 2014 Republican primary.\n\n\nIn his first election and attempt at running for office, Foster faced a primary challenge from Mackinac County Commissioner Mike Patrick, and won with a 61-49% margin. In the general election, Foster faced Democrat Dick Timmer, a Chippewa County Commission, and won with a 63-47% margin.\n\nIn his 2012 re-election campaign, Foster did not have a primary opponent. In the general election, he faced Democratic challenger Suzanne Shumway, and won with a 58-42% margin.\n\nIn 2014, Foster lost his primary against a Tea Party challenger, . 54–46.\n\n\nFoster served his first term as Chairman of the House Natural Resources, Tourism, and Outdoor Recreation Committee, and also served on the Tax Policy Committee and Banking and Financial Services Committee. Foster is serving his second term as Chairman of the House Commerce Committee, and is also serving on the Tax Policy Committee, Health Policy Committee, and Michigan Competitiveness Committee.\n\nServing with a Republican legislature and Governor, Foster has voted on successful legislation to make Michigan a right-to-work state, repeal the  and replace it with the Corporate Income Tax, and eliminate the pension tax exemption for state employees, and has made drastic reforms to the state's K-12 education system, including eliminating the cap on charter schools and instituting a controversial teacher merit-pay compensation system. Foster has also championed the expansion of the state's promotional advertising campaign, \"\".\n\n\nFoster is a graduate of Petoskey High School in Petoskey, Michigan. Foster earned a bachelor's degree in business and finance from .\n\n\nIn May 2012, it was reported that Representative Foster called a female member of the Michigan Nurses Association the \"C-word\" after a dispute over a lawnmower in downtown Lansing. Foster denied the accusations, and it was later reported that the woman had been intentionally trying to antagonize the gathering that Foster was attending.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Steven Marion Bieda''' (born January 21, 1961) is an American politician and member of the Democratic Party who is the former Assistant Democratic Floor Leader of the .\n\nBieda has served in the Michigan Senate since 2011, representing the , which includes the communities of , , , , , and portions of  and .\n\nIn December 2017, Bieda announced he would seek election to the  in 2018, representing . He ultimately lost the nomination to now incumbent representative . In February 2023 Bieda was appointed by Governor  to the 37th District Court in Warren, Michigan.\n\n\nBieda was raised in , and attended .\n\nHe received his bachelor's degree and  from , and later earned a  from the  as well as a  in taxation from .\n\nBefore seeking public office, Bieda worked as the Director of Labor Relations for the , and as a Senior Policy Analyst for the .\n\n\nIn 2002, Bieda was elected to the  for the .\n\nHis first term as State Representative, Bieda voted against a 2004 measure banning same-sex marriage in Michigan, which caused pundits to rank him as one of the three most vulnerable members of the House.\n\nHe went on to be re-elected in 2004 and 2006.\n\n\nBieda was elected to the  in November 2010, and was re-elected in November 2014.\n\nBieda has sponsored and passed more than 50 bills and public acts, in addition to co-sponsoring hundreds of others, as he's served in both the majority and minority during his tenure.\n\nIn Lansing, Bieda is known as a \"policy wonk\" and is noted to have \"an ability to work with Republicans in the legislature; he finally got them to pass a law to pay compensation to innocent people who were wrongly convicted and imprisoned.\"\n\nGovernor Whitmer appointed Mr. Bieda as Chairman of the Michigan Tax Tribunal within the Department of Licensing and Regulatory Affairs.\n\n\n\nBieda designed the reverse side of the U.S. Olympic Half Dollar that was issued in 1992. His design is an image of the Olympic torch and an olive branch. The inscriptions above and below read \"United States of America\" and \"Half Dollar\". A central inscription reads \"Citius Altius Fortius\" which is Latin for \"Faster, Higher, Stronger\".\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''George Cushingberry Jr.''' (born January 6, 1953) is an American politician from Michigan. Cushingberry was a member of the  and a member of .\n\n\nOn January 6, 1953, Cushingberry was born in Detroit,  Michigan. Cushingberry's father was George Cushingberry. Cushingberry's mother was Edna Cushingberry. In 1971, Cushingberry graduated from Detroit Cass Technical High School.\n\n\nCushingberry earned a bachelor's degree and a master's degree in Political Science, Urban Politics, Policy, and Administration from Wayne State University. In 1991 he earned his  from the .\n\n\nElected in 1975, Cushingberry became the youngest person to serve in the Michigan State House, where he served until 1982. After leaving the House, he became a member of the Wayne County Board of Commissioners, where he served for sixteen years.\n\nOn November 2, 2004, Cushingberry won the election and became a Democratic member of Michigan House of Representatives for . Cushingberry defeated Melvin E. Byrd with 95.69% of the votes. On November \n7, 2006, as an incumbent, Cushingberry won the election and continued serving District 8. Cushingberry defeated Melvin E. Byrd and Daniel L. Martin with 96.59% of the votes. On November 4, 2008, as an incumbent, Cushingberry won the election and continued serving District 8. Cushingberry defeated Thomas W. Jones with 96.90% of the votes.\n\n\nAfter being elected Cushingberry was appointed the Chairman of the Appropriations Committee until 2010.  After an unsuccessful run for State Senator, Cushingberry ran for City Council representing District 2 in Northwest Detroit winning by over 50% of the districts voters. Cushingberry was elected President Pro-Tempore of the City Council in 2014 and appointed Chairman of the Budget, Finance and, Audit Committee.\n\nCushingberry is an associate pastor at Northwest Unity Baptist Church in Detroit. He is a life member of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP), and hosts the  \"Northwest Unity Prospector Reveals\", on radio station WDRJ 1440 AM, Detroit MI from 2:30 - 3:30 every Saturday.  He is also a practicing Attorney in the following areas family law, commercial litigation(Business Law), bankruptcy, criminal defense and, owner of The Law Firm of George Cushingberry and Associates.\n\n\nCushingberry's wife is Maria Hazel Drew Cushingberry. They have two children.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Virgil K Smith''' (born December 18, 1979) is a  former member of the Michigan House of Representatives and . Smith previously represented the , which is composed of , ,  and the north side of . From 2003 to 2008, Smith represented State House district 7, comprising the northern tier of Detroit.\n\n\nSmith is the son of  of retired Chief Judge and former Michigan State Senator . In 2000, he was arrested for possessing alcohol whilst underage.\n\nIn 2004, Smith's license was revoked after facing two different alcohol-related offenses. It was reinstated in 2008. In 2010, he was pulled over on allegations he had been driving under the influence, but was not charged.\n\nOn May 6, 2009, Smith married Anistia Thomas. Smith filed for divorce in July 2009 and Thomas counter-sued for an annulment. Smith consented and it was granted on October 6, 2009. In May, 2015, Smith was charged with felonious assault, domestic violence, malicious destruction of property and felony firearm charges after he shot Thomas's car. Thomas was granted a  against Smith as a result of the incident. In 2016, Smith plead guilty to the malicious destruction of personal property, a felony, and was sentenced to ten months in prison.\n\n\nSmith did his undergraduate studies at  earning a degree in political science.  He received his master's degree in public administration from .\n\n\n\n\nSmith won the Democratic primary in 2002 against former state senator .\n\n\nIn 2010 Smith was elected to the , winning against. . He ran again in 2016 again , and was re-elected. In 2015, Smith pled guilty to malicious destruction of personal property after he shot at his ex-wife's car and resigned from his seat in the senate. The plea deal initially required Smith to resign senate seat and not run for public office for five years, but the county circuit overseeing the case judged that such a clause would violate the state constitution.\n\nSmith ran for the Detroit City Council in 2017. The Wayne County prosecutor appealed the ruling vacating part of his plea deal, but the appeal was dismissed in April 2017. Smith finished second in the August primary, where he faced Roy McCalister Jr. on the general election ballot. Smith went on to lose the general election to McCalister.\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Garlin Gilchrist II''' (born September 25, 1982) is an American politician and engineer serving as the 64th  since 2019. He is a member of the .\n\n\nGilchrist was born in . In 1982, his family moved to . His mother worked at  for 32 years, and his father worked in defense contract management for the . \n\nGilchrist earned a  with majors in  and  from the  in 2005.\n\n\n\n\n\nGilchrist moved to  and worked for  for four years, as a , where he helped build . Next, Gilchrist worked as a community organizer and director of new media for the Center for Community Change, now known as . Later, Gilchrist worked for  in , as national campaign director.\n\nIn July 2014, Gilchrist moved back to Detroit, working for the city government under  Beth Niblock as the director of innovation and emerging technology.  He created the Improve Detroit smartphone app that allows residents to report issues for the city to address. He served as founding executive director of the Center for Social Media Responsibility, within the , from the .\n\nIn 2017, Gilchrist ran for Detroit  against  Janice Winfrey. He lost by 1,482 votes.\n\nGilchrist was selected as a Community Change Champion in Community Organizing in 2019 for his work to advance social and racial justice in the United States.  at Detroit Metropolitan Wayne County Airport in November 2021]]\n\n\n selected Gilchrist as her  in the . The pair defeated the  ticket of  and . With Whitmer's victory, Gilchrist became the first African American to serve as the lieutenant governor of Michigan, as well as the first born in the 1980s. He took office on January 1, 2019.\n\nGilchrist was named a vice-chair of the . \n\nOn November 8, 2022, Whitmer and Gilchrist were re-elected by a wide margin in , defeating the Republican ticket of  and .\n\n\nOn April 9, 2020, Whitmer named Gilchrist as the chair of a statewide taskforce examining  in the . Gilchrist, later, claimed victory in reducing the racial disparities in COVID-19 deaths. According to a March 2021 study from the Duke-Margolis Center for Health Policy and the National Governors Association Center for Best Practices, the Michigan Coronavirus Racial Disparities Task Force “paved the way” for tacking racial inequities and reduced  of COVID-19 cases and mortality among Black residents. According to the study, the task force helped reduce the average number of cases for Black residents “dropped from 176 per million population per day in March 2020 to 59 per million population per day in October 2020.”\n\n\nGilchrist served as cochair of the Michigan Joint Task Force on Jail and Pretrial Incarceration, a bipartisan working group of officeholders, law enforcement officials, and stakeholders assembled by Governor Whitmer, in 2019, to examine the growing jail populations, which had tripled in 30 years, despite historically low crime rates. The group held over a dozen meetings with the public and stakeholders across Michigan in “one of the state's largest bipartisan collaborations on criminal justice reform to date.” The task force issued a final report with 18 recommendations, many of which were included a large package of dozens of bipartisan criminal justice reform bills passed and signed in to law by Governor Whitmer in January 2021.  \n\nThe “historic” bipartisan package was dubbed “a model for state-level policy change affecting local jail populations” by Pew Charitable Trusts. \n\nRepublican leaders of both legislative chambers praised the bipartisan package as an example of \"putting people before politics\" and \"thoughtful and purposeful policies built on the consensus and compromise of a diverse group of stakeholders.\" The legislation was aimed at protecting public safety, while helping thousands avoid arrest and incarceration for low-level nonviolent offenses. The bipartisan package included bills to:\n\n* Eliminate license suspensions for violations unrelated to dangerous driving\n* Classify traffic misdemeanors as civil violations \n* Provide discretion to officers to issue tickets, instead of making arrests for many misdemeanors\n* Limit occupational licensing boards’ consideration of applicants’ previous low-level offenses\n* Seal juvenile records from public view and create a process to automatically expunge juvenile records for those who don’t commit future offenses\n* Limit the use of warrants for first time failure to appear for low level criminal violations\n* Eliminate mandatory minimum prison sentences for violations of driving, environmental and public health state codes\n\n\nGilchrist and his wife have three children.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n|party=Democratic Party (United States)|votes=2,430,505|percentage=54.47%|change=+1.16%}}\n|party=Republican Party (United States)|votes=1,960,635|percentage=43.94%|change=+0.19%}}\n|party=Libertarian Party (United States)|votes=38,800|percentage=0.87%|change=-0.46%}}\n|party=Constitution Party (United States)|votes=16,246|percentage=0.36%|change=-0.33%}}\n|party=Green Party (United States)|votes=10,766|percentage=0.24%|change=-0.44%}}\n|party=Natural Law Party (United States)|votes=4,973|percentage=0.11%|change=-0.13%}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Gerhard Mennen \"Soapy\" Williams''' (February 23, 1911&nbsp;– February 2, 1988) was an American politician who served as the 41st , elected in 1948 and serving six two-year terms in office. He later served as  under presidents  and  and as chief justice of the .\n\nWilliams advocated for civil rights, racial equality, and justice for the poor. As assistant secretary of state, his remark that \"what we want for the Africans is what they want for themselves\", reported in the press as \"Africa for the Africans\", sparked controversy at the time.\n\nA staunch liberal, Williams was described by the '''' as a political reformer who \"helped forge the alliance between Democrats, blacks and union voters in the late 1940s that began a strong  tradition in Michigan.\"\n\n\nWilliams was born in , Michigan, to Henry P. Williams and Elma Mennen. His mother came from a prominent family; her father, Gerhard Heinrich Mennen, was the founder of the  brand of men's personal care products. Because of this, Williams acquired the popular nickname \"Soapy\".\n\nWilliams attended the  in Connecticut, an exclusive  . He graduated from  with an A.B. in history in 1933 after completing a senior thesis titled \"Social Significance of Henry Ford\". At Princeton, Williams was a member of the . He then received a  degree from the . While at law school, Williams became affiliated with the , departing from his family's strong ties to the .\n\nWilliams met Nancy Quirk on a blind date while attending the university. She was the daughter of D.&nbsp;L. Quirk and Julia (Trowbridge) Quirk, a prominent  family involved in banking and paper milling. Her brother, Daniel Quirk, was later mayor of Ypsilanti. The couple married in 1937 and had three children; a son, G. Mennen Williams Jr., and two daughters, Nancy Ketterer III and Wendy Stock Williams.\n\nHe worked with the law firm Griffiths, Williams and Griffiths from 1936 to 1941. Law firm partners included Hicks Griffiths and , later elected a member of Congress and lieutenant  governor of Michigan.\n\nDuring World War II, he served four years in the  as an air combat intelligence officer in the . He achieved the rank of  and earned ten . He later served as the deputy director of the  from 1946 to 1947, and was named to the  in 1947.\n\n\n in , October 1, 1959]]\nOn November 2, 1948, Williams was elected governor of Michigan, defeating Governor  with the support of labor unions and dissident Republicans. He was elected to a record six two-year terms in that post.  served three four-year terms, 1991–2003, equaling Williams's 12-year tenure. Both are surpassed by , who served from 1969 to 1983, just short of 14&nbsp;years.|group=lower-alpha}} Among his accomplishments was the construction of the . He appeared on the cover of '''' September 15, 1952, issue, sporting his signature green bow tie with white polka dots.\n\nWilliams believed the  was underfunded and outdated, and that the state's prisons were dangerously overcrowded. While visiting  in July 1950, Williams  by a group of three inmates hoping to escape. The governor had a knife held to his throat, but his attackers were soon overpowered by his bodyguard and prison employees. One of his attackers was shot dead. Williams was unharmed and mostly unshaken, choosing to continue on with his tour of the . He used the attack to his political advantage, blaming it on budget cuts made by the -controlled . Later in the same year, Williams gained prominence for his refusal to extradite , one of the , who had escaped from prison in Alabama in 1948 and hidden in Detroit for two years.\n\nAlso during Williams's 12&nbsp;years in office, a farm-marketing program was sanctioned, teachers' salaries, school facilities and educational programs were improved and there were also commissions formed to research problems related to aging, sex offenders and adolescent behavior.\n\nWilliams named the first woman judge in the state's history as well as the first black judge. As a delegate to the  in 1956, he unsuccessfully sought the vice-presidential nomination. At the 1952, 1956 and 1960 conventions he fought for insertion of a strong civil rights plank in the party platform. He strongly opposed the selection of  as vice president in 1960, feeling that Johnson was \"ideologically wrong on civil rights\". Williams made public his opposition, shouting \"No\" when a call was made for Johnson's nomination to be made unanimous. He was the only delegate to publicly oppose Johnson's nomination.\n\nHis final term in office was marked by high-profile struggles with the Republican-controlled  and a near-shutdown of the state government. He therefore chose not to seek reelection in 1960. Williams left office on January 1, 1961.\n\n\n and President Kennedy in 1961]]\nAfter leaving office in 1961, Williams assumed the post of  in the administration of President . His remark at a press conference that \"what we want for the Africans is what they want for themselves\", reported in the press as \"Africa for the Africans\", sparked controversy. Whites in  and , and in the British and Portuguese colonies contended that Williams wanted them expelled from the continent. Williams defended his remarks, saying that he included white Africans as Africans. Williams was defended by Kennedy at a press conference, saying that \"Africa for the Africans does not seem to me to be an unreasonable statement.\" Kennedy said that Williams made it clear he was referring to Africans of all colors, and \"I don't know who else Africa should be for.\"\n\nHe served in this post until early 1966, when he resigned to unsuccessfully challenge Republican US senator . Two years later, he was named by President  to be , where he served less than a year.\n\nIn 1969 he wrote a book on the emergence of modern Africa, ''Africa for the Africans''.\n\n\n\n\nWilliams was elected to the  in 1970 and was named chief justice in 1983, serving in that capacity through 1986. Thus, like  in the federal government, he occupied the highest executive and judicial offices in  government.\n\n\nWilliams left the court on January 1, 1987, and died the following year in Detroit at the age of 76, three weeks before his 77th birthday. He was temporarily entombed at Evergreen Cemetery in Detroit and there was a formal military funeral for him. After winter his remains were interred at the Protestant Cemetery on . His ''New York Times'' obituary said of Williams's diplomatic service: \"Traveling widely, he studied the needs of countries in the birth pangs of independence and brought their pleas for American investment and trust to Washington.\"\n\n\n\n\n\nThe state government's law building, G. Mennen Williams State Office Building in Lansing, constructed in 1967, was dedicated in Williams's honor on June 1, 1997.\n\nA G. Mennen Williams dinner is an annual event held by the Ionia County Democratic Party each July at the World's Largest Free Fair in . Originally called the Democratic Tent Dinner at its start in the mid-40s, it was renamed after Soapy in 1988 as a way to pay homage to the man that paved the way for dinners to be held at the fair. The Ionia Republican Party had held dinners at the fairgrounds during the 1940s, but the Democrats could not until Soapy stepped up and gained the party equal access in 1949.\n\nA portion of  in  is known as the G. Mennen Williams Highway.\n\nAt the , the Moot Court Board of Advocates hosts the annual G. Mennen Williams Moot Court Competition for all first-year students through their Applied Legal Theory and Analysis course. First year students draft a dispositive motion and brief in support as part of their writing course, and argue their position before a mock tribunal.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }
