    "pages": }\n|children      = 2\n|education     =  (, )\n|website       = \n|signature     = Debbie Sabenow signature 00.svg\n|module = \n}}\n'''Deborah Ann Stabenow''' ( ; née '''Greer'''; born April 29, 1950) is an American politician serving as the   from , a seat she has held since 2001. A member of the , she became the state's first female U.S. senator after winning the .\n\nBefore her election to the Senate, Stabenow was a member of the , representing  from 1997 to 2001. Previously, she served on the   and in the .\n\nStabenow was reelected to Senate in , , and . She became the state's senior U.S. senator upon 's retirement in 2015. Stabenow chaired the  from 2011 to 2015 and again since 2021. She became chair of the  in 2017. At the start of the , Stabenow became the dean of the Michigan congressional delegation, upon the retirement of Representative . In January 2023, she announced that she would not seek reelection .\n\n\n\nStabenow was born in , the daughter of Anna Merle (née Hallmark) and Robert Lee Greer. She grew up in . She graduated from , where she was president of her junior class, the first female class president at the school. She received a Bachelor of Arts from  in 1972 and a Master of Social Work '''' from Michigan State University in 1975.\n\n\n\n\nWhile a graduate student at  in 1974, Stabenow ran for public office for the first time, inspired by the threatened closure of a local nursing home. She won her first election in November 1974, becoming just the third woman elected to the  , on which she served from 1975 to 1978. Stabenow was the first woman and youngest person to date to chair the board of commissioners in 1977 and 1978. She was preceded as chair by one of her political mentors, Ken Hope. She was also instrumental in establishing a women's commission in Ingham County.\n\n\nIn 1978, Stabenow challenged Michigan State Representative  in a primary election. She won the primary and eventually the general election for the 58th House District. Stabenow served in the  from 1979 to 1990. She became a force in state Democratic politics and the first woman in House leadership to preside over the House. In 1990, Stabenow ran for the  seat being vacated by . She won the election, taking office in 1991 and serving one term through 1994.\n\n\n\nIn 1994, Stabenow ran in Michigan's Democratic  primary to challenge incumbent Republican  in the general election. U.S. Congressman  won the primary with a plurality of 35% of the vote to Stabenow's 30%. After the primary, Wolpe chose Stabenow as his running mate, and she appeared on the general election ballot as the Democratic nominee for lieutenant governor. Engler defeated the Wolpe–Stabenow ticket, 61%–38%.\n\n\nIn 1996, Stabenow ran for a seat in the , challenging incumbent Republican U.S. Congressman  for the opportunity to represent . She defeated Chrysler 54%–44%. In 1998, she was reelected with 57% of the vote. In the House, Stabenow served on the  and .\n\n\n in , ]]\n\n\n\n\n\n\nStabenow did not seek reelection to the House in 2000, choosing instead to challenge incumbent Republican U.S. Senator . She won the Democratic primary unopposed. In the general election, Stabenow defeated Abraham 49.5%–48% (a difference of 67,259 votes).\n\n\n\n\nStabenow was challenged by Republican ,  sheriff and former  Majority Floor Leader. Stabenow defeated him 57%–41%.\n\n\n\n\nStabenow was unopposed in the Democratic primary and defeated Republican nominee , former U.S. representative, 59% to 38%.\n\n\n\n\nStabenow was reelected to a fourth term, defeating Republican nominee , 52.3%–45.8%. The margin was 275,660 votes (6.50%), making this the closest U.S. Senate election in Michigan since .\n\n\n]]\nBefore her current committee assignments, Stabenow also served on the  and the .\n\nStabenow is only the second person from Michigan to have served in both houses of the  and both houses of the , the other being . She is also the first person to have served as a Michigan state legislator to be popularly elected to the U.S. Senate (until enactment of the  in 1913, U.S. senators were selected by state legislatures).\n\nStabenow became the third-ranking Democrat in the Senate on November 16, 2004, when she was elected secretary of the Democratic caucus. As caucus secretary, she assisted   in setting the Democratic agenda and priorities. Senator  was elected , the second-ranking Democratic spot. In November 2006, Reid announced that Stabenow would leave the caucus secretary position to succeed  as chair of the Democratic Steering and Outreach Committee, charged with \"engag[ing] Democratic Senators and community leaders across the country in an active dialogue\".\n\nAfter , President 's nominee for , withdrew from consideration, the  urged the president to appoint Stabenow, citing her focus on health care and her background as a social worker.\n\nStabenow became chair of the  in 2011, following the defeat of . A controversial item during Stabenow's tenure was the renewal and reform of the . Reid reintroduced 2012's Senate Farm Bill in the  in January 2013, saying that it was on his top priority list, and Stabenow voiced support for Reid's move, saying, \"Majority Leader Reid has demonstrated that the Senate will once again make supporting our nation's agriculture economy while cutting spending a top priority.\"\n\nOn October 29, 2014, Stabenow introduced the , a bill that would reaffirm the status of lands taken into trust by the  for the benefit of the Match-E-Be-Nash-She-Wish Band. The bill would clarify that the Match-E-Be-Nash-She-Wish Band's land trust could not be challenged in court under the Supreme Court decision ''''.\n\nStabenow was participating in the certification of the  when Trump supporters . Along with other senators and staff, she was evacuated from the Senate chamber through a stairwell and taken to a safe location. She called the experience \"heartbreaking\" and \"one of those things out of a movie\" and said she had not felt that much fear since her time at the Capitol during the . After the Capitol was secure, Congress returned to session to certify the election. Stabenow supported the certification. The day after the attack, Stabenow called for Trump's immediate removal from office through the invocation of the  or .\n\n\n* (chair)\n**As chairperson, Senator Stabenow is an ''ex officio'' member of all subcommittees.\n*\n*\n**\n**\n**\n*\n**\n**\n**\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\nThe  gave Stabenow a 6% lifetime conservative rating in 2020.\n\n\nStabenow supports keeping abortion legal. She has voted to expand , and against prohibiting minors crossing state lines for abortions, barring  grants to institutions that perform abortions, and criminal penalties for harm or death to a fetus in a violent crime.\n\n\nStabenow supported  in 2018 to , though she would like to ensure law enforcement is involved so that the law is implemented correctly.\n\n\nIn 2013, Greg Kaufmann of '''' wrote an article stating that Stabenow was prepared to cut $8 to $9 billion from the  (SNAP) program. In a lengthy statement, Stabenow's office rejected these accusations, maintaining that she \"strongly opposes any changes to food assistance that make cuts in benefits for people who need help putting food on the table\" and that she \"has been the number one defender against the House Republican proposal to cut food assistance by $40 billion.\" Kaufmann doubled down on his charges and challenged Stabenow's office's claims in detail.\n\nIn 2017, Stabenow fought to prevent the creation of additional work-requirement rules on SNAP recipients who were older or had smaller children and led a bipartisan effort to get the legislation passed.\n\n\nIn October 2002, Stabenow was one of 23 senators who voted against .\n\nIn April 2019, Stabenow was one of 34 senators to sign a letter to President  encouraging him \"to listen to members of your own Administration and reverse a decision that will damage our national security and aggravate conditions inside \", asserting that Trump had \"consistently expressed a flawed understanding of U.S. foreign assistance\" since becoming president and that he was \"personally undermining efforts to promote U.S. national security and economic prosperity\" by preventing the use of Fiscal Year 2018 national security funding. The senators argued that foreign assistance to Central American countries created less migration to the U.S. by helping to improve conditions in those countries.\n\n\nStabenow secured $100 million to repair and replace the water lines in , which were . She also pushed to include a program that would provide fresh fruits and vegetables to Flint children as part of the .\n\n\n\nStabenow has received low scores from free-market groups (, 2013, 0%; , 2016, 0%; , 2015–16, 0%) and high scores from fiscally liberal groups (Progressive Punch, 2015, 92%; , 2012, 91%).\n\nIn 2007, Senator Stabenow joined the bipartisan (70-23) support of  in order to combat conspiratorial policies by foreign oil producers, extending Sherman Anti-Trust Act protection to include foreign cartels such as OPEC, and bring down US oil and gas costs for US consumers. In 2008, she voted against the  proposed by President .\n\nIn 2009, Stabenow voted for President 's $787 billion  plan.\n\nIn 2010, she introduced the China Fair Trade Act, saying it would \"prevent federal taxpayer dollars from being used to purchase Chinese products and services until they sign on to and abide by the .\" The bill would also require a report on Chinese industrial policies and require the  to monitor the development of China's renewable energy sector.\n\nIn October 2011, Stabenow called for tax breaks for firms developing bio-based products, using crops like  and corn to create prescriptions drugs, plastics, and soaps.\n\nIn August 2012, Stabenow expressed support for \"strategic partnerships between farmers and industry\" and for a recent Obama directive to boost federal purchases of bio-based products.\n\nIn 2015, she introduced the Stabenow-Portman Amendment (SA 1299) to address  in the .\n\nIn 2015, the  gave Stabenow the Congressional Leadership Award \"for her significant contributions in the area of economic development.\" The IEDC cited her work on the , her sponsorship in 2013 of the New Skills for New Jobs Act, and her role in the federal bridge loan program.\"\n\nIn 2017, Stabenow introduced her American Jobs Agenda, which included two acts: the Make It In America Act and the . The former, \"would close loopholes in a 1933 law designed to give American companies priority when the federal government purchases goods.\" She said the act would require that the U.S. government: \"buy American...If the federal agency says they need a waiver, they need to measure how many American jobs will be impacted by purchasing that product made overseas.\" The latter, \"would create a tax cut for companies bringing jobs and business activities back to America from another country.\"\n\nIn April 2017, Stabenow was one of eight Democratic senators to sign a letter to Trump noting government-subsidized Chinese steel had been placed into the American market in recent years below cost and had hurt the domestic steel industry and the iron ore industry that fed it, calling on him to raise the steel issue with   in his meeting with him.\n\nIn May 2017, she and Senator  announced a $210,000  grant to the West Michigan Shoreline Regional Development Commission \"to help spur economic development in West Michigan.\" The same month, she said that owing to a major change in farmers' margins since the 2014 Farm Bill, the farm safety net needed to be strengthened, especially for dairy farmers.\n\nAt a July 13, 2017, economics , she said that the \"#1 request she gets in Michigan\" is for \"Professional technical jobs, building construction jobsfolks that can actually make things and do things.\" She said that Democrats can succeed in elections by \"going to our core. We are the party that are willing to take risks to make things better...We believe in our core in an economy that actually works for everybody. That is how you grow America.\"\n\nThe  thanked Stabenow in 2017 for supporting development of a \"biobased economy,\" specifically for her introduction of the Renewable Chemicals Act of 2017, which would \"allow taxpayers to claim a production tax credit of 15 cents per pound of biobased content of each renewable chemical produced during the taxable year.\"\n\nOn October 3, 2017, Stabenow and Peters introduced the Small Business Access to Capital Act, designed to \"reauthorize and improve the State Small Business Credit Initiative (SSBCI) to help small businesses grow and create jobs.\" It built \"on the successful SSBCI initiative that both lawmakers championed in the Small Business Jobs Act of 2010\" and that \"funds the Michigan Economic Development Corporation and other state-led lending programs that leverage private financing to help small businesses access the capital they need.\"\n\n\nStabenow has received high marks from groups supporting immigration (, 2013–14, 100%; , 2013–14, 100%) and low marks from groups opposed to immigration: , 2014, 0%; , 2017, 0%.\n\nDuring the two-day , Stabenow was among 81 senators who effectively ended the shutdown by approving a three-week stopgap spending bill that \"included reauthorizing the  for six years\". This agreement was obtained after the Republican leadership \"pledged to soon take up immigration legislation\". She said they had \"reached a bipartisan agreement that funds children's health insurance and moves us closer to a solution that provides long-term certainty for Michigan families and our national defense\".\n\nIn January 2017, she opposed  temporarily limiting immigration from several Muslim majority countries, saying it: \"is ruining America's reputation in the world, undermining our relationships with our most critical allies, and most heartbreakingly, destroying the lives of good and law-abiding people.\"\n\nStabenow voted against providing  financial support to undocumented immigrants on February 4, 2021.\n\n\nStabenow supported Obama's  that sought to prevent Iran from developing nuclear weapons for 10 years and attempted to halt their uranium production.\n\n\nRecounting a 2014 Senate hearing on ,  singled out Stabenow as the only committee member who pushed back on the idea that it was caused largely by the withdrawal from the workforce of middle-aged people who preferred to collect welfare. Stabenow \"pointed out that almost all the voters she heard from in high-unemployment Michigan still wanted to work.\"\n\n\nShe has received low scores from low-spending advocates (, 2016, 8%; , 2015, 0%; , 2015, 9%).\n\n\n in 2016]]\nIn 2011, Stabenow introduced the Reengaging Americans in Serious Education Act (RAISE UP Act), whereby the  would fund programs to help \"disconnected youth\" get diplomas, degrees, and job certifications. In 2012, she co-sponsored a bill to freeze  interest rates at 3.4 percent and make additional funds available for .\n\nIn 2016, Stabenow and others introduced the Reducing Educational Debt Act, which she promoted with the #InTheRed .\n\nShe expressed \"strong concerns\" about Trump's nomination of  as , saying: \"DeVos and her family have a long record of pushing policies that I believe have seriously undermined  in Michigan and failed our children.\"\n\n\nStabenow supports gun control and supports a national assault weapons ban.\nAfter the , Stabenow participated in the . One month later, she supported bills to ban people on the  from buying guns and to expand background checks. Neither bill passed the Senate. Stabenow blamed the  (NRA) for the bills' failure to pass.\n\nIn 2017, following the , Stabenow and  introduced a law that would make it illegal for people convicted of misdemeanor  to buy guns.\n\nStabenow has an \"A+\" rating from the  and an \"F\" rating from both the NRA and the .\n\n\nStabenow has helped open 10 community health centers in Detroit while in office.\n\nShe has received high scores from  (2017, 100%) and low scores from , (2013, 0%).\n\nIn the , she: \"promised to make the  lower prescription drug prices, to maintain  benefits and to give  a new prescription drug plan.\" She pledged to \"fight the pharmaceutical and insurance industriesthe two industries that spend the most money  federal officials\" and accused the pharmaceutical industry of \"making up to 20 percent net profit each year...on the backs of families, seniors and businesses.\" Her spokesperson said: \"In the last election, I think the pharmaceutical industry spent more campaigning against her than any other candidate...She was enemy number one.\" Stabenow voted for the  in December 2009, and for the . She also sponsored S. 2257, the Excellence in Mental Health Act.\n\nOn September 1, 2016, she said that approving money to combat  was a top congressional priority.\n\nIn August 2019, Stabenow was one of 19 senators to sign a letter to   and   requesting data from the Trump administration in order to help states and Congress understand the potential consequences in the event that the Texas v. United States Affordable Care Act (ACA) lawsuit prevailed in courts, writing that an overhaul of the present health care system would form \"an enormous hole in the pocketbooks of the people we serve as well as wreck state budgets\".\n\n\nIn April 2019, Stabenow was one of 41 senators to sign a bipartisan letter to the housing subcommittee praising the  Section 4 Capacity Building program as authorizing \"HUD to partner with national nonprofit community development organizations to provide education, training, and financial support to local community development corporations (CDCs) across the country\" and expressing disappointment that Trump's budget \"has slated this program for elimination after decades of successful economic and community development.\" The senators wrote of their hope that the subcommittee would support continued funding for Section 4 in Fiscal Year 2020.\n\n\nIn December 2011, Stabenow voted in favor of the . The bill included highly controversial provisions, drafted by Senators  and  in closed session, that would allow for the indefinite military detention without trial of American citizens deemed potential terrorists and enemies of the state.\n\n\n\n\nOn August 10, 2009, Stabenow was reported by '''' as saying, \"Global warming creates volatility. I feel it when I'm flying. The storms are more volatile. We are paying the price in more hurricanes and tornadoes.\" She has, however, opposed regulation of greenhouse gases, enhanced fuel efficiency standards in California, and greenhouse gas emission reporting standards.\n\nStabenow voted for the SBIR/STTR Reauthorization Act of 2011 (S.493). In March 2011, '''' accused her of joining \"the pro-polluter frenzy sweeping the U.S. Senate,\" saying that the legislation was: \"being used as a vehicle for senators who wish to prevent regulation of greenhouse pollution from oil refineries, coal-fired power plants, heavy industry, and other major emitters. Stabenow has added her amendment to three others intended to hamstring the Environmental Protection Agency on behalf of carbon polluters.\"\n\nStabenow's proposed amendment to keep the EPA from regulating  for two years also drew criticism. The amendment would have given “coal-fired power plants, oil refineries and other industrial sources a two year exemption” from rules requiring them to report greenhouse gas emissions. She defended her position by calling her amendment: \"a common-sense approach that allows protections from carbon pollution, determined by scientists and public health experts, to continue being developed while providing businesses the support and incentives they need as they reduce pollution, generate new clean energy technologies and create jobs.\"\n\nIn February 2019, in response to reports of the EPA intending to decide against setting drinking water limits for perfluorooctane sulfonic acid (PFOS) and  (PFOA) as part of an upcoming national strategy to manage the chemicals, Stabenow was one of 20 senators to sign a letter to Acting EPA Administrator  calling on the agency: \"to develop enforceable federal drinking water standards for PFOA and PFOS, as well as institute immediate actions to protect the public from contamination from additional per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS).\"\n\n\nIn 2010, Stabenow called for a total ban on drilling in the Great Lakes. Critics noted that \"a U.S. federal ban on all oil and natural gas  in the Great Lakes\" had already \"been in place since 2005\" and that Canada banned offshore oil drilling but had \"roughly 500 offshore gas wells in Lake Erie\" plus 23 \"slant wells\" that \"drill for oil on shore but extend under Lake Erie.\" In 2015, Stabenow and Gary Peters introduced the Pipeline Improvement and Preventing Spills Act \"to ban shipping of crude oil by vessel on the Great Lakes and require a comprehensive, top-to-bottom review of hazardous pipelines in the region.\"\n\nIn May 2017, Stabenow expressed support for the bipartisan effort to retain funding for The Great Lakes Restoration Initiative.\n\nIn September 2016, Stabenow and Peters led an effort to link an aid package for the  to flood relief funds for .\n\n\nOn August 31, 2006, Stabenow, Senator  and Representative  announced an agreement that would completely cease 's dumping of solid waste in Michigan within four years. This had been an issue in Michigan for the past several years. Stabenow had previously introduced legislation in the Senate intended to reduce the dumping of Canadian trash in Michigan. In July 2006, the Senate unanimously passed a law sponsored by Stabenow requiring the payment of a $420 inspection fee for every truckload of Canadian trash brought into Michigan.\n\n\nAsked in 2009 by  whether she would support a return of the , under which the federal government enforced an ideological \"balance\" on the airwaves, Stabenow said yes: \"I absolutely think it's time to be bringing accountability to the airwaves.\" Asked whether she would push for Senate hearings on the subject, she said, \"I have already had some discussions with colleagues and, you know, I feel like that's gonna happen. Yep.\" It has been noted that Stabenow's then husband was , an executive in left-wing radio (, ), whose career would have benefited from such legislation.\n\nStabenow is probably the most prominent politician to seriously support a new Fairness Doctrine.\n\n\nStabenow, as  Chair, added an amendment to the  that prohibited state laws requiring  for foods. She has been criticized because this amendment aided  and other agribusinesses, which donated over three-quarters of a million dollars to her campaign during that election cycle. In 2016, she was again criticized for her role in the passage of a law that overruled state laws mandating GMO labeling.\n\n\nIn January 2017, Stabenow opposed Trump's nomination of  as : \"Because of his record on  and his votes against anti- legislation, I cannot support him to be our nation's highest law enforcement officer...Families in Michigan and across the country deserve an attorney general who will enforce the nation's laws fairly and equally.\"\n\nThat March, she opposed Trump's nomination of  to the : \"After reviewing Judge Gorsuch's rulings, it is clear that he has a long record of siding with special interests and institutions instead of hard-working Americans. And, therefore, in my judgment, he does not meet this standard of balance and impartiality.\"\n\nIn July 2018, citing his past rulings on presidential powers, she opposed , furthermore stating that the FBI should perform a background check regarding .\n\nShe similarly opposed Trump's 2020 , stating: \"It's very clear from her writings, multiple writings, that she will be the vote that takes away health care for millions of Americans, including 130 million people and counting with pre-existing conditions...\" She voted against the nomination while wearing a  depicting Barrett's predecessor .\n\n\nOn January 5, 2023, Stabenow announced her intention to retire from the Senate. Her announcement cited a desire to \"pass the torch\" to Michigan's next generation of leadership: \"I have always believed it's not enough to be the first unless there is a second and a third\". She also noted time with family as a motivation for her retirement. If she serves in the Senate until her term ends in January 2025, she will have held elective office for 50 years. In February 2023, Michigan Representative  launched a campaign to succeed Stabenow in the Senate.\n\n\nIn February 2023, a portrait of Stabenow by Michigan artist Joshua Adam Risner was unveiled in the . Congressional committee chairs traditionally receive portraits in their committee rooms. Stabenow's portrait came due to her years as chair of the Senate Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry. It was commissioned by the .\n\nOn October 3, 2024, Washington Park in  was renamed Debbie Stabenow Park in her honor.\n\n\nStabenow is a member of the .\n\nStabenow was first married to Dennis Stabenow. The couple had two children and divorced in 1990.\n\nShe did not seek a fifth term in 2024 in order to spend more time with her family. Stabenow gave her 96 year old mother’s declining health as a reason.\n\nIn 2003, Stabenow married , co-founder of  and former executive vice president of . She has a stepdaughter from this marriage. They divorced in 2010.\n\nStabenow had a cameo appearance in the 2016 film '''' as governor of the unspecified state in which  is located. She was invited to appear because the scene was filmed in Michigan, and for her support for film-industry incentives.\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* official U.S. Senate website\n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Wilber Marion Brucker''' (June 23, 1894 &ndash; October 28, 1968)\n was an American  . Born in , he served as the 32nd  from 1931 to 1933 and as the  between July 21, 1955, and January 19, 1961.\n\n\nBrucker was born in Saginaw, Michigan, the son of   .  He graduated from the  in 1916 and enlisted in the , serving with its 33rd Infantry Regiment on the  during the  from 1916 to 1917.  He attended Officer Training Camp at , and was commissioned a second lieutenant. Brucker served in  during  with the 166th Infantry, , in the , , and  operations, 1917–1918.  He received the  and , and remained a member of the Officer Reserve Corps until 1937.\n\n\nA Republican, after the war, Brucker was assistant prosecuting attorney of  from 1919 to 1923, and then prosecuting attorney from 1923 to 1927. He married Clara Helen Hantel in 1923.  He served as assistant attorney general of Michigan, 1927–1928, and as , 1928–1930.\n\nIn 1930 he was elected as Michigan's 32nd governor, serving one term until being defeated in 1932 by  . During his two years in office, the police force in Michigan increased and a new state police headquarters in  was authorized. Also Michigan enacted legislation that allowed grand juries to investigate allegations of municipal government fraud and mismanagement. In 1936, Brucker defeated incumbent   in the Republican primary elections, but lost to Democrat  in the general election.\n\nHe was a member of the law firm of Clark, Klein, Brucker, and Waples, 1937–1954, and served as  from 1954 to 1955, during the .\n\nIn 1955, Brucker was appointed by   as Secretary of the Army, serving from July 21, 1955, to January 19, 1961. Brucker administered the Army during a period of major technological advance, especially in the missile-satellite field, and at a time when the Army's place in the national defense structure was overshadowed by a philosophy of \"\". Under his direction the Army instituted a five-element (pentagonal) organization concept for the division, established a  for emergency reaction, launched the United States' first satellite, , and adopted the .\n\n\nBrucker returned to legal practice in Detroit with the firm of Brucker and Brucker, 1961–1968, and was a member of the Board of Directors of .  He died in Detroit on October 28, 1968, and was buried at .\n\n\nBrucker Hall at  is named for him.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n*  at the \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

    "pages": }\n'''Frederick Stephen Upton''' (born April 23, 1953) is an American politician who served as a  from  from 1987 to 2023. A member of the , he represented  and much of southwestern Michigan for 18 terms before retiring in 2023.\n\nA former chairman of the , Upton has played a major role in shaping post- health care legislation. He is the only person in American history to vote to impeach two presidents; he voted for the  in 1998 and the  in 2021, as one of ten Republicans who voted to impeach Trump. After  retired at the end of the , Upton became the dean of .\n\n\nUpton was born in , the son of Elizabeth B. (née Vial) and Stephen Edward Upton (1924–2022). He attended , graduating in 1971. He earned a  in journalism from the  in 1975. He was a member of the  fraternity, Peninsular Chapter, and became a sports editor at '''' and thought he might someday cover the . He served on the congressional staff of U.S. Representative  from 1976 to 1980. He was in the  (OMB) under  from 1981 to 1985, while Stockman served as OMB Director.\n\n\n]]\n in 1988]]\n in 2001]]\n\n\n\nUpton ran in  against incumbent , Stockman's successor. Upton won the Republican  55%–45% and the general election with 62% of the vote.\n\n\nUpton won reelection to a second term with 71% of the vote.\n\n\nUpton defeated  in the Republican primary, 63%–37%. In the general election, he was reelected to a third term with 58% of the vote.\n\n\n\nAfter redistricting, Upton decided to run in the newly redrawn , winning reelection to a fourth term with 62% of the vote.\n\n\n\nAfter redistricting, Upton faced a primary challenge from State Senator Dale Shugars. Upton defeated Shugars 66%–32%. He won the general election with 69% of the vote.\n\n\n\nUpton defeated  nominee Scott Elliott, an art gallery owner, 65%–32%.\n\n\n\nUpton defeated Democratic nominee , 61%–38%.\n\n\n\nUpton defeated Democratic nominee , a Kalamazoo City Commissioner, 59%–39%.\n\n\n\nUpton defeated former State Representative  in the Republican primary, 57%–43%. In the general election, he defeated Cooney, 62%–34%.\n\n\n\nIn 2011, Hoogendyk met with the , a conservative  organization, about running against Upton again. Upton had been criticized for not being  enough by , , , Right to Life of Michigan, and the Southwest Michigan . On January 17, 2012, Hoogendyk announced that he would challenge Upton in the primary, the winner of which would face the Democratic nominee, former  and businessman .\n\nInitial polls showed Upton with a sizable lead over O'Brien, but an October poll showed Upton and O'Brien in a dead heat heading into the final stretch of the campaign.\n\n\n\nUpton won with 55.9% of the vote, defeating Democrat Paul Clements, Libertarian Erwin Haas, and Green Party candidate John Lawrence.\n\n\n\nUpton was reelected, defeating Democratic nominee Paul Clements, a political science professor at Western Michigan University, 58.5%–36.4%.\n\n\n\nUpton was reelected with 50.2% of the vote against Democratic nominee Matt Longjohn (45.75%) and  candidate Stephen Young (4.1%).\n\n\n\nUpton was reelected with 55.9% of the vote against Democratic nominee  (40.2%), Libertarian Party nominee Jeff Depoy (2.75%), and Green Party candidate John Lawrence (1.2%).\n\n\n\nUpton has been a member of moderate Republican factions  and the . On February 4, 2021, he joined 10 other Republican House members voting with all voting Democrats to strip  of her  and  assignments in response to controversial political statements she had made.\n\n\nUpton voted against passage of the  (ACA) and has since voted in favor of its complete repeal. In November 2013, in response to Americans losing their  coverage because of the ACA, Upton proposed a bill that would allow them to retain it. The essence of his bill was to allow insurance companies to maintain their individual insurance market policies according to state insurance rules that were in effect as of 2013. In 2017, Upton played an important role advancing Republican Party efforts to repeal the ACA.\n\nIn 2013, Upton introduced a bill that would grant the  more power to regulate drug  in the wake of the . In 2016, Obama signed the  into law, a bill Upton co-sponsored. The act establishes funds for biomedical research and to develop and implement a strategic plan for biomedical research. In 2018, Upton and Representative  worked together on legislation designed to combat . Among other things, it would allocate funding for research into new, non-addictive pain relievers.\n\n\n\nIn 2007 Upton co-sponsored the , which, among other things, mandated phased-in  standards for most light bulbs. At the time, he noted that the legislation, ultimately signed into law by President George W. Bush, would \"help preserve energy resources and reduce harmful emissions, all while saving American families billions of dollars on their electric bills.\"Grunwald, Michael   ''Time'' magazine, May 20, 2013, p. Business-6, Accessed September 4, 2018  called Upton \"all socialist\" for supporting the bill.\n\nIn April 2009, Upton said that \" is a serious problem that necessitates serious solutions. Everything must be on the table.\" But \"Upton has gradually retreated from his moderate stance on climate change and carbon emissions.\" He led a failed effort to stop the Obama administration from enforcing the new energy standards.\n\nUpton's website once stated: \"I strongly believe that everything must be on the table as we seek to reduce .\"Sheppard, Kate (January 4, 2011)  , '''' access-date September 4, 2018 In late 2010, he co-authored a '''' opinion piece saying he was \"not convinced\" that \"carbon is a problem in need of regulation\" and urging  to overturn ''.''\n\nUpton and  co-sponsored H.R. 910, the  of 2011.  Due to his environmental policies, '''' wrote in 2011 that Upton \"represents one of the biggest threats to planet Earth on planet Earth.\"\n\nIn 2012, Upton, as chair of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, said that Congress's refusal to set  limits \"constituted a decision and that lawmakers should act now to reverse the  emissions rules.\" Carbon regulation, he said, \"threatens to drive energy prices higher, destroy jobs and hamstring our economic recovery.\"\n\nOn October 22, 2013, Upton introduced the , a bill that would make changes to permitting requirements for pipelines and other energy infrastructure at international borders. He said the bill \"is a sincere effort to focus a targeted solution to lessons learned from the ... No one can rightly argue that the current presidential permit process as the State Department is not broken, no matter what side of the climate debate you're on.\" Upton added, \"we're creating a fair and transparent approval process for cross-border energy projects, putting them all on a level playing field for the benefit of North American energy security, lower energy prices, and jobs.\"\n\nAs of 2017, Upton has received more than $2 million in campaign donations from oil and gas companies and electric utilities over the course of his political career. In 2018, he joined the .\n\n\nUpton introduced legislation to reverse the  ruling on net neutrality in 2015. On November 5, 2021, Upton was one of 13 House Republicans to break with their party and vote with a majority of Democrats in favor of the .\n\n\nIn 2019, Upton supported a bill that requires background checks for private firearm sales. He has called for Congress to pass a bipartisan .\n\nIn March 2021, Upton was one of eight Republicans to join the House majority in passing the .\n\n\nIn 2004 and 2006, Upton voted for a constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage. In 2019, he voted against the Equality Act, which would extend existing civil rights legislation to protect LGBT individuals from discrimination.\n\nIn 2013, Upton condemned controversial anti-gay remarks by Republican National Committeeman .\n\nIn 2021, Upton was one of 29 Republicans to vote to reauthorize the . This bill expanded legal protections for transgender people, and contained provisions allowing transgender women to use women's shelters and serve time in prisons matching their gender identity.\n\nIn 2021, Upton was one of 33 Republicans to vote for the LGBTQ Business Equal Credit Enforcement and Investment Act.\n\nIn 2021, Upton co-sponsored the Fairness for All Act, the Republican alternative to the Equality Act. The bill would prohibit discrimination on the basis of sex, sexual orientation, and gender identity, and protect the free exercise of religion.\n\nOn July 19, 2022, Upton and 46 other Republican Representatives voted for the , which would codify the right to same-sex marriage in federal law.\n\n\n\nIn 2019, during the , Upton broke with his party, one of seven Republicans to side with Democrats by voting for legislation that would fund government services and end a .\n\nIn February 2021, Upton voted against a $1.9 trillion COVID relief bill that provided $10 billion in federal aid to Michigan.\n\n\nDuring Trump's presidency, Upton voted in line with Trump's stated position 78.6% of the time.\n\nIn July 2019, Upton was one of four Republican House members to vote in support of a motion to condemn comments Trump made on Twitter calling on four  Congresswomen, three of whom were born in the U.S., to \"go back and help fix the totally broken and crime infested places from which they came.\"\n\nOn December 18, 2019, Upton voted against .\n\nOn January 12, 2021, Upton announced he would vote to impeach Trump in the pending vote on , claiming Trump incited the , becoming the fourth House Republican to say they would vote to impeach. He ultimately did so alongside nine other Republicans on January 13. On January 21, 2021, the  Republican Party censured Upton for his vote to impeach Trump. He was later censured by the  Republican Party for voting to remove  from the House Education Committee.\n\nOn May 19, 2021, Upton was one of 35 Republicans who joined all Democrats in voting to approve legislation to establish the  meant to investigate the . Before the vote, he was one of few Republican lawmakers to openly express support for the commission.\n\nIn October 2024, Upton endorsed  in the 2024 presidential election, calling Trump \"unfit to serve\".\n\n\nIn June 2021, Upton was one of 49 House Republicans to vote to repeal the  against Iraq.\n\n\nOn October 21, 2021, Upton was one of nine House Republicans who voted to hold  in contempt of Congress.\n\n\nUpton supports .\n\nUpton voted for the Further Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2020 which authorizes DHS to nearly double the available H-2B visas for the remainder of FY 2020.\n\nUpton voted for the Consolidated Appropriations Act (H.R. 1158), which effectively prohibits ICE from cooperating with Health and Human Services to detain or remove illegal alien sponsors of unaccompanied alien children (UACs).\n\n\nUpton was one of three Republicans to vote for H.R. 8297: Ensuring Access to Abortion Act of 2022.\n\nUpton voted for H.R. 8373: The Right to Contraception Act. This bill was designed to protect access to contraceptives and health care providers' ability to provide contraceptives and information related to contraception. The bill would also fund .\n\n\nIn 2022, Upton was one of 39 Republicans to vote for the Merger Filing Fee Modernization Act of 2022, an antitrust package that would crack down on corporations for anti-competitive behavior.\n\n\n* \n\n\n* Congressional Automotive Caucus (Co-Vice Chair)\n* Congressional Competitiveness Caucus\n* Congressional Travel and Tourism Caucus\n* Diabetes Caucus\n* India Caucus\n* Indian-Americans Caucus\n*\n* Sportsmen's Caucus\n* Bipartisan Climate Solutions Caucus\n* \n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\nUpton's grandfather and eponym, Frederick Upton, served as vice-president  of appliance manufacturer and marketer , headquartered in , which was founded by his great-uncle . He and his wife have two children. Upton's niece is supermodel . Open Secrets reported that Upton had a net worth of $78 million in 2018, making him one of Congress's richest members.\n\nUpton is a supporter of  athletics, as well as an enthusiastic  baseball fan. He is a member of the  Society.\n\nUpton is a .\n\n\n\n|+ : Results 1986–1990\n! Year\n!\n! Republican\n! Votes\n! %\n!\n! Democratic\n! Votes\n! %\n!\n! Third Party\n! Party\n!     "pages": }\n'''Anthony G. Forlini''' (born February 4, 1962) is an American politician from Michigan. Forlini was a Republican member of the  for the  from 2011 through 2016.\n\n\nOn February 4, 1962, Forlini was born in , . Forlini's father was an Italian from the town of Cassino, Italy.\nForlini grew up in St. Clair Shores. Forlini attended St. Germaine Elementary School.\n\n\nIn 1984, Forlini earned a degree in Business from . Forlini is a Certified Financial Planner.\n\n\nAs a businessman, Forlini is the owner of Design Financial and President of INFINEX Investments & Design Financial, Incorporated.\n\nIn 2004, Forlini became a township supervisor in , until 2011.\n\nOn November 2, 2010, Forlini won the election and became a  member of  for District 24. Forlini defeated  and Keith P. Edwards with 50.18% of the votes. On November 6, 2012, as an incumbent, Forlini won the election and continued serving District 24. Forlini defeated Philip Kurczewski with 54.71% of the votes.\nDistrict 24 covers  as well as portions of  and . \n\n\nIn March 2016, Forlini announced that he was running for Congress in Michigan's 10th District, as , the then current Representative, was not running for another term.\n\nIn 2017, Forlini became an Operations Manager with Macomb County Public Works.\n\nAs of 2021, he is the current Macomb County Clerk. During his campaign, his tagline was \"Every vote matters, every vote counts,\" ensuring that a voter's voice matters in the eyes of the United States.\n\n\n* 2016 Knighted. . Presented by Maria Luisa Lapresa, the Consul of Italy in , .\n\n\nForlini's wife is Diane Forlini. They have three children and two grandchildren. Forlini's family currently live in .     "pages": }\n'''Ruth Johnson''' (born January 8, 1955) is an American businesswoman and politician currently serving as a member of the  since 2019. She was the 42nd  from 2011 to 2019 and a member of the  from 1999 to 2005. She is a .\n\n\nJohnson, of , was a former public , , and public official in a suburban area immediately north of  with a population of more than one million, prior to her election as secretary of state in November 2010.  She was elected to the  in 1988 and served for 10 years.  Johnson was elected to the  in 1998, and re-elected in 2000 and 2002;  meant she was ineligible for a fourth term. She was elected   and  in 2004, upsetting incumbent G. William Caddell in the Republican Primary and defeated Democratic nominee Jason Ellenburg in the general election. She became the first woman clerk in Oakland County's 176-year history. Johnson became popular for her community outreach event and parties.\n\nIn August 2006, Johnson was selected by Grand Rapids businessman and Republican gubernatorial nominee  as his running mate, becoming the GOP nominee for . DeVos and Johnson lost the  to the incumbent Democratic ticket of   and Lt. Gov. . In 2007, Johnson endorsed Sen. 's bid for the  and served as the Oakland County Chair for . Johnson was re-elected County Clerk in 2008, defeating Democrat Sheila Smith.\n\n\nAs secretary, Johnson promoted motorcycle safety initiatives, such as wearing high-visibility gear and encouraging riders to get a cycle endorsement. Johnson herself is a licensed motorcycle rider and often rides in to motorcycle-related news conferences. Johnson pushed her departments to foster safe driving among teens. After reviewing the department's teen driver licensing program, National Highway Traffic Safety Administration offered recommendations for improvement but overall gave the program high praise for combating the leading cause of death for teens in the United States. Like her time as Oakland County Clerk, Ruth Johnson because popular for community outreach events, and viral marketing campaigns\n\nIn 2014, Michigan was named the best state in the nation for registering qualified U.S. citizens at state motor-vehicle offices, according to USA Today. Also in 2014, the University of Michigan's Center for Local, State and Urban Policy found that the Secretary of State's Office was rated the second best state agency for job performance by community leaders. That same year, the state's Mackinac Bridge license plate was named the best designed plate in the world.\n\nIn July 2017, Ruth Johnson agreed to provide Michigan voter registration information to a federal commission created by  to investigate alleged illegal voting in the 2016 election. Johnson indicated she would only provide basic public voter information.\n\n\n\nIn 2010, she won the Republican nomination for secretary of state at the party's state convention. Her opponents were , , Anne Norlander and .  She went on to win the general election defeating Democrat , Libertarian , Green John Anthony La Pietra, and US Taxpayer Robert Gale.\n\n\n\nIn 2014, Johnson defeated Detroit lawyer and Democrat Godfrey Dillard, Libertarian James Lewis, US Taxpayers Robert Gale, and Natural Law Jason Gatties to earn a second term by 10.6 percentage points, receiving 1,649,047 votes to the defeated candidates 1,431,748 votes. She drew more votes than any other Republican candidate on the ballot.\n\n\nAfter her tenure as Secretary of State, she was elected as a Michigan State Senator in 2018 and re-elected again in 2022. In September 2020, Johnson filed a lawsuit against Secretary of State  for allowing votes postmarked before election day to be counted after election day. The lawsuit was later dismissed.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n|years=2011–2019}}\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

    "pages": }\n'''James \"Jase\" Bolger''' (born February 2, 1971) served as the  Speaker of the  from January 12, 2011 to the end of 2014 session. Bolger is a member of the , and represented  from 2009 to 2014. After being term limited out, he founded a consulting firm, Tusker Strategies. Bolger was also appointed by former Governor  on December 29, 2016 to the  and was elected chair on April 27, 2023.\n\n\nJames \"Jase\" Bolger was born in , the son of James and Eileen Bolger.Davis, Paula M. (January 9, 2011). . ''Kalamazoo Gazette''. Due to his father's job as a  trooper, the family moved around the state often, before settling in  when Jase entered first grade. He graduated  with a Bachelor of Business Administration with a dual major in Finance and Political Science. , ''Republican State Leadership Committee''; accessed December 20, 2014.\n\nPrior to entering politics, Bolger founded (and continues to help operate) a small collections/skip tracing business that updates phone records for Fortune 100 companies. An Eagle Scout, he has also been associated with AYSO Soccer, the Rotary Club, United Way, the KAAAP mentor program, Oaklawn Hospital, the Knights of Columbus and several Chambers of Commerce. He is married and has two children. Bolger and his family are Roman Catholic.\n\n\nBolger was first elected to public office in 2004 as a  Commissioner, he was later reelected for the same post in 2006.Western Michigan University GOP (May 21, 2008). . ''WMUGOP Blogspot.'' One of his stated priorities as a Commissioner was to minimize the county's spending which he believed was necessary to secure the county's future. During his time as county commissioner Bolger worked with the Democratic majority to achieve consolidation for three 911  dispatchers.Calhoun County Board of Commissioners (February 7, 2008) ''Calhouncountymi.gov'' The consolidation of the Battle Creek, Albion and Marshall centers into a single center, located in Marshall, resulted in improved service and a net saving of $1.5 million for local taxpayers.\n\nBolger was first elected as a State Representative in November 2008, when he defeated Democratic nominee Phyllis Smith by a 13-point margin. He was subsequently reelected in 2010 and 2012 and served as Speaker until 2014. In 2012, Democrats campaigned heavily trying to defeat Bolger, spending nearly $1 million on mail, television and radio s; however, Bolger won re-election to his third and final term.Klug, Fritz (November 7, 2012). , ''Kalamazoo Gazette''; accessed August 25, 2016.\n\nUnder Bolger's leadership, Republicans retained their majority in the Michigan House while President  was re-elected by a 9.5 point margin in Michigan, and   was re-elected by a 20-point margin., PressandGuide.com; November 7, 2012.\n\nHe represented Michigan's 63rd legislative District, which included the eastern Kalamazoo County city of Galesburg and the townships of Brady, Charleston, Climax, Comstock, Kalamazoo, Pavilion, Richland, Ross and Wakeshma; as well as the central/southern Calhoun County city of Marshall, village of Athens, Burlington, Homer, Tekonsha and the townships of Athens, Burlington, Clarendon, Eckford, Emmett, Fredonia, Homer, Leroy, Marengo, Marshall, Newton and Tekonsha.State of Michigan , Michigan.gov; accessed August 25, 2016.\n\nAfter completing his term Speaker of the Michigan House of Representatives, Bolger founded a consulting firm, Tusker Strategies. In addition to his private sector work, Bolger was appointed in 2016 to serve on the  for a term ending December 31, 2024. The Commission is a bipartisan, four-member body, appointed by the governor of the state to regulate all conditions of employment for state employees. On April 27, 2023 Bolger was elected to serve as Chair of the Michigan Civil Service Commission.\n\n\nBolger was elected as House leader in 2011, during his time as Speaker numerous legislative packages that aided Michigan's recovery passed. Specifically, the Michigan House has passed legislation to cut duplicative regulation, as well as reforming the tax structure and pension systems. In addition to those initiatives, the Speaker has worked with Republicans statewide to pass right-to-work legislation and education reform measures. The Michigan House has also passed a balanced budget ahead of schedule all four years Bolger served as Speaker.State of Michigan (June 13, 2013). , Michigan.gov; accessed December 20, 2014.\n\n\nDuring Bolger's term as Speaker he achieved bipartisan support for education reform.House Roll Call, Tenure Reform (June 30, 2011).  ''Roll Call Votes''.House Roll Call, Tenure Reform (June 30, 2011).  ''Roll Call Votes''. Since 2011, the Michigan House of Representatives have passed numerous education reforms including tenure reform, expansion of cyber and charter school choices, teacher benefit reforms and early childhood development investment. During Bolger's first year as Speaker, the House passed tenure reform.Mack, Julie (July 15, 2011). , ''Kalamazoo Gazette''. Tenure reform in Michigan guaranteed students would not be left with an underperforming teacher or lose a teacher who is exceeding. Tenure reform made it easier for a school district to fire ineffective teachers, and banned the  approach previously utilized.\n\nIn addition to tenure reform, Bolger and the House passed legislation that expanded school choice options, guaranteeing more students access to cyber and charter schools; the legislation passed with bipartisan support.Murray, Dave (May 20, 2012). , MLive.com; accessed August 25, 2016. The school choice legislation gradually lifts the cap on charter schools authorized by universities and allows for more cyber school options.\n\nDuring the Speaker's term, teacher benefit reforms were also accomplished.Eggert, Dave (June 14, 2012).  ''MLive.com''. The legislation, which is described as the biggest change in the state's teacher retirement system in a generation, allows school districts to allocate less towards retirement pensions and more towards students. School district leaders have noted the change to retirement pension requirements have been a blessing, saying the separation allows school districts to spend more on school operations.Dickson, James and Darren Littell (February 6, 2014). , ''The Detroit News''. The reform also created the option for teachers to commit more towards their own retirement, or have the option for a smaller pension.\n\nThe Republican-led House under Bolger increased funding for early childhood development by $65 million in 2013 and again in 2014.Melot, Derek (January 9, 2013). , ''Bridge Magazine''; accessed December 20, 2014. The changes to funding for early childhood development have resulted in at least 16,000 more students being able to attend pre-k schooling.Dwyer, Dustin (May 28, 2013). , ''Michigan Public Radio''; accessed December 20, 2014. Regarding increased early childhood development funding Speaker Bolger said,\n\n\n\nThe Speaker's comments on early childhood funding were applauded by the Children's Leadership Council of Michigan.\n\n\nMichigan saw a sharp decline in the labor force starting in 2008 and lasting until 2011, which resulted in 800,000 jobs lost.Bureau of Labor Statistics  ''Bureau of Labor Statistics'';' accessed December 20, 2014. In 2009, Michigan's unemployment rate hit a record-high 14.2 percent.Oosting, Jonathan (March 5, 2014).  ''MLive.com.'' During that same period Michigan saw its population base shrink. In 2011, Bolger worked with Republicans in the house to pass tax, education and pension reform measures, and employers have responded positively to the changes. Since the reforms were passed in 2011, more than 300,000 jobs returned to the state. During Bolger's time as Speaker from 2011 through 2014, Michigan had the fifth highest job growth in the nation, and the state's unemployment rate decreased to 6.7 percent.Gantert, Tom (January 3, 2014). , ''Michigan Capitol Confidential''; accessed December 20, 2014.\n\n\nFrom 2008 until the end of 2010 under a Democrat controlled Michigan House of Representatives and Democratic Governor , Michigan's poverty rate rose from 14.4% in 2008 up to 17.5% in 2011.Mackinac Center for Public Policy (December 5, 2015). , Michigan Capitol Confidential; accessed December 6, 2015. When elected Speaker, Bolger stated it was the goal of Republican leaders to address our state's increasing poverty rate by creating more jobs. Specifically, Bolger stated \"it has to be all about job creation.\n\nAfter four years of Republican reforms led by Bolger, Governor  and former Senate Majority Leader , Michigan saw significant economic improvement with more than 300,000 jobs added to state's economy, which aided the state's poverty rate decrease. While Bolger was Speaker, Michigan's poverty rate declined each year since 2011, from a high of 17.5% down to 16.2% in 2014.\n\n\nIn 2012, Michigan became the nation's 24th  state.Bennet, William (December 13, 2012). , cnn.com; accessed December 20, 2012. Prior to passage, Speaker Bolger was the sole legislative leader who supported right-to-work when other Michigan Republicans were lukewarm on the idea.Clark, Zoe and Rick Pluta (February 21, 2014). , ''Michigan Public Radio Network.''Luke, Peter (January 13, 2011). , mlive.com; accessed December 20, 2014. The day Bolger was elected Speaker of the Michigan House of Representatives he stated that fellow Republicans should join him in reviewing the potential for right-to-work legislation. During Bolger's term as Speaker, right-to-work legislation was introduced and passed by the House on December 6, 2012.Mackinac Center , ''Michigan Capitol Confidential''; accessed December 20, 2014. The legislation was eventually signed by Governor  on December 11, 2012. Nearly six years after passage, workers in Michigan earn 8.06% less than the states that border Michigan and kept collective bargaining.\n\n\nBolger worked with Senate Majority Leader Randy Richardville and Governor Snyder to pass tax reform in the state. The tax overhaul was the largest in 17 years, and included eliminating the Michigan Business Tax, reforming the personal income and pension tax systems. The changes in corporate tax structure have resulted in Michigan improving its corporate tax business environment from an all-time low ranking of 49th up to seventh-best in the country. Under the new tax changes, Michigan has become a top state for venture capital projects with 312 new projects in 2013.Arend, Mark (March 2014).  ''Site Selection.''  The state ranks fifth in new project development, and 10th for projects per capita.\n\nAdditionally, Bolger and the House passed legislation to improve the personal property tax system in Michigan.Oosting, Jonathan (February 25, 2014).  ''MLive.com.'' The personal property tax legislation, which was championed by the Lieutenant Governor , allows for 100 percent reimbursement to municipalities and an 80 percent reduction in business taxes based on the previous system.\n\n\nWhen Bolger assumed his new role the state was facing a $1.8 billion budget deficit, noting the budget deficit was a concern Bolger worked with Republicans to balance the budget. Prior to becoming Speaker, Michigan saw annual budget shortfalls of $1.5 billion on average, as well as repeated government shutdowns.Bridge Magazine (July 12, 2013).  ''MLive.com'' In his first year as Speaker, Bolger, Senate Majority Leader  and Governor  worked to pass a budget which resulted in Michigan seeing a more than $450 million surplus.Davey, Monica (February 8, 2012).  ''New York Times.''\n\nIn each subsequent year the Michigan legislature has passed, and the governor has signed a balanced budget. In each of the past three years, Michigan has seen a surplus that has also helped replenish the state's Rainy Day Fund, which in 2011 had $2.2 million in reserves and now is projected to surpass $700 million in reserves for the 2014-15 fiscal year budget.Egan, Paul and Kathleen Gray (February 5, 2014).  ''Detroit Free Press.''\n\n\nSpeaker Bolger has stated that he plans to work with legislators on both sides of the aisle to assist Detroit in its .Riley, Rochelle (November 3, 2013).  ''Detroit Free Press.'' In October 2013, the Speaker visited Detroit with state Representative , a Democrat from Michigan's 9th house district, and pledged to explore ways to fight crime, lower auto insurance rates and clean up the city. After the visit Speaker Bolger met with the  to discuss alternatives to fighting crime, as well as discussing plans about alternative sentencing options with other legislators.\n\nAlso, since that visit the Speaker has worked with local Detroit representatives to garner support for scrap metal theft legislation and education reform. Recently, the Speaker proposed a change to Michigan's auto insurance laws, which would help reduce cost for Detroit's drivers; after promoting his proposal the Speaker met with Representatives  and Santana in an effort to create bi-partisan reform.\n\n\nIn May 2014, Bolger announced the formation of a special committee, House Committee on Detroit's Recovery and Michigan's Future, to help Detroit settle the largest municipal  in history while protecting Michigan taxpayers statewide.Oosting, Jonathan, , mlive.com, May 13, 2014; accessed January 17, 2015. Bolger was quoted as saying \"we are putting a strong team in place to resolve this difficult issue today with a vision for a bright future.\" The committee introduced legislation to help Detroit avoid further bankruptcy litigation by offering a $194.8 million lump sum to the city's retirement systems. In addition to the one-time contribution, legislation was passed to create an oversight commission to aid Detroit's recovery.\n\nThe Speaker also called on unions to make contributions to help in the Detroit settlement.Egan, Paul & John Gallagher, , freep.com, April 18, 2014; accessed January 17, 2015. Bolger requested unions to make a material contribution that is reflective of other parties involved in the settlement. Bolger's request did not come without opposition, the '''' issued an editorial claiming Governor  should convince Speaker Bolger to drop his demand or go around Bolger. The '''' editorialized that the union contribution demand was too much, and the likelihood of unions contributing would be slim. Other critics wrote that Bolger's demand would imperil the settlement. Bolger did receive support from conservative columnists and was urged to continue his demand. Bolger held firm to his request, and unions - the first was The Michigan Building and Construction Trades Council - did agree to make material contributions towards health care costs to help with the Detroit bankruptcy settlement.Oosting, Jonathan (May 19, 2014) , mlive.com; accessed March 3, 2015. After unions agreed to contribution money towards the settlement, the Michigan House passed legislation with major bipartisan support.Livengood, Chad & Gary Heinlein (May 22, 2014).  , detroitnews.com; accessed March 3, 2015.\n\nGovernor Snyder called the legislative package an opportunity to change the direction of Detroit. Upon passage, the ''Detroit News'' called the final legislative package a \"grand piece of work\", and the '''' opined that the deal showed that lawmakers \"get it\".\n\n\n\nOn June 13, 2012, Speaker Bolger allegedly refused to recognize now former Michigan state legislator  for a full service day after she used the term \"vagina\" during a floor debate over a bill (HB 5711) to further regulate abortion in the state.Peralta, Eyder (June 14, 2012). , npr.org; accessed December 20, 2014. Initially, Brown claimed she was denied the opportunity to speak due to religious discrimination, and then later claimed she was silenced for saying \"vagina.\"\n\nA spokesman for Bolger said that Brown was not allowed to give her opinion on a school employee retirement bill because when Brown said \"Mr. Speaker, I'm flattered that you're all are so interested in my vagina, but no means no\", she had violated the rules of the House and had \"failed to maintain the decorum of the House.\"\n\n\nIn 2012, Bolger worked with then-Democratic Michigan state Rep.  to switch parties at the filing deadline.Reens, Nate (May 15, 2012).  ''Grand Rapids Press''. Schmidt expressed dissatisfaction with what he called extreme party bosses in the Democratic party. Schmidt recruited a replacement for Democrats, 22-year-old Matt Mojzak, who did not mount a campaign, thus effectively leaving the Democrats without a viable candidate. With no serious Democratic candidate, Schmidt effectively ensured his victory as a Republican.Abbey-Lambertz, Kate (July 19, 2012). , HuffingtonPost.com; accessed December 20, 2014. Schmidt reportedly offered to pay Mojzak $450 to file as the Democratic challenger. Schmidt later upped the amount to $1,000 when Mojzak announced he was going to withdraw his candidacy.\n\nBolger exchanged text messages with Schmidt, which indicated he was involved in the Mojzak affair.Reens, Nate (July 18, 2012).  ''Grand Rapids Press''.Egan, Paul (July 18, 2012). . ''Detroit Free Press''; retrieved July 20, 2012. \nSeveral independent investigations and a grand jury review exonerated Bolger of breaking any rules. Ingham County Circuit Judge Rosemarie Aquilina wrote that an exhaustive and diligent probe uncovered no crime or wrongdoing, and that an indictment was not warranted.Eggert, Dave (August 9, 2013). , ''CBS Detroit''; accessed December 20, 2014. Kent County Prosecutor Bill Forsyth condemned the scheme as a travesty but could not file charges. Bolger authored an  in the '''' offering his apology to any offended voters and noted his error in judgment.Bolger, Jase (July 20, 2012). , freep.com; accessed December 20, 2014.\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''John Jay Carton''' (November 8, 1856August 26, 1934) was the  from 1901 to 1904.\n\n\nCarton was born on November 8, 1856, in , , to parents John and Ann Carton. Carton had 13 siblings. Carton was of Irish ancestry.\n\n\nCarton was admitted to the bar on August 21, 1844. He became legal partners with . Carton was sworn in to the  on January 4, 1899. He would serve until 1904, becoming Speaker of the Michigan House of Representatives in 1901. From 1907 to 1908, Carton was a delegate to Michigan state constitutional convention from the 13th district.\n\n\nCarton married Addie C. Pierson on November 22, 1898, in . Carton was a .\n\n\nCarton died on August 26, 1934, in , Genesee County, Michigan.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
