    "pages": }\n'''Rosalynn Bliss''' (born August 3, 1975) is an American politician, social worker, and mayor of . The first woman to be elected mayor of Michigan's second-largest city, Bliss took office on January 1, 2016. She has served on the Grand Rapids City Commission since 2006. Bliss is a member of the Democratic Party.\n\n\nBliss comes from a large family of six brothers and three sisters. Her father was a brickmason, while her mother worked at a local grocery store.\n\nBliss grew up in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan in Sault Ste. Marie and graduated from  in 1993. Shortly after, she moved to , where she attended the  earning a Bachelor of Arts degree in  and  in 1997.&nbsp;Upon graduation, she moved to Grand Rapids and began her career working at Hope Network while attending graduate school at . She earned her master's in  and professionally started working in the field of domestic violence and child welfare. Originally, Bliss wanted to be a meteorologist up until she took calculus class in college.\n\nToday, Bliss takes pride in being a part of the Grand Rapids community and is currently fighting for stronger neighborhoods as well as affordable housing. Bliss is also extremely active outside of her mayoral duties as she currently serves as the Frederik Meijer Endowed Chair in Entrepreneurship and Innovation in Grand Valley's Frederik Meijer Honors College.\n\nBliss is an active member of her community and loves the outdoors. Her favorite place is the Two Hearted River in the U.P. and she says that she would like to kayak the entire length of the Grand River one day. She also enjoys music festivals as well as listening to local musicians. She states that her favorite song is Cat Stevens' “Father & Son” from ''Tea for the Tillerman'' (1970).\n\n\nBliss formerly served as director of residential services at DA Blodgett-St. John's, which provides emergency shelter and residential services for abused and neglected children. She also served as adjunct professor of social work at  since 2006 and currently serves as the Frederik Meijer Endowed Chair in Entrepreneurship and Innovation in Grand Valley's Frederik Meijer Honors College.\n\nBliss is past president of the Michigan Municipal League, Kent County Land Bank Authority, Downtown Development Authority, Experience Grand Rapids and Grand Valley Metro Council, among many other organizations. She is a member of the West Michigan Environmental Leadership Network.\n\nIn 2016, Bliss released a list of priorities, which were to improve racial equity and community-police relations, strengthen local schools, reduce homelessness, increase affordable housing and grow the local economy.\n\n'''Housing'''\n\nBliss established the Housing Advisory Committee in 2016 and tasked it with coming up with recommendations to improve zoning ordinances and increase the city’s affordable housing supply. The city had eleven recommendations in which nearly all of them were approved throughout 2018 and 2019 time frame. The goals that resulted in this process were aimed to allow for reduce requirements for duplexes, accessory dwelling units, protect applicants against predatory application fees and create an affordable housing density bonus.\n\nIn her 2022 State of the City address, Bliss stated: \"A four percent growth rate means that we need to build not dozens, not hundreds of more homes, we need to build thousands of more homes as quickly as possible,\" noting that affordable housing is already on the way. \"We're currently tracking an additional 700 affordable new housing units in the development pipeline, and many of these units will be online and available in 2023.\"\n\n'''Economic goals'''\n\nBliss implemented a food truck ordinance for Grand Rapids. “That was an economic development issue because it’s an entry point for entrepreneurs who don’t have a significant amount of access to capital to open a brick and mortar,” Bliss said. \"Knowing that many entrepreneurs get their foot in the door through a food truck, I wanted to create that opportunity for folks in our community. She stated, “I also believe food trucks add to the vibrancy of a community.\"\n\n\nBliss was first elected to the Grand Rapids City Commission in 2005. She was re-elected in 2009 and 2013. During her time as a city commissioner, she led a Blue Ribbon Panel on Parks, was a founding member of the non-profit organization Friends of Grand Rapids Parks and served on the millage campaign for Parks, Pools and Playgrounds. She served on the Uptown Corridor Improvement District and was a part of the Fulton Street Farmers Market Redevelopment, among other neighborhood and community initiatives.\n\n, Mayor  was prohibited from seeking a fourth term. Bliss was one of four candidates who entered the race to succeed Heartwell; the others were , John George, and Willard Lee. A  was held on August 4, 2015; Bliss received 66% of the vote. Because she won a majority of the vote, Bliss was elected in the primary election without a need for a runoff election.\n\n\nBliss became the 59th mayor of Grand Rapids on January 1, 2016. She is the first woman to hold that role, as well as the youngest mayor in 130 years.\n\nBliss’s first words as mayor were in regards to George Hartwell, the previous mayor of Grand Rapids. She expressed her gratitude by saying, “I am standing on the shoulders of many great leaders who came before me.” During Bliss’s first term as mayor, she was joined on the commission by newcomers Jon O’Connor and David Allen who were both former school board members. As well as Ruth Kelly who was re-elected and library commissioners Rachel Anderson, James Botts and Sophia Brewer. |date=2015-12-18 |title=Rosalynn Bliss becomes Grand Rapids mayor |url=https://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/2015/12/rosalynn_bliss_becomes_grand_r.html |access-date=2022-12-09 |website=mlive |language=en}}\n\nDuring her inaugural State of the City speech, Bliss expressed her entire to-do list. This consisted of, “Foster racial equity, Provide more affordable housing. Enliven neighborhoods, Strengthen schools. Restore the Grand River’s rapids. Solve homelessness. Grow the local economy.”\n\n\nAnother major action Bliss took in her first term as mayor was she was able to work with city workers to begin getting them implicit bias training. Bliss strongly believed this was important as she states, “We must confront a difficult issue that has grown to an unacceptable proportion in our city…It starts with how the city government looks and how we think. We learn to honestly assess our own biases, and know how those biases impact others, specifically in how they result in denying opportunities for others.”\n\n\nDuring her first term as mayor, Bliss also chose to prioritize bettering police–community relations. She refers to the police force as the “canopy that covers our neighborhoods” and highly emphasizes the fact that a community and a police force would be stronger working together.\n\n\nBliss got fellow commissioners on board to create a fund that can be donated to local neighborhoods in order to fund projects. “This would create an innovative, creative way to empower people to come together to work on projects”.\n\n\nAt the beginning of Bliss’s mayoral term, she also urged colleagues to pass an ordinance in order to hold property owners accountable for blighted vacant properties. Bliss strongly believes that these vacant properties contribute to the lack of success in a neighborhood. “We can’t allow these properties to drag down neighborhoods like a diseased tree branch that, if left untrimmed, the disease spreads.”\n\n\nBliss also created a general plan for the Grand Rapids movement towards sustainability. Some goals were to provide a city park within walking distance of all the citizens, completely make the change to renewable energy throughout the entire city by 2025, increase recycling habits, increase the tree canopy to 40% throughout the city, and pave over 100 miles of bike lanes to stray away from the use of motor vehicles.\n\n\nMayor Bliss hopes to be able to restore the aesthetic and accessibility of the Grand River in the City of Grand Rapids. “Imagine being at Riverside Park and seeing rowing on the river, canoeing or kayaking through the city, and the eventual capacity to ride your bike on a 10-mile urban trail all along the river from Riverside Park to Millenium Park and beyond.” Like all other of the policies that Bliss will be focusing on, she really is hoping to bring the Grand Rapids community closer. She then went on to say, “These are realistic dreams. The groundwork has already started to restore our namesake – Grand Rapids.”\n\n\nShe won reelection on November 5, 2019. She defeated Daniel Schutte with over 83% of the vote. Bliss received 23,717 votes compared to Schutte, who only received 4,476 votes. For Bliss’s second mayoral run, her campaign fund totaled to $87,200 going into election week.\n\nOn the ballot for Bliss’s second election, voters also had the opportunity to vote for permanent parks millage which would ultimately create a fund for the city's public parks and pools.\n\nAs mayor, Bliss joined 130 US mayors launching a ten-minute walk to a park campaign. She was appointed by Governor Snyder to serve on the Child Lead Poisoning Elimination Board. She has been a proponent of  with the city, twice receiving gold certification from the Michigan Green Communities Network in the Michigan Green Communities Challenge for their work in approving a bicycle action plan, zero cities project, having a strategic plan with sustainability as a core value and converting the city's yard waste site to a composting facility. Bliss actively participated in the Living Cities Racial Equity Here initiative resulting in policy and budget process changes to incorporate a racial equity toolkit.\n\n\nDuring the COVID-19 pandemic Bliss made sure to keep in touch with her community. In her letter she states safety precautions that could be taken in order to protect those who could be highly affected by the pandemic. She also went on to express the fact that there were many services being offered throughout the city of Grand Rapids. She also urged citizens to stay informed on the latest updates and initial steps towards combatting the pandemic.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Derek E. Miller''' (born October 25, 1983) is the former Treasurer of . Previously, he was elected to the  in 2014 and served as an Assistant Prosecutor in Macomb County, a role he returned to in 2017. Miller is currently awaiting trial on charges related to public corruption in the Macomb County Prosecutor's Office.\n\n\n\nMiller has been an Assistant Prosecuting Attorney for . He has served as a trial attorney for the Prosecutor's Office in both Circuit and District Courts. He also held a position in the Senior Crimes Unit, which specializes in prosecuting criminals who prey on the elderly. He also served as his office's liaison to  and 's Drug Court and has served on the  39th District Sobriety Court. Prior to his career in law enforcement, Miller worked as a sole proprietor attorney. He received his bachelor's degree in  from  and Juris Doctor from the .\n\nHe was born and raised in Warren, where he graduated from  and continues to make his birth city and state of  home.\n\n\nAfter serving for four years in the Macomb County Prosecutor's Office Miller sought to succeed term-limited state Rep.  in the Michigan House of Representatives. Miller won the Democratic nomination uncontested and won the general election with ease, defeating Republican Beth Foster, taking 64 percent of the vote.\n\nOn December 5, 2015, Macomb County Treasurer Ted Wahby died at the age of 84, after being elected five times as treasurer and serving since 1995. After an extended search, Miller was appointed Macomb County Treasurer on January 29, 2016. Miller was sworn in as treasurer by   and formally resigned his seat in the state legislature on February 1, 2016. Miller won the Democratic nomination uncontested for a full-term on August 2, and was slated to face Republican Larry Rocca in the general election.\n\nMiller was narrowly upset by Rocca in his bid for a full term, in what many believe was on the coattails of Republican Presidential nominee . Trump garnered 54 percent of the vote in Macomb County, which also saw Republicans  and Karen Spangler win countywide races as Public Works Commissioner and County Clerk respectively and Trump became the first Republican to carry Michigan in a presidential election since 1988. Following the expiration of his term as County Treasurer, Miller returned to the Macomb County Prosecutor's Office as an assistant prosecutor.\n\n\nOn March 24, 2020,   charged Miller, Macomb County Prosecutor Eric Smith and two others with multiple felony counts related to embezzlement for allegedly misusing taxpayer funds for personal use. Miller is charged with official misconduct in office and conspiracy to commit a legal act in an illegal manner; both felonies with a maximum penalty of five-years in prison. Smith was charged with 10 felonies, including one count of running a criminal enterprise, which carries a maximum of 20-years in prison. Nessel's office alleged that Smith misused approximately $600,000 in funds from forfeiture accounts. Smith resigned as prosecutor on March 30, 2020, Miller was placed on paid administrative leave by Acting Macomb County Prosecutor Jean Cloud on April 3, 2020. Miller was formally arraigned via video conferencing on May 12, 2020, and was released on $100,000 personal recognizance bond.\n\n\nHis grandfather, Art Miller, became the first mayor of the city of Warren in 1957. His grandmother, Edna Miller, was the first woman elected Macomb County Clerk and served for over 28 years. Derek's father, Art Miller Jr., served in the  from 1977-2003, where he was the Democratic Leader of the Senate. He sponsored and directed over 300 pieces of legislation during his 25 years of Senate leadership. Art Miller Jr. died June 25, 2020, at the age of 73 due to an ongoing battle with lung cancer.\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Lauren Plawecki''' (born 1994) is an American politician from  who represented the which comprises the cities of  and , and parts of ,  and in the  after being  to fill the remaining two months of the term left vacant by the death of her mother, .\n\n\nPlawecki is a graduate of  in  and the  with a degree in Art History and has worked or interned at museums all over the world,  including the Palazzo Vecchio in Florence, the Guggenheim Museum in New York City and the Norton Simon Museum in California.\n\n\nPlawecki had never planned on following her mother's footsteps by entering politics. On June 25, 2016, Julie Plawecki was hiking out in  when she suddenly collapsed. Attempts to revive her proved unsuccessful and she was then pronounced dead. It is presumed she suffered a heart attack.\n\n  called a special election on July 5, 2016, to fill the remainder of Plawecki's term, with the special primary taking August 30 and the special general election to take place alongside the regularly scheduled general election on November 8, 2016. On July 6, 2016, Lauren was one of 11 Democrats that filed to be the Democratic nominee for her late mother's seat in the . Since Rep. Plawecki was slated to face no Democratic opposition in the August 2 primary, Democratic precinct delegates in the 11th House district would select the Democratic nominee for the November 8 general election. On July 7, 2016, Lauren Plawecki was not chosen to replace her mother.  , who at 20-years-old became the youngest ever Inkster City Councilman and is an undergraduate student at the , was chosen and will run unopposed in the Democratic primary on August 2.\n\nDespite not being chosen to run for the full two-year term, Lauren filed to run to finish her mother's remaining term. Since she was the lone Democrat to file for the seat (along with only one Republican filing for the seat, Robert Pope, an 85-year-old retired sheriff's deputy who was also running for the full two-year term against Jones), a primary was not necessary. Lauren won the special election, taking 65 percent of the vote and was sworn-in as a state representative on November 29, 2016.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Matthew Gillard''' (born March 9, 1973) is a politician from the  of .  He is a .  He formerly represented the  (), which is located in the north-eastern part of the state.  It includes , , , , , and  Counties.\n\n\nGillard was born to Joel and Donna Gillard on March 9, 1973. He went on to graduate from Alpena High School and received a Bachelor of Arts degree from , and a Juris Doctor from . He was an attorney in the firm of Gillard, Bauer, Mazrum, Florip, Smigelski, and Gulden until he was elected to the State House in 2002. He lives in  with his wife, Jessica, and four children.\n\n\nGillard was elected to the State House in 2002, to succeed outgoing Democratic representative .  He was the vice-chairman of the House Appropriations Committee and he chaired the Judiciary and School Aid and Education Subcommittees.  Gillard comfortably won reelections in 2004 and 2006.  Term limits prevented him from running for re-election in 2008.\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Aaron Thomas Bliss''' (May 22, 1837 – September 16, 1906) was an American  politician who served as a  and the 25th , and was from .   was named after him.\n\n\nBliss was born to Lyman and Anna M. (Chaffee) Bliss in  and attended the common schools.  He was employed as a clerk in a store in , in 1853 and 1854 and with the $100 he made there he attended a select school in , in 1854.  The following year, Bliss moved to Bouckville, a small town in , where he engaged in mercantile pursuits.\n\n\nDuring the , Bliss enlisted as a private in the Peterman Guards of the Tenth New York Volunteer Cavalry, October 1, 1861, and reported for duty at .  After a quick advancement to lieutenant, his regiment formed a part of  and was ordered to the front, joining the .  He commanded a squadron from Washington, D.C. during the  and his rank advanced to .  He also fought in the battle of , , , Ground Squirrel Church, , ,  and .  Then he was captured on General Wilson's raid near .  For six months he was held at the  prisons of , , , and , where on November 29, 1864, like the man who would later precede him as governor, , Bliss escaped from a Confederate prison.  He walked near three weeks until he reached  army at , just two days before its evacuation.  Bliss soon rejoined his own command at , where he remained until the war ended.\n\n\nIn December 1865, he moved to  and found employment at a shingle mill.  With his brother, Lyman W. Bliss, and J. H. Jerome, he formed A. T. Bliss & Company and engaged in the manufacture of  and the exploitation of lands along the Tobacco River.  On March 31, 1868, he married Allaseba Morey Phelps of Solsville, New York, north of the town of .  That same spring the brothers bought the Jerome mill at , and it became A. T. Bliss & Brother.  In 1880, Bliss was one of the organizers and a director of the Citizen's National Bank, which was reorganized into the Bank of Saginaw, and was president and director of the Saginaw County Savings Bank.\n\n\nIn 1882, Bliss was elected member of the  from Saginaw County (), and during that time helped establish a soldiers' home in .  He was appointed  on the staff of Governor  in 1885, with the rank of , and held the same position on the staff of the commander in chief of the  in 1888.\n\n\nIn 1888, Bliss was elected as a  from  to the , serving from March 4, 1889, to March 3, 1891.  Among notable bills he introduced were for appropriating $100,000 for a federal building in Saginaw and $25,000 for an Indian school at Mt. Pleasant.  He was an unsuccessful candidate for re-election in 1890 to the , being defeated by  .\n\nAfter leaving Congress, Bliss resumed the lumber business and also engaged in banking.  He was department commander of the Grand Army of the Republic in Michigan in 1897.\n\n\nIn 1900, Bliss was elected , defeating  , and was re-elected in 1902, serving from 1901 through 1904.  During his four years in office, the Michigan Employment Institution for the Adult Blind was established in Saginaw, a state highway department was formed, and railroad taxation was sanctioned.\n\n\nBliss was a patron of the Home for the Friendless, the Y.M.C.A., the Methodist Church and was also a member of the  and .\n\nBliss died less than two years after leaving office at the age of sixty-nine in , while on a visit for medical treatment.  He is interred in Forest Lawn Cemetery in .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n Retrieved on February 14, 2008\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n* ; .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Luren Dudley Dickinson''' (April 15, 1859 – April 22, 1943) was an American politician. He served as the 37th  from 1939 to 1941. He holds the record of the oldest person to ever serve as Michigan governor, beginning at the age of 79 and leaving office at the age of 81.\n\n\nDickinson was born in , son of Daniel Dickinson (1828–1903) and Hannah Elisabeth Dickinson (née Leavens; 1830–1916); as an infant his family moved to Michigan. In Michigan his family purchased land and undertook farming. As a boy Dickinson spent most of his time working on the family farm but by studying often at home he was able to complete high school and at the age of eighteen qualified to be a teacher. He was impressive as a teacher and thus moved up quickly becoming first  and then  of schools at the age of 21.  In 1888, he married Zora Della Cooley and they had one child by adoption - Rilla Ethel Patterson (née Dickinson), grandson Robert Patterson, and granddaughter Della Patterson, the latter would accompany the Governor while in office.\n\n\nDickinson's involvement in community schools sparked his interest in local politics. He joined the Republican Party, was elected to the  and served from 1897 to 1898 and from 1905 to 1908. He was then elected to the  and served from 1909 to 1910.\n\nAfter his one term in the State Senate, Dickinson was elected the 35th  in 1914 and later re-elected to this office. He would spend most of the rest of his political career as lieutenant governor, being elected to the post seven times and defeated three times (1924, 1932, and 1936). He was also an unsuccessful candidate in the Republican primary for governor in 1920 against , who was successful in the general election. Dickinson served as Lieutenant Governor under five governors: , 1915–17; , 1917–21; , 1927–29; , 1929–33; and , 1939.\n\n\nIn 1939, incumbent Governor  died suddenly in office and thus, a month short of Dickinson's 80th birthday, he became Governor of Michigan.\n\nAs governor, he spent much of his time conducting state business at his farm near  rather than at the state capital in . He was well known for his informal appearance and actions which included having his swearing in ceremony at his farm, dressing in modest clothing and continuing to undertake farm work during his term.  During his twenty one and a half months in office, a law was passed which made it mandatory for public school teachers to take an oath of loyalty to the government. Also during his term, gambling and open bars were contested and the  was activated for service in World War II.\n\nIn 1940, he ran for a full term but his campaigning was hampered due to the illness and later death of his wife. He lost the election to  .\n\n\nDickinson was a member of the  and .  He died two years after leaving office at the age of eighty-four in Charlotte and is buried at the Maple Hill Cemetery of that town.\n\n\n\n\n\n*  via web.archive.org \n* \n* , Michigan.gov\n* , stapor.com\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

He is a former  member of both houses of the  and a current member of the .\n\n\nDennis Olshove and his wife Fran were married in 1980. They have four children: Steven (Chelsea), Michael (Jenna), Marc, and Ryan.\n\n\nOlshove attended , a Catholic, college preparatory high school previously located in , , before moving to , in 1982. He went to  and has a B.A. in s.\n\n\nOlshove served in the  from 1991 to 1998. Since 1999, he has served in the . Olshove was first elected to serve in the  in 2002, and won re-election in 2006.     "pages": }\n\n'''Philip Aloysius Hart''' (December 10, 1912December 26, 1976) was an American lawyer and politician. A , he served as a  from  from 1959 until his death from cancer in Washington, D.C. in 1976. He was known as the \"Conscience of the Senate\". The  is named in his honor.\n\n\nThe grandson of Irish immigrants, Philip Hart was born in , to Philip Aloysius and Ann (née Clyde) Hart. His father was a banker who served as president of the Bryn Mawr Trust Company. He received his early education at , and then attended .\n\nHart studied at  in Washington, D.C., where he was the student body president and an award-winning debater. He received a Bachelor of Arts degree '''' from Georgetown in 1934. In 1937, he received a  degree from the  at .\n\nIn June 1943, Hart married , the daughter of . Her father was by then a philanthropist and had owned the . Jane was an aviator who was the first female helicopter pilot in Michigan. She later qualified in the 1960s as one of the  group. The couple met through her brother, who was Hart's roommate at Georgetown. They have four surviving sons and four daughters. Hart's namesake, Philip Jr., died as a toddler. He was buried in a family plot, followed decades later by his father nearby.\n\n\nHart was admitted to the  in 1938 and became an associate in the Detroit firm of Beaumont, Smith & Harris. During , he served in the  as a  with the  (1941–1946). He was wounded during the   on  when shrapnel from an exploding artillery shell damaged the inside of his right arm. Following the war, he returned to Michigan and recovered at the  in . There he became acquainted with fellow veterans  and , both also future U.S. senators. He was decorated with the  with clusters, , , and .\n\nIn 1946, Hart returned to Detroit and entered the general law practice of Monaghan, Hart & Crawmer. He became politically active in the Democratic Party and, from 1949 to 1951, he served as Michigan's Corporation Securities Commissioner, a political appointee position. His duties included the approving of stock issues of corporations in the state, licensing real estate brokers and builders, and collecting real estate taxes. In 1951 Hart was appointed as state director of the Office of Price Stabilization, serving for a year. For his work in that office, he was named Outstanding Federal Administrator of the Year in 1952 by the Federal Business Association.\n\nIn 1952, he was appointed as , serving for one year. He next served from 1953 to 1954 as legal adviser to  , a former law school classmate.\n\nIn 1954, Hart ran for electoral office, elected as the 51st , on a ticket with Governor Williams. He served two terms, until 1959. His re-election in 1956 made him the first Democrat in Michigan to serve two terms as lieutenant governor.\n\n\n  and President  in the , 1961]]\nHart  as a Democrat to the United States Senate in the Democratic wave election of 1958, defeating one-term incumbent Republican  by a 54% to 46% margin. He was reelected by overwhelming margins  and . (His 1970 opponent was former  .) Some conservatives in Michigan attempted to  Hart from office for his stands on  and busing for racial integration, with bumper stickers reading \"Recall cures Hart attacks,\" but the  does not authorize the recall of elected federal officials, and Hart was strongly re-elected by supporters.\n\nHart was the chief Senate sponsor of the , also known as the Hart-Celler Act, which ended the discriminatory quotas that restricted immigration from most of the world since 1924.\n\nHart died in office. He had announced his intention not to run for re-election in June 1976 and was diagnosed with cancer a month later. The same year, the Senate voted to name its new  after him, the . It would have been the first federal government building named after someone still living. The vote was 99-0, with Hart abstaining. He died of  a few days later, just before his term would have expired, and he would have retired. , who had just been elected to the seat for the next term, was named to fill Hart's seat for the remaining days of the congressional session.\n\nHart is interred in St. Anne's Catholic Cemetery on  in a family plot near his namesake son, who died as a toddler.\n\n\n*In 1982, the , the third to be constructed, was officially dedicated and named for him.\n*Other buildings named after Hart include the  in ; the  along the ; the Philip A. Hart Visitor Center of the Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore in Empire, Michigan;  in ; and the Hart-Kennedy House in , the headquarters of the .\n*The Philip Hart Memorial Scholarship was established at  in  as a full scholarship, to be awarded to a student who exemplifies the ideals and goals of the Senator.\n*The  room at  is named in his honor.\n*The visitor center at  is named after Hart, who first introduced the bill in Congress to establish the park in 1961. \n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* O'Brien, Michael. ''Philip Hart: The Conscience of the Senate''. East Lansing: Michigan State University Press, 1995. .\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Woodrow Stanley''' (June 12, 1950 – February 15, 2022) was an American  politician. He was mayor of  from 1991 until his recall in 2002, and was a member of the  from  from 2009 to 2014.\n\n\nStanley was born in , on June 12, 1950. He attended and graduated from . He then attended  earning a bachelor's degree in political science. At , he had done additional course work towards a Masters of Public  Administration.\n\n\nIn 1983, Stanley was appointed to the Flint City Council representing the 2nd ward being reelected until his election to the office of Mayor of the City of Flint defeating the incumbent .  Stanley was elected to three terms as Mayor defeating (in order) future mayor  (1995) and City Councilor Scott Kincaid (1999).   He was  in 2002 due to the city's shaky financial condition and a state appointed Financial Manager was appointed after he left office.  In  2004, Stanley was elected to the Genesee County Board of Commissioners, 2nd District.  In his second term as Commissioner, Stanley was selected to be chairman of the Board of Commissioners.\nIn November 2008, Stanley was elected to the Michigan House of Representatives from the 34th District.\n\n\nStanley died at  in Flint on February 15, 2022, at the age of 71.\n\n\n;Mayoral Elections Results\n\n;State Representative Election Results\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Carolyn Jean Cheeks Kilpatrick''' (born June 25, 1945) is a former American politician who was  for  and then  from 1997 to 2011. She is a member of the .  In August 2010 she lost the Democratic primary election to , who replaced her in January 2011 after winning the . Kilpatrick is also the mother of former Detroit Mayor .\n\n\n\nBorn Carolyn Jean Cheeks in , she graduated from Detroit High School of Commerce. She then attended  in  from 1968 to 1970 and earned a  from  () in 1972. She earned a  from the  in 1977. She worked as a high school teacher and was later a member of the  from 1979 to 1996.\n\n\n\n\n*''''''\n**\n\n\n*Canada-United States Inter-Parliamentary Group\n*\n*\n\nShe was one of the 31 House Democrats who voted not to count the 20 s from  in the . Republican President George Bush won the state by 118,457 votes.\n\nOn December 6, 2006, the  unanimously chose Kilpatrick as its chairwoman for the  (2007-8).\n\nOn September 29, 2008, she voted against the . \n\n\n\nIn 1996, Kilpatrick challenged three-term incumbent  in the 1996 Democratic primary for what was then the 15th District.  She defeated Collins by a shocking margin, taking 51.6 percent of the vote to Collins' 30.6 percent.  This was  in this heavily Democratic, black-majority district.  She was reelected six times, never dropping below 80 percent of the vote.  Her district was renumbered as the 13th District after the 2000 Census.  She faced no major-party opposition in 2004 and was completely unopposed in 2006.\n\n\n\nHer first serious opposition came during the 2008 primarythe real contest in this districtwhen she was challenged by both former   and   in the Democratic primary. Kilpatrick's campaign was plagued by the controversy surrounding her son and his involvement in a text messaging sex scandal. On the August 5 primary election, Kilpatrick won with 39.1 percent of the vote, compared to Waters' 36 percent and Scott's 24 percent.\n\n\n\nIn 2010, she was again challenged in the Democratic primary.  Unlike in 2008, her opposition coalesced around State Senator , who defeated her in the August 3 primary. “This is the final curtain: the ending of the Kilpatrick dynasty,” said Detroit political consultant Eric Foster of Foster, McCollum, White and Assoc.\n NPR and CBS News both noted that throughout her re-election campaign, she was dogged by questions about her son, , who is in prison on numerous corruption charges. ''Michigan Live'' reported that her election defeat could in part be attributed to the Kwame Kilpatrick scandals.\n\n\nKilpatrick was married to Bernard Nathaniel Kilpatrick, with whom she has daughter Ayanna and son , a former Mayor of . Carolyn Cheeks Kilpatrick divorced Bernard Kilparick in 1981. She has six grandsons including two sets of twins and two granddaughters. Both her former husband and son were on trial, under an 89-page felony indictment.  On March 11, 2013, her son was found guilty on 24 of 30 federal charges and her former spouse was found guilty on 1 of 4 federal charges.\n\n* She is a member of the Detroit Substance Abuse Advisory Council.\n* She is a member of  sorority\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*\n* at ''Michigan Liberal''\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

He was previously mayor of  and a member of the  Commission. McMillin graduated from the  in 1987 with a bachelor's degree in economics and accounting. He is a certified public accountant. In 2009, McMillin was of the most conservative politicians in Michigan, having defeated a Royal Oak gay rights ordinance and supporting a county commission resolution defining marriage as a union between a man and a woman.\n\nMcMillin was the Honorary Chairman of Concerned Taxpayers of Michigan, a ballot question committee opposing a proposal to raise state taxes on the May 5, 2015 ballot.\n\nMcMillin was elected Chairman of the 8th Congressional District Republican Committee of Michigan on February 20, 2015.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*  – article in Detroit Free Press\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Irma Clark-Coleman''' (born April 14, 1937) is a politician from the  of . She was a  member of the , representing the  from 2003 to 2010. Previously she was a member of the  from 1999 to 2002. \n\n\nClark-Coleman attended Detroit Public Schools and holds a B.A. and M.A. in communications from . Beginning in 1967, Clark-Coleman held a variety of positions in  government; starting as a stenographer, and eventually serving as assistant director for Public Information to the county Road Commission, Media Relations Manager for Wayne County Executive , Press Secretary to County Executive  and Director of Human Relations. Clark Coleman retired from Wayne County in 1998.\n\n\nClark-Coleman is married to Rev. Ron D. Coleman, Sr., pastor of God Land Unity Church. Clark-Coleman has two children.\n\n\nIn 1991, Clark-Coleman was appointed to the  - and served in that capacity until 1998. Clark-Coleman served as the board's vice president and president (1996–1998).\n\nClark-Coleman was elected to the  () in 1998 - and re-elected in 2000. In 2002, she was elected to the  - and re-elected in 2006. Clark-Coleman served on the Senate Appropriations Committee. Under the term limits provisions of , Clark-Coleman was barred from seeking re-election in 2010.\n\n\n*'''2006 election for Michigan State Senate - Michigan 3rd District'''\n\n::\n\n*'''2006 election for Michigan State Senate - Michigan 3rd District (Democratic primary)'''\n\n::\n\n*'''2002 election for Michigan State Senate - Michigan 3rd District'''\n\n::\n\n*'''2002 election for Michigan State Senate - Michigan 3rd District (Democratic primary)'''\n\n::\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n* profile\n*''Follow the Money'' - Irma Clark-Coleman\n**  campaign contributions\n* campaign finance reports and data\n* campaign finance reports and data\n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''John James Conyers Jr.''' (May 16, 1929October 27, 2019) was an American politician of the  who served as a  from  from 1965 to 2017. Conyers was the  and the longest-serving African American member of Congress in history.\n\nAfter serving in the , Conyers became active in the . He also served as an aide to Congressman  before winning . He co-founded the  in 1969 and established a reputation as one of the most  members of Congress. Conyers joined the  after it was founded in 1991. Conyers supported creation of a  system and sponsored the . He also sponsored a bill to establish  as a federal holiday, and was the first congressperson to introduce  in support of  for the descendants of  slavery.\n\nConyers ran for  in 1989 and 1993, but he was defeated in the primary both times.\n\nConyers served as the  on the  from 1995 to 2007 and again from 2011 to 2017. He served as chairman of that committee from 2007 to 2011 and as chairman of the  from 1989 to 1995. As the longest-serving current member of Congress, Conyers was the  from 2015 to 2017. By November 2017, he was the last remaining member of Congress who had served since the . In the wake of allegations that he had sexually harassed female staff members and secretly used taxpayer money to settle a harassment claim, Conyers resigned from Congress on December 5, 2017.\n\n\n\nConyers was born and raised in Detroit, the son of Lucille Janice (Simpson) and John James Conyers, a labor leader. Among his siblings was younger brother William Conyers. After graduating from , Conyers served in the  from 1948 to 1950; the  from 1950 to 1954; and the  from 1954 to 1957. Conyers served for a year in Korea during the  as an officer in the  and was awarded combat and merit citations.\n\nAfter his active military service, Conyers pursued a college education. He earned both his  (1957) and  (1958) degrees from . After he was admitted to the bar, he worked on the staff of Congressman . He also served as counsel to several Detroit-area . From 1961 to 1963, he was a referee for Michigan's workmen's compensation department.\n\nConyers became one of the leaders of the civil rights movement. He was present in , on October 7, 1963, for the voter registration drive known as Freedom Day.\n\n\n\n\nIn 1964, Conyers ran for an open seat in what was then the 1st District, and defeated Republican Robert Blackwell with 84% of the vote. He was reelected 13 times with even larger margins. After the , Michigan lost a congressional district, and there was redistricting. Conyers's district was renumbered as the .\n\n\nIn 1992, Conyers won re-election to his 15th term in his new district, which included western suburbs of Detroit, with 82% of the vote against Republican nominee John Gordon. He won re-election another nine times after that. His worst re-election performance was in , when he got 77% of the vote against Republican nominee . In 2013, his district was renamed as the .\n\nIn total, Conyers won re-election twenty-five times and was serving in his twenty-sixth term. He was the  as longest-serving current member, the , and the . He was the second-longest serving member of either house of Congress in Michigan's history, trailing only his former boss, Dingell. He was also the last member of the large Democratic freshman class of 1964 who was still serving in the House.\n\nIn May 2014, Wayne County Clerk Cathy Garrett determined that Conyers had not submitted enough valid nominating petition signatures to appear on the August 2014 Primary Election ballot. Two of his workers circulating petitions were not themselves registered voters at the time, which was required under Michigan law. But on May 23, Federal District Judge Matthew Leitman issued an injunction placing Conyers back on the ballot, ruling that the requirement that circulators be registered voters was similar to an Ohio law which had been found unconstitutional in 2008 by a Federal appeals court. The Michigan Secretary of State's office subsequently announced they would not appeal the ruling.\n\n\n\nConyers was one of the 13 founding members of the  (CBC) and was considered the Dean of that group. Formed in 1969, the CBC was founded to strengthen African American lawmakers' ability to address the legislative concerns of Black and minority citizens. He served longer in Congress than any other African American. In 1971, he was one of the original members of .\n\nIn 1965, Conyers won a seat as a freshman on the influential , which was then chaired by Democratic Congressman  of New York. The assignment was considered an elite one, as Judiciary ranked behind only  and  in terms of the number of Members who sought assignment there.\n\n in 1993]]\nAccording to the '''', Conyers has been considered, with , , , and , to be one of the most  members of Congress for many years. , known for her prominent role in the , moved to Detroit and served on Conyers's staff between 1965 and 1988.\n\nConyers was known to have opposed regulation of . He opposed the . After the  in 1968, Conyers introduced the first bill in Congress to make King's birthday a federal holiday. He continued to propose legislation to establish the federal holiday in every session of Congress from 1968 to 1983, when  was finally  by President .\n\nIn 1983 he joined with 7 other congressional representatives to sponsor a resolution to  over his sudden and unexpected .\n\nAccording to ''The New Republic'', Conyers was a member of the  in 1983.\n\nConyers introduced the \"Commission to Study Reparation Proposals for African Americans Act\" () in January 1989. He re-introduced this bill each congressional term. It calls for establishing a commission to research the  of  and its effects on current society, which is to recommend ways to remedy this injustice against African Americans. The current version was introduced and referred to committee on January 3, 2013. Conyers first introduced the proposed resolution in 1989, and has stated his intention to annually propose this act until it is approved and passed. Since 1997, the bill has been designated \"H.R. 40\", most recently, , alluding to the promise of \"\". If passed, the commission would explore the longstanding effects of slavery on today's society, politics, and economy.\n}}\n\nConyers served as the ranking Democratic member on the House Committee on the Judiciary from 1995 to 2007 and again from 2011 to 2017. He served as chairman of that committee from 2007 to 2011 and as chairman of the House Oversight Committee from 1989 to 1995. As the longest-serving current member of Congress, Conyers was the dean of the House of Representatives from 2015 to 2017.\n\nIn March 2016, Rep. Conyers and Representative  introduced legislation to protect consumers' access to civil courts. The bill was entitled the \"Restoring Statutory Rights Act\".\n\nConyers served more than 50 years in Congress, becoming the ; he was the longest-serving African American member of Congress. By November 2017, Conyers was the last remaining member of Congress who had served since the .\n\n\n\nConyers was critical of President  during his tenure. He was listed as number 13 on President  during the president's 1969–74 presidential tenure. The president's Chief Counsel described him as \"coming on fast\", and said he was \"emerging\" as a \"black anti-Nixon spokesman\". Conyers, who voted to  in July 1974, wrote at the time,\n\n}}\n\n\n\nConyers submitted the  (Expanded and Improved Medicare for All Act) (H.R. 676); as of 2015, it had 49 cosponsors. He introduced it with 25 cosponsors, in 2003, and reintroduced it each session since then. The act calls for the creation of a universal  system in the United States, in which the government would provide every resident health care free of charge. To eliminate disparate treatment between richer and poorer Americans, the Act would prohibit private insurers from covering any treatment or procedure already covered by the Act.\n\n\nConyers was one of the  who prosecuted the in case the  of Judge . Hastings was found guilty by the  and removed from his federal judgeship.\n\n\n\nOn May 5, 2005, Conyers and 88 other members of Congress wrote an open letter to the White House inquiring about the . This was a leaked memorandum that revealed an apparent secret agreement between the Bush administration and the  to  in 2002. '''', among the first to publish news of the leak, wrote that the discovered documented revealed the intentions of Bush and  to invade Iraq, along with revealing that the two had \"discussed creating pretextual justifications for doing so.\"\n\nThe memo story broke in the United Kingdom, but did not receive much coverage in the United States. Conyers said: \"This should not be allowed to fall down the memory hole during wall-to-wall coverage of the  and a .\" Conyers and others reportedly considered sending a congressional investigation delegation to London.Tony Allen-Mills and Tom Pattinson, \"\", ''The Times'', May 22, 2005.\n\n\n\nIn May 2005, Conyers released a report about  in the state of  during the  called ''What Went Wrong in Ohio: The Conyers Report On The 2004 Presidential Election''. The report included the following claims:\n* Too few voting machines in Kerry-voting wards, leading to long queues. A ''Washington Post'' piece exemplified , where wards with many machines per voter mostly had Bush majorities, and wards with relatively few machines per voter were typically in favor of Kerry. The numbers disenfranchised statewide were in the tens of thousands or hundreds of thousands of voters.\n*   made a decision to limit provisional ballots, leading to the estimated disenfranchisement of tens or hundreds of thousands of voters.\n* Voter turnout for minorities was suppressed by  targeting 35,000 of these voters, and \"challenging\" tactics were used to intimidate voters and cause longer lines.\n* Where absentee ballots were not issued in time, provisional ballots were not permitted, affecting thousands or tens of thousands, especially seniors. The order from Ken Blackwell to do this was found illegal by a federal court, violating the .\n* Improper voter purges and registration errors disenfranchised at least 10,000 voters, likely tens of thousands statewide.\n* 93,000 spoiled ballots where no vote was cast for president, including undervote rates as high as 25% in some counties, from people who likely stood in line.\n* Statistical abnormalities in the differences between  results and actual votes registered at those locations.\n* Issues of faulty  machines, such as over 24 electronic machines in  transferring an indeterminate quantity of votes into the Bush column and out of the Kerry column.\n* In , public observers were prevented from viewing the vote counting, due to specious claims that a terrorist threat had been called by the . The FBI stated it gave no such warnings.\n* Little-known s got twenty times more votes than would be expected in .\n* Voter turnout of a suspiciously-high 98.55% in .\n* Provisional ballots being rejected due to lack of guidance on how to process. In once case, about 8,000 of the 24,000 provisional ballots were rejected.\n* Cheat sheets were handed out by a voting machine manufacturer to the election officials, giving guidance on how to avoid doing a hand-recount in the face of anomalies.\n\nWhile some courts before the election found that certain restrictive voting policies of Ohio Secretary of State Ken Blackwell were illegal, claims of voter and machine fraud swaying the election have not achieved mainstream acceptance, and several have been refuted.\n\nConyers was one of 31 members of the House who voted not to count the 20  from  in the . The state was won by Republican President George Bush by 118,457 votes.\n\n\n\n\n in Newark, New Jersey, in 2007]]\n\nOn August 4, 2006, Conyers released his report, ''The Constitution in Crisis: The Downing Street Minutes and Deception, Manipulation, Torture, Retributions and Cover-ups in the Iraq War'', an edited collection of information intended to serve as evidence that the  altered  to justify the .\n\n''The Constitution in Crisis'' examines much of the evidence presented by the Bush administration prior to the invasion and questions the credibility of their sources of intelligence. In addition, the document investigates conditions that led to the  at  in Iraq, as well as further evidence of  having been committed but not made known to the public. Finally, the document reports on a series of \"smear tactics\" purportedly used by the administration in dealing with its political adversaries. The document calls for the  of President  and Vice President . Conyers refused to back  proceedings, however.\n\n\n\nConyers proposed House Resolution 288, which condemns \"religious intolerance\" and emphasizes  as needing special protection from acts of violence and intolerance. It states that \"it should never be official policy of the United States Government to disparage the , Islam, or any religion in any way, shape, or form,\" and \"calls upon local, State, and Federal authorities to work to prevent  and acts against all individuals, including those of the Islamic faith.\" The bill was referred to the House subcommittee on the Constitution in June 2005.\n\nIn 2005, Conyers introduced House Resolution 160, a house resolution that would have condemned the conduct of , then the  of the  in India. The resolution was cosponsored by Republican Representative  (Republican of Pennsylvania). The resolution's title was: \"Condemning the conduct of Chief Minister Narendra Modi for his actions to incite religious persecution and urging the United States to condemn all violations of .\" The resolution cited a 2004  report on Modi stating that he was \"widely accused of being reluctant to bring the perpetrators of the killings of Muslims and non-Hindus to justice\". (See .) The resolution was not adopted.\n\n\n\n\n\nIn April 2006 Conyers, together with ten other senior , filed an action in the , challenging the constitutionality of the . The complaint alleged the  was not afforded due consideration by the  before being signed by the President. The action was subsequently dismissed on grounds of lack of .\n\n\n\nIn April 2006, the  and the U.S. Attorney's office sent independent letters to the , saying two former aides of Conyers had alleged that Conyers used his staff to work on several local and state campaigns of other politiciansincluding for the . (She won a seat in 2005.) He also forced them to baby-sit and chauffeur his children.\n\nIn late December 2006, Conyers \"accepted responsibility\" for violating House rules. A statement issued December 29, 2006, by the House Ethics Committee chairman  and Ranking Minority Member , said Conyers acknowledged what he characterized as a \"lack of clarity\" in his communications with staff members regarding their official duties and responsibilities, and accepted responsibility for his actions.\n\nIn deciding to drop the matter, Hastings and Berman said:\n. Retrieved May 10, 2017.}}\n\n\n\nConyers repeatedly introduced the , a bill that would overturn the , an  of the . Conyers's bill would forbid the government from mandating that federally funded research be made freely available to the public. The legislation was supported by the publishing industry, and opposed by groups such as the . Writers  and  accused Conyers of being influenced by publishing houses, who have contributed significant money to his campaigns.\n\n\n\nOn January 13, 2009, the House Committee on the Judiciary, led by Conyers, released ''Reining in the Imperial Presidency: Lessons and Recommendations Relating to the Presidency of George W. Bush'', a 486-page report detailing alleged abuses of power that occurred during the , and a comprehensive set of recommendations to prevent recurrence. Conyers introduced a bill to set up a \"truth commission\" panel to investigate alleged policy abuses of the Bush administration.\n\n\n\nIn late July 2009, Conyers, commenting on the  in the , stated: \"I love these members, they get up and say, 'Read the bill'... What good is reading the bill if it's a thousand pages and you don't have two days and two lawyers to find out what it means after you read the bill?\" His remark brought criticism from  advocates such as the , which referred to readthebill.org in response.\n\n\n\nIn October, Conyers responded to allegations from four Republican Congress Members, in the wake of the launch of the book '''', that the  (CAIR) sought to plant Muslim \"spies\" in . He strongly opposed the accusations, saying:\n\nand the responsibilityto participate in our political process, including by volunteering to work in Congressional offices. Numerous Muslim-American interns have served the House ably and they deserve our appreciation and respect, not attacks on their character or patriotism.}}\n\n\n\nAt a December 16, 2010, hearing of the  on the subject of \"the  and the Legal and  Issues Raised by \", Conyers \"argue[d] strongly against prosecuting WikiLeaks in hasteor at all.\"Elliott, Justin (December 16, 2010)  , '''' He strongly defended the  organization, saying:\n... [L]et us not be hasty, and let us not legislate in a climate of fear or prejudice. For, in such an atmosphere, it is our  freedoms and our cherished  that are the first to be sacrificed in the false service of our .}}\n\nConyers's statement was \"in marked contrast to the repeated calls from other members of  and  officials to prosecute WikiLeaks head  immediately.\"\n\n\n\nIn 2014, Conyers, along with , introduced a bipartisan amendment to the  which would prohibit the  from providing any form of  assistance to the , a  unit accused by Conyers of being a \"far-right  militia\". The amendment was subsequently passed by the House of Representatives in 2015. Conyers' decision to introduce the amendment was the subject of both praise and criticism, with detractors noting that claiming that large numbers of  are members of the Azov Battalion is a common theme of .\n\nConyers stated, \"If there's one simple lesson we can take away from U.S. involvement in conflicts overseas, it's this: Beware of unintended consequences. As was made vividly clear with U.S. involvement in  during  decades ago, overzealous military assistance or the hyper-weaponization of conflicts can have destabilizing consequences and ultimately undercut our own national interests.\" He also voiced concerns about sending  to .\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 2015, a former employee of Conyers alleged that he had sexually harassed her and dismissed her. She filed an affidavit with the . Conyers had entered into a confidentiality agreement with the former employee and had paid her a $27,000 (~$}} in ) settlement from his publicly funded office budget in 2015. '''' reported on the allegations and settlement on November 20, 2017; ''Buzzfeed'' also reported allegations that Conyers \"repeatedly made sexual advances to female staff,\" caressed female staffers' hands in a sexual manner, and rubbed their backs and legs in public.... reportedly settled a wrongful dismissal complaint in 2015 after a former employee accused him of firing her for resisting his 'sexual advances'... Conyers's office did not immediately respond to a request for comment from The Hill.}}\n\nOn November 21, 2017, Conyers issued a statement in which he said, \"In our country, we strive to honor this fundamental principle that all are entitled to due process. In this case, I expressly and vehemently denied the allegations made against me, and continue to do so. My office resolved the allegationswith an express denial of liabilityin order to save all involved from the rigors of protracted litigation.\"\n\nAlso on November 21, 2017, the House Ethics Committee launched an investigation into multiple sexual harassment allegations against Conyers.\n\nOn November 22, 2017, '''' reported that , founder of  (CREW), publicly accused Conyers of having harassed and verbally abused her during her tenure working for the House Judiciary Committee. On one occasion, Sloan alleged that Conyers had summoned to his office, where she found him sitting in his underwear; she quickly departed.\n\nLater in November 2017, there were reports that another woman accused Conyers of sexual harassment. House Minority Leader , who had initially stated that Conyers was an \"icon\" and had done a great deal to protect women, called upon Conyers to resign. She said the allegations against him were \"very credible\".\n\nOn December 5, 2017, aged 88, Conyers resigned his House seat because of his mounting sexual scandals. The announcement came the day after another former staffer released an affidavit accusing Conyers of sexual harassment. The same day, an article by ''The Washington Post'' published allegations by Courtney Morse that Conyers had threatened her with a similar fate to that of , a staffer found murdered in a park in Washington, DC. She said that after she rejected his advances, he \"said he had insider information on the case. I don't know if he meant it to be threatening, but I took it that way.\"\n\nAt a time when the  was pushing for action against men who harassed women, some media and supporters in Detroit believed Conyers had been unfairly treated. He was reported as the \"first sitting politician to be ousted from office in the wake of the #MeToo movement.\"\n\n\n\n in 1971]]\n* Founding Member and Dean of the \n* \n* \n* \n* Out of Afghanistan Caucus (Co-chair)\n* Congressional Full Employment Caucus\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\nWhile serving in the U.S. House, Conyers made two unsuccessful runs for : one in 1989 against incumbent  and again in 1993.\n\n\n\nIncumbent Democratic Mayor Coleman Young decided to run for a fifth term, despite growing unpopularity and the declining economy of Detroit. In the September primary, Young won with 51% of the vote. Accountant Tom Barrow qualified for the November run-off by having 24%, and Conyers received 18% of the vote. Despite the difficulties of the city, Young defeated Barrow in the run-off with 56% of the vote.\n\n\n\nIn June 1993, incumbent Democratic Mayor Coleman Young decided to retire instead of seeking a sixth term, citing his age and health. Many observers believed he had decided not to test his growing unpopularity. In a '''' poll in February, 81% said Young should retire. Conyers was one of the 23 candidates who qualified for ballot access.\n\n was the front runner in the mayoral campaign from the beginning. The 51-year-old former  raised over $1.6million to finance his campaign. He won the September primary with 54% of the vote. Conyers came in fourth place. Archer won the November election.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nConyers married , a teacher in Detroit, in 1990. She was 25 and he was 61; they had two sons together, John James III and Carl Edward Conyers. Monica Conyers served as vice administrator of Detroit's public schools, and in 2005 was elected to the Detroit City Council. Monica Conyers pleaded guilty to bribery charges on June 26, 2009 and served slightly more than 27 months in prison; her sentence was completed on May 16, 2013. In September 2015, Monica Conyers filed for divorce, citing a \"breakdown of the marriage\". However, the Conyerses reconciled in late 2016.\n\nConyers's grandnephew, , was elected to the  in 2016. He generated controversy by telling of Conyers's planned retirement in interviews before the Congressman announced it himself, and claiming his great-uncle's endorsement. Following the Congressman's resignation, Ian Conyers announced that he would run in the special election for the Congressman's seat. The Congressman instead endorsed his son, John Conyers III, as his successor. John Conyers III chose not to run. Ian Conyers was defeated in the Democratic primary by .\n\n\nConyers died at his home in Detroit on October 27, 2019, at the age of 90. His funeral was held on November4 at Detroit's Greater Grace Temple.\n\n\n\nIn 2007, Conyers was awarded the  from the .\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*  at \n*  at The National Visionary Leadership Project\n* \n*  movement co-founded by John Conyers and Linda Grover\n* \n;Articles\n*  Congressman John Conyers Jr.,  (October 15, 2003)\n*  (prepared at the request of Congressman John Conyers, January 5, 2005)\n*  (originally signed by 89 U.S. Congress members), John Conyers, et al.     "pages": }\n\n'''Darrin Quiroz''' '''Camilleri''' (born January 28, 1992) is an American politician from  who represents the  in the  since 2023. He previously represented the  in the . A member of the , his constituency includes several  communities, including , , , ,  and .\n\n\nCamilleri was born in , to a  immigrant father and a second-generation  mother. He is the oldest of three children. After graduating from  in , he pursued a Bachelor of Arts degree in political science and government from , which he received in 2014.\n\n\nDuring his undergraduate studies, Camilleri served as student body president and worked as an intern for Congressman ; he credits this experience as \"inspir[ing] him to think it was possible to run for an elected office to serve others.\" For two years after finishing his bachelor's, Camilleri taught social studies at Consortium College Preparatory High School in southwest  through .\n\nCamilleri's first political experience came as a member of the Brownstown Parks and Recreation Commission.\n\n\nHe then decided to run for the 23rd District of the Michigan House of Representatives seat being vacated by  State Representative  in the . Camilleri defeated three other Democratic candidates in the August 2016 primary.\n\nIn the 2016 general election, Camilleri faced Republican Bob Howey. Earning the endorsement of – among others – the  Editorial Board, Camilleri defeated Howey by 323 votes. In defeating Howey, Camilleri became the only Democrat in the state of Michigan to take a seat held by a Republican during that election cycle.\n\nUpon taking his seat in the Michigan State House, Camilleri was chosen by then-Minority Leader  to serve as one of two assistant House Democratic Caucus leaders.\n\n\nIn the , Camilleri faced Republican Michael Frazier. He defeated Frazier 23,416 votes to 17,935 votes.\n\nIn his second term, Camilleri was appointed as House Democratic Whip.\n\n\nIn the 2020 election, Camilleri faced Republican John Poe. He defeated Poe 30,231 votes to 27,300 votes\n\nIn his third term, Camilleri served on the Education Committee, the Families, Children, and Seniors Committee, and the Financial Services Committee.\n\n\nOn January 10, 2022, Camilleri announced his campaign for Michigan's 4th State Senate District.\n\nOn August 4, 2022, he won the Democratic Party nomination unopposed.\n\nIn the 2022 general election, Camilleri faced Republican Houston James. He defeated James 64,393 votes to 51,963 votes.\n\nCamilleri was chosen to be assistant majority leader, the first Democrat to hold this position since 1983. He also became Chairman of the PreK-12 School Aid Budget, and was chosen to serve on committees that encompass Elections, Energy, Transportation, and Labor.\n\nHe was sworn in on January 1, 2023.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Frederick C. Martindale''' (December 18, 1865September 21, 1928) was an American politician who served as the 26th  from 1909 to 1914 as a member of the . He previously served in both chambers of the .\n\n\nMartindale was born in  on December 18, 1865. Martindale was born to parents Wales C. and Clara Martindale.\n\n\nMartindale was a lawyer. On January 2, 1901, Martindale as sworn in as a member  of the  from the  2nd district. He served in this position until 1902. In 1902, Martindale unsuccessfully ran for position of the member of the  from the . On January 4, 1905, Martindale was sworn in to this position, which he served in until 1908. Martindale served as  from 1909 to 1914.\n\n\nMarindale married Mary Tireman.\n\n\nMartindale killed himself via self-inflicted gunshot wound on September 21, 1928.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Fred Durhal Jr.''' (born 1951) is an American politician who served as a member of the .\n\nDurhal was born on December 27, 1951, to Doris Jean and Fred Durhal Sr., in , the family moved to Detroit in 1952. Durhal attended schools in Detroit graduating from Detroit's . He then attended ,  and the . Majoring in Political Science and Government Administration. Rep. Durhal is divorced, and the father of six children.\n\nDurhal was first elected to the House of Representatives in 2002, after a contentious court battle with then Gov. John Engler, who refused to schedule a special election to fill the seat vacated by the election of Kwame Kilpatrick as Mayor of Detroit. Durhal sued Gov. Engler in federal court and eventually won the right to have the election scheduled. Durhal then won the vacant seat. Mr. Durhal served three and one half terms making him the last \"Dean\" (highest seniority) member of the legislature.\n\nPrior to being elected, Mr. Durhal served as the Executive Director of the Virginia Park Citizens District Council, the nonprofit community organization responsible for the rehabilitation of the Detroit neighborhood that was ravaged during the 1967 Riots. Durhal served as an assistant to Detroit Mayor Coleman A. Young; District Director for U.S. Congresswoman Barbara Rose Collins (D, 13th Dist. Michigan); Community Development Specialist for the Michigan Economic Development Corporation (MEDC), Program Manager for the Michigan Land Bank Fast Track Authority; Economic Development Director on Loan from the state MEDC to the City of Highland Park, Michigan; Deputy Director of the Detroit Charter Revision Commission, He served as the first Black Political Director of the Michigan State Democratic Party; as Communication Specialist for the Michigan House of Representatives Central Staff; Executive Director and later Chairman of the Michigan Legislative Black Caucus; .During his election as State Representative in 2008 Durhal was elected on the same ticket as U.S. Senator Barack Obama, the first Black U.S. President. Durhal's legislative record includes, Appropriations Chair of General Government; Vice Chairman of Corrections Appropriations Sub Committee, Co-Sponsor, Michigan Amber Alert Acts; Sponsor of Detroit Bankruptcy 'Grand Bargain' Act that released the city from the historic Chapter 9 Bankruptcy by transferring $1.8 M from state government to the city to save pensions for city workers. Durhal has numerous Public Acts signed into law.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Brenda B. Jones''' (born October 24, 1959) is an American politician who served as a member of the  from 2006 to 2022, and as the president of the City Council from 2014 to 2022. A member of the , Jones also briefly served as the  for  from November 29, 2018, to January 3, 2019. She won the  to succeed  following his resignation in December 2017, and  . She ran for the seat again in , losing the Democratic primary to Tlaib by a wide margin.\n\n\n\nBrenda B. Jones was born on October 24, 1959, in Birmingham, Alabama, and her family moved to Detroit, Michigan, during the . She attended public schools in Detroit, where she graduated from  and later received a  in psychology from . She also earned a  from Wayne State University.\nJones worked for  and was later elected as a union president of the  Local 4004 in Detroit. She was appointed as an executive on the boards of the Detroit Economic Growth Corporation and the Detroit Transportation Commission.\n\n\n\nIn 2005, Jones was elected to the Detroit City Council after placing ninth in the general election where nine seats were available and was reelected in 2009, 2013, and 2017. In 2015, the council voted for her to serve as the President of the Detroit City Council with five voting in favor of her and four voting in favor of incumbent President Saunteel Jenkins.\n\nJones did not seek reelection in 2021.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nOn December 5, 2017, Representative  resigned after sexual harassment allegations were made against him and that he had secretly used taxpayer money to settle a harassment claim. A special election was called to replace Conyers and Jones narrowly won the Democratic primary for the special election–the real contest in this heavily Democratic, black-majority district. No  qualified to run, though any Republican challenger would have faced nearly impossible odds. Conyers had held the seat since 1965 (it had been numbered as the 1st from 1965 to 1993 and as the 14th from 1993 to 2013), and his lowest winning percentage was 77 percent.\n\nHowever, in the Democratic primary for the general election, Jones was defeated by former state representative . Prior to the general election, Jones filed to run as an independent write-in candidate, prompting criticism.\n\nDuring the course of the election campaign, questions arose as to whether Jones could serve in her Detroit City Council post concurrently with serving in Congress, an unprecedented situation up to that point. An opinion by the Detroit Corporation Counsel, written in August 2018, stated that it was likely possible for Jones to legally serve in both capacities based on state law. The Counsel advised that the  be consulted to clarify federal and House rules.\n\nIn the November 6 special election, Jones won with 86.8 percent of the vote, facing only a  candidate as opposition. On the same day, she received 633 votes in the regular election for a full two-year term.\n\n  delayed swearing Jones in until November 29, after receiving guidance from the  on how Jones could minimize conflicts of interest. She introduced two bills and cast 77 votes during her five-week tenure in the House of Representatives.\n\n\n\nOn March 25, 2020, Jones filed to run again in the Democratic primary for Michigan's 13th congressional district against Tlaib. Tlaib was considered possibly vulnerable to a primary challenge, due to her status as a , divisive rhetoric and attacks made on many popular national Democrats. For example, Tlaib booed former Secretary of State and 2016 Democratic Nominee . However, Jones' campaign was wracked by allegations of financial misconduct. On April 2, Jones announced that she had tested positive for . Jones decisively lost the primary election to Tlaib 66%-34% on August 4. The margin of Jones's loss was considered to be large.\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* , elected in a similar situation\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Tenisha Renee Yancey''' (born August 29, 1976) formerly served as a  member of the , where she represented the . \n\nYancey was elected in the 2017 Special Election called to fill a vacancy created when former representative  resigned after being charged with fraud.\n\n\nYancey is the niece of former  Vice President, Jimmy Settles.\n\nYancey worked for the Wayne County Executive's office and the Wayne County Land Bank prior to receiving her  degree in 2012. After passing the Michigan Bar in May 2014, Yancey joined the Wayne County Prosecutor's office; where she worked until her employment ended in April 2017.\n\n\nIn 1995, when Yancey was a teenager, she was found guilty of retail fraud and plead guilty to stalking. She served two years' probation for the stalking incident. Two years later, in 1997, she was sentenced to one year's probation for not stopping at the scene of a property damage accident.\n\n\nTenisha Yancey was elected to the  School Board on November 8, 2016. Yancey had no children attending school in the , but cited her experience in the court system as making her qualified to serve on the Board.\n\n\nAfter the resignation of  due to pending legal issues, Yancey ran in the 2017 special primary election to replace him in . A friend of Bank's, he volunteered in her campaign. She earned 33 percent of the vote in the primaries against attorney Pamela Sossi. In the primary and election, she was supported by then mayor . During the election, her previous convictions were brought up by her opposition.\n\n\nIn the November 8, 2017, Special Election General, Yancey received 7,266 votes, or 71% of the vote.\n\n\nOn April 19, 2022, Yancey filed to run for Judge of the 3rd Circuit Court. On April 19, 2022, Yancey also filed to run for Judge of the 36th District Court. On April 22, 2022, Yancey abandoned her candidacy for Judge of the 3rd Circuit Court.\n\n\n()}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n()}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Paul Mitchell III''' (November 14, 1956 – August 15, 2021) was an American businessman and politician who served as the  for  from 2017 to 2021. A member of the  for most of his Congressional tenure, he left the party in December 2020, three weeks prior to his departure from Congress, and became an . In July 2019, Mitchell announced that he would not run for re-election in 2020 to spend more time with his family.\n\n\nMitchell was born in , . The oldest of six children, he was raised in .\n\nMitchell graduated from  with a  in 1978.\n\n\nPaul Mitchell previously owned and operated . He ran for the 32nd district seat in the  in 2013 to succeed , but withdrew from the race. He became the chairman of the  of Michigan, a conservative nonprofit foundation. Mitchell led a campaign opposed to Proposal 1, a  proposing a tax plan for roads, on the May 2015 ballot.\n\n\nMitchell ran for the  in  in 2014, losing the   to . He moved to  in 2015 to run for the House of Representatives in that district, following 's decision not to run for reelection. He won the primary, defeating  and . Mitchell won the general election, defeating Frank Accavitti.\n\nMitchell assumed office on January 3, 2017. He was a member of the . He voted in favor of the unsuccessful , which would have repealed the  and replaced it with another program.\n\nIn July 2019, Mitchell announced he would not seek a third term in Congress, citing the \"rhetoric and vitriol\" of the federal government, a desire to spend more time with his family, and health issues.\n\nShortly after a post on  was sent by President  on July 14, telling four female, minority, first-term congressional representatives to \"\" to their countries of origin, Mitchell called a fellow House GOP leader and asked him to persuade Trump to cease his rhetoric. Mitchell said, \"It's the wrong thing for a leader to say\", and he told the leader, \"It's politically damaging to the party, to the country.\" A few days later, while Mitchell waited to go on to a prime-time television network appearance, he saw a clip of Trump rally attendees chanting, \"send her back,\" aimed at one of the congresswomen, . Mitchell asked an aide, \"How do I even respond to this on TV?\" For Mitchell, the final straw was the refusal of Trump staffers to listen. Mitchell begged  , and the   to arrange a one-on-one conversation between Mitchell and Trump to address his misgivings., '''', September 22, 2019. Retrieved September 27, 2019.\n\nOn November 29, 2020, Mitchell tweeted a response to a tweet by Trump claiming rigged elections: \"Oh my God. . @realDonaldTrump Please for the sake of our Nation please drop these arguments without evidence or factual basis. #stopthestupid\". The hashtag is a reference to \"\", a slogan used by Trump supporters who claimed that the election had been stolen from Trump.\n\nOn December 14, 2020, during an interview with CNN's , Mitchell announced he would no longer continue as a member of the Republican Party and would serve out the rest of his term in Congress as an .\n\n\n*\n**\n**\n*\n**\n**\n*\n** (Vice Chair)\n**\n**\n\n\nMitchell moved to , when he married his wife, Sherry Mitchell, in 2008. A longtime resident of , near , he purchased a home in  to run for the 10th district seat in Congress.\n\nIn June 2021, Mitchell announced he had been diagnosed with stage 4  and underwent surgery to remove a mass and blood clot near his heart. He died on August 15, 2021, aged 64.\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
