    "pages": }\n'''Samuel 'Buzz' Thomas''' (born January 28, 1969) is a politician from the  of . He was a  member of the , representing the  beginning in 2003 and served as the Democratic Floor Leader until 2011 when he reached his two term limit. His district is completely located in the city of  and includes portions of northwest, east, central, and southwest Detroit. Previously he was a member of the  from 1997 to 2002.\n\n\nThomas was born in Detroit in 1969 and is a graduate of Detroit Country Day School and the University of Pennsylvania . Before becoming an elected official he worked as a homebuilder in metro Detroit, where he was Construction Manager for Parkside Building Company and Avis Tech Park partners, managing both commercial renovations and single-family, residential construction. He also held senior positions with US Representatives Barbara Rose Collins (MI) and Bob Carr (MI). \n\n\nIn 1996, one hundred and four years after his great grand uncle, , was the first African-American elected to the Michigan Legislature, Thomas was elected to the .  He represented the , located in northwest Detroit. He served in the House for six years. In 2002, he was elected by his House colleagues as the House Democratic Leader, one of the youngest members ever elected to that position and only the second African American elected as a House leader.\n\nIn 2002 he was elected to the Michigan Senate and re-elected in 2006. In 2007, his colleagues once again elected him to a leadership position, as the Senate Democratic Floor Leader. He is one of the few Michigan legislators to have held leadership positions in both the Michigan House and Senate.\n\n\nSenator Thomas received many recognitions for his service, including being named one of Michigan’s five “Key Technology Leaders” by the '''', One Of Four Up-And-Coming Leaders by Savoy, “Most Dedicated Detroiter” and “Best Local Politician” by Real Detroit Magazine, \"A Rising Star\" by both '''' and Hotline, and an \"Under-40 Political 'Buzz' Saw\" by the Michigan Front Page. He has received awards and recognition from over two dozen community groups, publications, and organizations.\n\n\nBuzz Thomas was the ranking Democrat on the Economic Development and Regulatory Reform Committee. He also served on the Homeland Security and Emerging Technologies Committee and on the Energy Policy Committee.\n\n\n*'''2006 Election for the Michigan State Senate - 4th District'''\n\n\n*'''2002 Election for the Michigan State Senate - 4th District'''\n\n\n*'''2000 Election for the Michigan State House'''\n\n\n*'''1998 Election for the Michigan State House'''\n\n\n*'''1996 Election for the Michigan State House'''\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n* profile\n*''Follow the Money'' - Samuel Buzz Thomas III\n**      campaign contributions\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Lorenzo Thurston Durand''' (December 9, 1849August 7, 1917) was an American lawyer and politician.\n\n\nLorenzo T. Durand was born in  on December 9, 1849 to parents George H. Durand and Margret McMillan. George was of English descent and Margret was of Scottish descent. In 1858, the family moved to , where they settled on a farm. In the 1860s, either in 1860 or 1863, the family moved to .\n\n\n\nDurand received up to a high school education before becoming a law student in the office of J. Brousseaer for a year. For two years after this, he studied law under the firm  & Smith. In 1870, Durand graduated with an LL.B from the  and was admitted to the Michigan bar that same year. Durand served as an assistant to   for several years.\n\nIn 1870, Durand partnered with DeForrest Paine to form the law firm Durand & Paine, which lasted until around 1878, when Durand was elected  prosecuting attorney. In this position, he served two terms, returning to private practice in 1882. As legal counsel for the Union Street Railway Company of Saginaw, Durand argued for the company's right to electrify their railways. This became a reality in 1889. By this time, Durand was president of the company. Durand later served as an attorney for the Central Bridge Company of Saginaw and as the president of the Saginaw County Savings Bank. At some point, Durand was a member of the Saginaw County Bar Association, and served as its president.\n\nIn 1897, Durand was selected as a trustee of the Union Saginaw School District, and later was elected as president of the Saginaw Board of Education. In 1902, Durand served as the Democratic nominee in the . Durand was defeated by incumbent Republican governor, . After Bliss' death, Durand would serve as one of the executors of Bliss' will, and the chief counsel for his estate. Also in 1902, Durand was selected as a United States senatorial candidate in a complimentary way, as the senators representing Michigan at the time were both Republican. At some point, Durand was also to be nominated for the position of Michigan Attorney General, but he did not give consent to the nomination. In 1917, Durand was an unsuccessful candidate for the position of circuit judge in Michigan's 10th Circuit.\n\n\nLorenzo T. Durand was the brother of  . On February 15, 1872, Lorenzo married Flora Caroline Moore, daughter of . John Moore was a notable judge and lawyer in the area who, like Lorenzo, served as the Democratic gubernatorial nominee in . Durand was a . Lorenzo was an .\n\n\nDurand died of heart trouble on a business trip to  in a Woodward train car on August 7, 1917. Durand was buried in .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }
  }

Kestenbaum, was a  of history at .\n\nIn 1973, he graduated from .  He received a bachelor's degree in economics from Michigan State University, followed by a  from  in 1982.  He later studied  at .\n\n\nKestenbaum was an analyst and computer lab director for Michigan State University, later becoming an academic specialist there. It was during this time that he created '''' in 1996. He was later on staff at the 's  (ISR) Survey Research Center, and has taught historic preservation law at .\n\n\nKestenbaum is a .  He served as a er in  (1983–88) and  (2000–02). In 2004, he was elected as the  /, the first Democrat in that position in 72 years.  He was unopposed for reelection in 2008, reelected in 2012, unopposed in 2016, and reelected in 2020.\n\nKestenbaum currently serves as co-chair of the Legislative Committee for the Michigan Association of County Clerks.\n\nOn March 22, 2014, following a U.S. District Court ruling that Michigan's ban on same sex marriage was unconstitutional, Kestenbaum was one of four Michigan county clerks to open for special hours while the ruling was in effect; his office issued marriage licenses to 74 gay and lesbian couples. His office also provided fresh same-day same-sex marriage licenses within minutes of the US Supreme Court '''' ruling.\n\n\nKestenbaum was married to Janice Gutfreund, and they have one child.     "pages": }\n\n'''Patrick Outman''' (born  1992) is an American politician from Michigan. A member of the , he is a member of the  from the . First elected in 2020, he the state House on January 1, 2021.\n\n\nPat Outman was born around 1992 in  to father . In 2010, Pat graduated from . Pat later earned a degree in business administration and legal studies from , where he graduated with honors. He was elected to the state House as a Republican from  in November 2020. He took office in January 2021. He replaced outgoing state Representative , and fills the seat formerly occupied by his father. At the time, the district covered all of  and parts of .\n\nIn February 2021, Outman introduced a bill seeks to allow winners of multi-state lotteries to collect their winnings while staying anonymous.\n\nIn 2021, Outman was one of four representatives (all Republicans) to vote against HB 4856, which would allow government agencies to exempt from disclosure under the state Freedom of Information the names of victims of sexual misconduct who sue as anonymous plaintiffs. The legislation was one piece of a bipartisan package brought after the .\n\nIn 2021, Outman was one of eight Republican legislators to co-sponsor the \"Fact Checker Registration Act\" a bill that would require  organizations to register with the government and file proof of a $1 million . The bill was introduced by Republican Representative , a prominent . The Michigan Press Association said that the bill infringed on the  , and Lasinski said it aimed to \"intimidate and harass\" journalists. In 2022, Outman was one of 17 Michigan Republican legislators who signed a letter urging the state attorney general to investigate debunked claims of \"election fraud\" in the 2020 election based on '''', a debunked film pushed by  and other election deniers.\n\nIn 2021, Outman was one of three House representatives who voted against a bipartisan ethics package that established a specific  policy for the Michigan Legislature. The bill (HB 4011) prohibits state legislators from voting on bills that could personally benefit them, their families, or businesses. The bill passed the House on a 105&ndash;3 vote; the other \"no\" votes came from Republicans  and .\n\nIn 2022, Outman sponsored a , HB 210, that accused Michigan public schools of harboring \"radical politics\" and engaging in \"political indoctrination.\" He offered no evidence for these claims. The resolution also criticized Democratic Governor  for vetoing a bill to create a -type program for private school tuition. The resolution was approved by the state House Education Committee on a party-line vote.\n\nIn the 2022 election,  put Outman in the . The new district covers northeastern Kent County;  parts of northern Kent County (including ); and portions of Montcalm and , including  and . He defeated Democratic nominee Tammy L. DeVries with 68.2% of the vote.\n\nControl of both chambers of the Michigan Legislature flipped in the 2022 election, with Democrats winning the majority in the new legislative session that began in 2023.Cory Smith, , ''The Daily News'' (Greenville, Mich.) (March 27, 2023). Outman and his father (a state senator) opposed the labor-rights package of bills signed into law by Governor  in March 2023; the legislation, which passed the House and Senate on party-line votes, repealed the \"\" enacted in 2012 under Governor  and reinstated the  law.\n\n\nOutman is a member of the .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Bryan Richard Posthumus''' (born October 26, 1984) is an American politician serving as a member of the  from the . Elected in 2020, he assumed office on January 1, 2021.\n\n\nBryan Posthumus was born in 1984 in  to parents Pamela and . Dick would later serve as . Bryan's sister  served as a state representative. Posthumus graduated from  in 2003 and earned a bachelor's degree in  management from  in 2007.\n\n\nPosthumus is a fourth-generation farmer, and the co-owner of West Michigan Hopyards. Posthumas has served on the . Apart from the agriculture business, Posthumus has also served as the CEO and director of consulting for Tuebor Strategies, vice president of business development for USA Financial, and Compactio, Inc. On November 3, 2020, Posthumus was elected to the , where he has represented the  since January 1, 2021.\n\nAfter redistricting, Posthumus was left in the , where he is seeking re-election. Posthumus, on August 2, defeated former police officer Kathy Clark in the Republican primary. In the general election, Posthumus defeated Democratic nominee Meagan Hintz.\n\n\nPosthumus married his wife, Elizabeth Lonick in December 2022. They reside in . Posthumus is a .\n\n\nOn April 30, 2021, Posthumus was arrested on suspicion of drunk driving. During the incident, in , he started to drive off-road, hit a mailbox, and then his car rolled over. At the time of the crash, his blood alcohol level was .13%, while Michigan's legal limit is .08%. On July 23, Posthumus pleaded guilty to the misdemeanor charge and was sentenced to 15 days in jail along with two years probation, 15 days of community service, and a $1,820 fine. He pledged to pay back the state for any legislative salary earned during time served.\n Posthumus was previously convicted for drunk driving in 2013.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Bartholomew Thomas Stupak''' (; born February 29, 1952) is an American politician and . A member of the , Stupak served as the  from  from 1993 to 2011.\n\nStupak chose not to seek re-election in 2010. He departed Congress in January 2011, and was succeeded by , a  from the . Stupak is now a  with .\n\n\nStupak was born in , and graduated from  in  in 1970. He is an . He earned his  from , a community college in  in 1972. He earned his  in criminal justice from  in 1977, graduating '''', and he earned a  degree from  in  in 1981. He worked as an  police officer in 1972. Stupak later served as a  Trooper from 1973 to 1984 and as a member of C-Street while in Congress. He also practiced law.\n\n\nIn 1988, Stupak was elected a , representing , , and  counties, defeating two-term Republican Jim Connors. In 1990, Stupak ran for state senator but lost a hotly contested  to eventual general election winner .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 1992, Stupak ran for the House of Representatives in the 1st District, covering the Upper Peninsula and the northernmost swath of the Lower Peninsula. The district had previously been the 11th, represented by retiring seven-term incumbent Republican . Stupak won the heavily contested Democratic primary, and defeated Republican , Davis' predecessor, in the general election. He was the first Democrat to represent this district since 1967, and only the third Democrat to win it in the 20th century. He was easily reelected in 1994 during a bad year for Democrats, becoming the first Democrat in 56 years to be elected to more than one term in the Northern Michigan district.\n\nStupak defeated Republican Don Hooper of  in the ,  and , and Republican  In 2008.\n\nOn April 9, 2010, Stupak announced that he would not run for re-election, and that he would retire from Congress at the end of his then-current term.\n\n\n and health care professionals were among the top four industries contributing to his campaigns in 2006, 2008 and 2010. Of his top 20 largest contributors throughout his political career, 16 were unions and associations, two were energy companies, one was an insurance company and one was a telecommunications firm.\n\n\n*''''''\n**\n**\n** (Chairman)\n\n\n*Founder and co-chair of the Law Enforcement Caucus\n*Co-chair of the Congressional Northern Border Caucus\n*Member, \n\nDuring his service in Congress, Stupak sponsored 36 bills, but none became law. He cosponsored 157 bills, 5 of which were enacted into law. He voted with the members of his party 96% of the time, and abstained from 5% of the votes. Because of the 1st District's extensive length of  shoreline (over 1,600 miles), Stupak was very active on issues related to the protection of the Great Lakes, including opposing sale or diversion of Great Lakes water and drilling for oil and gas under the lakes.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2009, Stupak voted against the , which expanded Federal regulation and oversight of the US financial system in the aftermath of the US financial and banking crisis of that year.\n\n\nStupak voted for the Local Law Enforcement Hate Crimes Prevention Act of 2009, which expanded the definition of  to include crimes motivated by sexual orientation or gender identity.\n\n\n\nStupak expressed a desire to support the 2009  put forth by President , but wanted restrictions on coverage for . Therefore, Stupak and Republican Congressman  submitted an amendment known as the  to prohibit such payments. The Stupak–Pitts Amendment was adopted by the House of Representatives, but a similar provision was defeated in the  version of the legislation (known as the ). Stupak announced that he and several other Democratic representatives who supported health reform legislation but opposed abortion would not vote for the final version of the legislation unless the Stupak-Pitts Amendment was included. The ensuing controversy made Stupak \"perhaps the single most important rank-and-file House member in passing the bill.\"\n\n held a \"Stop Stupak\" rally on Capitol Hill in December 2009. In the ensuing months, Stupak publicly stated that the pressure and opposition he received in regard to his abortion stance on the health reform legislation had caused him to unplug the phone at his house due to \"obscene phone calls and threats\" and had made his life a \"living hell.\" \"My staff is overwhelmed and we're accosted basically wherever we go by people who disagree,\" Stupak added.\n\nIn March 2010, President Obama and Stupak reached an understanding whereby the President promised to sign an  barring federal funding of abortion through the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, and Stupak and several of his allies promised to withdraw their opposition to the bill.  accused Stupak of betraying their movement, with the  revoking an award it had planned to give to him and instead running $150,000 worth of radio advertisements against him. Stupak was targeted by the  in the wake of his compromise. In April 2010, Stupak announced his intention to retire from Congress, leading conservative groups to point to the political consequences of his compromise as a possible reason for his decision. However, Stupak himself attributed his retirement to the exertion of constant travel back and forth from Washington, D.C.\n\nStupak also supports a  and  healthcare.\n\n\nStupak rented a room at the , a Washington, D.C. facility of  (also known as The Family), a Christian fraternal organization.Parnes, Amie (February 2, 2010).  Politico.  Retrieved on March 5, 2010 The Fellowship has been the subject of controversy over its claimed tax status as a church, the ownership of the property and its connection to the Fellowship, and the reportedly subsidized benefits the facility provides to members of Congress.\n\n, author of a book about The Fellowship, said, \"When I lived with The Family at Ivanwald, a house for younger men being groomed for leadership, I was told that Stupak was a regular visitor to the Cedars.\" The Cedars, according to the '''', is also owned by The Family and hosts weekly prayer events. Stupak has denied any affiliation with the Family and appeared to deny knowledge of the organization, stating \"I don't belong to any such group\" and that \"I don't know what you're talking about, [The] Family and all this other stuff.\"\n\n\n*'''1992 Democratic primary for Congress'''\n**Bart Stupak, 48.63%\n**Mike McElroy, 43.11%\n**Daniel Herringa, 8.27%\n*'''1992 general election'''\n**Bart Stupak (D), 53.93%\n** (R), 43.58%\n**Gerald Aydlott (), 1.52%\n**Lyman Clark (), 0.96%\n*'''1994 general election'''\n**Bart Stupak (D), 56.86%\n**Gil Ziegler (R), 41.99%\n**Michael McPeak (NL), 1.12%\n*'''1996 general election'''\n**Bart Stupak (D), 70.68%\n**Bob Carr (R), 27.24%\n**Michael C. In 2008 Casperson unsuccessfully challenged Bart Stupak, the incumbent for Michigan's .\n\nThe Stupaks' son Ken graduated from 's School of Law in 2006 and resides in California. Their other son, Bart Jr., died by suicide in May 2000. Congressman Stupak testified before the   during a 2002 hearing on the safety of , an acne medication, which he believes contributed to his son's death.\n\n\n\n\n\n* ''official campaign site''\n* \n*, video interview with  from ''''\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n| term_start5         = January 3, 2009\n| term_end5           = January 3, 2015\n| predecessor5        = \n| successor5          = \n| office6             = Commissioner of the \n| governor6           = \n| term_start6         = April 9, 2003\n| term_end6           = August 7, 2007\n| predecessor6        = Jim Kipp\n| successor6          = Scott Bowen\n| state_senate7       = Michigan\n| district7           = \n| term_start7         = January 3, 1995\n| term_end7           = December 31, 2002\n| predecessor7        = \n| successor7          = \n| birth_name          = Gary Charles Peters\n| birth_date          = \n| birth_place         = , , U.S.\n| death_date          = \n| death_place         = \n| party               = \n| spouse              = Colleen Ochoa\n| children            = 3\n| education           = \n| website             = \n| branch              = \n*\n**\n\n| serviceyears        = 1993–2008\n| rank                = \n| unit                =  \n| battles             = \n| mawards             = \n|module = \n}}\n'''Gary Charles Peters Sr.''' (born December 1, 1958) is an American lawyer, politician, and former  serving as the   from  since 2015. A member of the , he was the  for , which included the eastern half of , the , , , and , from 2009 to 2015 (the district was  until 2013).\n\nBefore his election to Congress, Peters served in the , spent 22 years as an investment advisor, and worked briefly in academia. He was elected to the Rochester Hills City Council in 1991 and represented the  in the  from 1995 to 2002. He was the Democratic nominee for  in , narrowly losing to  . He was then appointed commissioner of the  by Governor , serving from 2003 to 2008, when he resigned to successfully run for Congress.\n\nIn , Peters was elected to the  seat being vacated by retiring Democratic incumbent . He was unopposed in the Democratic primary and defeated Republican  in the general election. He was the only non-incumbent Democrat to win a Senate election in 2014. Peters was reelected in , defeating Republican challenger  in a close race.\n\nOn January 28, 2021, Peters was selected as chair of the  for the . He was later selected again for the . Peters will become Michigan's senior senator when  retires in January 2025.\n\n\n\nGary Charles Peters was born December 1, 1958, in , where he grew up. He is the son of Madeleine A. ( Vignier) and Herbert Garrett Peters, a historian and statistician. His mother was a French  and his father was American.\n\nPeters graduated from  in 1976 and chose to attend , where he graduated '''' in 1980 with a  degree in  and was inducted into  and . He earned a  from the  in 1984. Peters also holds a  and a Master of Arts in political science from  and a  in philosophy from . He also earned a diploma from the College of Naval Command and Staff, .\n\n\nPeters joined the  in 1993 at age 34. He served more than ten years in units at , including . During his Navy service, Peters earned the  designation and carried out assignments as an .\n\nPeters's reserve duty included time in the  supporting ; he served overseas again during increased military activity following the . Peters attained the rank of  before leaving the Reserve in 2008; his awards include the  and the . In 2018, he received a diploma from the .\n\n\nPeters worked for 22 years as a financial advisor, serving as an assistant vice president at  from 1980 until 1989, when he joined  as a vice president.\n\nFrom 2007 to 2008, Peters served as the third Griffin Endowed Chair in American Government at . In that part-time position, he taught one class a semester, plus preparing additional student activities including two policy forums, and developing a journal of Michigan politics and policy, for $65,000 a year. Peters announced his candidacy to run for Congress two months after being hired. Some student and faculty members protested Peters's hiring, saying he could not be objective in the classroom while running for office and that the university job was subsidizing his campaign.\n\nPeters also has taught  at Wayne State and  and business  courses at .\n\nPeters was a senior policy and financial analyst for the Michigan Department of Treasury and served on arbitration panels for the  and the .\n\n\nPeters served on the  City Council from 1991 to 1993.\n\n\nAfter a failed attempt in 1990, Peters was elected to the  to represent the -based 14th district in November 1994. He was reelected in 1998 and served until 2002, stepping down then due to the state's s. Peters was succeeded in the 14th district by .\n\n\nThe 14th district is one of the most diverse state Senate districtscontaining nearly every racial, ethnic, and religious group in Michigan. Located in southeastern , it includes the cities of , , , and .\n\nPeters was chosen by his Democratic colleagues to chair his party's caucus. He was also a member of the Michigan Law Revision Commission and served on the Michigan Sentencing Commission. Both the  and the Senate passed a bill sponsored by Peters which banned any new wells under the state waters of the Great Lakes except in case of a state energy emergency. The bill passed into law without the signature of Governor .\n\n\nPeters served as the  of the Senate Finance, Education, Judiciary and Economic Development Committees. He was also a member of the Natural Resources and the Mental Health and Human Services Committee.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\nIn his final year as a member of the Michigan Senate, Peters was a candidate for governor and later for . As the Democratic nominee for attorney general, he lost in November 2002 to Republican  by about 5,200 votesless than a 0.17% margin. Peters decided not to contest the election results despite reported irregularities. Several mistakes were reportedly found during analysis, including a precinct in  that recorded Peters with 96 votes when he actually had 396. The race was the closest statewide contest in Michigan since the 1950 gubernatorial race.\n\n  appointed Peters as the  commissioner on April 9, 2003.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nOn August 7, 2007, Peters ended months of speculation by formally announcing he would run against eight-term  congressman  in the 9th district, which included almost all of . Peters resigned as state lottery commissioner to devote his full energy to the campaign.\n\nKnollenberg was considered vulnerable due to an increasing Democratic trend in what was once a classic bastion of suburban conservatism. His opponents in 2002 and 2004 had performed significantly below the Democratic base in the district, but he was nearly defeated in 2006 by , a former radio talk-show host who spent virtually no moneythe closest a Republican had come to losing the district in almost half a century. This led the  to target Knollenberg for defeat.\n\nIn the 2002 state attorney general race, Peters performed at or above the Democratic base in 72% of the 9th district precincts. In his 1998 state Senate campaign, he performed at or above base in 99% of the precincts.\n\nPeters won the November 4 election by 33,524 votes, taking 52% of the vote to Knollenberg's 43%.  carried Oakland County by 15 points; roughly two-thirds of Oakland County was in the 9th. Peters was the fourth person and first Democrat to represent the district since its creation in 1933 (it was the 17th district from 1933 to 1953, the 18th from 1953 to 1973, the 19th from 1973 to 1983, the 18th from 1983 to 1993, and the 11th from 1993 to 2003, becoming the 9th in 2003).\n\n\n\nIn November 2010, Peters defeated challenges by Republican , Libertarian Adam Goodman, Independent Bob Gray, Independent Matthew Kuofie, and Green Douglas Campbell.\n\n\n\nDue to the state's population decline, as reflected by the 2010 census, Michigan lost one congressional district. As a result of the subsequent redistricting of House seats, much of Peters's 9th district, including his home in Bloomfield Hills, was merged with the , represented by fellow Democrat . The new district retained Peters's district number (the 9th) but geographically was more Levin's district.\n\nIn September 2011, Peters opted to run in the newly redrawn 14th district. The district had previously been the 13th district, represented by freshman Democrat . The redrawn district is based in Detroit, but contains a large chunk of Peters's old State Senate district and portions of his old congressional district. Indeed, Peters had represented most of the Oakland County portion of the district at one time or another. Due to Detroit's dwindling population, it was no longer possible to keep the district exclusively within .\n\nIn the August 2012 Democratic primary, Peters defeated Clarke, who had opted to follow most of his constituents into the reconfigured 14th even though his home had been drawn into the reconfigured 13th (the old 14th), and Southfield Mayor . The 14th was a heavily Democratic, 58% Black district, and Peters was overwhelmingly favored in November. As expected, he bested Republican John Hauler in the general election with 82% of the vote. He was the first white congressman to represent a significant portion of Detroit since 1993.\n\n\nPeters was sworn into his first term in January 2009. During his time in office, he voted for the , also known as the stimulus, the , the , which would have established a national emissions trading plan, but was not passed by the full Congress, the , also not passed into law, the , and the  to provide conditional permanent residency to certain immigrants.\n\nPeters worked with the Obama administration to obtain debt forgiveness for .  Chairman  said Peters was the \"single most effective person\" in fighting against the forces that wanted to let  go bankrupt. In Congress, Peters opposed a plan to provide disaster relief aid, the funds for which would have come from the  (ATVM) loan program.\n\nIn July 2010, the '''' wrote that Peters was \"criticizing the leadership of his own party. Peters and three other Democratic legislators... this week formed the Spending Cuts and Deficit Reduction Working Group and proposed a series of bills to cut spending. Peters's bill makes cuts in the federal energy budget.\" \"We have been growing increasingly frustrated with the lack of action and talking about specifics and putting those on the table\", Peters said. \"We've been frustrated with both Democratic leadership and Republicans.\"\n\nPeters allied himself with the  movement, making an appearance at  on November 6, 2011. He told reporters: \"It's speculation on Wall Street that we're still paying the price for here, particularly in Detroit, that almost brought the auto industry to a collapse because of what we saw on Wall Street. So we put in restrictions, or put in regulations necessary to rein that in, and right now in Washington I'm facing a Republican majority that wants to undo that.\"\n\nIn 2011, Peters was one of 118 house Democrats who signed a letter to President Obama urging him to support the  (UNFPA), a multinational organization that provides health services (including birth control) to women, children and families in more than 150 countries.\n\nIn 2014, Peters voiced opposition to a Michigan law that prohibits insurers from offering abortion coverage as a standard feature in health plans.\n\nPeters was named senior whip for the Democratic caucus in 2013.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 2014, Peters ran for the  seat being vacated by retiring Senator . Levin and Senator  endorsed Peters, and his entrance largely cleared the field of potential Democratic challengers.\n\nPeters's largest independent supporter was the Senate Majority PAC, which spent almost $3.2million for ads attacking the Republican nominee, . In July 2014, Senator  supported Peters at a campaign fundraising event.\n\nWhile the race was considered competitive early on, various missteps by Land's campaign and her reluctance to appear in public benefited Peters; he had consistent leads in polls late in the campaign.\n\n\n\n\nPeters faced Republican nominee  in the November 2020 general election. James previously ran unsuccessfully for Senate in 2018 against Stabenow. Less than a month before the election, Peters became the first sitting U.S. senator ever to publicly reveal a personal family experience with abortion. He was reelected, though by a closer margin (1.7%) than expected.\n\n\nPeters was participating in the certification of the  on January 6, 2021, when Trump supporters . Along with other senators and staff, Peters was evacuated from the Senate floor when rioters breached the Capitol. He hid in a secure location, where he tweeted that the attacks were \"dangerous, unacceptable and an attack on our democracyand must stop.\" Peters blamed Trump, calling him \"a clear and present danger\" and calling for his immediate removal from office through the  or impeachment. Peters also called for investigations into the security and intelligence failure that resulted in the breaching of the Capitol and the five deaths. He led the investigation as chair of the .\n\n\n*\n**\n**\n**\n**\n**\n*\n**\n** (Chair)\n*\n**\n**\n**\n**\n* (Chair)\n*\n\n\n\nIn the Bipartisan Index created by  and the , Peters was ranked the 17th-most bipartisan U.S. senator (and the 4th-most bipartisan Democrat) during the . The  gave him a 7% lifetime conservative rating in 2020. In March 2021, the nonpartisan Center for Effective Lawmaking ranked Peters the most effective senator in the 116th Congress (2019–2021), despite being in the minority party.\n\n\nPeters supports . In the late 1980s, his first wife had a wanted pregnancy that failed at four months, but her miscarriage did not proceed naturally, causing a health emergency. Their hospital did not perform abortions, but Peters's wife was able to get an emergency abortion at another hospital in part because she and Peters were friends with the hospital's administrator. Peters has supported the , and in 2015 voted for the .\n\n\n\nIn March 2017, Peters cosponsored the  (S. 720), which made it a federal crime to encourage or participate in boycotts against Israel and s in the occupied  if protesting actions by the Israeli government.\n\n\nIn November 2017, in response to efforts by  to purchase tech companies based in the U.S., Peters was one of nine senators to cosponsor a bill that would broaden the federal government's ability to prevent foreign purchases of U.S. firms through increasing the strength of the  (CFIUS). The CFIUS's scope would be expanded to allow it to review along with possibly decline smaller investments and add additional national security factors for CFIUS to consider, including whether information about Americans would be exposed as part of transactions or whether the deal would facilitate fraud.\n\n\nPeters is a gun owner. In 2010, he had a D rating from the ; by 2020, Peters had an F .\n\nIn the wake of the 2016 , Peters participated in the .\n\nIn January 2019, Peters was one of 40 senators to introduce the Background Check Expansion Act, a bill that would require background checks for the sale or transfer of all firearms. Exceptions to the bill's background check requirement included transfers between members of law enforcement, loaning firearms for hunting or sporting events on a temporary basis, providing them as gifts to members of one's immediate family, transferring them as part of an inheritance, or giving one to another person temporarily for immediate self-defense.\n\n\nIn 2009, Peters voted for the . He has opposed attempts to repeal the law, and supported a Medicare public option to expand health care access.\n\n\nOn February 4, 2021, Peters voted against providing  financial support to undocumented immigrants.\n\n\nPeters is married to Colleen Ochoa, who is from . Peters has three children. They reside in .\n\nAccording to financial disclosure documents, Peters had assets between $1.7million and $6.3million at the end of 2014. In 2014, Peters's net worth ranked 37th in the Senate.\n\nPeters received the  in 2019. He is a member of the . His ancestor William Garrett served in the  in the Revolutionary War alongside George Washington at Valley Forge during the harsh winter of 1777–1778.\n\nPeters is an avid  and has made a tradition of annual motorcycle tours of Michigan.\n\nPeters is an . He has said his religion is important to him and \"gives me comfort in rough times\".\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* official U.S. Senate website\n*\n\n*\n* at \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n()|years=, }}\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=since January 3, 2015}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Thomas George''' (born December 2, 1956) is an American physician and politician from the  of . As a  member of the , he represented  as well as an eastern portion of . George is a physician and former medical director for Hospice of Greater Kalamazoo.  He is currently the co-chairman of the Department of Anesthesiology at 's Homer Stryker School of Medicine.\n\n\nGeorge studied biology at the  . He was a recipient of the William J. Branstrom Freshman Prize and was a six-term James B. Angell scholar. He entered the  at the end of his junior year. He completed a post graduate residency in anesthesiology at the University of Michigan. After his political career he returned to work as an anesthesiologist in . He was awarded his bachelor's degree from the University of Michigan in 2010.\n\n\nIn 2000, George was elected  to serve as a member of the , representing the . After serving one term in the , George cast his bid for a newly vacant seat in the  in 2002. George was reelected  to the senate in 2006, in a campaign against  challenger and term-limited state representative . From 2007-2010 George served as chairman of the Senate Health Policy Committee. While serving in the legislature he authored over forty public acts. In 2010, while attending a commencement address given by President  for Kalamazoo Central High School's graduation, a man in the audience collapsed and George initiated . The man was successfully resuscitated and taken to a nearby hospital.\n\n\n\nOn January 26, 2009, on the 172nd anniversary of Michigan's statehood, George announced his plans to form a gubernatorial exploratory committee.  In 2010 Michigan's current governor  was ed, leaving the seat open to contenders.\n\nGeorge joined , the Oakland County Sheriff and former state senator, Businessman , Congressman  and Michigan Attorney General  as 2010 Republican gubernatorial candidates. The Republican primary election  was won by Snyder.\n\n\nGeorge is a past-president of the  and has authored articles on various topics including  1855 US Senate race, Lincoln's 1856 visit to Kalamazoo, Illinois'  and s, Kalamazoo history, and the history of the Michigan Republican Party.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Brown, born April 9, 1956) is the current clerk, former assistant clerk, and former  member of the .\n\nBrown had a career in radio, for  (now WFXD) in  and as news director at  in , before working as a reporter for the . He was also the director of the Marty's Goldenaires Senior Drum and Bugle Corps in Bessemer.\n\nImmediately prior to his election to the House, Brown served 16 years as  Clerk and Register of Deeds, and was named Michigan County Clerk of the Year in 1992.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Bronna Kahle''' is a nonprofit executive, former State Representative, and public servant from Michigan.\n\n\nIn January 2023, after serving as a member of the  for six years, Bronna became President and CEO of the Lenawee Community Foundationa nonprofit organization that is focused on enhancing health, civic, culture, education, and human services for Lenawee residents.\n\nShe was first elected to the  for District 57. on November 8, 2016. She was re-elected in 2018 and again in 2020.\n\nIn the Michigan Legislature, she became a leader in the efforts to protect funding for critical in-home service programs such as Meals on Wheels, reform our criminal justice system, and lower the price of car insurance. She also worked to find solutions to help victims of human trafficking rebuild their lives  and lift up those suffering from mental illness or addition.\n\nBefore her election to the Michigan Legislature, Kahle served as Director of the Adrian Senior Center. She also owned and operated a small business, which provided home care for seniors and vulnerable members of the community.\n\nIn addition to her professional work, Kahle's community involvement includes the Lenawee Walk to End Alzheimer’s, Adrian Symphony Orchestra, Adrian Chamber of Commerce, Zonta of Lenewee, Adrian College, Habitat for Humanity’s Neighborhood Revitalization Initiative, and Associated Charities.\n\nBronna Kahle's professional awards include:\n\n* Legislator of the Year · Michigan Association of School Social Workers (MASSW) · 2022\n* Legislator of the Year · Leading Age Michigan · 2022\n* Visionary for Safety and Justice Award · Alliance for Safety and Justice · 2021\n* Guardian of Small Business Award · National Federation of Independent Business (NFIB) · 2020\n* Michigan Chamber of Commerce Champion Award · Michigan Chamber of Commerce · 2019\n* Legislator of the Year · Michigan Manufacturers Association · 2018\n* Good Public Health Policy Award · Michigan Pharmacists Association · 2018\n* Alzheimer's Champion Award · Alzheimer's Association · 2017\n\n\nKahle earned a Bachelor's degree in Business Administration and a Master’s degree in Business Administration from . She also holds a Bachelor’s degree in Business Administration, with a concentration in Marketing and Minor in Communication, from  in Maryland.\n\n\nBronna Kahle lives in Adrian, Michigan with her husband, Patrick Kahle. They have two grown children.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Franz Christian Kuhn''' (February 8, 1872 – June 16, 1926) was an American lawyer and judge. He served as  and later as a justice of the  in the early 20th century., Michigan Supreme Court Historical Society.Associated Press, , June 17, 1926. Kuhn was a .\n\n\nKuhn was born in  on February 8, 1872. He was education in the  public schools. He graduated from the  of the  in 1893 and from the Law Department of the University of Michigan (later the ) in 1894.\n\n\nFollowing graduation, Kuhn began practicing law in Mount Clemens. He served as circuit court commissioner of  until 1896, when he was elected Macomb County .  Kuhn was reelected in 1898 and 1900.\n\nIn 1904, Kuhn became  of Macomb County, and remained in that position until 1910, when he resigned to accept an appointment as . The vacancy in the attorney general position had been caused by the resignation of , who had resigned to accept an appointment to the Michigan Supreme Court.\n\nOn September 6, 1912,   appointed Kuhn to the  to fill a vacancy caused by the death of Justice . In November 1912, Kuhn was elected to a full term on the Supreme Court.\n\nHe resigned in 1919 and briefly returned to private practice before becoming president of the  in February 1920. Kuhn remained president of the telephone company until his death.\n\nHe died on June 16, 1926, at  in Detroit, at the age of 65, after a brief illness. He was buried at Mount Clemens.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n| allegiance = \n| branch = \n| serviceyears = \n| rank = \n| unit = \n| battles = \n| mawards = \n| website = \n}}\n'''Adolph Mongo''' (born January 15, 1954) is “a prominent political voice in Detroit,” who has served as a political advisor, newspaper reporter, radio host, and podcaster. As of August 2023, Mongo resides in . \n\n\nMongo was born on January 15, 1954, in Detroit, Michigan, and was raised in  where he attended  public schools.\n\nWhile a junior at , Mongo was managing editor of \"The Eagle American,\" the high school newspaper. Mongo was the first African-American student to hold the position. During his senior year, Mongo helped to lead the school to its first state championship in track, where he earned All State Honors.\n\n\nIn 1972, Mongo was awarded the WJR Scholarship in Broadcast Journalism as an incoming freshman at the  in . In May 1976, Mongo graduated, receiving his  with . Mongo later attended , where he received a  in labor history in 1999.\n\n\nFollowing undergraduate, Mongo joined the  Reserves. Mongo received a certificate in photo journalism from the  (DINFOS) in 1978.\n\n\nFrom 1978 until 1983, Mongo worked as a reporter for the \"\", \",\" the \"South Haven (Michigan) Daily Tribune\" and the \"\" newspapers. \n\nFor seven years, Mongo hosted \"Detroit in Black & White,\" a two-hour radio show on  Superstation/WFDF. In February 2023, Mongo left 910AM Superstation/WFDF and started a podcast titled \"Detroit in Black and White.\" The podcast first aired on February 25, 2023, and the first two podcasts had over 3,000 hits.\n\nMongo has also appeared on the  television program \",\" as well as 's \".\"\n\nMongo has been featured as an expert in Detroit politics by newspapers and publications throughout the United States, including: \",\" \",\" \",\" \",\" and \".\"\n\nMongo has contributed as a columnist to \",\" \"The Michigan Chronicle,\" \",\" \"Deadline Detroit,\" and has been a regular guest on 92.3 FM (), Fox 2 News \"Let It Rip,\"  (NBC) \"Flash Point,\" CBS Detroit, and \"The Detroit News\" web program \"Hold the Onions.\"\n\nTwo of Mongo's newspaper advertisements, \"Lynching is Still Legal in America\" and \"Sometimes a handshake and an acknowledgment makes a difference,\" sparked nationwide controversy in 2005 and 2006.\n\nMongo is spotlighted in chapter thirteen of Tim Skubick's book, \"See Dick and Jen Run\" (2006).  Skubick highlights Mongo's involvement in the 2006 race for Michigan governor. Mongo is also featured in 's, book, \",\" in a chapter titled \"Mongo.\"\n\n\nIn April, 1968, after the  of  Mongo organized a walkout in his school to protest the administration's decision not to let students leave early to attend church service. During his senior year in high school, Mongo was elected student mayor of Oak Park. Mongo won, making him the first African-American student to hold that office.\n\nFrom 1984 until 1991, Mongo was deputy director of public information under Detroit mayor .\n\nMongo was also a consultant for , the owner of the  that links Detroit to Canada. The Ambassador Bridge is the busiest international crossing in the U.S.\n\nIn 1998, Mongo led a protest against the  after a supervisor at Sinai Hospital posted a sign stating \"no black people allow\" outside a patient's room. The supervisor was later fired.\n\nIn 2007, Mongo campaigned for the release of three black students falsely accused of killing a woman from .\n\nIn April 2011, Mongo led a boycott against the Detroit NAACP's 56th Annual Fight for Freedom Fund Dinner and called for NAACP president Rev. Wendell Anthony to resign his position after Anthony had honoured  at a dinner. Mongo said that Anthony's actions were \"making it OK for people like Kid Rock to fly the … confederate flag\".Kid Rock had previously displayed the  in concerts.\n\nIn 2016, Mongo ran State Senator 's campaign for mayor of Detroit, against incumbent Mayor Mike Duggan. In 2018, Mongo was the campaign manager for 's campaign for the Democratic nomination in . The seat was vacant, due to the resignation of .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n\n\n|birth_place= , U.S.\n|death_date= \n|death_place= Alpena, Michigan, U.S.\n|spouse= Josephine White Morrison\n|children=2\n|party=\n|education=\n}}\n'''William Alfred Comstock''' (July 2, 1877 – June 16, 1949) was an American  who served as the 33rd .\n\n\nBorn in 1877 in , he attended the , where he was admitted to the  fraternity, graduating in 1899. Within the Zeta Psi Fraternity, \"The Vision of Bill Comstock\" is known as his desire to unite all the chapters through the publication of a newsletter known as ''The Circle'', which he first published in 1909. He established a successful career in real estate, banking and railroad construction.\n\n\nIn 1911, Comstock entered politics by serving as the Democratic county chairman. He served as  of Alpena from 1911 to 1912 and served as its mayor from 1913 to 1914. He was a member of  , from 1914 to 1916. He was a member of  in 1915 and served as its chairman from 1920 to 1924. Then he served as a member of  from Michigan, 1924–30. He served as a delegate to  from Michigan 1924 which nominated  for , again in 1928 to nominate , and lastly in 1932 to nominate , the only successful candidate of the three. Comstock was an unsuccessful candidate for  in 1926 and 1928 against , and unsuccessful as well in 1930 against .\n\nIn 1932, Comstock defeated Brucker and served as governor from 1933 to 1935. During his tenure, the state's first sales tax law was authorized, an old age pension system was initiated, but later failed; a trust commission was established; and an eight-day bank holiday was affirmed, which later led to President Roosevelt's announcement of a national holiday. He also pardoned  the former mayor of , who had been imprisoned for bribery with twelve others in 1932. Tenerowicz was later elected to .\n\n\nComstock later served as a member of the Michigan Civil Service Commission from 1939 to 1940, and as a member of the Detroit City Council from 1942 to 1949.\nHe was a member of the , , , and . He died from a stroke in  on June 16, 1949, and is interred there at Evergreen Cemetery.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Sheldon Andre Neeley''' (born September 20, 1968) is an American politician, currently serving as the  of . He was elected as Flint's mayor in 2019 and served an abbreviated three-year term before being re-elected in 2022. Neeley is a registered Democrat and a former state representative in Michigan's 34th House district. He served two complete terms and one partial term in the  between 2015 and 2019. He resigned from his position in the House when he was elected as the  in 2019. Neeley's wife, , was elected to his former seat on March 10, 2020. Neeley served two complete terms and one partial term on the Flint City Council between 2005 and 2014, prior to his tenure as Michigan Representative and was the Council's first African-American member to have come from Flint's Sixth Ward.\n\n\nNeeley was born September 20, 1968, to parents Marva and Sam Neeley. He was born and raised in Flint, Michigan, graduating from  in 1986.\n\nNeeley obtained his associate degree from . He later attended , though he did not graduate. In October 2022, Neeley received backlash after Fox News Digital published an article revealing that multiple sources, including the Mayor of Flint page on the city's website, claimed he had received a bachelor's degree from Saginaw Valley State University. He later claimed this error was the fault of a political staffer.\n\nNeeley worked as a broadcast technician for  for 27 years. He was the local union president of the  until 2020. He also served as a work experience counselor for 10 years for the . For 4 years, he served as CEO of the Flint Inner City Junior Golf League, an organization founded by his father, Sam Neeley.\n\n\n\n\nNeeley first ran for Flint City Council in 2001, losing to incumbent Mark Horrigan in the city’s 6th Ward .\n\nIn Neeley's second bid for Flint City Councilship in 2005, Horrigan chose not to run for re-election, instead opting to endorse Neeley. With Horrigan's retirement from the council, the 6th Ward was left without an  councilman. Neeley won the 6th Ward’s August 2 primary election, allowing him to move on to the , where he faced challenger Nancy DeKatch. Neeley and DeKatch each refrained from issuing  against one another throughout their campaigns. Neeley received an endorsement from the Genesee County Democratic Black Caucus a few days prior to the Flint City Council’s November 8 general election. Neeley won election to the Flint City Council by a large margin, receiving nearly three times as many votes as DeKatch in the 6th Ward’s general election. Neeley was elected  of the Flint City Council by his peers soon after.\n\nNeeley was re-elected vice president of the Flint City Council by his peers in November of both 2006 and 2007.\n\nIn 2009, Neeley ran for re-election to the Flint City Council. He won a plurality of votes cast in the 6th Ward’s August 4 primary election, advancing to face primary runner-up J.C. Walker in the general election. In October, Neeley was endorsed by both the Greater Flint  and the Flint Police Officers Association. Neeley won re-election to the Flint City Council in the 6th Ward’s general election on November 3.\n\nNeeley ran for re-election to the Flint City Council again in 2013. He ran unopposed in Flint’s 6th Ward primary election. He also ran unopposed in the general election and was re-elected to the Flint City Council on November 5.\n\n\nIn 2014, Neeley ran for election in . In the Democratic primary, Neeley ran against seven other , including future Flint mayoral race opponent and then-councilman Eric Mays. At a candidate forum in June 2014, Neeley expressed his support for  and local law enforcement. In  2014 voter questionnaire, Neeley voiced his opposition to Michigan’s implementation of  and listed job creation, education, and public safety as top priority issues. Neeley also suggested that elected officials in Flint be subject to s.\n\nOn August 5, Neeley won the 34th district Democratic primary with a plurality of votes. He received 2,966 votes, while runner-up Omar Sims received 1,888. In the Michigan House of Representatives 34th district general election, Neeley faced Republican Bruce Rogers, who ran unopposed in the district’s Republican primary. Neeley received more than 90% of votes cast in the general election and was elected to the  on November 2.\n\nIn 2016, Neeley ran for re-election to the Michigan House of Representatives in the state’s 34th district. He went unopposed in the Democratic primary. In the 2016 edition of  Voter Guide, Neeley voiced his support for  freezing as a temporary solution to rising tuition costs and listed infrastructure repair, environmental safety, law enforcement and economic growth as top priority issues. Neeley beat Republican challenger Page Brousseau in the November 8th general election, receiving nearly 90% of the vote.\n\nNeeley ran for re-election to the Michigan House of Representatives again in 2018. Neeley beat opponents Steven Greene and Syrron Williams in the August 7th Democratic primary with nearly 90% of votes cast in the 34th district. He went on to win the district’s general election, beating Republican Henry Swift with 90% of the vote on November 6.\n\n\nNeeley ran for Flint Mayor in 2007. When questioned by ''The Flint Journal'', Neeley identified public safety and economic development as key issues in the 2007 mayoral race. On August 2, Neeley received endorsements from both Sisters United and the Afro-American Police League. Neeley was eliminated in Flint's  primary election. In October, after then-mayor and candidate for re-election  used a photo which featured Neeley in campaign material, the councilman threatened to sue Williamson. Williamson won re-election as Flint's mayor in November.\n\nNeeley ran for Flint Mayor again in 2009. Neeley stressed the importance of economic development during his campaign. He was eliminated in Flint's nonpartisan primary election.\n\nNeeley announced his  for Flint Mayor in April 2019. In the city’s August 6 nonpartisan primary election, Neeley faced Greg Eason, Don Pfeiffer, and incumbent . Neeley and Weaver advanced to Flint's general mayoral election after receiving 3,586 votes and 3,815 votes, respectively. Over the course of the 2019 election cycle, Neeley raised $23,465 while Weaver raised $299,738. After a number of Flint residents alleged ballot mishandling, Neeley personally requested that the  oversee Flint's mayoral election. Neeley's request was denied. In the November 5th general election, Neeley won 7,082 votes to Weaver’s 6,877, and Neeley was elected as Flint's mayor.\n\nOn February 2, 2022, the ''Flint Journal'' published an article stating that Neeley had disclosed his intention to run for re-election as Flint's mayor to the paper on January 31. On May 28, 2022,  announced her endorsement of Neeley for Mayor of Flint. Neeley received 4,943 votes (48.8% of those cast) in Flint's nonpartisan primary election held on August 2. Former Flint Mayor Karen Weaver was runner-up in the 2022 primary, receiving 4,062 votes (40.1%). In the Flint mayoral general election on November 8, Neeley netted 11,692 votes, winning a second term as Flint's mayor. Weaver garnered 10,411 votes. Neeley's re-election campaign spending reached a total of $166,000.\n\n\n\n\nGiven Flint's strong mayoral powers, the mayor has the ability to appoint government officials, including police and fire chiefs. In November 2019 when Neeley was elected, he appointed Phil Hart as the interim police chief, who was standing in while Neeley found the right officer to fill the important position permanently. In Hart's time as police chief, he had the job of addressing Flint's rising gun violence in a way that would set up for the incoming permanent police chief. Neeley and Hart worked together to end the gun buyback program, recruiting new officers, and increasing neighborhood patrol. In September 2020, Terrance Green took over as the permanent Flint police chief. He previously served in the neighboring town of Mt. Morris as police chief, as well as commander for the drug unit of Genesee County.\n\n\nCompared to 2019 when Neeley took office, there was a 30% increase in homicides, ranking Flint the tenth highest city for violent crimes in 2020. In the light of rising homicides and shootings, Neeley asked for emergency state and federal assistance initially in July 2021, but pushed to extend the emergency help indefinitely to try to curb the street violence. Through several executive orders, the Flint Police Department partnered with community mental health professionals to offer trauma counseling and community outreach programs to help the Flint community through this violence.\n\nIn continued efforts to curb the rise of Flint gun violence, Neeley ended the gun buyback program, a program that auctions off confiscated guns back to the public, these funds then go to supporting the Flint police department. Neeley believed ending this program was an essential step towards limiting the guns that return to the streets. The Flint police department now destroyed of all guns that were collected through police work after Neeley's order, which urges that keeping guns out of neighborhoods is more important than the department funding. Neeley states he is not anti-guns but rather is against guns becoming a street currency in Flint.\n\n\nThe City of Flint began their COVID response on Tuesday, March 17, 2020, by closing City Hall. Flint was the second city in Michigan to acknowledge the pandemic as a state of emergency. However, Neeley did not implement a stay-at-home order, instead asking residents to voluntarily limit their social meetings. Flint is the only city in its area to employ a medical advisor to guide them through the pandemic. The city also implemented a program to provide water bill relief to residents during the pandemic, and was the only city in Michigan to do so.\n\n\nAs of 2019, when Neeley was elected, the Flint water crisis was still an issue in the city. The city was still working on changing its water pipes from lead as well as building a water treatment plan. The Water Infrastructure Improvements for the Nation Act provided $100 million dollars to fund these expenditures. As of July 2016, before Neeley took office, the lead in Flint’s water had been within state levels.\n\n\nOn March 8, 2020, Neeley announced his  of  in the .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

    "pages": }\n'''Daniel Timothy Kildee''' (; born August 11, 1958) is an American politician serving as a  from Michigan since 2013, representing the state's  since 2023. A member of the , he previously served as the Genesee County Treasurer from 1996 to 2013, before succeeding his uncle, , in Congress.\n\nFrom 1977 to 2009, Kildee was a municipal elected official. On November 16, 2023, he announced he would not seek re-election in 2024.\n\n\nKildee was born in . He attended  and . In 2008, he finished his coursework at CMU, earning a B.S. in  administration.\n\n\nAt age 18, Kildee became one of the nation's youngest elected officials when he was elected to the Flint Board of Education in 1977. In 1984, Kildee was elected to serve on 's board of commissioners. He served on the board for 12 years, including five as chair.\n\nIn 1991, Kildee ran for . He was one of four candidates to challenge incumbent Mayor  in the August 6 nonpartisan primary election. City Councilman  finished first with 24% of the vote. Collier ranked second with 23% of the vote, qualifying for the November election. Kildee finished third with 18%. In 1996, Kildee was elected Genesee County Treasurer. He was reelected in 2000, 2004, and 2008. In 2008, he received 72% of the vote.\n\nIn 2002, Kildee helped create the  Land Bank, a Washington-D.C. based nonprofit organization focused on . The land bank has helped to clean up vacant and abandoned structures in the community.  The Genesee County Land Bank was the first community land bank in the U.S. The concept of community land banks has since expanded to other U.S. cities.\n\nIn 2009, Kildee co-founded and served as president of the Center for Community Progress, a nonprofit focused on urban revitalization. He resigned as county treasurer to oversee the group.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nKildee's uncle, , served in the  representing . In July 2011, Dale Kildee announced he would retire from Congress. Dan Kildee declared his candidacy for the House on November 1, 2011. He was unchallenged in the Democratic primary. In the , he defeated Republican State Representative , 65% to 31%.\n\n\n .]]\n\nIn January 2013, then-  appointed Kildee assistant whip. His fellow freshmen Democratic members elected Kildee to serve as their representative to the caucus's .\n\nIn 2019, Kildee helped secure $11.2 million in federal funding to demolish blighted homes in Saginaw. He supported Steny Hoyer's \"Make it in America\" legislation, which would remove tax breaks for companies that move jobs overseas.\n\nIn a September 2016 speech on the U.S. House floor, Kildee claimed that House Republican leaders were refusing to approve emergency aid to Flint because a majority of its residents are Black. Congress passed a funding measure that provided $170 million in aid to communities including Flint that sought infrastructure improvements for their water.\n\nKildee voted with President Joe Biden's stated position 100% of the time in the , according to a '''' analysis.\n\n\n\nIn 2022, Kildee voted for H.R. 1808: Assault Weapons Ban of 2022.\n\n\nKildee is a supporter of abortion rights and emphasized the issue during his . In September 2022, he hosted a reproductive rights roundtable alongside Representative  in .\n\n\nOn January 31, 2023, Kildee voted against H.R.497:Freedom for Health Care Workers Act, a bill which would lift COVID-19 vaccine mandates for healthcare workers.\n\nOn February 1, 2023, Kildee voted against a resolution to end COVID-19 national emergency.\n\n\nKildee voted for the . Kildee has attributed the rising rates of inflation to the .\n\n\nIn 2019, Kildee voted for Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's amendment to H.R. 2500, which would prohibit the president from deploying troops on the southern border to enforce immigration law.\n\n\nKildee voted to  then-president  in both  and . On July 27, 2019, he was one of 95 Democrats to vote against the motion to table H. Res. 498, which would table the impeachment inquiry into Trump.\n\n\nKildee has criticized the 60-vote majority Senate rule and compared it to Jim Crow Era laws.\n\n\nKildee introduced legislation that included a provision for a $7,500 tax credit for electric vehicle buyers.\n\n\nIn 2014, Kildee voted against H.R. 1944: The Private Property Rights Protection Act of 2014, which would have prohibited government use of eminent domain for the purpose of economic development.\n\n\nIn April 2018, Kildee, , , and  launched the . The Freethought Caucus advocates for more non-religious representation in Congress and opposes state promotion of religion.\n\nKildee supports humanist chaplains and in 2013, Kildee voted against an amendment that would prohibit funds from being used to appoint chaplains without an endorsing agency.\n\n\nKildee is a sponsor of H.R. 40, the Commission to Study and Develop Reparation Proposals for African Americans Act. The bill would allow history books to go into more depth on African American struggles and set up a reparations commission for those with enslaved ancestors.\n\n\nIn 2013, Kildee voted in favor of intervention and arming the Syrian Opposition against  and .\n\n\nIn 2022, Kildee was among the representatives to sign a letter calling on President  to lift tariffs on China.\n\n\nKildee has voted in favor of aid to .\n\n\n\n\nKildee voted for the  amendment to H.R. 1, the Voting Rights Act which would lower the voting age to 16.\n\nOn February 9, 2023, Kildee voted against H.J.Res. 24: Disapproving the action of the District of Columbia Council in approving the Local Resident Voting Rights Amendment Act of 2022 which condemns the District of Columbia's plan that would allow noncitizens to vote in local elections.\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n* \n* \n*\n*\n* House Pro-Choice Caucus\n* \n\n\n\nKildee was a candidate in the , setting up an exploratory committee and filing to run. He ultimately dropped out of the race. He was also rumored to be considering a run in the , but publicly declared he would not run.\n\n\nKildee has been married to Jennifer Kildee since 1988. They have three children. His brother Timothy was killed in a shooting in 2024.\n\nOn March 31, 2023, Kildee announced that he had been diagnosed with , saying that a \"very small tumor\" had been found in one of his tonsils. He said he would undergo surgery and described his prognosis as \"excellent\".\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* official U.S. House website\n*\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Rocca's father is  and his step-mother is . Rocca's parents both are politicians in Michigan and previously served in the .\n\n\nRocca earned a bachelor's degree from . Rocca practiced business law and product liability law.\n\nIn November 2004, Rocca was elected as member of the Michigan State House of Representatives for .\n\nIn November 2010, Rocca was elected as member of Michigan State Senate for District 10.\n\nRocca was the chairman of the Regulatory Reform Committee in the Senate and he was the vice-chair of the Joint Committee on Administrative Rules.\n\nAs of June 2018, due to term limits, Rocca will not be able to run for another term.     "pages": }\n\n\n'''Lynn Nancy Rivers''' (née '''Carruthers'''; born December 19, 1956) is an American  and lawyer from . She served four terms in the  from 1995 to 2003.\n\n\nRivers was born in , and graduated from Au Gres-Sims High School, , in 1975. She was married the day after graduation, and had 2 children by age 21.\n\nShe received a  in  from the  in 1987 and a  from  in 1992.\n\n\nShe served as a trustee of the   from 1984 to 1992. She was a member of the  between 1993 and 1994.\n\nRivers was elected as a  from Michigan's 13th District to the  for the  and to the three succeeding Congresses, serving from January 3, 1995, to January 3, 2003.\n\nAfter Michigan lost a district in the  reapportionment, much of her district was merged into a redrawn  together with long-time incumbent . Rivers challenged Dingell in the Democratic primary for the new 15th. However, running in a district that was over 65 percent new to her, she lost to Dingell by 18 points.\n\nImmediately after leaving Congress, she taught political science at the  and at .\n\n\n\n\nDuring her first US House run in 1994, Rivers spoke publicly about her long struggle with . She was about 21 when she was diagnosed. While in Congress she spoke about her condition on the House floor, making her the first openly bipolar member of Congress. In 1998, the National Mental Health Association (NMHA) named her \"Legislator of the Year.\"\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  at \n*\n\n\n\n\n |years= 1993&ndash;1995}}\n\n\n\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
