    "pages": }\n'''Thaddeus George McCotter''' (born August 22, 1965) is an American politician, radio host, and a member of the . He was the  from  from 2003 to 2012. The district at the time consisted of portions of 's northwestern suburbs, such as ,  and . He was also a  for the .\n\nMcCotter first entered politics in 1992 when he was elected to the  Commission. He then served in the  from 1999 to 2003. In , McCotter was elected to the U.S. House of Representatives. From July to September 2011, McCotter was a candidate for the Republican presidential nomination for the 2012 race. After a last place finish in the  in August and failing to secure a spot in the presidential debates, McCotter suspended his campaign.\n\nAfter ending his presidential campaign, McCotter decided to run again for his seat in Congress, but he failed to qualify for the  in his congressional district after most of his petition signatures were rejected as invalid. McCotter himself was not suspected of wrongdoing, though several of his staffers were charged with duplicating signatures and other electoral crimes, and some convicted. McCotter later sued some of the perpetrators for damage to his reputation, but fallout from the ensuing scandal resulted in McCotter's resignation from Congress in July 2012.\n\n\nMcCotter was born in , Michigan, and is a 1983 graduate of  in . His mother, Georgia Joan McCotter, was the city clerk of Livonia.\nHe received a  from the  in 1987 and a  from the same school in 1990.\n\nMcCotter had a private law practice and was a  trustee before being elected to the  Commission in 1992. While on the commission, he worked to change the county charter to require that new taxes require the approval of two-thirds of the Commission and 60% of voters.\n\nMcCotter was elected to the  in 1998. As a state senator, he helped apportion the U.S. Congressional district from which he was subsequently elected in 2002.\n\n\n\n\n* \n** \n** \n** \n\n\n* Congressional COPD Caucus\n* House Sovereignty Caucus (co-founder)\n* \n* Sportsmen's Caucus\n\nShortly before the midterm elections in November 2006, McCotter made a $250,000 contribution to the . After the elections, when the Republicans became the minority party in the House of Representatives, McCotter was elected chairman of the , the fifth-ranking post among House Republicans. The other  seeking the post was Congressman  of southern California.\n\n\nMcCotter was a member of both the moderate  and the conservative .\n\nIn May 2007, McCotter, along with 55 other Republicans, voted for a bill written by House Democrats aimed at stopping energy , against the wishes of House Minority Leader , who labeled the bill \"as pointless political \".\n\nMcCotter was a supporter of the United States' involvement in both the  and the . In his 2011 book ''Seize Freedom!'', he wrote that the wars \"were never separate wars; they have always been battle theaters in the War for Freedom.\"\n\nOn September 22, 2008, McCotter became the first Republican in the House of Representatives to oppose the $700 billion , calling it \"American socialism\". A week later, he and 132 other Republicans voted against the bill.\n\nAt the end of July 2009, McCotter introduced a bill to allow pet owners a $3,500 tax deduction for pet care costs.\nThe bill, called the ''Humanity and Pets Partnered Through the Years'' (HAPPY) Act, was criticized by Howard Gleckman of the  as \"the poster puppy for all that is wrong with the tax code.\"\n\nMcCotter supported -friendly measures including collective bargaining agreements for government jobs and , although he later said his vote for the so-called card check method was a mistake.\n\n\nMcCotter was elected in November 2002, defeating Democratic Candidate Kevin Kelley of Redford, to the . He was reelected in the . McCotter ran unopposed in the 2006 Republican primary. His opponent in the  was  Tony Trupiano, a progressive radio talk show host from . McCotter, Trupiano,  nominee John Tatar, and  nominee Charles Tackett met only once for a recorded  public forum in mid-October. In radio and direct-mail advertisements, McCotter criticized Trupiano's position on , and he was reelected with 55 percent of the vote.\n\nIn November 2008, McCotter defeated Democrat Joseph Larkin, Green Party candidate Erik Shelley, and Libertarian John Tatar. McCotter won 51 percent of the vote to Larkin's 45 percent. In November 2010, McCotter defeated Democrat Natalie Mosher with 59 percent of the vote to Mosher's 39 percent.\n\n\n\nIn May 2011, McCotter confirmed that he was considering a run for the Republican Party nomination for President of the United States in .\nBy late June, sources indicated that McCotter would enter the race.\nOn June 23, 2011, a McCotter representative bid $18,000 for a site at the  Auction in .\nOn July 1, 2011, McCotter announced that he had filed with the  (FEC) as a candidate for president.\nOn July 2, 2011, McCotter announced his candidacy at WAAM Freedom Fest in , outside of Detroit.\n\nThroughout his campaign, commentators suggested that McCotter's lack of name recognition nationwide would hamper his chances of winning the nomination. In opinion polls that included McCotter, he received less than one percent and he came in last place in the August 2011 . On September 22, 2011, McCotter announced the end of his campaign for the presidential nomination, and said that his exclusion from presidential debates had hindered it. Given the lack of media coverage of his campaign, McCotter called the end of his presidential campaign \"death by media.\" He said he would endorse  and would run again for his  .\n\n\nIn April 2011, McCotter was the only member of Michigan's 15-member congressional delegation who did not confirm he was running for reelection. He indicated interest in running against incumbent Democrat  for the U.S. Senate seat in Michigan in 2012, but in May 2011 announced that he would not campaign for the position.\n\nAfter announcing his intention to run for reelection, McCotter was expected to win the Republican nomination easily, but on May 25, 2012,   announced that he had failed to submit enough valid petition signatures to qualify for the August 7 primary ballot. Although McCotter had submitted 2,000 signatures, the maximum permitted by Michigan law for congressional primaries, a preliminary review indicated that fewer than the required minimum of 1,000 were valid. According to a spokeswoman for the Secretary of State's office, several of McCotter's petition signatures were duplicates. Michigan election law stipulates that if duplicates are found, both the original and duplicate are ruled invalid. McCotter had the option of running as a write-in candidate in the primary election or as an independent in the general election if he failed to qualify for a primary ballot spot.\n\nAt the time the apparent fraud was uncovered, McCotter was on a congressional trip to . On May 26, a source within McCotter's campaign told the '''' that McCotter conceded that the signatures would be ruled invalid, and that he was considering a write-in effort. McCotter confirmed this to Nolan Finley of '''', adding that he did not understand what happened with the signatures on the petitions.Schultz, Marsha. . '''', May 28, 2012.\n\nLater that day, state officials announced in two separate reviews that more than 85 percent of McCotter's petition signatures were invalid. The Secretary of State's office said its review revealed only 244 of 2,000 signatures were valid. Numerous petition sheets appeared to have been copiedin some cases, as many as three timesand in some cases a different canvasser's name was attached to one of the copies. Michigan elections director Chris Thomas conducted his own review, and said there was evidence signatures from 2010 petitions had been cut-and-pasted onto the 2012 sheets. Thomas also said that McCotter had only turned in 1,830 signatures, and all but 244 were invalid. His office's review revealed that dozens of petition sheets appeared to have been copied in what he described as an \"unprecedented level\" of fraud.\n\nLate on May 27, the Secretary of State's office announced that it found the potential fraud egregious enough to ask   to look into the matter. In an op-ed that ran in the May 29, 2012, ''Detroit News'', McCotter announced he would mount a write-in campaign in the Republican primary for his seat. He also acknowledged that the signatures in question were indeed invalid, based on his own legal team's review. Likening himself to  in '''', McCotter said that he was running a write-in campaign to \"clean up my own mess.\"\n\nOn June 2, McCotter announced that he was ending his bid for reelection and would leave the House at the end of his term. In his statement, he said that he felt obligated to fulfill his duties in Congress and assist Schuette and Johnson in getting to the bottom of the petition fraud. These obligations, he said, made mounting a write-in bid for Congress impossible. \"One can't clean up a mess multitasking,\" he said. McCotter was the first sitting congressman since the late 1940s not to qualify for his party's primary.\n\nA month later, on July 5, ''The Detroit News'' reported that McCotter had spent much of the time since his presidential campaign failed writing a  script for a comedy/variety show starring himself, to be called ''Bumper Sticker: Made on MoTown''. It featured characters with the same nicknames he used for members of his staff and a guest appearance by conservative commentator . \"They take pot shots about McCotter's ill-fated bid for the White House while spewing banter about drinking, sex, race, flatulence, puking and women's anatomy\", the newspaper wrote.\n\n\nOn July 6, 2012, McCotter resigned from the House. He said:\n\nHe also wrote:\n\nWhile McCotter was not suspected of any wrongdoing, several of his staff members were charged with crimes.Blake, Aaron (July 6, 2012). \"\". ''The Washington Post''. District Director Paul Seewald pleaded guilty to falsely signing a petition and was given two years of probation. Deputy District Director Don Yowchuang pleaded no contest to ten counts of felony forgery and was given three years of probation. Scheduler Lorraine O'Brady pleaded no contest to five counts of falsely signing a nominating petition and was sentenced to 20 days in jail. District Representative Mary M. Turnbull pleaded no contest to the felony of committing an illegal act and was sentenced to two years of probation and one day in jail.\n\nMcCotter's resignation left the 11th district unrepresented until the , when Democrat  was elected in a special election to finish McCotter's term. Republican  succeeded Curson in January 2013 as the representative of the redrawn 11th district.\n\n\nIn January 2014, McCotter launched ''Thaddeus McCotter's Freedom Asylum'', a radio program on  in . It was canceled by June 2014.\n\nIn June 2017, McCotter served as an  in the . McCotter regularly appears on the ''John Batchelor Show'' radio program, on Cumulus Media, across the United States.\n\n\n* ''Seize Freedom!: American Truths and Renewal in a Chaotic Age'', , 2011\n* ''Bumper Sticker: Made on Motown'' (unfinished television pilot)\n\n\nMcCotter is a practicing Catholic.\n\nIn December 2005, McCotter joined with several other Congressmen to form the \"\", a   and  band set to play for United States troops stationed overseas over the holiday season. He played lead . In June 2006, the band played at President 's picnic on the White House lawn, where Bush was quoted calling McCotter \"that rock-and-roll dude\". McCotter was once in a band called the New Flying Squirrels.\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n*  ''official U.S. House website''\n* \n* \n*   at the  (presidential)\n*  at  (presidential)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Angela Kaye Witwer''' is an American politician and a  member of the , serving the 76th House District. Detroit Free Press |url=https://www.freep.com/elections/results/race/2022-11-08-state_house-MI-23896/ |access-date=April 21, 2023 |website=www.freep.com |language=en}}\n\n\nWitwer was born in , a village near . She grew up on a farm with her parents, George and Marilyn, and her three sisters.\n\nWitwer is an alumna of Waverly Community Schools. She received her bachelor's degree in business and marketing from .\n\n\nBefore being elected to the state legislature, Witwer spent 22 years working in clinical health care, including 's burn unit and as a manager in pediatric rehabilitation. Later, she became the manager of Sparrow Hospital's community relations and marketing department.\n\nWitwer also co-founded Edge Partnership, a public relations, marketing, and advocacy group. She has also served as the vice president of Waverly Community Schools Board of Education, and has spent time as a member of the Lansing Regional Chamber of Commerce Economic Club committee, McLaren Greater Lansing Foundation Board of Directors, and the Wharton Center for Performing Arts Advisory Council.\n\n\nWitwer was first elected to the Michigan House of Representatives on November 6, 2018. She won by fewer than 800 votes against opponent Christine Barnes.\n\nWitwer was re-elected to the Michigan House of Representatives in 2020 for House District 71, defeating opponent Gina Johnsen.\n\nWitwer won her election in 2022 with over 55% of the vote. This time she was elected to House District 76, defeating  opponent Jeremy Whittum. The district change was due to the state's recent .\n\n\nWitwer resides in Delta Township, where she has been a resident for almost 50 years.     "pages": }\n'''Kevin M. Cotter''' (born September 26, 1977) is an American politician who represented the  in the ., ''Central Michigan Life'', November 3, 2010. He is a member of the . He worked as an attorney in Mt. Pleasant before winning election to the state House in 2010. After serving as chair of the House Judiciary Committee and vice chair of the Elections and Ethics Committee, in November 2014 he was selected by the Republican caucus to serve as Speaker of the Michigan House of Representatives for the 2015-16 legislative session. On September 8, 2016, a federal lawsuit was filed against Representative Cotter (and numerous other defendants) by former State Representative Todd Courser.\n\n\nCotter is a graduate of Shepherd High School and holds a bachelor's degree in Entrepreneurship and Business Administration, as well as a Master's of Science in Administration, both from . He also earned a Juris Doctor degree from ., mlive.com; accessed January 2, 2015.\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Jon Hoadley''' (born August 14, 1983) is an American politician from . A member of the , Hoadley has represented the which includes the entire City of  and the majority of in the  since first winning election .\n\nIn April 2019, Hoadley announced that he would run in the 2020 Democratic primary election in . He won the Democratic primary but lost to incumbent Republican  in the November 2020 general election.\n\n\n\nHoadley was born on August 14, 1983, to Michael and Diane Hoadley. He has an older sister. Hoadley grew up in . After high school, he moved to Michigan and graduated from .\n\n\nHoadley has been involved in  and progressive political advocacy since college, and has worked on political campaigns since 2004. He has worked for the , managed the campaign opposing , and served as executive director of the . Currently, he serves on the Michigan Advisory Committee to the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights.\n\nPrior to his election to the Michigan Legislature, he became president and owner of Badlands Strategies, a progressive public affairs consulting firm. During this time he managed a local campaign to defend Kalamazoo's local non-discrimination ordinance, and assisted with a similar campaign in . He also managed the campaign to elect Justice  and worked with the Unity Michigan Coalition.\n\n\n\nHe was elected to serve the 60th district in the Michigan House of Representatives in November 2014 and re-elected in 2016 and 2018.\n\nIn his first term in the Michigan House of Representatives, he served on the House Elections Committee and the House Appropriations Committee, where he has served as the Democratic vice chair of the Judiciary and Agriculture subcommittees and sat on the Higher Education subcommittee.\n\nIn his second term in the Michigan House of Representatives, he served on the Appropriations Committee. He was the Democratic vice chair of the Higher Education and Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development subcommittees. He also served on the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality Subcommittee.\n\n\nHoadley defeated David Buskirk and Pamela Brown Goodacre in the Democratic primary for the 60th district of the Michigan House of Representatives on August 5, 2014. He then went on to defeat  candidate Mike Perrin in the general election on November 4, 2014.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAfter being elected to his first term in November 2014, Hoadley was unopposed in the 2016 Democratic Party primary for the 60th district of the Michigan House of Representatives. He went on to defeat the Republican Party nominee, Kalamazoo College student Alexander Ross, and Libertarian Party nominee, activist Logan Fleckenstein, in the general election on November 8, 2016.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nHoadley was a candidate in the  in . He won the Democratic primary on August 4, 2020, and challenged incumbent representative  in the November 3, 2020, general election. According to his campaign website, Hoadley ran on a platform of progressive policies, such as a  and  system. His campaign website stated that he has been endorsed by Democratic politicians and organizations including , , Michigan Governor , and the .\n\nThe day before Michigan's Democratic primary, a blog Hoadley had kept as a college student was deleted from the Internet. In the blog, Hoadley had discussed drug use and sex and made controversial comments about women and children. Hoadley's campaign said the blog was \"bad college poetry.\" The  said Hoadley's controversial comments were satirical and taken out of context. The group accused the  of using  against Hoadley in relation to the blog. In a Facebook video, Hoadley apologized for the comments, and his Democratic primary challenger, Jen Richardson, apologized for her part in publicizing the comments.\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\nHoadley is openly gay and lives in Kalamazoo with his partner, Kris.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*  government website\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''John J. Gleason''' (b. August 26, 1954 ) is a  politician and former Clerk/Register of Deeds for .\n\n\n\n\nGleason was elected to the Genesee County Board of Commissioners in 1994. He moved on to be elected to the state House of Representatives 48 District in 2002 continuing as Representative until he was elected to Michigan Senate in 2006. He was reelected State Senator in 2010 to his final available term under state term limits. Considering a run for the soon to be vacated U.S. Representative office by , Gleason instead filed to run for the newly combined office of Genesee County /. Both current officeholders, Clerk Michael J. Carr and( , of the soon to be merged positions filed to run for new office. Bogardus withdrew assuming Carr would continue his campaign while Carr also withdrew to retire leaving Gleason the sole Democratic candidate for Clerk/Register. Gleason defeat Republican Michael Stikovich in the Clerk/Register general election 119,838 to 52,996. Local news outlets reported on April 8, 2022, Gleason was arrested on several charges. The charges are bribing or intimidating a witness and willful neglect of duty.\nOn October 25, 2022, he pleaded guilty and resigned from office.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Hazen Stuart Pingree''' (August 30, 1840 – June 18, 1901) was a four-term  mayor of  (1889–1897) and the 24th  (1897–1901). A  who migrated from New England, he was a successful  businessman turned politician.\n\nAs a businessman turned politician, Pingree was elected mayor in 1889 after a colorful campaign in which Pingree revealed his tolerance by making a circuit of saloons. Pingree added to the old stock Yankee Republican base by making large inroads into the German and Canadian elements. He was reelected in 1891, 1893 and 1895. Warning repeatedly against the dangers of monopolistic corporations, he launched nationally visible crusades against Detroit's streetcar, gas, electric, and telephone companies. He successfully forced rate reductions that won him widespread popularity. He won public approval for a citizen-owned electric light plant and became a national spokesman for municipal ownership and public regulation of utilities and street railways.\n\nWhen the nationwide Panic of 1893 caused a severe depression, Pingree gained support by opening empty lots to garden farming launching Pingree's \"Potato Patch Plan\", initially financed by Pingree, who sold his prize horse to pay for the farming tools and seeds. Pingree was a Republican, whose policies competed for support of the  voters and labor union members. He supported the gold standard in 1896, and worked to carry Michigan for  over silverite  in the intensely competitive 1896 U.S. presidential election.\n\nPingree was on the ballot too, and was elected governor of Michigan. As governor, he succeeded in forcing passage of the nation's first major statewide reappraisal of railroad and corporate property, with intent on implementing taxes. That led to a rational basis for railroad regulation and other trust busting ideas launched by the Republican Party. A survey of scholars in 1985 ranked Pingree as the third-best mayor in all of American history.\n\n\nPingree was born in , to Jasper Pingree and Adeline (Bryant) Pingree and attended the common schools in . At the age of fourteen, he moved to , where he worked at a cotton factory. Two years later, he moved to , and worked several years as a cutter in a shoe factory.\n\n\nIn 1862, Pingree enlisted in the  to serve in the  with the 1st Massachusetts Heavy Artillery Regiment (Company F). He fought on the front line during 's  and the . The regiment he fought with was then ordered to defend Washington, D.C., until May 15, 1864, and then was sent to the front again. He fought with the Second Brigade of Tyler's Division, , which participated in battles at Fredericksburg Road (May 18), Harris Farm (May 19), and  (May 19–21).\n\nHis regiment was then assigned to the Second Corps, Third Division, in the  and fought at North Anna (May 24–25) where he and some other men were captured by a detachment of 's command. Pingree was confined in Confederate prisons at  and , and at . He was then taken to  and, while  was on his march to the sea, he was taken to , where he later escaped by pretending to be someone else during a roll call for a prisoner exchange in November 1864. Pingree rejoined his regiment, fought in many more battles, and was present at  when  surrendered on April 9, 1865. A few months later, on August 15, his regiment was mustered out.\n\n\nPingree was a cobbler by trade and, following the war, moved to Detroit and briefly worked for 's shoe company. In 1866, Pingree and his accountant, Charles H. Smith, purchased Baldwin's shoe-making machinery and formed the Pingree and Smith company.\nIn 1883, Smith retired from the firm and J. B. Howarth and Pingree's son Joe joined the partnership. By 1886, it was a $1 million company with 700 employees turning out a half-million shoes and boots a year. It was the second biggest shoe manufacturer in the U.S. In March 1887, a fire destroyed the entire plant, yet they were able to recover.\n\nIn 1872, Pingree married Frances A. Gilbert of . They had three children – Joe, Hazel, and Gertrude, who died in 1894 of tuberculosis at age 19.\n\n\nPingree had never been active in politics. As a citizen reformer he was elected  in 1889 on a platform of exposing and ending corruption in city paving contracts, sewer contracts, and the school board. He soon turned to fighting privately owned utility monopolies. He challenged the electric and gas monopolies through municipally owned competitors. His largest struggle, however, was with , president of the , over lowering streetcar fares to three cents. Pingree again attempted to create a competing municipally owned company, but was barred from creating a railway by the .Holli, 1970. When the company sought a thirty-year contract with the city, Pingree opposed it, leading a major shareholder, , to express vehement disapproval. (retrieved 24 January 2018).\n\nDuring the severe nationwide , Pingree expanded the public welfare programs, initiated public works for the unemployed, built new schools, parks, and public baths. He gained national recognition through his \"potato patch plan\", which allowed poor people to use  of vacant city land for growing food. He was also an advocate of economist 's .\n\nA 1993 survey of historians, political scientists and urban experts conducted by Melvin G. Holli of the  saw Pingree ranked as the fourth-best mayor of a major American city to serve between the years 1820 and 1993.\n\n\n\nIn 1896 Pingree was nominated as the GOP candidate for . He campaigned on a platform of pluralism, inviting the Germans and other ethnics to join a grand coalition that would bring prosperity to everyone, unlike the false prosperity promised by the silverites. He carried the state both for himself and Republican presidential candidate .\n\nAfter taking office on January 1, 1897, he intended to also fill the last year of his term as mayor of Detroit, which would have lasted until elections in November 1897. However, his right to hold the two offices simultaneously was contested, and after the  ruled against him, Pingree resigned as mayor.\n\nDuring his four years in office, Pingree promoted the regulation of railroad rates, equal taxation, and municipal ownership of public utilities. He also supported the direct election of U.S. senators; an ; an income tax; primary elections; the power of \"referendum\", the abolition of child labor, and compulsory arbitration of labor disputes. Opposition from Democrats and business-oriented Republicans blocked most of his proposals. Pingree expressed the Progressive fear of corporate power, saying, \"I do not condemn corporations and rich men\", he said, \"but I would keep them within their proper spheres. It is not safe to entrust the government of the country to the influence of Wall Street.\"\n\n\n, Detroit.]] Pingree did not run for reelection in 1900. In 1901, Pingree arrived in London, England, while returning from an African safari with his son. He was stricken with  and was unable to return to the U.S. , Pingree's famous look alike, even sent his own physicians to London's Grand Hotel to assist in Pingree's recovery.\n\nPingree was interred at the , Detroit, Michigan, and later reinterred at the  in Detroit. There is a statue of Pingree standing in the  in Detroit, commemorating him as \"The Idol of the People\". The sculpture was made by Austrian sculptor .\n\nThere is also a bronze bust of him on the thirteenth floor of the Coleman A. Young Municipal Building in Detroit.\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n* Holli, Melvin G. ''The American Mayor: The Best & the Worst Big-City Leaders'' (1999), pp.&nbsp;35–75.\n* Holli, Melvin G. \"Mayor Pingree Campaigns for the Governorship\", ''Michigan History'' (1973) 57#2, pp.&nbsp;151–173.\n*\n* \n*Loomis, Bill. \"Hazen Pingree: Quite possibly Detroit's finest mayor\", \n* \n* Sych, Lawrence. \"Political Clubs In Michigan Election Campaigns: A Comparison of the Pingree and Griffin Campaigns\", ''Michigan Academician'' (2002) 34#2 pp 143–162. compares 1896 and 1978\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Frank Dwight Fitzgerald''' (January 27, 1885 – March 16, 1939) was an American . He was elected as the 34th and 36th  and was the only Michigan governor to die in office.\n\n\nFitzgerald was born in , the son of , a member of the  from , 1st District, 1895–1896, and Carrie G. (Foreman) Fitzgerald. He was married on June 28, 1909, to Queena M. Warner and they had one child together. He was also the father of , a  and justice of the  as well as chief justice in 1982. Fitzgerald was also the grandfather of , who was a member of the Michigan House from the  1987-1992 and  1993–1996, and the great-grandfather of , the Democratic State Representative from the  in . He attended Grand Ledge High School, and received further education at the Ferris Institute (now ) in .\n\n\nFitzgerald entered politics in 1913, serving as clerk of the State House, as well as serving as clerk of the State Senate, a position held six years. He was also deputy secretary of state from 1919 to 1923.\n\nFitzgerald served as a delegate from Michigan to the  at which   was nominated for President. He was a member of Michigan Republican State Central Committee, 1925–1926 and secretary of the , 1929–30. In 1931, he was elected . He served as a delegate to the , when the convention nominated incumbent President . Hoover ultimately lost to  in the .\n\nIn 1934, Fitzgerald resigned from office to run for Governor of Michigan. He was elected, defeating  Arthur J. Lacy and served a full two-year term. During his term, the state budget was balanced and the consolidation of state agencies was promoted. He was a delegate to the , which nominated , who ultimately lost to Roosevelt in the 1936 General Election. Later that year, Fitzgerald was defeated in his bid for re-election as governor by Democrat .\n\nFitzgerald's son, , was a Michigan State Senator and Michigan Supreme Court Justice. Fitzgerald's grandson, , served in the Michigan State House of Representatives between 1986 and 1998. Fitzgerald's great-grandson, , is a Democratic State Representative for the 83rd Michigan House District, which includes portions of the City of Grand Rapids and the City of Wyoming.\n\n\nFitzgerald defeated Murphy in 1938, and joined  as the only two people to serve non-consecutive terms as Governor of Michigan. He suffered a heart attack after battling the flu and died in Grand Ledge at the age of fifty-four, only two and a half months after retaking office. Fitzgerald was the only Michigan governor to die in office and was succeeded by  .\n\nFizgerald was a member of , , , ,  and . He is interred at Oakwood Cemetery in Grand Ledge, Michigan. In the city of Warren, Michigan, Fitzgerald High School was named in honor of the former governor on Ryan Rd.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Andrew James Coulouris''' (born August 10, 1978) is a politician from the  of . He is a former  member of the  from the , located in , which includes the city of , , , and .\n\n\nCoulouris graduated from  in 1996. He earned a bachelor's degree in political science from the  and a  degree from the . He and his wife Natasha have been married since 2002 and have a child, Alex, who was born in 2006, and Mia who was born in 2010. He is a member of St. John's Episcopal Church in Saginaw.\n\n\n\n\nCoulouris served as a member of the  City Council, having been appointed on February 11, 2002 to fill the remaining term of a seat vacated by another council member. He was subsequently elected to the city council in the 2003 election for a full four-year term, but he resigned before completing his term on September 12, 2005. He also served as Assistant Prosecuting Attorney for Saginaw County, although the position is not an elected position.\n\n\nIn the August 8, 2006 Democratic primary election he was the leading candidate among five candidates having received a plurality with 39.18% of the votes. In the general election held on November 7, 2006, Coulouris defeated Republican Joel Wilson, receiving 80.94% of the votes cast in the 95th District, a district heavily favoring candidates from the Democratic Party. His first term ended on January 1, 2009.\n\nIn the August 5, 2008 Democratic Primary election he defeated Terry W. Sangster, a former County Commissioner and Democratic candidate for State Representative, receiving 77.56% of the votes cast in the 95th district. Coulouris defeated Republican Ted Rosingana in the November 4, 2008 General Election, receiving 85.47% of the votes cast in the 95th District.  Had he not resigned, his second term would have ended on January 1, 2011.\n\nAs a state representative, Coulouris served on the Banking and Financial Services, Health Policy, Judiciary, and Tax Policy Committees. He was the Chair of the Banking and Financial Services Committee.  Coulouris was also named 2009 Legislator of the Year by the .\n\n\nUnder Michigan's legislative , Coulouris was eligible for one additional term as a State Representative. As opposed to running for reelection in 2010, Coulouris instead announced that he would not seek a third term, citing the desire to spend more time with his family. However, it was later revealed that Coulouris took a job as a lobbyist for  in , and he resigned his position as State Representative on April 30, 2010. This left the 95th District without representation for a period of over 5 months, until the special election of  in November 2010.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Herbert J. Rushton''' (February 14, 1877December 11, 1947) was a  politician.\n\n\nRushton was born in , on February 14, 1877, to parents Thomas F. and Mary Rushton. Rushton was of English and Irish descent.\n\n\nRushton  attended high school in . Rushton then attended the . Rushton then studied law with a lawyer in . In 1905, Rushton moved to  due to health concerns. There, Rushton was admitted the Washington state bar in 1907. Rushton moved back to Michigan in 1908.\n\n\nUpon returning to Michigan, Rushton practiced law, first in , then in . Rushton served as the Escanaba city attorney on and off for 21 years. Rushton was  Prosecuting Attorney from 1913 to 1914. On November 2, 1926, Rushton was elected to the  where he represented the  from January 5, 1927, to 1932. In 1927, Rushton drafted the bill which would create the . Rushton was a delegate to the  from Michigan in 1932 and in 1936. In , Rushton ran unsuccessfully for the position of . Rushton served as  from 1941 to 1944.\n\n\nRushton was married to Loretta Payne. Together they had four children. Rushton was a member of the  and of the . Rushton was .\n\n\nRushton died on December 11, 1947, in . He was interred at Lakeview Cemetery in Escanaba.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Sal Rocca''' (October 29, 1946 – December 13, 2020) was an American politician who served as a member of the  for several years, as well as serving a few terms as a member of the  Board of Commissioners. He made an unsuccessful run for the Republican nomination for the  district in  and areas north, losing to  in the 1998 primary. Rocca's son  later represented the district previously represented by his father.\n\n\nRocca was born in , , Italy, to Virginia and Ororio Rocca. When Rocca was six, his family moved to , Canada. At age 13, he immigrated with his family to the United States, settling in , . Rocca graduated from Detroit's Southwestern High School and has taken courses at . Rocca was a  and a member of St. Blase Catholic Church in Sterling Heights.\n\n\nRocca was first elected to the Michigan House of Representatives in 1974 as a . He served through 1980. In 1982, he was again elected to the State House serving through the end of 1994. In 1992, he switched parties to become a . From 1995 to 2001, Rocca served as a member of the Macomb County Board of Commissioners. During this time his wife Sue filled the state house seat he had previously held. In 1998, he ran for the Republican nomination for the state senate seat vacated by the death of  but lost to Dave Jaye in the primary. \n\nHe was again elected to the State House in 2000 and served through the end of 2004.\n\nRocca previously worked for  and was a licensed real estate broker. During his last term in the Michigan House Rocca had the most time as a member of the house of any member, since unlike most of his other fellow house members in 1992 he had not used up all his post-1992 six years allowed by the term limit laws.\n\n\nRocca died from  in , on December 13, 2020, during the . He was 74.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''John N. Damoose''' ( , born February 5, 1972) is an American politician and television producer serving as a member of the  for the . He has served since January 1, 2023, succeeding  after redistricting. He previously served as a member of the  from the . He is known for working on bipartisan initiatives such as sexual assault prosecution reform, Great Lake conservation projects, and manufacturing revitalization efforts.\n\n\nDamoose graduated from  in . He earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in political science from the  in 1994.\n\n\n\n\nAfter graduating from college, Damoose worked for the Christian Broadcast Network in  and later as a producer on ''''. In 1997, he returned to , where he founded 45 North Productions with his father. Damoose has also written several books, including ''Red Sky in the Morning''. His company has produced numerous television specials on American history, including ''A Nation Remembers: The Story of Pentagon Memorial'', ''The Medal: Celebrating Our Nation's Highest Honor'', and ''Arlington in Eternal Vigil.''\n\n\nIn the 2020 Republican primary, Damoose placed first in a field of seven candidates for a seat in the . Damoose then defeated Democratic nominee Jim Page in the November general election. He assumed office on January 1, 2021. In this role, he received various recognitions, such as the renowned Excellence in Education Award. Damoose served as Majority Vice-Chair of the Communications and Technology committee; he additionally was a member of the House Regulatory Reform, Rules and Competitiveness, and Education Committees.\n\n\nDamoose currently holds the position of State Senator for Michigan's 37th district, winning the election on November 8, 2022, by nearly 18,000 votes. Simultaneously, he serves as the Minority Vice-Chair for both the Education committee and the Appropriations Subcommittee on Joint Capital Outlay. Further, he is a member of the Appropriations, Energy and Environment, and Housing and Human Services committees.\n\n\nDamoose and his wife, Margo, have four children and live in , . Damoose's grandfather, Naseeb G. “Ance” Damoose, was a political leader who served as the city manager of  in the 1950s. Damoose's father, John B. Damoose was a marketing executive at  and  before establishing 45 North Productions. John B. was Chrysler's youngest Vice President at the time as well as one of the first Lebanese individuals to hold an executive position in the .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Andrew Frederick Fink''' (born July 30, 1985) is an American politician serving as a member of the  since 2021, currently representing the . A member of the , Fink is candidate in the .\n\n\nFink was born on July 30, 1985, in ., ''Michigan Manual'' (2021-2022 ed.), p. 229. He received a bachelor's degree in politics from   and a  from the . He was a member of the  from 2011 to 2014.\n\nIn 2017, he moved from  to , where he ran a satellite office of his family's , Fink and Fink, PLLC. He was district director for , a Republican member of the  and the Senate Majority Leader, from January 2019 to January 2020. Fink is a member of the , the American Legion, and was a commissioner-at-large for the .\n\n\nIn the 2020 Republican primary for the , , Fink ran against farmer Andy Welden, realtor Daren Wiseley, and  Mayor Adam Stockford. The district covers  and ; incumbent  could not run for reelection due to term limits. Of the 16,881 total votes in the August 2020 Republican primary, Fink received 6,520 votes (38.62%), Welden 4,310 votes (25.53%); Wiseley 3,126 votes (18.52%), and Stockford 2,925 votes (17.33%).\n\nDuring his 2020 campaign, Fink took the position that  's actions in response to the  were unconstitutional.  His primary campaign was supported by Citizens for Energizing Michigan's Economy (CEME), a  \"\" group related to , which ran several mailers and ads in favor of Fink.\n\nIn the general election, Fink faced Democratic nominee Tamara Barnes of , a director of the .  Fink won 71.22% of the vote (30,208 votes) and Barnes 28.78% of the vote (12,208 votes).\n\nUpon taking office, Fink was assigned to the House Appropriations, Military and Veterans Affairs and State Police; and Health Policy committees.\n\nAfter redistricting, in 2022, Fink was elected to the .\n\nIn September 2023, Fink announced his candidacy for the .\n\n\nFink lives in . He is married to Lauren Grover and has five children.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Dale Edward Kildee''' (September 16, 1929 &ndash; October 13, 2021) was an American politician who served as  of  from 1977 to 2013. He was a member of the .\n\nHis district included ,  and . In July 2011, Kildee announced he would retire after his term was up in . ''The Hill'' July 15, 2011 He was succeeded by his nephew .\n\n\nKildee was born in  on September 16, 1929 to Timothy and Norma (Ullmer) Kildee. He was the fourth of five children. In his senior year of high school, he won the  Medal of Citizenship. In 1947, Kildee received his high school diploma from St. Mary's High School.\n\nHe earned his  from  in  in 1952. He earned a teacher's certificate from the  in 1955. He did graduate work in history and political science at the  in  from 1958 to 1959 under a ship. He earned an  from the  in 1961. He was a teacher at the  from 1954-56. Coming back in 1956 to Flint, Kildee taught  until 1964.\n\n\nKildee served as a member of the   from 1965 to 1974. He then subsequently served as a member of the  from 1975 to 1976.\n\n\n\n\n'']]\n\nIn 1976, incumbent Democratic U.S. Representative  resigned after being appointed to fill the vacant seat in the  caused by the death of . State Senator Kildee won the general election with 70% of the vote. He won re-election 17 times, each with at least 56% of the vote except in 1992, 1994, and 2010. In 1992, he defeated Megan O'Neill with 54% of the vote. He won  with 74%, while he lost the district's other two counties:  and . In the 1994 rematch, he defeated her with just 51% of the vote, the lowest winning percentage of his career. In 2010, he defeated Republican farmer and businessman John Kupiec with 53% of the vote. Kupiec won  with 60%, while losing the district's other three counties. Kildee won  (49%),  (61%), and  (55%).\n\n\nIn 1997, Kildee founded the House's  Caucus to advocate Native American issues. In 2010, Kildee revealed that he would be voting for the Senate version of the Health Care reform bill without the  language restricting federal abortion funding. In addition, reports surfaced that he attempted to convince  Democrats in the Stupak coalition to vote for the bill.\n\n\nHe was a senior member of the  and served as ranking Democrat on the Subcommittee on Education Reform and a member of the Subcommittee on Employer-Employee Relations. He was also a member of the , where he sat on the Subcommittee on National Parks and Public Lands and the Subcommittee on Forests and Forest Health. From 1993 on, he served as co-chair of the Congressional Automotive Caucus. From 1997 on, he served as co-chair of the Native American Caucus.\n\n\nHe met his future wife Gayle, a French teacher, while teaching at Central High School. They married in 1965 and had three children, Paul, Laura, and David. Both sons became army captains; their daughter became a commercial property manager.\n\nIn November 2011, Patrick Kildee, a second cousin of the congressman, accused Kildee of sexually abusing him more than 50 years previously when he was 12 years old. In response Kildee called the allegation untrue.\n\nKildee died on October 13, 2021, in , at the age of 92.\n\nKildee was a .\n\n\n\n|+ : Results 1976&ndash;1990\n! Year\n!\n! Democrat\n!     "pages": }\n\n'''John Joseph Henry Schwarz''' (born November 15, 1937), is an American physician and independent politician from , who was elected to the  in 2004 as a moderate . He represented  from January 2005 to January 2007.\n\n\nDr. Schwarz was born and raised in , after his family moved there in 1935 so his father could work as a physician in the  Hospital. He has two older siblings, Frank and Janet. He attended Fremont Elementary School, W.K. Kellogg Junior High School, and graduated from Battle Creek Central High School. He played on the baseball, swimming and football teams at B.C. Central. In 1959, he received a  in  from the , , where he played on the 1956 reserve football team as a center.\n\nDr. Schwarz graduated from Wayne State University Medical School in 1964 and interned at Los Angeles County Hospital before enlisting in the Navy. Next, Dr. Schwarz served in Southeast Asia for five years, first with the U.S. Navy in Vietnam and as an assistant naval attaché in Indonesia. He was then a member of the Defense Intelligence Agency, before serving with the Central Intelligence Agency for three years in Indonesia, Laos, and Vietnam. During his time in Indonesia, Dr. Schwarz met  on several occasions and, at then-U.S. Ambassador to Indonesia ’s direction, even taught Suharto basic English phrases for about six weeks. Schwarz left the CIA in 1970 to attend Harvard University, finishing his residency in otolaryngology in 1973.\n\nHe returned, with his new family, to Battle Creek in 1974, and has been a practicing  in Battle Creek since that time. He currently sees patients at the Family Health Center in Battle Creek, a federally qualified health center. He is a . His first wife, Anne, died in 1990, and he is divorced from his second wife. He has one daughter from his first marriage.\n\n\nIn 1984, Schwarz was elected Mayor of Battle Creek.  In 1986, he was elected to the .  In 2002, he ran for , but was defeated in the primary by a wide margin.\n\nIn 2006, Schwarz voted against the , which would have banned every state from legally recognizing . Schwarz is considered to be a moderate Republican who supports abortion rights and favors embryonic .\n\n\nOn the state level, Schwarz was appointed to Gov. 's Emergency Financial Advisory Panel, led by former Michigan governors  (R) and  (D). On the national level, Schwarz was appointed by Secretary of Defense  to serve on the independent panel to investigate the conditions at  in suburban Washington, DC. Schwarz was reappointed to the Altarum Institute Board of Trustees, a position he held prior to his congressional service, in February 2007. Altarum Institute is a nonprofit health policy research institute based in Ann Arbor, Michigan. He also accepted a teaching position at the University of Michigan's , which began in fall 2007.\n\nIn 2010, Schwarz considered running for governor of Michigan as an independent in . However, on June 2, 2010, he announced he would not run due to fundraising issues.\n\n, Schwarz is a member of the 's board of directors.\n\nOn June 16, 2014, Schwarz signed a brief in support of same-sex marriage.\n\nFrom 1991 to 2005 Schwarz served as a trustee for . Schwarz also served as campaign chair for the college's previous capital campaign during 2007-2009 academic years for Olivet College.\n\n\n* '''2006 Race for the U.S. House of Representatives, 7th District'''\n**  (R), 50%\n**  (D), 46%\n** David Horn (UST), 1%\n** Robert Hutchinson (L), 2%\n** Joe Schwarz, 1% (Write-in candidate)\n* '''2006 Race for the U.S. House of Representatives, 7th District – Republican Primary'''\n**  (R), 53%\n** Joe Schwarz (R) (inc.), 47%\n* '''2004 Race for the U.S. House of Representatives, 7th District'''\n** Joe Schwarz (R), 58%\n** Sharon Renier (D), 36%\n* '''2004 Race for the U.S. House of Representatives, 7th District – Republican Primary'''\n** Joe Schwarz (R), 28%\n** Brad Smith (R), 22%\n**  (R), 18%\n**  (R), 14%\n** Gene DeRossett (R), 11%\n** Paul DeWeese (R), 7%\n* '''2002 Race for Governor – Republican Primary'''\n**  (R), 81%\n** Joe Schwarz (R), 19%\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Lee Roberson Chatfield''' (born May 25, 1988) is an American former politician and a  former member of the . He was first elected from the  in 2015. He was  from 2017 to 2019, and  from 2019 to 2021. In April 2024 he was charged with thirteen felony counts of embezzlement, larceny and conspiracy involving spending private foundation and state money for personal use while he was Speaker of the Michigan House. \n\n\nChatfield received a  from , an unaccredited, now defunct  in , and a  from  in Virginia.David Eggert, , Associated Press (February 3, 2019). Before his election to the state House in 2014, he worked at a Christian school in northern Michigan operated by his father, a minister. Chatfield was a teacher, coach and athletic director at the school.\n\n\n\nChatfield was first elected to the Michigan House of Representatives in 2014, after defeating a Republican incumbent, , in the .Katy Steinmetz, , ''Time'' (December 5, 2014).Lauren Gibbon, , ''MLive'' (December 25, 2020). Chatfield criticized Foster for supporting  and for supporting an extension of Michigan's  to prohibit  in housing and employment.\n\nChatfield took office in 2015. He was re-elected to the state Legislature in 2016 with 67 percent of the vote, and in 2018, with over 58 percent of the vote.\n\n\nChatfield was speaker of the state House from 2019 to 2020. Elected at age 30; he was believed to be the youngest House speaker in recent memory. Legislators assuming the role of House Speaker in Michigan at age 30 or younger are as follows:  at age 29 in 1838,  at age 26 in 1845,  at age 27 in 1857,  at age 29 in 1863,  at age 29 in 1887,  at age 30 in 1889, and  at age 30 in 1913.\n\nDuring Chatfield's tenure as speaker of the House, Michigan had , with both chambers of the legislature controlled by Republicans, but with a Democratic governor (). Chatfield and the Senate Majority Leader  both repeatedly clashed with Whitmer over issues such as the state budget, road funding,  legislation, and criminal justice legislation.\n\nAs speaker, Chatfield presided over the passage of a bipartisan auto insurance bill that allowed motorists to choose their level of  coverage. However, proposed road infrastructure improvements became mired in deadlock, with Chatfield rejecting a proposal by Whitmer to fund road repairs by raising the  by 45 cents. Negotiations for long-term road funding broke down, and Legislature passed a bill without support from Whitmer's administration. Whitmer signed the bill, but with 147 es plus several administrative transfers.\n\nChatfield and Shirkey both opposed Whitmer's actions to use a government shutdown on business during .\n\n\n\n\nInitial allegations that Chatfield sexually abused a high school student at a school where he taught led to multiple financial and corruption charges against Chatfield and his wife, though no sexual abuse charges were filed.\n\nOn January 6, 2022, '''' reported Michigan State Police were investigating Chatfield over allegations that he sexually abused a girl for 12 years, beginning in 2009 when she was between 14 and 15 years old and continuing until 2021. When she was 18 she married Aaron Chatfield, Lee's brother. Lee Chatfield has admitted having an affair with his sister-in-law and with other women, but said that these affairs were between consenting adults.\n\nThe sexual abuse is alleged to have begun when the girl was attending Chatfield's church, Northern Michigan Baptist Bible Church, and continued while she was a student at the school associated with the church, where Chatfield taught physical education.\n\nAttorney General  charged Chatfield and his wife with financial crimes in April 2024, alleging they milked political accounts for personal travel, housing and other benefits. \n\n\nIn 2018, Chatfield attempted to bring a loaded, unregistered handgun onto a commercial flight at . He was fined $250 for failure to register his handgun, which he had purchased in December 2015. He also paid a $1,960 fine assessed by the . Chatfield had previously introduced a bill in the Michigan House of Representatives to make handgun registration voluntary.\n\n\nChatfield was a strong supporter of President . Chatfield, along with Michigan Senate Majority Leader , met with Trump on November 20, 2020, as Trump and his campaign , in which Trump was defeated by  (both nationally and ). , the U.S. representative for , said that the purpose of the meeting may have been to discuss the appointment of  electors to the . Despite pressure from Trump, Chatfield ultimately declined to support passage of a Michigan Legislation to pass a resolution purporting to retroactively change Michigan's slate of electors for Trump, saying that such a move \"would bring mutually assured destruction for every future election in regards to the Electoral College\" and \"we would lose our country forever.\"\n\n\nDue to s, Chatfield was ineligible to run for another term in the Michigan House of Representatives. In mid-February 2021, after leaving office, Chatfield was appointed as the new CEO of Southwest Michigan First, a privately funded economic development organization covering the seven counties of  (Berrien, Branch, Calhoun, Cass, Kalamazoo, St. Joseph and Van Buren).\n\nChatfield's hiring caused a backlash due to Chatfield's past stances in opposition to LGBTQ rights. Various groups including the City of Kalamazoo and the Kalamazoo Promise, pulled support from Southwest Michigan First.\n\nFollowing the backlash from his hiring, Southwest Michigan First and Chatfield stated that they would support expanding the state's civil rights act (the ) to prohibit discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity, a stance that the Southwest Michigan First board had voted in 2017 to support. During his tenure in the Michigan House, Chatfield had opposed such an expansion, which he viewed as an infringement on religious freedom. A few days after beginning his new job, Chatfield resigned, citing the controversy.\n\n\nChatfield married his high school sweetheart, Stephanie (Zondervan), and they have four sons and one daughter.\n\n\n\n\n\n*  (Michigan House Republicans)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Gary J. McDowell''' (born April 21, 1952) is a U.S. politician from the state of . He was elected to three, two-year terms in the  and served from January 1, 2005, until January 1, 2011. In 2010 and 2012, he was the  nominee for  against  . Prior to serving in the Michigan House of Representatives, McDowell was a member of the   for 22 years. He also served on the Chippewa County Economic Development Corporation Board of Directors from 1987 until 2004.\n\n\nMcDowell was born and raised on a farm in . He is the oldest of ten children. His father was a  and a hay broker. His mother was a . He graduated from Rudyard High School in 1970 and attended .\n\nIn addition to being a farmer, he was also a  delivery driver for 23 years. He was a  and  for 18 years.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2002, he ran for , challenging incumbent Republican Scott Shackleton. He lost 69 percent to 31 percent. In 2004, Shackleton was term-limited from the  and McDowell decided to run again. He defeated Walter North, a former member of the state Senate, 54 percent to 46 percent.\n\nIn 2006, he won re-election to a second term by defeating Republican Jay Duggan 59 percent to 41 percent. In 2008, he won re-election to a third and final term defeating Republican Alex Strobehn 65 percent to 35 percent.\n\n\nMcDowell introduced 98 bills in six years in the Legislature. He has missed a total of 96 votes.\n\n\n;2009\n*House Committee on Appropriations\n**Community Health subcommittee (Chairman)\n**Agriculture subcommittee (Vice Chairman)\n**Higher Education subcommittee\n\n\n\n\n\nMcDowell faced Benishek, independent Glenn Wilson,  nominee Keith Shelton,  nominee Ellis Boal, and  nominee Patrick Lambert in the general election. Democratic incumbent  had announced his retirement, leaving this an open seat.\n\n\n\nOn September 15, 2011, McDowell announced his intent to run against Benishek in the 2012 election. He has been endorsed by the  and the . McDowell lost his bid to defeat Benishek for a second straight election, losing to the freshman incumbent by less than 2,000 votes of over 347,000 that were cast. McDowell considered challenging Benishek for a third time in the 2014 elections, but ultimately declined.\n\n\nMcDowell lives in Rudyard with his wife Carrie. They have three daughters, Alivia, Emily and Rochelle, two grandsons, Garrett and Bruin, and one granddaughter, Shiloh. He is a member of the Rudyard First Presbyterian Church.\n\n\n\n\n\n* at Michigan House Democrats\n*  ''official campaign site''\n* \n* at \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Nicholas Hart Smith''' (born November 5, 1934) is a retired American politician from the  of , who served as a  member of the  from 1993 until 2005, representing from the 7th District of Michigan.\n\n\nSmith was born in , where he still lives. He earned a  from  in , in 1957 and an  in  from the  in 1959. Smith served in the  from 1959 to 1961 where he became a captain. He was Squadron Commander in the  and later an Intelligence Officer. He operates a dairy farm in Addison.\n\nSmith served on the  board of trustees, 1962 to 1968. He was township supervisor and on the  board of supervisors from 1966 to 1968. He then served as assistant deputy administrator and director of energy in the  between 1972 and 1974.\n\nSmith served as a member of the  from the  from 1979 to 1983. He then served as a member of  from the  from 1983 to 1993. While in the Michigan Senate, he was appointed President Pro Tempore from 1983 to 1990.\n\n\nSmith ran for Congress in the 7th District in 1992, winning the Republican primary by seven points. His nearest opponent was fellow state senator , a considerably more moderate Republican. Smith was the major candidate from the eastern portion of the district, while Schwarz and the others were all from the western portion. The candidates from the western portion split the vote, allowing Smith to win despite getting only 37 percent of the vote. No Democrat even filed for the general election, handing the seat to Smith. He was reelected five times.\n\nSmith was a relatively low-profile congressman for most of his career, compiling a reliably conservative voting record despite representing a fairly marginal district. However, Smith gained national attention in 2004 in the controversy over the . Smith had announced earlier he was not running for reelection later that year, having promised during his initial run to only serve six terms (12 years) in the House. However, he'd endorsed his son, Brad, as his successor. Smith stated that members of the House Republican leadership told him that if he voted for the Medicare bill, business interests would give $100,000 to his son's campaign. When Nick Smith refused to vote for the bill, he was told that his son would never get into Congress. Ultimately, Brad Smith was defeated in the Republican primary by Schwarz, who was elected in November.\n\nIn March 2004, the  admonished fellow Representative from Michigan  and House Majority Leader  for their involvement in the affair.\n\n\n* , former Congressional staffer for Smith\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n'''Curtis Hertel Jr'''. (born January 9, 1978) is an American politician who served as a state senator from 2015 to 2023, for the  in Michigan, representing the .\n\nHertel is a member of the . He previously served two terms as the Ingham County Register of Deeds, and more recently served as Governor 's top lobbyist. He was a candidate for  in the  to succeed , who   and will succeed retiring .\n\nHe is the son of , who was co-speaker of the Michigan House of Representatives from 1993 to 1994. Hertel's brother, , was elected to the Michigan State Senate in November 2022.\n\n\nHertel holds a bachelor's degree from , where he attended from 1996 to 2000. Hertel served on the Ingham County Board of Commissioners from 2001 to 2008, representing the north half of East Lansing and Meridian Township. From 2005 to 2008, Hertel worked as a Legislative Liaison for the Department of Community Health under Governor .\n\nHertel was elected Ingham County Register of Deeds in 2008, and re-elected to a second term in 2012. As Register of Deeds, Hertel filed a lawsuit against mortgage firms  and  in 2011, seeking millions in unpaid taxes on property transfers in the county. The outcome is still pending.\n\n\nHertel was elected to the Michigan State Senate in 2014, where he served as the Minority Whip and Chairperson for the Democratic Caucus Campaign Committee. He served as senator for the  in Michigan, which represented the cities of  and , as well as the townships of , , , , , , , , , , , and .\n\nHe introduced bills to offer tax credits to Michigan college graduates who elected to remain residents of the state after graduation. He also introduced legislation to require discussions on affirmative consent in high school sex education classes. In March 2016, he introduced a bill to put $3&nbsp;million into the First Responder Presumed Coverage Fund, which would give money to firefighters who develop cancer due to chemical exposure on the job.\n\nIn November 2018, Hertel was re-elected to the 23rd district in the Michigan State Senate, where he served four more years. Hertel served as the top-ranking Democrat on the Senate Appropriations Committee.\n\n\nDue to , Hertel was ineligible for re-election in . He joined the gubernatorial administration of  as Whitmer's top lobbyist in the role of director of legislative affairs. He announced his resignation from the Whitmer administration on June 30, 2023. Less than a week after resigning from the Whitmer administration, where he had negotiated the state's $82&nbsp;billion budget, Hertel took a role at the nonprofit Greater Flint Health Coalition, which was expected to benefit from the state budget in the form of a $1.5&nbsp;million grant. Hertel denied that his involvement in the state budget included knowledge of the $1.5&nbsp;million budget appropriation earmarked for the Greater Flint Health Coalition. According to ''The Detroit News'', the arrangement \"puts a spotlight on the close, behind-the-scenes relationships between groups seeking assistance from state government and officials in positions to provide it.\"\n\nOn July 10, 2023, Hertel announced his candidacy for , currently held by , who had already announced her candidacy for the US Senate.\n\n\nHis wife, Elizabeth Hertel, serves as Michigan's Department of Health and Human Services director.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n'''Rosetta A. Ferguson''' (née '''Sexton'''; July 1, 1920November 18, 2015) was a politician in , USA.\n\n\nFerguson was born on July 1, 1920, in , to parents Gaberil Sexton and Earnie Sexton.\n\n\nFerguson attended public schools in  and . She later attended .\n\n\nIn 1961, Ferguson was a candidate in the primary for the position of delegate to  from  5th district. On November 4, 1964, she was elected to the  where she represented the  from January 13, 1965, to 1972. On November 7, 1972, she was again elected to the Michigan house of representatives where she represented the  from January 10, 1973, to 1978. She advocated for more coverage of ethnic history in textbooks. She was known for her opposition to drugs, especially , and abortion. In an incident in 1977, on the house floor, Ferguson threw a glass ashtray at state representative , which hit him in the head.\n\n\nFerguson married in 1935 and had four children. She was a member of the . Ferguson was .\n\n\nFerguson died on November 18, 2015, and was buried in Florence, Mississippi.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Michael Goschka''' (born October 21, 1953) is a  politician from the  of . He was a member of the  from 1993 through 1998.  He was then elected to the  and served as Senator from 1999 through 2007. In high school Mike was a top long distance runner, at Chesaning High, setting a school record in the two-mile with a 9:57.1. He also competed on the varsity cross country team his junior and senior years.  He ran two years on the varsity team at Delta College.\n\nGoschka achieved a political upset by defeating then-Speaker of the House,  (D-Taymouth Twp.), by 142 votes (50.18% of the vote), in 1992. He then won two subsequent elections in the same geographical district with 66.1% of the vote in 1994, and 66.6% in 1996.\n\nBeing elected to the Michigan State Senate in 1998 in a heavily Democrat district, and winning reelection in 2002, it was in his second term that Goschka established himself as a strong proponent of Higher Education. As Chairman of the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Higher Education, Goschka worked at reducing the funding gap between the lower-funded-per-student schools vs. the higher-funded-per-student schools. He successfully convinced his colleagues that a basic minimum funding floor should exist for every college student in the State of Michigan's public universities, regardless of which school they attended.\n\nGoschka was also recognized as a \"Friend of Agriculture,\" as designated by Michigan Farm Bureau, and received their \"Silver Plow\" Award. As the author of 34 laws in the State of Michigan, Goschka was the primary sponsor of two major agricultural bills that are now law, providing a $5 million interest-free loan to a large sugar beet cooperative that was formed by growers, and ending the \"pop-up tax\" on agricultural land that remained in agricultural use.\n\nGoschka also was the recipient of the \"Guardian of Small Business\" by the National Federation of Independent Businesses (NFIB), as well as the top honor given out the Michigan Chamber of Commerce. Additionally, he was honored by Saginaw Valley State University in May 2006 with an Honorary Doctor of Laws degree.\n\nGoschka is currently employed as the Legislative Director for state representative .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

He is a member of the .\n\n\nCropsey was born in , the son of , who was a member of the state house of representatives from the 42nd district, 1981–1982; and of the state senate from the 21st district, 1983–1990.\n\nCropsey holds a B.S. in  from  and a  from .\n\n\nCropsey served in the  from 1979 to 1982 and from 1993 to 1998. He was vice chairman of the State Board of Canvassers from 1999 to 2001, and chairman in 2001. Cropsey was a member of the Michigan Senate from 1983 to 1986 and also from 2003 to 2010, serving as majority floor leader during his second term (2007 to 2010). In March 2007 Cropsey became co-chairman of the \"Americans of Faith\" coalition that supported the presidential candidacy of .\n\nCropsey has strongly opposed  and sexually explicit . He received a Defender of Freedom Award from the  in 1996 and a Legislator of the Year Award from the Michigan Conservative Union in 1983.\n\n\nCropsey married Erika Rumminger in 1979, and the couple has four children.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
