    "pages": }\n|children      = 3\n|education     = \n}}\n\n'''John Mathias Engler''' (born October 12, 1948) is an American politician, lawyer, businessman, and lobbyist who served as the 46th  from 1991 to 2003. Considered one of the country's top lobbyists, he is a member of the .\n\nEngler was serving in the Michigan Senate when he enrolled at  and graduated with a  degree, having served as a  since 1979. He was elected Senate majority leader in 1984 and served there until being elected governor in . He was reelected in  and , and is the last Michigan governor to serve more than two terms. After his governorship, he worked for .\n\nEngler served on the board of advisors of the , an educational organization that continues the intellectual legacy of noted conservative and Michigan native . Engler also served on the board of trustees of the Marguerite Eyer Wilbur Foundation, which funds many Kirk Center programs. Engler was a member of the  board of trustees until 2014. As of 2018, he serves on the board of directors of . Previous board service included serving as a director of  and  and as a trustee of Munder Funds.\n\n\nEngler, a Roman Catholic, was born in , on October 12, 1948, to Mathias John Engler and his wife, Agnes Marie (née Neyer), but grew up on a cattle farm near .\n\nHe attended , graduating with a degree in  in 1971, and , graduating with a  degree in 1981.\n\nHe was elected to the  as a state representative in 1970 at the age of 22. He served in the House from 1971 to 1978. His campaign manager in that first election was a college friend, . Engler later became the first Republican youth vice-chair for the Michigan Republican Party, defeating future U.S. Senator . Posthumus later went on to be elected a state senator, Senate Majority Leader and Lieutenant Governor. He was Engler's running mate in the 1998 election and served from 1999 to 2003.\n\n\n  in 1988]]\n  in 1991]]\n\n\nEngler's administration was characterized by  of state services, income tax reduction, a sales tax increase, educational reform, welfare reform, and major reorganization of  departments.\n\nIn 1996, he was elected chairman of the , and in 2001, he was elected to head the National Governors Association.\n\nIn 2002, near the end of his final term, Engler and the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality attempted to negotiate a consent order with  that would have resulted in a ninefold increase in the allowable levels of dioxins. The consent order would have resulted in Dow not having to pay to clean up high levels of toxins in , near its plant there, as well as in the  flood plain, which had been contaminated by dioxins dumped into the river from the facility and from overflow from waste ponds. The consent order fell through in late 2002.\n\n\n\nDuring the , Engler was considered to be a potential vice presidential running mate for Republican nominee . However, Dole instead selected , a former representative and .\n\n\nEngler endorsed Texas Governor  in the 2000 Republican primary. After Bush secured the GOP nomination, Engler's name was again floated as a possible running mate. In his book '''', Bush says that Engler was someone he was \"close\" with and could \"work well with.\" Ultimately, Engler was passed over for the running mate position in favor of . After the election, Engler's close political ally , who narrowly lost his re-election bid for the Senate to , was chosen as Bush's Secretary of Energy.\n\n\nEngler's lieutenant governor, , sought to succeed Engler in the 2002 gubernatorial race. Posthumus lost the race to the state's attorney general, Democrat .\n\n\nIn 1990, Engler, then the state senate majority leader, challenged Governor  in his bid for a third term. Political observers viewed his bid as a long shot, and he trailed Blanchard by double digits in the polls the weekend before the election. However, on election day, Engler pulled off the upset, defeating Blanchard by approximately 17,000 votesa margin of less than one percentage point. In 1994, Engler ran for his second term. The Democrats nominated former Representative , who had close ties to the labor movementa potent force in Democratic politics in Michigan. Engler bested Wolpe 61 to 39 percent, and the state Republican Party made significant gains.  picked up the Senate seat of retiring Democrat . Republicans gained a seat to break a tie in the state House of Representatives, taking a 56–54 majority, while also picking up a seat in the U.S. House of Representatives. Republican  won an upset victory to win the post of Secretary of State.\n\nMichigan voters re-elected Engler to his third and final term in 1998. He won a landslide victory over lawyer . Engler took 1,883,005 votes62 percent of the totalto Fieger's 38 percent and 1,143,574 votes. Engler's landslide helped the state Republican Party gain six seats in the state House of Representatives, taking control of the chamber they had lost two years previously with a 58–52 margin, as well as picking up an additional seat in the State Senate, for a 23–15 majority. Republicans also gained a seat on the technically non-partisan state Supreme Court, holding a 4–3 majority over the Democrats.\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAfter leaving the governor's mansion in January 2003, Engler served as president of the state and local government sector of . Engler left that position in June 2004 to be elected president and CEO of the . Engler's tenure at the NAM ended in January 2011. In January 2011, Engler was named president of the .\n with (left to right): , John Engler and  at the presentation of final report of the Secretary's Advisory Committee on Transformational Diplomacy in 2008]]\n\nIn 2017, Engler was appointed to a four-year term on the governing board of the  project.\n\n\nOn January 30, 2018, Engler was named the interim president of  to replace , who was embroiled with the school in the  involving . The appointment of Engler sparked controversy due to his previous handling of sexual misconduct as governor of Michigan. Engler's tenure as interim president was plagued by controversies, brought on by Engler's apparent callous statements and actions toward survivors during Board of Trustees meetings and statements that were reported by the press. One of Nassar's victims, , said Engler \"chose to stand against every child and every sexual assault victim in the entire state, to protect an institution.\"\n\nEngler resigned on January 16, 2019 after the Board of Trustees indicated its intent to ask him to resign following a series of embarrassing incidents regarding Nassar's victims and his responses to issues in the aftermath. Engler initially indicated he planned to resign on January 23, 2019 but the Board required him to resign the morning after he submitted his resignation letter.\n\n\n\nIn 1975, Engler married , who served in the Michigan House of Representatives before running for lieutenant governor of Michigan in 1986. The day after she lost the race for lieutenant governor, she filed for divorce. The couple had no children together; she remarried in 2002, and died in 2022.\n\nEngler married Michelle DeMunbrun, a Texas attorney, on December 8, 1990. The couple has triplet daughters, born November 13, 1994. As First Lady, Michelle Engler served as the founding chair of the Michigan Community Service Commission. Michelle Engler was named to the  (Freddie Mac) board in 2001 by President , and re-appointed in 2002.\n\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n}}\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Hammel''', a  politician, was a  from the .\n\n\nHammel obtained a bachelor's degree from the .\n\n\nHammel served on the  Board of Commissioners and served as its chair before being elected to the Michigan State House of Representatives in 2006.     "pages": }\n\n\n|birth_place = , U.S.\n|party       = \n|spouse      = \n|children    = 3\n|education   =  (, , )\n|signature   = Rick-snyder-sigsvg.png\n}}\n'''Richard Dale Snyder''' (born August 19, 1958) is an American business executive, venture capitalist, attorney, accountant, and politician who served as the 48th  from 2011 to 2019.\n\nSnyder, who was born in , began his career in business in 1982. He was  of  from 2005 to 2007, a co-founder of Ardesta, LLC, a  firm, HealthMedia, Inc., a digital health coaching company, and is currently CEO of SensCy, a cybersecurity company based in .\n\nA member of the , he won the  and won reelection in . Snyder was term-limited and could not seek re-election in  and was succeeded by Democrat . Snyder was considered a possible Republican Party candidate for  in , although ultimately  was selected.\n\nIn 2014, Snyder gained national attention during the , in which he was accused of mishandling the situation that exposed thousands of Flint residents to lead-contaminated water. A report by the University of Michigan School of Public Health concluded Snyder bore \"significant legal responsibility\" for the Flint water crisis. In 2020, an article was published in '''' detailing evidence of corruption and a cover-up by Snyder, including that he was warned repeatedly about the dangerous effects of the decisions he had made about the Flint water supply. In January 2021, Snyder was among those criminally charged for the crisis. He pled not guilty to two misdemeanor charges. In December 2022 Genesee County Judge  dismissed the charges.\n\n\nSnyder was born to Dale F. and Helen Louella Snyder in Battle Creek, Michigan, where he was raised. His father owned a local  company in Battle Creek, and was of paternal  descent. He has an elder sister. When he was 16, he took a business class at  on weekends. By his senior year at Lakeview High School in , Snyder had earned 23 college credits.\n\nSnyder visited the admissions office of the  in November 1975 and spoke with the admissions director, who recommended that Snyder attend Michigan and create his own degree. Snyder received a  in 1977, a  in 1979, and a  in 1982, all from the University of Michigan. Snyder is also a  (CPA).\n\nHe resides in  with his wife Sue and their three children and has a vacation home near . The couple were married in 1987 at Cherry Hill Presbyterian Church in . Snyder has indicated he is a practicing .\n\n\n\n\nSnyder was employed with , from 1982 to 1991, beginning in the tax department of the  office. Snyder was named partner in 1988. The next year, Snyder was named partner-in-charge of the  practice in the  office. He served as an   of accounting at the University of Michigan from 1982 to 1984.\n\n\nSnyder joined the computer company  (based in , ) in 1991 as the executive vice president. He served as president and chief operating officer from 1996 to 1997. He remained on the board of directors until 2007. From 2005 to 2007, Snyder served as the chairman of the board. During 2006, Snyder served as interim chief executive officer while a search for a permanent replacement was made. His tenure on the Gateway board ran from 1991 to 2007 until Gateway was sold to  Snyder stated that he did not vote for outsourcing while he was a Gateway board director and he worked to bring jobs to America as the interim CEO of Gateway.\n\n\nIn 1997, Snyder returned to Ann Arbor to found Avalon Investments Inc., a  company with a $100 million fund, along with the co-founder of Gateway, . Snyder was president and chief executive officer of Avalon from 1997 to 2000. He then co-founded Ardesta , an investment firm, in 2000 along with three co-founders, which invested in 20 start-up companies through 2011. He was chairman and chief executive officer of the company.\n\n\n\nIn 1998, Snyder angel funded and co-founded, with University of Michigan (U-M) School of Public Health professor , HealthMedia Incorporated (HMI), a developer of digital health coaching applications that implemented tailored questionnaires to gather personal information with the goal of creating customized health promotion plans for individuals. The U-M's  played an integral role in helping HMI get started with Vic Strecher as the founding CEO and the U-M's publicly funded Health Media Research Laboratory (founded and directed by Strecher and now called the ) providing the new company with exclusive research and development findings into health-related computerized tailored messaging and the exclusive licence to sell that content (). Despite these university-based start-up and R&D advantages, HMI got off to a poor performance start and in 2001 Snyder replaced the founding CEO (Strecher remained on the HMI board) and personally rescued the company from insolvency with more of his own money. After multiple rounds of more additional financing through venture capital (Arboretum Ventures, Ardesta, Avalon Capital Group, AvTech Ventures, Chrysalis Ventures, Princeton Fund) and yet never achieving profitability, HMI was sold in 2008 for a reported $200 million to . The sale of HMI transferred the ownership of all the personal health information accrued from their millions of users to Johnson & Johnson and played a key role in the negotiated price. At the time of the reported $200 million deal, U-M President  was on Johnson & Johnson's board of directors and the U-M secured millions of dollars with its equity stake in the company.   When campaigning for Michigan governor in 2010, Snyder was quoted as saying, \"That company (HMI) is one of the best success stories in the state.\" () (). Following Snyder's election as Michigan governor, Johnson & Johnson then folded HMI into a subsidiary () and is no longer operating in the state of Michigan.\n\n\nIn July, 2022, Snyder co-founded SensCy along with former State of Michigan CIO David Behen Ann Arbor entrepreneur Bhushan Kulkarni, and Dave Kelly who led cyber command for the Michigan State Police. SensCy is a cybersecurity start-up focused on helping small and medium-sized organizations improve their cyberhealth. Snyder's firm invented the SensCy Score, a numeric representation of an organization's cyberhealth. The SensCy Score is similar to the FICO score used for credit worthiness as it provides visibility into how a company is performing on key cybersecurity metrics. SensCy stands for Sensible Cyber and aims to be the trusted guide for small and medium-sized organizations.\n\n\nSnyder serves on the boards of the  (a National Historic Landmark), the Michigan chapter of the , and several boards associated with his alma mater the University of Michigan. He was also first chair of the Michigan Economic Development Corporation in 1999 under Republican governor  and was also the chair of .\n\n\n\n\n\nSnyder competed with   ,  , United States Congressman , and   as candidates for the Republican  nomination. , chairman of the , endorsed Snyder for the Republican nomination for governor. He campaigned as \"pro-life, pro-Second Amendment, [and] pro-family,\" with a focus on the economy.Bomey, Nathan (September 9, 2009).  , AnnArbor.com. Retrieved December 13, 2014. His campaign emphasized his experience in growing business and creating jobs in the private sector, saying that his opponents were mainly career politicians. Snyder favors the standard exceptions on abortion for rape, incest, and saving the life of the mother (he signed legislation banning  abortion in October 2011); he opposes federal funding of abortions; he would not ban embryonic stem cell research; he supports upholding traditional marriage, but would allow civil unions.Christoff, Chris (August 27, 2010).  , ''Detroit Free Press''. Retrieved December 13, 2014.\n\nIn August 2010, Snyder won the primary to secure the Republican nomination with a  of 36% of the vote. In the general election in November, Snyder faced Democratic nominee , the mayor of , and three  candidates. In October 2010, Snyder's campaign total exceeded $11.6 million, outpacing his opponent. Snyder released his tax returns for 2007 and 2008. Snyder won with 58 percent of the vote.\n\nWith Snyder's election in 2010, Republicans gained a majority in the Michigan House and increased the Republican majority held in the Michigan Senate. Snyder was the first  (CPA) to be elected governor of the state and at the time, the only CPA to serve as a governor in the United States.\n\n\n\nIn January 2014, Snyder launched his campaign for a second term as governor. He was unopposed in the Republican primary and faced Democratic former United States Representative  for the general election. Snyder was considered vulnerable in his bid for a second term, as reflected in his low approval ratings, however, Schauer suffered from a lack of name recognition. He garnered approximately 51% of the vote in the November 2014 election, defeating Schauer and earning a second term.\n\n\n\n\n Chief Justice ]]\n ,  , Canadian  for Science and Technology ,  , and Canada 2020 Chair  at the US–Canada Partnership: Enhancing the Innovation Ecosystem conference at the  in , , November 2, 2011.]]\nSnyder was inaugurated as governor on January 1, 2011, at the  in . His first executive order as governor was to divide the Department of Natural Resources and Environment into two distinct departments as they were a few years before: the Department of Natural Resources and the Department of Environmental Quality.\n\nOn January 7, 2011, Snyder announced he was appointing Michigan Supreme Court Justice  to head the Department of Human Services and appointed Michigan Appeals Court Judge  to fill the resulting Supreme Court vacancy. Snyder delivered his first State of the State address on January 19, the earliest Michigan State of the State since Governor John Engler's 1996 address on January 17. He endorsed the  for the first time publicly in the address, which was received favorably by Republicans. Snyder appointed , a pro-life Democrat, and formerly Speaker of the House, to serve as state treasurer in his administration.\n\nSnyder presented his first budget to the legislature on February 17, 2011, calling it a plan for \"Michigan's reinvention,\" and saying it would end Michigan's deficits. He described the budget as containing \"shared sacrifice\" but added that his budget plan would create jobs and spur economic growth. The $46 billion budget reduced $1.8 billion in spending, raised taxes by eliminating tax exemptions on pensions, while at the same time abolished the state's complex business tax, replacing it with a significantly reduced flat tax on the profits of s. This shift in tax burden led State Senate Minority Leader Gretchen Whitmer to criticize the budget, saying that it did not involve \"shared sacrifice,\" but instead was balanced \"on the backs of our kids, working families, and our seniors\" and \"picks out who he's willing to leave behind.\" Snyder supported the government backed rescue of the American auto industry. This reflected the view of a 56% of Americans in 2012 who supported the 2009 auto bailout according to a Pew Research Center poll (63% support in Michigan).  on 20 March 2021\n\nOn March 16, 2011, Snyder signed a controversial bill into law that gave increased powers to  of local municipalities to resolve financial matters. The bill was repealed by voter initiative in November 2012. However, weeks later in December 2012 Snyder signed a revised version of the bill back into law.\n\nOn December 22, 2011, Snyder signed into law The Public Employee Domestic Partner Benefit Restriction Act, which prevents the same-sex domestic partners of public employees at both the state and local level from receiving health benefits. In January 2012, the  filed a lawsuit against Snyder and the state of Michigan in federal court on behalf of five Michigan same-sex couples, each with one spouse working for local public schools or municipalities in Michigan. The suit alleged that the law violates the  of the  of the . On June 28, 2013, a federal judge struck down the law. He has also engaged in trade missions to  and , focused on attracting attention on companies such as .Buss, Dale (April 1, 2012). , ''Forbes''. Retrieved December 13, 2014.\n\nFollowing approval from the legislature, Snyder signed the fiscal year 2012 budget in June, the earliest it had been completed in three decades. In May 2012, Snyder joined a bipartisan effort urging the  to pass a measure to affirm that States can collect sales taxes on online purchases.\n\nAs governor, Snyder abolished the state's complex business tax in favor of a , and signed a bill which raised taxes by eliminating tax exemptions for pensions. For years Snyder had said anti-union legislation was not on his agenda, when on the morning of December 6, 2012, during a  session of the Republican-controlled Michigan legislature, Snyder called a joint press conference with the legislative leadership to announce fast-track . The legislation passed both houses of the Michigan legislature that day, without committee votes or public hearings. A $1 million appropriation added to the legislation made it ineligible for repeal via referendum. On December 10, President  visited 's  factory in , and told employees the legislation was about the \"right to work for less money.\" The law effectively provides that payment of union dues cannot be required as a condition of employment. After a required four-day wait between the houses of the legislature passing each other's bills, Snyder signed the legislation into law on December 11, 2012, making Michigan the 24th right-to-work state in the United States as part of a plan to attract business and jobs to the state.. Retrieved December 11, 2012. The Employee Free Choice Act, as it was named, has received mixed results in polls.Egan, Paul (January 16, 2013). . ''Detroit Free Press''. Retrieved June 28, 2013.\n\nA Market Research Group poll conducted in March 2012 showed Snyder's approval rating rising to 50% among likely voters, which matched that of President Barack Obama, placing Snyder among the most popular Republican governors in states carried by Obama in the 2008 election cycle. Snyder was briefly mentioned as a possible pick to be the Republican Party candidate for  in 2012.Carpenter, Mackenzie (February 20, 2011). , ''''. Retrieved March 23, 2012. His business executive background and 'positive' style were cited as political assets, with his deeds seen as strengthening the case for electing a business executive candidate as President of the United States.Decker, Brett M. (April 18, 2012). , ''The Washington Times''. Retrieved December 13, 2014.White, Joseph (October 31, 2011). , ''The Wall Street Journal'' online. Retrieved December 14, 2014. He was also mentioned as a potential Republican Party candidate for  in 2016.Crain, Keith (December 2, 2012).. ''Crain's Detroit Business''. Retrieved June 28, 2013.\n\nIn December 2012, Snyder signed legislation requiring facilities where at least 120 s were performed annually to obtain a state license as freestanding surgical facilities. Planned Parenthood had urged Snyder to veto the bill claiming it unnecessarily increases costs.\n\nIn January 2013, Snyder traveled to  to meet with  . He was last in Israel in 1999 as a venture capitalist. \"I had a chance to see the start of high-tech boom in Israel and that's great to see. This is really a startup nation. They've done a great job of being entrepreneurial, innovative, and that's a major part of their economy now and the good part is we can learn from that.\"\n\nIn March 2013, Snyder announced a  for the city of Detroit and appointed an emergency manager, . As a result of emergency manager appointments under Snyder's watch, over half of the state's black population lived in cities where the local government was appointed rather than elected by the voters.\n\nOn December 27, 2013, Snyder signed a bill into law which nullified Section 1021 of the , which contained a controversial provision that allowed the government and the military to indefinitely detain American citizens and others without trial.\n\nOn January 23, 2014, Snyder announced plans to offer visas to 50,000 immigrant workers with advanced degrees to help jumpstart the Detroit economy. The program's advocates claimed the program was expected to bring an influx of new jobs and a more stable tax base.\n\nIn June 2014, Snyder appointed a 15-member commission for improving and reforming Michigan's public defense efforts for the poor in the criminal justice system in order to effectively meet and ensure the rights safeguarded by the Constitution.\n\nOn September 10, Detroit reached a deal with three Michigan counties over regional water and sewer services that was hoped to eliminate one roadblock to federal court approval of the city's plan to adjust its debt and exit bankruptcy. The deal with Oakland, Wayne and Macomb counties created a regional water and sewer authority, but allowed Detroit to maintain control of its local system. The deal was crucial to adjusting the city's $18 billion of debt and exiting the biggest-ever municipal bankruptcy.\n\nOn December 18, the Governor issued an executive order to establish the  to house a new state agency, Talent Investment Agency, created from the merger of Michigan State Housing and Development Authority, the Workforce Development Agency, the Governor's Talent Investment Board and the Unemployment Insurance Agency. Over objections from the state legislature, the department would come into effect 60 days after the start of the next legislative session.\n\nIn November 2015, Governor Rick Snyder declared his opposition to permitting Syrian refugee relocation to the state of Michigan.\n\nA compilation of online surveys showed that Snyder's approval rating was below 40 percent in April 2018.\n\nIn December 2018, Snyder granted clemency to 61 Michigan prisoners.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFrom 2011 to 2015, Snyder appointed several individuals as  for . In 2014, emergency manager  was responsible for changing the source of drinking water for the city to the , which has  (TTHM) in it. It was later discovered that the water was too corrosive, and leached lead out of the service lines that was then ingested by the people of the city. In September 2015, a study by the  found that the community's children were being . While Flint transitioned back to its prior source of water in October 2015, lead levels in the city's water remain above the federal action level.\n\nAmid allegations that the Michigan Health Department was stalling water treatment expert ' effort to obtain public records, journalists have asked when the State of Michigan knew about the lead poisoning. Details were released by the '''' and '''' on 26 February 2016 that Valerie Brader, Snyder's senior policy adviser and deputy legal counsel, and his chief legal counsel Mike Gadola had expressed concerns to him about Flint's water in October 2014, nearly six months after Flint had begun using the river water to save money, despite Governor Snyder claiming he was unaware of the issue until very recently.\n\nA petition from Angelo Scott Brown, a Flint pastor and former Democratic Party gubernatorial candidate, to  Snyder was denied by the Board of State Canvassers.  Filmmaker and Flint native  has called for Snyder's arrest on charges of corruption and assault, and has started a petition on his website.\n\nOn November 13, 2015, four families filed a federal  lawsuit in the  in Detroit against Snyder and thirteen other city and state officials, including former Flint Mayor  and ex-emergency financial manager Darnell Earley. The  alleges that the officials acted  and , leading to serious injuries from , including s, s, and \".\"\n\nOn December 15, 2015, Mayor Weaver declared the water issue as a citywide public health state of emergency to prompt help from state and federal officials.  Snyder apologized for the incident. Snyder declared a State of Emergency on January 5, 2016, for .\n\nOn January 16, 2016, Snyder requested that the federal government declare a state of emergency in Flint.\n\nAccording to '''' and , \"...in March 2016 Snyder released a new 75-point action plan to address the contamination crisis, calling for a “much higher standard” for drinking water regulations but stopping short of advocating for complete replacement of all underground lead service lines in the city. The plan included short-, intermediate- and long-term goals, including making infrastructure improvements; creating a data-sharing agreement with state and federal environmental agencies; and setting up a protocol for a “drinkability declaration” for Flint water.\"\n\nIn mid-April 2016, Snyder initiated his own 30-Day Flint Challenge. \"The plan was to drink solely Flint tap water for an entire month to show residents that the water was safe and that he cared about the people.\" However, the Detroit Metro Times reported that the governor left town on April 23 to spend the week touring Europe for trade discussions, breaking his promise.\n\nIn July 2018, Drs Hernan Gomez of the University of Michigan and Kim Dietrich of the , toxicology and environmental health experts, published an  article in  titled  “The Children of Flint were not ‘Poisoned.” In the essay article the authors referred to the findings in a study ''“Toxicohistrionics”: Flint, Michigan and the Lead Crisis'' published in the June issue of . According to their opinion and the study, there was a small increase of children whose blood lead levels surpassed the Centers for Disease Control reference level (from 2.2 percent to 3.7 percent), but none were at a level that required urgent medical treatment.\"\n\nOn April 16, 2020, an article was published giving details of evidence of corruption and a cover-up by Snyder and his \"fixer\" Rich Baird, and saying the statute of limitations on some of the most serious felony misconduct-in-office charges would expire on April 25, 2020. The article was published by , written by  and Jenn Dize, the co-founders of ''Status Coup'', with photos by Brittany Greeson. Responses from Michigan state authorities denied that a deadline was approaching and said that criminal prosecutions would follow.\n\nOn January 12, 2021, It was announced that nine former government officials including Rick Snyder would face charges resulting from the Flint water crisis. Snyder was charged with two misdemeanors of willful neglect but he pleaded not guilty to the charges. Following its practice of paying the legal costs for state employees charged with a criminal offense, the administrative board of Michigan approved an up to $1.45 million contract with  law corporation to defend the former governor Snyder.\n\n\n\nJust before leaving the governor's office, Snyder formed a new Ann Arbor based company called RPAction LLC whose staff consists of former officials of the Snyder administration.\n\nOn June 29, 2019, Snyder accepted a soon-to-be appointment at Harvard to share his knowledge of state and local government. On July 3, he tweeted that he was \"turning down\" the offer: \"It would have been exciting to share my experiences, both positive and negative; our current political environment and its lack of civility makes this too disruptive.  I wish them the best.\"\n\nSnyder endorsed   during the , alleging that \"President Trump lacks a moral compass. He ignores the truth\" and that the president \"also demonstrated that he does not fully appreciate policy matters, including public health, the economy and foreign relations, nor does he seem to want to learn.\"\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  official Michigan government site\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Jewell Jones''' (born April 11, 1995) is an American politician from the  of . He served on the  of , and was elected to represent the  of the  as the youngest representative in state history. He is a member of the .\n\n\nJones's parents involved him in his church and in volunteering from a young age. He became a  in his family church. Jones graduated from  in , in 2013. He is a student at the , where he is pursuing a Dual-Degree in Business and Political Science. He participated in the . During his years in school, he became involved in politics, working on the political campaigns of  for  and Hilliard Hampton for mayor of , in 2014. In 2015, at the age of 20, he was elected and sworn into the Inkster City Council, becoming the youngest councilperson in the city's history. Jones campaigned for  in the 2016 election.\n\n\n\nJones was elected to the Inkster City Council at the age of 20, becoming the youngest person to ever sit on the city council. As an Inkster City Councilman, Jones focused on the city's education system.\n\n\nFollowing the death of , the  member of the  for the 11th district, in 2016, , her daughter, was the only candidate to file for the  nomination in the  to finish her term, which she won. However, s selected Jones to be the Democratic Party's nominee for the 11th district in the 2016 general election. He won, receiving 66% of the vote against  nominee Robert Pope, and became the youngest State Representative in Michigan's history.\n\n\n\nOn May 26, 2018, Jones was pulled over for speeding, window tint, and having an obstructed license plate. He was cited for driving with open intoxicants, although officers stated that Jones and all of the passengers were sober. His  for the  charges was set for August 24, 2018.\n\nOn April 6, 2021, Jones was arrested on charges stemming from a motor vehicle accident.  Paramedics arrived first and observed a woman with her pants down, and Jones with his pants partially down.  When police arrived, Jones was charged with resisting and obstructing a police officer, operating a motor vehicle with high blood alcohol content, operating a motor vehicle while intoxicated, possession of a weapon under the influence of alcohol and reckless driving. During the arrest, Jones told officers that he would call governor , and warned the officers that he runs the state budget. Jones's attorney denied that he resisted the arrest, and said that his statements regarding the governor and the budget were made in an attempt to stop the officers from using excessive force.\n\nOn September 15, after being arraigned, Jones was found to have attempted to smuggle a handcuff key into the jail. The key was attached to the bottom of his foot, with clear tape.\n\nFollowing his arrest, Jones was stripped of his committee assignments in September 2021.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*  at Michigan House Democrats\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Abdullah H. Hammoud''' (; born March 19, 1990) is an American politician serving as the  of , since 2022. A member of the , Hammoud had previously served in the , representing the  from 2017 to 2021.\n\nHammoud is the first ,   and first  mayor of Dearborn as well as the second youngest mayor in the city's history. His election is considered historic as the city is home to one of the largest ern and Muslim populations per capita in the United States.\n\n\nHammoud was born in , to a   family. His father worked as a  and his mother, who had not completed high school, further pursued her education and became a small-business owner. Hammoud earned a  in  from the , a  in  and  from the , Ann Arbor, and a  from the  on the same campus.\n\n\nAt 26, then a healthcare advisor at the , Hammoud decided to run for office after his older brother unexpectedly died. Hammoud defeated  nominee , a  , in the general election by a margin of 61% to 38%.\nUpon his election, Hammoud became the first  and  to represent the 15th district.\n\n\nHammoud backed   in the .\n\nWhen President  visited a  factory in Dearborn during the , Hammoud gave him a letter calling for a ceasefire and a re-evaluation of the hip.\n\n\n\nOn January 25, 2021, Hammoud announced he would run for . Election night results on the August 3 primary showed him in first with 50% followed by Susan Dabaja with 15.6% and Tom Tafelski with 13.5%. Hammoud finished first and he advanced to a November 2 general election against . In the November election, Hammoud won the race for mayor, making him the first Arab American and first Muslim mayor of Dearborn. His term began January 1, 2022.\n\n\nOne of Hammoud's first actions as mayor of Dearborn was to establish a local . The city became the first in Michigan to set up such a department voluntarily. Hammoud also sought reforms to the city's police force, including the elimination of employment policies prohibiting beards, tattoos and loose hair, in an effort to increase diversity. In addition, he instructed officers to focus on dangerous traffic violations rather than . Hammoud credits his reforms as having led to a 50 percent decrease in the proportion of tickets issued to Black drivers and a 10 percent decrease in the number of car accidents in the city.\n\nHammoud has also pushed for investments in water and sewer infrastructure, parks, and green spaces. He has also advocated a reduction in  for new construction projects as part of a  strategy for the city, which was heavily impacted by flooding in 2019 and 2021.\n\nBecause of the Biden administration's stance on the , Mayor Hammoud declined an invitation to meet with Biden campaign officials before the president's withdrawal from the . Explaining his decision on , Hammoud wrote, \"I will not entertain conversations about elections while we watch a live-streamed  backed by our government.\"\n\nAccording to '''', Hammoud has been approached by , the 's presidential nominee in both  and , to be her running mate in Stein's . Hammoud, however, would not meet the age requirement for US vice presidents (35 years old by January 20, 2025, the date of the new president's inauguration), as required under the .\n\nHammoud spoke at a Dearborn rally on the Israel-Gaza war on September 24, 2024, immediately following a speech by activist . The two embraced as Hammoud joined Siblani on the stage. Siblani called for the \"return [of Israelis] to Poland\" and praised  leader . Hammoud did not address Siblani's respect for the Hezbollah leader or the crowd's calls of \"death to Israel\", nor did he respond to the local media's request for comment.\n\n\nHammoud is married to Fatima Beydoun, a physician.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Laura Cox''' (born August 7, 1964) is an American  from . Cox is a former  member of , and the former chairwoman of the .\n\n\nCox has an undergraduate degree in , and a master's degree in Criminal Justice Research and Planning from .\n\n\nCox was a  special agent for 13 years.\n\nIn 2004, Cox was first elected to the Wayne County Commission, where she served until 2014. Cox chaired the Ways and Means Committee. Cox has been the 11th Congressional District chairperson, treasurer to the Wayne 11th Congressional District Republican Committee, and on the  as a member of the Policy Committee, Women for Bush 2008 Co-Chair, and as a delegate at-large to the .\n\nOn November 4, 2014, Cox won the election and became a Republican member of the  for . Cox defeated Stacey Dogonski with 61.77% of the votes. On November 8, 2016, as an incumbent, Cox won the election and continued serving District 19. Cox defeated Steve King with 61.42% of the votes.\n\nOn November 6, 2018, Cox ran for the  seat for  but lost the election. Cox received 47.33% of the votes and she was defeated by  with 50.56% of the votes.\n\nIn 2018, Cox was endorsed for State GOP chair by campaign manager Brad Parscale. On February 23, 2019, Cox was named the chair person of . Cox's co-chair is Terry Bowman.\n\n\n\nAfter Joe Biden won the 2020 presidential election, President  refused to concede and made baseless claims of fraud. Cox called for delaying the certification of election results in Michigan. Her complaints about the election results focused solely on Wayne County, which includes Detroit, a majority-black city. Cox falsely claimed that Republican poll watchers were prevented from observing the ballot counting in Detroit; in fact, there were more than 134 Republican poll watchers in the TCF Center in Detroit, where ballots were counted. Politico described Cox's comments on Republican poll watchers as egregiously dishonest.\n\n\nCox is married to , a former attorney general of Michigan. They have four children. Cox and her family live in Livonia, Michigan.\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Prior to that, Steckloff served 8 years on the Farmington Hills City Council.\n\n\nSteckloff was born around 1984 in  to mother . In 2002 she graduated from her home city's . On November 3, 2020, Steckloff was elected to the , where she has represented the  since January 1, 2021. She resigned from the city council to serve in the state legislature.\n\nIn the Michigan House, Steckloff serves on the Appropriations Committee and is Vice-Chair of the Transportation Subcommittee. She also is a member of the Joint Capital Outlay and Licensing & Regulatory Affairs/Insurance & Financial Services Subcommittee of the Appropriations Committee.\n\n\nIn 2015, Steckloff was diagnosed with , the most common form of . Due to the diagnosis, Steckloff experienced bouts of depression and suicidal thoughts. Her experiences were featured in the 2016  documentary ''Death Is Not the Answer''.     "pages": }\n'''Mallory Ann McMorrow''' (born August 23, 1986) is an American politician who has served in the  since January 2019. She became senate  on January 1, 2023. A member of the , she represents the ; before that, from 2019 to 2023, she represented the , which included , , , , , , and , Michigan. Prior to running for the Michigan Senate, McMorrow worked in .\n\n\nMcMorrow was born in the  section of , and graduated from . She was raised Catholic and her family was active in their local parish. McMorrow sang in her church choir, and her mother taught  (CCD) classes. However, her parents divorced, and their priest called her mother \"disappointing\" and said she was \"not living up to the Church's expectations\" as he had not seen her in church. McMorrow said that on Sundays, she and her mother volunteered at local s outside of the .\n\nMcMorrow received a  in industrial design from the  in 2008. During her junior year at Notre Dame, she won a public design contest for the 2018 version of the . She also finished second in a contest to design the logo for the . After graduation, McMorrow worked for design firms in New York and Los Angeles, as well as for  and , before moving to Michigan.\n\n\nMcMorrow participated in the  in Detroit, and began writing postcards to , the , challenging positions of the . She applied to 's Michigan chapter, which provides training to political candidates.\n\nIn 2018, McMorrow ran for the , seeking to represent . She was unopposed in the 's , and faced incumbent Republican senator  in the general election. McMorrow defeated Knollenberg, receiving 52 percent of the vote, with 73,138 votes to Knollenberg's 67,798. Michigan Senate Democrats chose McMorrow to serve as the assistant minority floor leader.\n\nIn January 2020, McMorrow, lobbyist Melissa Osborn and '''' reporter Allison Donahue accused Republican state Senator  of sexual harassment. McMorrow stated that Lucido touched her lower back and upper buttocks in November 2018, shortly after she was elected to the state senate, and made comments during a training session that suggested she won her election because of her appearance.\n\nIn June 2021, McMorrow introduced Senate Resolution 57, the third time it had been introduced, which proposed to declare June as Gun Violence Awareness Month. The resolution was not adopted by the Senate, instead being referred to the State Government Operations Committee. She also introduced Senate Resolution 58, which asked the  to authorize the installation of electric vehicle charging stations at rest areas along the Interstate Highway System and allow charging station providers to charge a fee for public use of the stations. Also that month, she co-sponsored the reintroduction of Senate Resolution 60, introduced by Senator , which proposed declaring June as  in Michigan. The resolution was adopted.\n\nIn April 2022, Republican State Senator  claimed in a campaign fundraising email that McMorrow wanted to \".\" On April 19, 2022, McMorrow took to the senate floor to defend herself against Theis' accusations, stating:\n\n:\"I am the biggest threat to your hollow, hateful scheme. Because you can't claim that you are targeting marginalized kids in the name of 'parental rights' if another parent is standing up to say no. You say, 'She's a groomer. She supports pedophilia. She wants children to believe that they were responsible for slavery and to feel bad about themselves because they're white.' I am a straight, white, Christian, married, suburban mom who knows that the very notion that learning about slavery or redlining or systemic racism somehow means that children are being taught to feel bad or hate themselves because they are white is absolute nonsense. No child alive today is responsible for slavery. No one in this room is responsible for slavery. But each and every single one of us bears responsibility for writing the next chapter of history... we are not responsible for the past. We also cannot change the past. We can't pretend that it didn't happen, or deny people their very right to exist.\"\n\nNeither Theis nor the  apologized for the false accusations, and Theis did not respond to McMorrow's speech on the senate floor. McMorrow's speech, which she uploaded to social media platforms, received over one million views just a few hours after it was posted. As of May 26, 2022, the video of McMorrow's speech has more than 15 million views on Twitter alone.\n\nDuring redistricting following the , prior to the 2022 elections, Michigan's independent  merged McMorrow's district with the district represented by fellow Democrat . In the primary election held August 2, 2022, McMorrow defeated Bullock for the Democratic Party's nomination for the 8th District. McMorrow defeated Republican Brandon Ronald Simpson in the November general election. On November 17, 2022, McMorrow announced that she would serve as Senate Majority Whip in 102nd Senate session.\n\nOn August 19, 2024, McMorrow delivered a speech at the  and brought out a giant copy of the roughly 900-page . It became one of the Democratic Party's most consistent tools against the campaign of former President , claiming \"They went ahead and wrote down all the extreme things that Trump wants to do in the next four years\" and she gave her support to  . McMorrow's debut book, ''Hate Won't Win: Find Your Power and Leave This Place Better Than We Found It'', is set to be published by Hachette Book Group on March 25, 2025.\n\n\nMcMorrow supports expanding investment in renewable energy practices and funding clean water initiatives in her district. She supports ,  initiatives, and .\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n|percentage=100.0}}\n\n\n\n\n|percentage=100.00}}\n\n}}\n\n\n|percentage=100.00}}\n\n\nMcMorrow married , the former head of 's content sales department and editor of the weblog . The wedding was held in June 2017 in the  district of . They have a daughter named Noa born in January 2021 and they live in .     "pages": }\n'''Timothy Lee Walberg''' (born April 12, 1951) is an American politician serving as a  from Michigan since 2011, representing the state's  since 2023. A member of the , he previously represented the  from 2007 to 2009 and from 2011 to 2023. As the longest tenured member from , Walberg is the current Dean of its delegation to the \n\n\nWalberg was born and raised in , Illinois, the son of Alice Ann and John A. Walberg. His paternal grandparents were Swedish. In 1964, Walberg served the  as a volunteer. Walberg graduated from  in 1969 and briefly served the  From 1973 to 1977, Walberg served as pastor at Grace Fellowship Church in New Haven, Indiana.\n\n\nWalberg was a member of the  from 1983 to 1998. He also spent time as a pastor and as a division manager for the  in  while continuing to live in Michigan.\n\n\n\n;2004\n\n\nAfter six years out of politics, Walberg ran in a field of six candidates in the 2004 Republican primary for the 7th District after six-term incumbent  retired. Walberg finished third in the primary.   won the primary and the general election.\n\n;2006\n\n\nWalberg defeated Schwarz in the Republican primary. In the general election, he defeated Democratic nominee Sharon Renier, 50%–46%.\n\nIn 2007, there was a failed recall effort against Walberg.\n\n;2008\n\nEntering the 2008 race, Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee chairman  identified Walberg as one of the most vulnerable Republican incumbents in Congress. On August 23, 2007, State Senate Minority Leader  announced he would challenge Walberg. The previous occupant of the seat, , who lost to Walberg in the 2006 Republican primary, declined to run but on September 30 endorsed Schauer.\n\nSchauer narrowly defeated Walberg in the November election, 49% to 47%. Between the two candidates, around $3.5 million was spent on the campaign, making it one of the most expensive House races in the 2008 election. Schauer outspent Walberg by nearly $300,000.\n\n;2010\n\nOn July 14, 2009, Walberg announced that he would challenge incumbent . He defeated Marvin Carlson and Brian Rooney in the Republican primary.\n\nPolling showed the race as a dead heat. Walberg defeated Schauer, 50%–45%.\n\n;2012\n\nWahlberg defeated Democratic nominee Kurt Haskell, 53%–43%.\n\n;2014\n\n\nWalberg defeated former Democratic State Representative  with 54% of the vote.\n\n;2016\n\n\nWalberg defeated Doug North in the August 2 Republican primary and Democratic nominee State Representative  in the general election, with 55% of the vote.\n\n;2018\n\n\nWalberg defeated Driskell again, with 53.8% of the vote.\n\n;2020\n\n\nWalberg defeated Driskell a third time, with 58.7% of the vote.\n\n;2022\n\n\nDue to redistricting, Walberg, the incumbent of the 7th congressional district, faced Democratic opponent Bart Goldberg, an attorney, in .  Walberg was re-elected with 62.4% of the vote.\n\n\n* \n** \n* \n** \n** \n** Vice Chair, \n\n\n* \n* \n*\n* \n\n\n\nWalberg rejects the . On the subject, he said in May 2017, \"I believe that there is a creator in God who is much bigger than us. And I’m confident that, if there’s a real problem, He can take care of it.\"\n\n\nWalberg has repeatedly voted to repeal the . Walberg shares an office with , which was vandalized by  in June 2022, just before the '''' decision.  attributed the attack to the group .\n\n\nIn 2015, Walberg cosponsored a resolution to . Walberg also cosponsored a resolution disagreeing with the Supreme Court decision in '''', which held that same-sex marriage bans violated the constitution.\n\nWalberg voted against the  codifying '''' and '''', recognizing marriages across state lines regardless of \"sex, race, ethnicity, or national origin of those individuals.\"\n\nOn October 8, 2023, Walberg gave a keynote speech at the National Prayer Breakfast in , at the invitation of Ugandan legislator . Walberg's trip to Uganda was paid for by , which sponsored the breakfast. During his speech, Walberg urged Uganda to \"stand firm\" against international pressure to \"change you\", apparently referencing sanctions by the United States government against Uganda over the recently enacted , which prescribes lengthy prison sentences and in certain instances the  for homosexual activities. “Worthless is the thought of the world, worthless, for instance, is the thought of the World Bank, or the World Health Organization, or the United Nations, or, sadly, some in our administration in America who say, ‘You are wrong for standing for values that God created,’ for saying there are male and female and God created them,\" said Walberg. Bahati, the original sponsor of the Anti-Homosexuality Act, stated that Walberg had told him “Uganda is on the right side of God,” when he asked Walberg if he were comfortable associating with Bahati. Walberg additionally praised Uganda's President , who also spoke at the breakfast, and who signed the Anti-Homosexuality Act into law.\n\n\nWalberg has repeatedly invoked  conspiracy theories about President , arguing that Obama should have been impeached over his birth certificate.\n\n\nIn December 2020, Walberg was one of 126 Republican members of the  to sign an  in support of '''', a lawsuit filed at the  contesting the results of the , in which  defeated incumbent . The Supreme Court declined to hear the case on the basis that Texas lacked  under  to challenge the results of an election held by another state.\n\n\n\nIn March 2024, responding to a question about \"why are we spending our money to build a port for them,\" referring to the Biden Administration's plan to build a  to facilitate delivery of  in the , Walberg told the crowd the U.S. \"shouldn’t be spending a dime on humanitarian aid\" and instead “should be like . Get it over quick.\" The , a U.S.-based Muslim civil rights group, condemned Walberg's comments as a \"clear call to genocide.\" Dawud Walid,  Chief director of CAIR's Michigan chapter, said: \"This ... should be condemned by all Americans who value human life and international law.\" \"To call indifferently for the killing of every human being in Gaza sends a chilling message,\" Walid added.\n\nTadatoshi Akiba, a member of  and former mayor of Hiroshima City, and others held a press conference at City Hall on April 10. The letter of request, which was read out loud, criticized the Hibakusha for their suffering from radiation damage and psychological damage, and said \"We regret your ignorance and insensitivity to the unjust suffering and human misery that occurred as a result of the atomic bombings.\"\nJapanese Diet member  criticized the event as a \"defeat for diplomacy\". In response, Japanese Foreign Minister  stated that she was not considering protesting.\n\nWalberg also opposes humanitarian aid to Ukraine in the . “Instead [of] 80 percent in Ukraine being used for humanitarian purposes, it should be 80 [to] 100 percent to wipe out Russia  if that’s what we want to do.” Walberg also voted against aid to Ukraine in 2022.\n\nIn response, Walberg denied advocating the use of nuclear weapons, claiming that he merely \"used a metaphor to convey the need for both Israel and Ukraine to win their wars as swiftly as possible\" despite his reference to the US dropping atomic bombs on two Japanese cities to bring an end to WWII.\n\n\n;2004 election for the U.S. House of Representatives – 7th District Republican primary\n*  (R), 28%\n* Brad Smith (R), 22%\n* Tim Walberg (R), 18%\n*  (R), 14%\n* Gene DeRossett (R), 11%\n* Paul DeWeese (R), 7%\n\n;2006 election for the U.S. House of Representatives – 7th District Republican primary\n* Tim Walberg (R), 33,144, 53%\n*  (R) (inc.), 29,349, 47%\n\n;2006 election for the U.S. House of Representatives – 7th District\n* Tim Walberg (R), 49.93%\n* Sharon Renier (D), 45.98%\n* Robert Hutchinson (L), 1.55%\n* David Horn (UST), 1.47%\n*  (write-in), 1.07%\n\n;2008 election for the U.S. House of Representatives – 7th District\n* Mark Schauer (D), 48.79%\n* Tim Walberg (R), 46.49%\n* Lynn Meadows (G), 2.96%\n* Ken Proctor (L), 1.76%\n\n;2010 election for the U.S. House of Representatives – 7th District\n* Tim Walberg (R), 50.1%\n* Mark Schauer (D), 45.4%\n* Other, 4.5%\n\n;2012 election for the U.S. House of Representatives – 7th District\n* Tim Walberg (R), 55.4%\n* Kurt Haskell (D), 44.6%\n\n\nWalberg and his wife, Sue, have been married since 1974. They have three adult children: Matthew, Heidi, and Caleb.\n\nWalberg is an ordained pastor.     "pages": }\n| successor           = \n| birth_name          = Noah Jeremy Arbit\n| birth_date          = \n| birth_place         = , \n| death_date          = \n| death_place         = \n| party               = \n| education           =  ()\n| website             = \n}}\n\n'''Noah Jeremy Arbit''' (born September 21, 1995) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  since 2023. A member of the , Arbit represents , anchored in , alongside , , , and portions of  and  townships. First elected in the November , Arbit is the youngest LGBTQ+ person ever elected to serve in the Michigan Legislature.\n\n\nNoah Arbit was born on September 21, 1995, alongside his fraternal twin brother, to parents Edie and Steve Arbit. Arbit was raised with his two brothers in , and attended , including Lone Pine Elementary School, West Hills Middle School, and Andover High School, before completing high school at the  in 2013.\n\nIn 2018, Arbit graduated from  with a Bachelor’s Degree in  and . His undergraduate thesis, entitled “International Law and the Israeli Embassy and AMIA Bombings in Buenos Aires: Iranian Terrorism, Argentine Corruption, and the Birth of an International Cold Case”, was published by the Pennsylvania Undergraduate Law Review in Spring 2018.\n\n\nIn 2016, Arbit took a semester off college to work for ’s , leading the campaign’s organizing efforts in West Bloomfield, Commerce, and  townships in central-west . He has cited Clinton’s loss in the 2016 election as a major turning point in his career, compelling him to shift focus from foreign affairs to local and state politics.\n\nFollowing his graduation, Arbit worked as a staffer for ’s 2018 gubernatorial campaign in Oakland County, and later, as a fundraiser for the Michigan House Democrats.\n\nFollowing the 2018  in Pittsburgh, and a perceived rise in  nationally, Arbit founded the Michigan Democratic Jewish Caucus, stating its mission to “elevate Jewish voices in the , combat antisemitism and extremism, and advocate for progressive policies to build a better, stronger, fairer Michigan.” As chair of the Michigan Democratic Jewish Caucus, Arbit was outspoken about the need to combat antisemitism in politics, and the importance of Jews running for office in Michigan. He was named to the ’ annual “36 Under 36” list in 2020 and 2022.\n\nIn January 2021, Arbit was appointed Director of Communications for the Oakland County Prosecutor’s Office, serving under Prosecutor . He organized the Office’s first-ever Racial Justice Advisory Council, as well as its first ever Pride celebration.\n\n\nIn August 2021, prior to the completion of Michigan’s redistricting process, Arbit announced his candidacy for the Michigan House of Representatives, filing to run in an undetermined district anchored in his hometown of West Bloomfield. In his announcement, Arbit cited the urgency of combating rising hate crimes and extremism, as well as addressing Michigan’s mental health crisis.\n\nOn August 2, 2022, backed by record-breaking fundraising and endorsements from U.S. Representative , local leaders, and organizations, including the , Arbit came first in a competitive, three-way Democratic primary for Michigan’s 20th House District, defeating West Bloomfield School District board member Ken Ferguson and former legislative staffer James Sklar by nearly 16 percentage points, with 7,180 votes (46.6%) to Ferguson’s 4,785 (31%), and Sklar’s 3,448 (22%).\n\nOn November 8, 2022, Arbit was elected to the Michigan House of Representatives in the 2022 General Election, defeating Republican Party nominee Albert Mansour with 56.6% of the vote to Mansour’s 43.4%. Arbit is only the second Democrat to represent a state house district comprising West Bloomfield and Commerce Townships since before the Civil War, and is the youngest openly gay person ever elected to the Michigan Legislature.\n\nOn December 4, 2022, Arbit was sworn in as State Representative by  Justice  at the Jewish Community Center in West Bloomfield. U.S. Representative  also participated in Arbit’s ceremony.\n\n\nArbit is ; he and his family are congregants at  in West Bloomfield. Arbit is also openly gay, and has cited his experiences as a part of the Jewish and LGBTQ+ communities as compelling him to get involved in politics, to run for office, and particularly, to focus on strengthening Michigan’s  laws.\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Otis Milton Smith''' (February 20, 1922 – June 29, 1994) was the first African American justice on the  and the  for .\n\nSmith graduated from law school at  in 1950, where he was a member of the first volume of the school's ''Law Review''.\n\nHe then went to , where he engaged in private practice until 1957.  At that time he was appointed to the Michigan Public Service Commission. His reputation for fighting graft there earned him a nickname: \"the man who shot Santa Claus.\"\n\nFrom 1959 until 1961 Smith served as .\n\nHe was appointed a justice of the Michigan Supreme Court in 1961 by Governor  He retained his seat in the 1962 election but lost re-election in 1966, and was then hired by General Motors.  He would rise to become vice-president and General Counsel. In , Smith served as a . In 1983, his portrait was dedicated at the Michigan Supreme Court.  A portrait also hangs in the admissions of The Catholic University of America, .\n\nA scholarship in his name is administered by the Community Foundation for Southeast Michigan.  It is given to a single mother, and can be used for tuition at , any campus of the , or the law school at The Catholic University of America.\n\n\n*\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''JoAnn Watson''' (April 19, 1951 – July 10, 2023) was an American pastor, media personality and was a Detroit city councilor for ten years. She was an on-air personality for 910 AM Superstation/ and Comcast Channel 91 \n\nWatson was an associate professor at . Watson also served as the Associate Pastor of West Side Unity Church and was a faculty member at the Unity Urban Ministerial School.\n\n\nJoAnn Watson was born on April 19, 1951 and raised in . She was the daughter of Jefferson Nichols Sr. and Rev. Lestine Kent Nichols.\n\nAfter graduating from  in 1968, Watson attended the , where she earned her Bachelor of Arts degree in Journalism and was later recognized as a \"Distinguished Alumnus\" and, in 1996, given the \"Leonard F. Sain Esteemed Alumni Award\". Watson also was awarded an honorary Doctorate in Humanities.\n\n\nWatson began her career in public service as the executive director of the Downtown Detroit . She would eventually rise to the position of assistant executive director of the National YWCA. From 1987 to 1990, she worked the New York headquarters and directed their Office of Racial Justice. She later worked the executive director of the Detroit .\n\nIn 1989, Watson was selected as a delegate to the Women for Meaningful Summits/USA, which was held in the .\n\nIn 2001, Watson was selected to serve as a delegate to the .\n\nIn 2016, Watson was chosen by  as one of a six-member boardto advise them on the creation of Melodya doll that depicts a 9-year old African American girl living in Detroit during the .\n\nWatson was the founding President of the National Association of Black Talk Show Hosts; was a consultant to Pathways to College; was a member of the Detroit Council of Elders; was a member of the National Black Council of Elders. and served as President of the National Anti-Klan Network and as President of the Center for Democratic Renewal.\n\n\nWatson was a contributing author to \"Should America Pay?\", Dr. 's 2003 publication on reparations, and wrote the foreword to 's 2017 book, ''Black Detroit: A People's History of Self Determination''.\n\n\nPrior to her service as a member of the city council, Watson served as public liaison for Congressman .\n\nIn 2003, Watson filed to run in a Special Election called to fill a vacancy on the , which was created when Councilwoman Brenda Scott died on September 2, 2002. On April 29, 2003, Watson won the Special Election 52% to 48%, defeating .\n\nWatson would subsequently win re-election to City Council and served as City Council President Pro Tem.\n\nDuring Watson's tenure on City Council, her staff included future Michigan State Legislator , who interned in her office.\n\nIn 2013, Watson announced her intention to retire. In December of that year, a celebration of her career was held at the , where Dick Gregory again was the headliner.\n\n\nWatson died on July 10, 2023, at the age of 72.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Brian Nelson Calley''' (born March 25, 1977) is an American politician who served as the 63rd  from 2011 to 2019. A member of the , he was previously elected to the  from 2007 to 2011.\n\nCalley is known for his advocacy for people with  and their families; his daughter is autistic. Calley campaigned to require Michigan health insurance plans to include coverage for , signing into law a package providing for such reforms as acting governor.\n\n\nCalley was born in , the third of six children. The family moved from  to , in 1982 where his father was stationed in the U.S. Army. Two years later, the family moved back to Michigan where Calley graduated from Ionia High School in 1994. After attending  while a student at Ionia High School, he earned a bachelor's degree in business administration from  in 1998 and a Master's in Business Administration from  in 2000. In the 10 years preceding his election to the Michigan legislature, Calley held various positions within the banking industry, primarily making commercial loans. During this time he served two terms on Ionia County Board of Commissioners, both as Vice Chairperson.\n\nCalley was elected to the Michigan House of Representatives in 2006 and re-elected in 2008. He served both terms in the minority, with the 2009–2010 term seeing the smallest Republican caucus in 40 years. In the House he gained a reputation as an expert on tax policy and served as minority vice chair of the House Tax Policy Committee. He was named the 2008 \"Legislator of the Year” by the state's Small Business Association, the first time a freshman lawmaker has received that designation.\n\nIn 2010, despite securing the Republican nomination for state Senate days earlier, Calley was announced as gubernatorial candidate 's running mate. Tea Party supporters from west Michigan momentarily contested Calley's nomination during the state Republican Convention at Michigan State University's Breslin Center in favor of Bill Cooper, a Norton Shores businessman and former candidate for Congress. Cooper withdrew his name from consideration and publicly threw his support behind Calley. In securing the nomination for lieutenant governor, the state Senate nomination was vacated and former state Representative  was chosen to fill the spot.\n\nSnyder and Calley went on to defeat   and his running mate,  Mayor  in the general election by 58% to 39%.\n\n\n\nCalley assumed office as the nation's youngest lieutenant governor and Michigan's youngest lieutenant governor since  in 1959. Calley undertook an active role in the Snyder administration.\n\nIn early 2011, Calley broke a 19–19 deadlock in the Michigan Senate, voting in favor of a massive tax reform package that eliminated the Michigan Business Tax and replaced it with a flat, six-percent corporate income tax. The package, a major goal of the Snyder administration, also reduced the state's individual income tax rate from 4.35 percent to 4.25 percent starting on January 1, 2013, and eliminated most of the state's exemptions and deductions.\n\nFor two years, he attended weekly classes at the  at  before receiving his  in spring 2015.\n\nIn May 2017, Calley announced a campaign to make the legislature part-time.\n\nCalley unsuccessfully ran to succeed Snyder in the . On August 7, 2018, he lost the Republican primary, receiving 25% of the vote, placing second behind Michigan state Attorney General  who eventually lost the general election on November 6, 2018 to Democrat .\n\n\nCalley, whose daughter Reagan is , is known for his outspoken advocacy for autism awareness. As a state lawmaker Calley served on the Health Policy Committee and supported autism insurance reform - unaware his own child actually had the disorder. He stated he first suspected his daughter's condition during a committee hearing as parents of autistic children shared their similar experiences.\n\nAs lieutenant governor, Calley is widely credited for leading a successful legislative push to require that insurance companies cover treatments for autism. He signed the bills into law as acting governor while Rick Snyder was on an unannounced trip to Afghanistan. Citing these efforts, Calley was named the 2011 \"Executive Champion” by the national autism advocacy organization .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Robert J. VerHeulen''' is a  politician from  who served in the . Prior to his election to the House, VerHeulen served as the mayor of . He was also an attorney for  and served on several community boards and organizations.\n\nIn November 2018, VerHeulen proposed a bill to limit the powers of an incoming Democratic administration in Michigan. In the 2018 elections, Democrats obtained the governor, secretary of state and attorney general posts; Democrats last held all three positions at the same time in 1990. The bill would give greater powers to the Michigan legislature, where the Republican Party holds a majority of seats. The bill would also shift oversight of the Michigan Campaign Finance Act away from the Secretary of State to a commission.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

A member of the , Aiyash serves as the chamber's majority floor leader. He represents much of  , , , , , and all of the city of .\n\n\nAiyash was born and raised in , the seventh of eight children. His parents immigrated to  from . Aiyash was educated in the  and earned a Bachelor of Arts degree from , where he studied pre-medicine, political science, and Muslim studies.\n\n\nWhen he was 13, Aiyash worked as a community organizer for the . In 2015 and 2016, he worked in the office of State Rep. .\n\nIn 2018, Aiyash was a candidate for the Democratic primary to represent . He finished second after , who won the general election. During his campaign, Aiyash was endorsed by the ''''.\n\nAbraham announced his candidacy for the  of the  following the death of  in March 2020. In the Democratic primary, Aiyash placed first in a field of 13 candidates. He defeated Republican nominee Howard Weathington, Working Class Party candidate Linda Rayburn, and Independent MD Rabbi Alam in the November general election. He assumed office on December 1, 2020.\n\nIn 2023, Aiyash became majority leader of the House of Representatives, the first Arab-American to do so. He also became the highest-ranking Muslim American in the state's legislative history.\n\n\nAiyash has shown support for , legislation against pollution and other issues surrounding the environmental and public health.\n\nAiyash has advanced legislation aimed at gun reform to curb gun violence. Aiyash has proposed legislation to make  and  state holidays.\n\nAiyash supports expanding civil rights. In 2023, he co-sponsored a bill in the  which amended the  to include protections for the .\n\nAiyash opposed a resolution calling for the support of Israel and condemnation of the Hamas terrorist attacks against Israel, saying the resolution fails to recognize the suffering of the Palestinians. Aiyash stated \"I think any conversation around what is happening in Israel and Palestine that makes no acknowledgement of the 70-plus year occupation and mistreatment of the Palestinian people is disrespectful.”\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Martin''' \"'''Marty'''\" '''Knollenberg''' (born September 21, 1963) is a  politician from the  of  who previously served in the  from the . He was a member of the , representing the  which covers the cities of  and  in . He is the son of former  , who represented  from 1993 until 2009.\n\nKnollenberg was elected to the State House in 2006 and re-elected in 2008 and 2010.  He was term limited in 2012 and succeeded by Republican .  He had previously served as an Oakland County Commissioner from 2002 to 2004 and Oakland County Parks and Recreation commissioner from 2004 to 2006. He was the subject of controversy in 2015 for stating \"the non-white population\" was a contributor to the failure of Michigan's worst-performing schools in a State senate education committee meeting, adding that \"We can't make an African American white.\" He later apologized for his \"clunky\" choice of words.\n\n\nKnollenberg has a bachelor's degree in history from .\n\n\nKnollenberg has served three terms in the Michigan State House. He pushed for legislation in 2011 that would prevent teachers from receiving pay increases while they negotiate their labor contracts. He was the chief sponsor of House Bill 4054, a controversial  in Michigan.\n\nDuring his tenure in the Michigan House, Knollenberg sat on the redistricting committee. Following his father's defeat in 2008 by , Knollenberg was expected to use his position to  the district. Political analyst  said \"I didn't think there's any question that he would love to seek revenge on behalf of his father if the circumstances are right  especially if it's against Peters.\"\n\nIn early 2013 Marty Knollenberg was among candidates planning to run for mayor of  after mayor  was recalled in the November 2012 election.\n\n\n\n\nKnollenberg was a candidate for election in the 2004 Republican primary for the 41st District House seat, being vacated by term-limited representative . He faced former-State Representative  who was running for his final term after leaving office in 2002 to run for state Senate, and upstart candidate Mike Bosnic.\n\nBosnic was also a subject of Knollenberg's literature. He was accused by Knollenberg of accepting an illegal $2,500 contribution from the Heroes of Public Education, which was then a new  subject to a smaller campaign contribution limit. Campaign finance reports later revealed that the Secretary of State required Bosnic to repay $2,000 of the donations because it exceeded campaign limits.\n\nDespite Pappageorge's endorsement of Knollenberg, the August primary was won by Gosselin with 38% of the vote, with Knollenberg garnering 29% and Bosnic 28%.\n\n\nIn the August 2006 primary, Knollenberg faced Clawson School Board Trustee and attorney Mike Bosnic. Knollenberg won by a 53.5-46.5% margin.  The contest was labeled by Michigan Information & Research Service (MIRS), a Lansing-insider political publication, as the fourth most interesting primary in Michigan.\n\nKnollenberg defeated  college student Eric Gregory in the November general election by a 58-42% margin.\n\n\nKnollenberg was re-elected with 57.46% of the vote for his second-term in November 2008, defeating opponent Evan Treharne (41.98%), a 24-year-old school teacher. In the campaign, Knollenberg made attacks ads about Treharne's age.\n\n\nKnollenberg was re-elected to the Michigan House for a final time in November 2010.\n\n\nKnollenberg was term-limited in 2012 and in 2011 formed a congressional campaign committee in anticipation of running for a seat in the US House of Representatives. He abandoned his plans after being redistricted into the same district as . Knollenberg ran for the office of Treasurer of Oakland County and was defeated by incumbent .\n\n\nKnollenberg ran in the special election to replace Janice Daniels as the Mayor of Troy, Michigan. He lost to Dane Slater, who was serving as interim mayor.\n\n\nKnollenberg was elected to the Michigan Senate in 2014 after the Troy Republican survived a crowded primary GOP field of candidates that included former Reps. Chuck Moss and Andrew Raczkowski. In the general election, Knollenberg defeated Democrat Cyndi Peltonen 58 to 42 percent.\n\n\nKnollenberg ran for re-election to another term in the Michigan Senate. After running unopposed in the Republican primary, he was defeated in the general election by Democrat  48 to 52 percent.\n\n\nKnollenberg was the subject of controversy in 2015 for statements he made during a State senate education committee meeting that suggested failing schools could be fixed if African American students could be made white. He stated, \"You mentioned why these school fail, and you mentioned the economically disadvantaged and non-white population are contributors to that. You know, we can’t fix that. We can’t make an African American white. It is what it is, and we can't fix that.\"\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Jennifer Elkins''' is a  politician from  who served one term in the , in 2003 and 2004, until being unseated by . Prior to her election to the House, Elkins was a member of the  Board of Commissioners.\n\nElkins was passionate about youth and social services, serving as a member of the executive committee of the Mid-Michigan Community Action Agency, as vice chair of the Human Services Coordinating Body during her tenure on the county board, as a member of the Michigan Association of Counties' Human Services Committee, and with numerous other area and community organizations.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
