His district consisted of , , and western  Counties.\n\nPotvin was the chief executive officer of Western Concrete Products Company, and board chairman and executive committee member of the . He also served as a second lieutenant in the .\n\n\nIn 1996, Potvin was cited by Michigan's Department of Environmental Quality (DEQ) for the illegal dumping of several hundred gallons of toxic materials into an old elevator pit by Cadillac's branch of Western Concrete Products Company. The clean-up effort ranged from 1998 until its termination in 2002 and cost the company $162,500 in fines.\n\n\nAn , Potvin remained involved in the  as an adult, serving on the executive board member of the Scenic Trails Boy Scout Council and as assistant scoutmaster for Boy Scout Troop 125 in Cadillac.\n\nPotvin is a board member of , and a member of Quality Deer Management, the , and Right to Life of Michigan.\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Tim Greimel''' is an American politician who serves as Mayor of , and previously as a member of the , to which he was elected in a  in 2012 following the resignation of . After Greimel's election to a full term in , his colleagues elected him to serve as the House's minority leader.\n\nIn October 2017, Greimel announced his candidacy for the  to represent  but in the  on August 7, 2018, he lost to .\n\nIn November 2021, Greimel was elected , with 61.66% of the vote.\n\n\nTim Greimel attended the , from which he received his bachelor's degree in economics and political science, a master's degree in public policy, and juris doctor degree. Greimel was admitted into the  on November 15, 2000. He has a focus in , and .\n\n\nIn May 2005, Greimel was elected to serve on the  Board of Education. He received 7,817 votes, the second-largest number of votes behind Michelle J. Shepherd, who received 7,989 votes. During his time on the school board, Greimel briefly served as president of the board. In August 2008, and again in 2010, Greimel was elected as County Commissioner of the 11th district. At the end of 2011, Greimel won a special election for  in the . Following the special election, Greimel won the election for a full term in 2012. Greimel served as the Democratic Leader for the House until 2018, when he lost the Democratic primary to  by 4,636 votes.\n\nIn 2021, Greimel ran for mayor of . Greimel delivered his first state of the city address for Pontiac on September 29, 2022.\n\n\n\n\nAccording to , during his time in the legislature, Greimel supported legislation to expand and support technical careers education. One of Greimel's main campaign promises was to improve Pontiac Public Schools by hiring liaisons-and-recreation coordinators, and working with , , local s, and non-profits to improve recreation, after school activities, and early education, and increase technical education.\n\n\nMost of Greimel's views and work about infrastructure has been in roads. Greimel introduced legislation to refund Michigan drivers with a tax credit for car damage caused by damaged roads. According to his campaign website, Greimel planned to spend more money on Pontiac's roads, specifically the  loop, to improve access to downtown. His campaign also promised to increase access to Wi-Fi and spend money on water-and-sewer repairs. During his time in the state legislature, Greimel called on former Governor  to resign after the .\n\n\nGreimel believed enforcing anti-blight policies and code enforcement for the appearance of buildings would help strengthen Pontiac's neighborhoods. He also planned on implementing  and  programs, and to re-establish s.\n\n\nGreimel believed in making downtown a , and make Pontiac an easier-and-friendlier place to do business. This included consistent and accessible permits, moving the  downtown, facilitating free entrepreneurship classes, implementing more Pontiac-specific policies, and promoting women-and-minority-owned businesses. Greimel acted on this and developed a Downtown Redevelopment Plan.\n\n\nDuring his mayoralty, Greimel worked with  officials to redevelop Pontiac's downtown area and increase foot traffic. Greimel planned to demolish the Phoenix Center and replace it with a recreational space that would serve as a city center. Greimel described the Phoenix Center as a \"dilapidated eyesore of a derelict parking structure\".\n\nOakland County purchased two buildings to be used as office space in downtown Pontiac. Greimel expected the increased foot traffic from county employees and the new city center would boost economic activity in Pontiac's downtown area. The redevelopment project is expected to cost around $120–130 million, most of which would come from the state, Oakland County, and the . Greimel said the downtown redevelopment plan \"will ensure the city owns a large space that can facilitate outdoor concerts and serve as a town square and public place for the community\".\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }}}}\n| known_for   = \n| occupation  = Lawyer\n| signature   = \n|alma_mater   = \n}}\n\n'''Alva Marvin Cummins''' (February 24, 1869August 8, 1946) was an American lawyer. Cummins was admitted to the bar in 1891. From there, he went on to serve in leadership positions at multiple bar associations. Cummins also had a political career marked by several electoral defeats. Cummins was nominated by the Democratic party for positions such as congressman, governor, and state attorney general.\n\n\nAlva M. Cummins was born on February 24, 1869, in , to parents Jeptha and Phebe Cummins. Alva's parents were pioneers from . Alva received a public school education. In 1881, Alva's parents moved to . There, Alva began studying at Groton College. In 1888, the Cummins family moved back to Michigan, settling in . Alva graduated from . After studying in the law office of Samuel L. Kilbourne in , Alva was admitted to the Michigan Bar in 1891.\n\n\n\nAfter being admitted to the bar, in 1891, Cummins started to practice law in Mason. In 1896, Cummins was elected Ingham County Prosecuting Attorney. On January 1, 1897, Cummins formed a partnership with lawyer Louis B. McArthur. In 1899, Cummins moved to Lansing, where he joined the law firm which became known as Thomas, Cummins & Nichols. In 1912, the firm changed its name to Cummins & Nichols. In 1922, Cummins once again began practicing alone as Cummins and Charles W. Nichols dissolved the firm. By 1938, Cummins was part of a firm entitled Cummins & Cummins. Cummins served as the chairman of the commission which drafted the Michigan Judicature Act of 1915, which recodified Michigan court procedure. Cummins was a part of several bar associations, including the Lansing Bar Association, the Ingham County Bar Association which he had been the dean of, the  which he served as the president of, and the .\n\n\nCummins was a lifelong Democrat who made several unsuccessful attempts to run for political office in his life. Cummins served four years on the Lansing Board of Education. Cummins was a member of the Michigan Democratic State Central Committee in 1907. In 1908, Cummins was a delegate to the Democratic National Convention. Cummins was the Democratic nominee for the  seat representing the  in  and . In 1922, Cummins served as the chairman of the Democratic state advisory convention, with no intention to run for office himself, however, without Cummins' prior knowledge, the convention nominated him for governor. In the September Democratic primary, Cummins won against the only other candidate, James B. Balch, former mayor of Kalamazoo. Cummins was defeated by incumbent Republican  in the  on November 7. Cummins received 218,252 votes, compared to Groesbeck's 356,933. Cummins again served as a delegate to the Democratic National Convention in 1924. There, he presented Governor  as a potential presidential nominee. In 1926, Cummins was the Democratic nominee for , ultimately being defeated by . Cummins received 154,031 votes compared to Potter's 415,981. In , Cummins was a candidate for the , but he was defeated in the primary.\n\nDespite being a Democrat, Cummins was appointed to some positions by Republican governors. Governor  appointed Cummins to the public utilities commission, which he served on from May 1929 to June 1931. Governor  appointed Cummins to the liquor control commission in 1940.\n\n\nCummins married Jennie Osborn on May 25, 1892. Together, they had one daughter. Jennie died on April 19, 1898. On February 22, 1900, Cummins married Fannie Fitch. Fannie's grandfather, , and her father, , were both prominent Democratic politicians who served in the . Together, they had two children. Fannie died on May 13, 1942, and was interred at Maple Grove Cemetery in Mason. Cummins was a  and a member of the .\n\n\nIn 1944, Cummins moved to  for retirement after illness prevented him from being active in political and legal affairs. In 1946, Cummins visited his son, Charles Fitch Cummins, and stayed at his house near . While visiting, Cummins died of a heart attack on August 8.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

        ]

    "pages": }\n\n'''Ranjeev Puri''' (born  1984) is an American politician serving as a member of the  since 2021, representing the , and serving as the House Majority Whip since 2023.\n\nBefore joining the Legislature, Puri worked in financial consulting and then went on to work for President Barack Obama. Puri received his undergraduate degree in economics and finance and went on to receive his MBA from the University of Chicago Booth School of Business in 2014.\n\n\nPuri was born around 1984 in  to immigrant parents. He earned a bachelor's degree in economics from . In 2014, Puri obtained a Master's of Business Administration from the  at the .\n\n\nPuri worked on 's presidential campaign. Since 2013, Puri worked in business development for . Puri is affiliated with the Michigan Indian American  Caucus. \n\nPuri was endorsed by the then-incumbent state representative  when he ran in the primary for the  seat representing the . On August 4, 2020, Puri won this primary. On November 3, 2020, Puri won the general election for this seat, assumed office on January 1, 2021. With his victory, Puri became the youngest Asian-American elected to the Michigan Legislature, and the first ever Sikh-American elected in Michigan's legislative history. \n\nUpon starting his second term in the Michigan House in January 2023, Puri was appointed as Chair of the Appropriations subcommittee on Transportation. As Chair, Puri has been vocal about the need to modernize Michigan's infrastructure to prepare for robust public transit and mobility options. \n\nIn 2023, Puri made national headlines with his statement in response to the Michigan State University shooting. Puri is an advocate for common sense gun reform, and has spoken of his own personal experience with gun violence as his family's former place of worship fell victim to a white supremacist mass shooter in the  in 2012.\n\nIn 2024, he sponsored legislation to take away the ability of homeowners associations to block homeowners from putting in place energy efficiency structures on their houses, such as  and home . The bill passed the Michigan state legislatures on party lines before being signed into law by Governor Gretchen Whitmer.\n\n\nPuri resides in . Puri is married and has three children. Puri is .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n\n'''Alan Bruce Sanborn''' (born July 21, 1957) is a retired politician from the  of , serving parts of three terms in both the  and .\n\n\nSanborn is the son of Lois and . Kenneth Sanborn is a former member of the , former  judge, and one of the attorneys who undertook the successful defense of  in 1953. The Radulovich case was a major factor in helping to turn public opinion in the United States against .\n\nSanborn was born and raised in . He attended  and graduated with a  in  with a minor in . He married Lori McQuiston on August 6, 1982. Sanborn and his ex-wife have three children.\n\n\nSanborn worked from 1978 to 1998 as a  probation officer. In 1996, Sanborn challenged and lost to incumbent  in the Republican primary for the  of the Michigan House of Representatives. In a special election in February 1998, Sanborn was elected to the seat after Jaye resigned to run for an open  seat.\n\nIn 2001, after Jaye became the first member of the  to be expelled from office,\n Sanborn came out on top of a field of thirteen Republican candidates, including Jaye, in a primary special election held September 11, 2001. In the heavily Republican district, Sanborn easily won the general special election on November 6, 2001.\n\nSanborn was re-elected in 2002, 2004 and 2006, and was named by Lansing-based political newsletter ''Inside Michigan Politics'' as \"Michigan's Most Conservative Legislator\" in 2003, 2004, and 2005. On January 1, 2011, Sanborn's term in the Senate officially came to an end, though his political aspirations did not. After returning to work as a juvenile probation officer for Macomb County, he put his hat in the ring for former Rep. Candice Miller's seat in Congress. After an unsuccessful run, he retired from his position with the county in 2018 to establish a property rental business in Lexington, Michigan.\n \nHis more notable legislative achievements include \"Lisa's Law\" (which protects probation officers) and a bill allowing visitation rights to grandparents.\n\n\nIn March 2015, 7-term incumbent   shocked political pundits by announcing her intentions to retire at the end of her current term and not seek an 8th term in 2016 in . Sanborn was amongst the first candidates to be mentioned as a possible successor to Miller. He formed an exploratory committee on March 30, 2015, which gave him the ability to raise and spend money for a possible Congressional campaign and formally announced his candidacy on April 21, 2015.\n\nSanborn finished third in a five-person field, taking 16 percent of the vote, finishing behind winner Paul Mitchell, who took 37 percent of the vote, and state Sen. , who took 28 percent.\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Arthur Jay Lacy''' (September 30, 1876April 6, 1975) was an American politician, lawyer, and philanthropist. In , Lacy served as the  Michigan gubernatorial nominee.\n\n\n\nArthur J. Lacy was born on September 30, 1876, in Nirvana, , to parents Francis Daniel Lacy and Eunice Amelia Lacy. Arthur attended school until age twelve, and was also tutored at home by his father. In 1894, Arthur started to attend Northern Indiana Normal School (now known as ), and ended up earning an  from the Northern Indiana Normal School of Law. In 1896, Arthur started attending the , where he again earned an LL.B in 1898.\n\n\nIn 1896, Lacy was admitted to the Indiana Bar, despite being underage, and was admitted to the Michigan Bar in 1898. In 1899, Lacy moved to , where he started his law career. He served as city attorney for Clare from 1899 to 1909. Lacy served as mayor of Clare from 1902 to 1906. In , Lacy unsuccessfully ran for the  seat representing the . Lacy would also unsuccessfully run for the position of prosecuting attorney. In , Lacy served as a delegate to  from Michigan.\n\nIn 1909, Lacy was invited by 's lawyer, , to practice law in . Lacy moved to Detroit in July the same year. Lacy also unsuccessfully ran for the position of  in 1909. Lacy was a member of the law firm Millis, Griffin and Lacy from 1912 to 1913. In 1913, Lacy was appointed as judge of the then-new Detroit Domestic Relations Court by Michigan Governor . The court was dissolved by the  eight months later in 1914. In 1914, Lacy joined the law firm Anderson, Rackham, and Wilcox, where he replaced former member . By 1938, the firm was known as Anderson, Wilcox, Lacy and Lawson. In 1919, Lacy began serving on the Detroit Civil Service Commission. In 1920, Lacy was appointed as the head of the civil service commission by  . Lacy served as Couzens' personal lawyer for the rest of his life. He would serve on the civil service commission until 1923. In 1926, Lacy unsuccessfully ran in the  primary for the  seat representing the .\n\nIn 1930, Lacy would being a personal campaign against heavy taxation and high governmental costs during the , which would gain him prominence in the Democratic Party. Accomplishments during this campaign included assisting thirty small banks in Michigan in avoiding  from 1932 to 1933 and co-authoring the Michigan Emergency Banking Act. In 1933, Lacy served as a delegate to the Michigan convention to ratify the , where he represented the  1st district. In 1934, Lacy was persuaded to run in the Democratic Primary for the position of Governor of Michigan. On September 11, 1934, Lacy won the primary, defeating incumbent Democratic Governor . In the , on November 6, 1934, Lacy was defeated by  nominee . Lacy's political career rapidly waned after this. Lacy disagreed with many of Democratic President 's policies, such as deficit spending and . As such, he became a Republican, but he was not accepted by the party. Lacy continued to focus on his law practice, as well as philanthropy. By 1938, Lacy was a member of the , the Michigan Bar Association, and the Detroit Bar Association. In 1947, Lacy became less active in his law firm. He continued to focus on income tax cases, as he was considered an expert in the field.\n\n\nOn November 1, 1898, Lacy married Beth Malissa Garwick. Beth died in 1970. From 1918 to 1919, he served as president of the . Lacy was . Lacy was a .\n\n\nLacy died on April 6, 1975, in .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n'''Tudor Dixon''' (; born May 5, 1977) is an American anti-abortion politician, businesswoman and  political commentator. A member of the , Dixon was the party's nominee for  in the . She became the Michigan Republicans' first female nominee for governor. Dixon lost the election to incumbent  governor  by 10.6 points.\n\n\nDixon grew up in , the daughter of Vaughn Makary (died 2022) and Catherine Makary, graduating from  in 1995. She is of partial  descent.\n\nDixon received a  with a major in  from the  in 1998. In the 2000s, she moved to  in .\n\n\nBefore her career in media, Dixon was an executive at Michigan Steel Inc, her father's steel foundry. In 2017, Dixon co-founded Lumen Student News, a now-defunct news site that produced -leaning lessons for grade school students.\n\n\nIn 2018, she became a conservative commentator, anchoring the weekly program ''America's Voice Live'' on , a streaming news and opinion channel.  \n\nIn March 2023, Premiere Networks launched The Clay Travis & Buck Sexton Podcast Network, with Dixon becoming their debut host. She hosts “The Tudor Dixon Podcast”.\n\n\n\n]]\nIn May 2021, Dixon announced her candidacy to become the Republican Party's nominee for  in the , seeking to challenge incumbent Democrat . In a July 2022 Republican primary debate, Dixon pledged loyalty to Trump. During the campaign, Dixon promoted 's . In a May 2022 debate, when asked, \"Do you believe Donald Trump legitimately won the 2020 election in Michigan?,\" Dixon responded, \"Yes.\" In subsequent media appearances, Dixon would not say whether she still held that belief.\n\nTrump endorsed Dixon after Trump's former Secretary of Education  wrote a letter to the former president, asking him to support Dixon, whom DeVos termed \"the only one who can stand toe to toe with\" Whitmer. In August 2022, Dixon won the Republican primary.\n\nDixon was endorsed by Trump, the , former acting director of national intelligence , representative for Michigan's 2nd congressional district , GOP House Conference Chair , and former Democratic representative for Hawaii's 2nd congressional district .\n\nDixon lost the general election. On November 9, she called Whitmer to concede the race.\n\n\n\n\nDixon supports a ban on all abortions except solely when necessary to save the life of the pregnant woman, and would oppose any exceptions for rape or incest. She has also said she does not believe the mother's health is a sufficient reason, saying that the \"health of the mother and life of the mother are different.\" In an interview, she described the example of a 14-year-girl raped by her uncle as a \"perfect example\" of an abortion that she believes should be prohibited, adding, \"a life is a life for me.\" In follow-up interviews, she has repeated her belief that there should be no exceptions for victims of rape and incest. Following her run for election, Tudor Dixon hosted President Trump on her podcast where she said President Trump encouraged her to talk about abortion differently. “You came to me and you said, ‘You got to talk differently about abortion.’ And we could not pivot, we could not pivot in time,” Dixon said. \n\nIn a Fox News interview, Dixon praised former United Nations Ambassador  for her answer on abortion during a GOP primary debate, where Haley argued Republicans should find \"consensus\" by focusing on banning late-term abortions, encouraging adoptions and fostering policies that protect doctors and nurses who don't want to perform abortions. \"It was the perfect response,\" Dixon said.\n\n\nIn a June 2020 episode of her ''America's Voice Live'' show, Dixon said \"our kids are not at risk\" of catching . When Whitmer brought this up during an October 2022 debate, Dixon denied making the comment and said \"My own children have had COVID, so I would never say that.\"\n\nFollowing an October 2022 decision to include COVID-19 vaccines on the CDC's optional immunization recommendation schedule, Dixon alleged that \"liberal policymakers are pushing COVID-19 vaccines on our children and forcing parents out of the process\". According to ''Michigan Advance'', the state \"does not have a vaccine mandate for COVID-19 and unvaccinated children are not precluded from attending school\"; the media outlet further noted that \"This is not the first time Dixon has touted  and children\".\n\nIn a June 2020 episode of her show, Dixon invoked a conspiracy theory that the COVID-19 pandemic was part of a plot that Democrats have planned for decades in order to topple the United States.\n\n\nDixon plans to found Education Savings Accounts, which can hold funding for students to use on various options of schools. In order to establish Education Savings Accounts, she has called for the repeal of the state's constitutional provision prohibiting public funding of private schools. \n\nDixon proposed a piece of legislation that would ban teachers from talking about sexual orientation or  with K-3 students. She called for the resignation of the leader of  due to LGBT training materials, stating that \"our schools are laboratories for their social experiments and our children are their lab rats.\"\n\nIn June 2022, Dixon spoke in support of a bill that would prohibit  shows in public schools and permit parents and guardians to sue schools that host drag shows. Critics highlighted the lack of evidence for such events in Michigan schools, and they pointed out that drag shows were not defined in the bill.\n\n\nDixon has made public comments that have been condemned as  by a journalist and an activist, such as defending the usage of . She also described  as \"oppressive garments\". She thinks that  aims to control the black population and that the  were part of a scheme by Democrats to take down Donald Trump. During her campaign for governor, Dixon made a gender-based attack, suggesting her opponent is not a \"real woman\".\n\n\nDixon supports tax cuts, especially by ending the state's flat income tax of 4.25%, which makes up one-sixth of the state's total budget. Her plan to replace revenue lost by the tax cut relies on tourists from other states. Dixon has vowed not to cut police funding. Dixon has criticized Gretchen Whitmer for her order to shut down the Line 5 pipeline, arguing that the closing will only lead to an increase in energy prices. She has also criticized Whitmer's policies regarding nursing homes during the COVID-19 pandemic. Dixon, whose grandmother died at a nursing home amid the pandemic, accused Whitmer of being \"ruled by fear\".\n\n\nDixon supports the Michigan Voter ID Initiative. If passed, the initiative would require governmental ID to vote, end the sending of unsolicited applications for absentee ballots, abolish , prohibit , restrict election expenses to be publicly funded, and toughen punishments for election fraud. Dixon also called for an audit of the 2020 election results in Michigan.\n\n\nDixon is married to Aaron William Dixon, a financial controller, and they have four daughters. She is a  survivor, having been diagnosed in 2015.\n\nDixon is an .\n\nDixon considers  a hobby and has appeared in low-budget s.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''James Richard Fouts''' (born August 8, 1942) is an American politician who served as the mayor of  from 2007 to 2023.\n\n\nFouts grew up in , where his father served as the city assessor, and later as city manager. Prior to election to public office, he spent his career as an educator, teaching government, political science, and psychology in the . His last teaching position was at , where he taught for about ten years.\n\n\nIn 1976, Fouts ran as a  for the Michigan state house of representatives in the 70th District. Fouts was elected to the Warren City Council in 1981, where he served for 26 years as a . During his tenure, he initiated several anti-tobacco proposals.\n\nIn 2007,  had reached the  as mayor of Warren and did not seek re-election. Fouts ran against City Clerk Richard Sulaka for the open seat and won 62% to 38%. In the 2007 campaign, finance reports show that Sulaka outspent Fouts $332,000 to $225,000. Sulaka described Fouts as a \"maverick\" and attributed his victory to voters seeking an alternative to the previous administration. The election also saw Warren citizens electing a new clerk, new treasurer, and a majority of new council members.\n\n\n\nHis enforcement of local building codes led to the demolition of dilapidated buildings and the promotion of neighborhood \"clean sweeps\" by city inspectors and was touted as a model for other mayors.\n\nIn response to the challenges facing the automotive industry, an industry which employs many Warren residents, he initiated a \"Buy American Products\" policy for automotive purchases by heads of city departments.\n\nIn 2009, Fouts tried to convince General Motors to relocate its headquarters from Detroit to Warren.\n\nHis 2011 re-election campaign was endorsed by the ''Detroit Free Press'' who said the campaign had become \"way too focused on legal battles over Fouts' age\" which became an issue when his opponents filed suit to remove him from the ballot because he had refused to place his age on the candidacy form. He won the lawsuit and the election with more than 80% of the vote against City Councilwoman Kathy Vogt.\n\nIn 2012, he acted to ban smoking within 100 feet of any city building without legislative approval, but the court said he did not have the authority and had the \"No Smoking\" signs removed. Fouts brought the measure back to the city council, after they had tabled it in September.\n\nIn July 2014, Fouts personally denied permission to establish an  \"Reason Booth\" at Warren City Hall, as a counterpoint to a \"Prayer Booth\" that was established in the city hall's atrium by a local  church in 2009. The resident denied permission, Douglas Marshall, filed a federal lawsuit against both the city and Fouts. Represented by the , , and , Marshall's lawsuit was based on the  rights to free speech and a violation of the . The defendants failed to respond to the lawsuit, and in 2015 the federal court ordered that the reason station \"be allowed to operate on terms not less favorable than the terms granted to the 'Prayer Station' currently allowed in the atrium space\" and entered a $100,000 judgment against the city and Fouts for costs, damages and attorney fees.\n\nIn 2014, Fouts sued to invalidate 2014 Proposal 1, a voter-approved referendum that eliminated the Michigan personal property tax for businesses (which applies to industrial machinery and office equipment) and replaced it with an Internet sales tax. Fouts alleged that the ballot wording was biased. The Michigan Court of Claims declined to invalidate the ballot initiative, and Fouts ultimately dropped an appeal.\n\nIn March 2016, Fouts claimed that he was asked by security at the  to refrain from showing excessive enthusiasm for , and that he was threatened with ejection.\n\nFouts won a third term in November 2015, carrying 85% of the vote.\n\nIn November 2016, Fouts accused Macomb County Executive  of a coverup of illegal dumping. In response, Hackel provided a series of audio recordings to the media, that he claimed to have received from unidentified sources, allegedly of Fouts making derogatory comments. Fouts claimed that the recordings were manufactured and manipulated. These led to calls for Fouts's resignation. In a post on , Fouts declared his intention to remain in office through to the end of his term in 2019; he would go on to be reelected to a fourth term later that year, with 57.5% of the vote.\n\nIn late 2017, amid the , Fouts and Warren Police Commissioner Jim Dwyer created a program to offer rewards to residents of the city who give confidential tips to police informing on suspected drug deals.\n\nIn April 2020, Fouts directed the Warren Police to not enforce the provision of 's executive order on COVID-19 banning commercial lawn services. Fouts stated the lack of lawn maintenance would lead to higher numbers of mosquitoes and rodents and be a health hazard and that it is an essential service.\n\nIn January 2023, Fouts filed paperwork to run for a fifth term as mayor in the November 2023 election, despite voters passing a charter amendment in 2020 establishing a three-term limit for the office of mayor. The city's election clerk approved his candidacy, and was promptly sued by the City Council. Fouts claimed to have been grandfathered in, having been elected to all four terms before the amendment passed; a Macomb County judge sided with Fouts in March. The decision was overturned by the  in April, and the clerk was ordered to disqualify Fouts.\n\n\nFouts rejoined the Democratic Party in 2024, and that April, he filed to run in the Democratic primary for Michigan's redrawn , challenging incumbent Representative . McFall defeated Fouts, 71% to 29%.\n\n\n\nFouts won his re-election to the City's Mayoral office over challenger Kelly Colegio. \n}}\n\n\n 9,649\n}}\n\n\n\nFouts won his re-election to the City's Mayoral office by an extremely large margin over challenger Karen Spranger. \n}}\n\n\n 8,407\n}}\n\n\n\nFouts won his re-election to the City's Mayoral office by an extremely large margin over challenger Kathy J. Vogt. \n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\nThe Macomb Clerk's website does not have election results for Fouts' first election.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Kevin J. Green''' (born June 18, 1970) is a  politician.\n\n\nKevin Green was born on June 18, 1970, to parents Joe and Colleen Green. He grew up in , and earned a bachelor's degree in business administration from . He also earned a master's degree in public administration from . In 1994, Green interned for the city manager of .\n\n\nGreen worked as a business manager for . In 1995, Green became the real estate and community relations manager of the Western Michigan region for . Green is a member of the Wyoming-Kentwood Area Chamber of Commerce and the  Chamber of Commerce.\n\nIn 1999, Green started to serve as a  city council member. He became the youngest elected official in Wyoming, Michigan history. He served on the city council until 2004. On November 2, 2004, Green was  to the , where he represented the . Green was sworn in on January 15, 2005.\n\nOn October 29, 2008, Green was arrested for drunk driving. The  Sheriff's Department report says that Green was found passed out in a parked, running car, covered in vomit and smelling of alcohol in . Green initially said that he was pulled over by the police. He later claimed that he was not passed out, but instead had fallen asleep. Green repeatedly refused to take a breathalyzer test. He later took the breathalyzer test at the jail. His blood alcohol level was 0.13%. The legal limit in Michigan is 0.08%. News of his arrest was spread by November 5, 2008, the day after his  to the state house. Initially, Green was charged with drunk driving, a conviction which had the potential to land Green in jail. On November 25, Green pleaded guilty to \ndriving while impaired, a lesser charge which only involves fines, the adding of , and a license restriction. Green agreed to step down from two committees for the rest of the year: the Health Policy Committee and the Banking & Financial Services Committee. Green retained his position on the Senior Health, Security and Retirement Committee and as state house whip. Green served the remainder of his term in the state house until January 1, 2011. He was then term limited.\n\nIn 2014, Green ran for the  seat representing the . While Green and  shared many political views, such as standing against , abortion, and increasing the minimum wage, MacGregor's primary campaign managed to get significantly more donations from . On August 5, Green was defeated by MacGregor, who went on to win the .\n\nIn 2016, Green ran to be the supervisor of . On August 2, in the Republican primary, Green defeated incumbent supervisor, Nancy Clary. In the general election, he was unopposed.\n\nGreen ran for the state senate seat representing the 28th district again in the . The seat was made vacant when  left the office after being elected Kent County treasurer. During his campaign, Green advocated for a \"\" of the . The primary took place on August 3. He faced challengers  and . He was ultimately defeated by Huizenga, coming in second place. On August 18, Green petitioned for a recount in the primary election. He cited two irregularities which made him question the integrity of the election: Green won more in-person votes, but lost due to mail-in support for Huizenga, and he claimed that there were an unspecified number of people who voted in the primary who do not normally vote in primaries.\n\n\nGreen is married to Chele and has two children.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Stephanie Gray Chang''' is an American politician and a  member of the , representing the . She previously served in the  representing the .\n\nChang is the first  woman to serve in the . She was also the first woman to give birth while serving as a Michigan State Senator.\n\n\nChang was born at  in . She was raised with her older sister, Josephina, in  and is the daughter of parents who emigrated from  to pursue work in the auto industry.\n\nIn 2005, Chang graduated from the  with a bachelor's in psychology and a minor in Asian/Pacific Islander American Studies. In May 2014, she received a master's in public policy and a master's in social work at the University of Michigan.\n\nWhile at the  at the University of Michigan, Chang was a  Leadership Fellow, interning at the Detroit mayor's office, as a paid intern via the .Wogan, J. B. . ''''. January 22, 2015. . David Bohnett Fellows – UM Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy. . ''BohnettFoundation.org''. . ''BohnettFoundation.org''.. , . May 31, 2011.. , .\n\n\n\n\nBefore her election, Chang worked for about a decade as a community organizer in Detroit. During that time, she worked for  Michigan as the state director,  in Michigan as the alumni engagement and evaluation coordinator, the James and Grace Lee Boggs School as the community engagement coordinator, the Campaign for Justice as deputy director, Michigan United as an organizer, and as an assistant to .\n\nChang was the co-founder and past president of Asian and Pacific Islander American Vote-Michigan and previously a mentor with the Detroit Asian Youth Project. She also co-founded and is a board member for Rising Voices of Asian American Families. She is a board member of the Southwest Detroit Community Justice Center.\n\n\nChang became the State Representative for Michigan's House District 6 in January 2015. In her first term, she served on the Committees on Criminal Justice, Education, and Judiciary. In her second term, she served on the Committees on Education Reform, Law and Justice (where she serves as Minority Vice Chair), and Natural Resources.\n\nMuch of her legislative work is focused on air quality, affordable and safe drinking water, education and criminal justice reforms.\n\nShe was the chair of the Progressive Women's Caucus, a founding member of the Asian Pacific American Legislative Caucus, and a member of the Detroit Caucus, Michigan Democratic Latino Legislative Caucus and Michigan Legislative Black Caucus. She also served on the federal Environmental Protection Agency's Local Government Advisory Committee, which provides advice and recommendations to the EPA administrator to help develop strong partnerships with local governments to deliver environmental services and programs. Chang also focuses much of her work with residents in the district with the Mary Turner Center for Advocacy, the Neighborhood Service Center, ranging from saving homes from tax foreclosure to hosting a community baby shower for low-income pregnant women. In 2016 she launched the Girls Making Change fellowship, a leadership program for high school girls of color in District 6.\n\nChang faced  in a Democratic Party primary for  District 1 on August 7, 2018, winning 49% to Cook Scott's 11%. During the election, Cook Scott made racially charged comments about Chang, referring to her as \"ching-chang\" and \"the \", but later issued an apology through a representative.\n\nChang currently serves as State Senator for District 3 and as the Minority Floor Leader in the State Senate. She is the Minority Vice Chair for the Committee on Judiciary and Public Safety and for the Committee on Finance.\n\nShe has passed legislation related to female genital mutilation, criminal justice reform,  \",\" business improvement zones, domestic violence, and reentry services for previously incarcerated but exonerated people.\n\n\nChang and her husband, Sean Gray, live in  with their two young daughters.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Joseph Allen Tate''' (born December 13, 1980) is an American politician and former professional football player from . Tate has served as a  member of the  from  since 2019 and as  since 2023.\n\n\n\nTate was born in , the youngest of four children. His father, Coleman Sr., was a Detroit firefighter who died when Tate was an infant. His mother, Debra, was a Detroit public school teacher. Tate spent his early years in the Jefferson Chalmers and Sherwood Forest communities of Detroit.  His mother later moved the family to , where Tate attended , graduating in 1999.\n\n\n\nTate attended  on a football scholarship. He earned four letters at Michigan State from 2000–03 and started 29 games his last three years at left guard. A two-time Academic All- selection in 2000 and 2001, he garnered second-team All-Big Ten honors from the media in 2003 as the Spartans went 8-4 in the regular season and played in the  against , which . He made his mark off the field as well during his time in , as he also was presented MSU's Community Service and Leadership Award.\n\nAfter two seasons with the , Tate returned to Michigan State University to pursue a master's degree in kinesiology while serving as a strength and conditioning graduate assistant under coach Ken Mannie in 2007 and 2008.\n\nTate attended the 's  and School of Natural Resources obtaining his dual MBA/MS in 2017.\n\n\nTate graduated from  in 2003 with a degree in public policy and was then signed by the  as an offensive lineman. He later played for the  and .\n\n\nIn 2009, Tate joined the  as an officer, serving two deployments in Afghanistan as platoon commander and company executive officer of his infantry unit during . After an honorable discharge, Tate returned to his native Michigan to pursue his MBA.\n\n\n\n\nUpon graduation in 2017, Tate became a program manager at Detroit Economic Growth Corporation.\n\n\nOn November 6, 2018, Tate won the general election and became a member of , serving District 2, a community that covers part of Detroit’s Lower East Side, , Grosse Pointe Woods, Grosse Pointe City, and Grosse Pointe Farms. He was elected to a second term in 2020.  After the  gained control of the  in the s, Tate became the first  to be elected .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Steve Lindberg''' (born June 2, 1944) is a  politician from the  of . In 2006, he was elected to the  representing the , which is located in Michigan's  and includes the counties of , , , and most of . He was the Chairman of the Labor Committee.\n\n\nLindberg was born in , on June 2, 1944. He graduated from Gwinn High School in 1962 and attended  where he received a  in Business Administration, his teaching certificate and later a  in Guidance and Counseling. In 1968, Lindberg began teaching at the Women's Job Corps Center at Northern Michigan University. He then taught in the Marquette Public Schools System as a teacher and . He owned a travel agency in . Lindberg retired in 1997.\n\n\nLindberg was elected to replace outgoing representative  on November 7, 2006, who retired due to term limits. Lindberg received more than twice as many votes as his  opponent, Joel Westrom. Lindberg won a highly competitive four-way Democratic primary earlier in the year. He represented the 109th district, located in Michigan's . He sat on the Education, Energy and Technology, Labor, Tourism, and Outdoor Recreation and Natural Resources committees. Lindberg won re-election in 2008 against Republican Doreen Takalo and Independent Richard Hendricksen. In 2009, Lindberg became chairman of the Labor Committee.\n\nLindberg has a relatively liberal voting record in the State House. He voted No on SB 776, the bill which amended the Michigan penal code to ban  and . He voted Yes on HB 4836, a bill which would characterize discrimination based on sexual orientation a . He twice voted to ban  smoking in public places. Lindberg has a generally pro-labor, pro-environment voting record. The Michigan  gives him a lifetime rating of 100. The Michigan  also gives him a lifetime score of 100.\n\n\n*'''2008 election for State House'''\n**Steve Lindberg (D), 61%\n**Doreen Takalo (R), 30%\n**Richard Hendricksen (I), 7%\n*'''2006 election for State House'''\n**Steve Lindberg (D), 67%\n**Joel Westrom (R), 33%\n*'''2006 Democratic primary election for State House'''\n**Steve Lindberg (D), 45%\n**Mike Taylor (D), 29%\n**Rod DesJardins (D), 14%\n**Richard Hendricksen (D), 11%\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

A member of the , McFall represents portions of , , and , along with all of , and .\n\n\nMike McFall was born on March 4, 1974, and grew up in , a suburb of . Growing up his father worked for  and was a member of  while his mother worked at a local elementary school.\n\nMcFall graduated from  with a bachelor of science in community development and public administration. He worked in the nonprofit sector and as a Membership Services and Philanthropy Associate for the Williams Syndrome Association before being elected.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2017, McFall and his husband moved to Hazel Park, where he quickly became part of the local community, joining local community boards and becoming elected to the city council in 2019. As a member of the city council and the downtown development authority he launched the Downtown Hazel Park Initiative, designed to rejuvenate the downtown and attract business from wealthier, surrounding communities. He would also be elected   of the city.\n\n\nIn February 2022 McFall announced his candidacy for the Michigan House of Representatives, filing to run in the newly drawn 8th district, declaring his priorities to be supporting skilled trades, fixing municipal finance, and supporting mental health. He also made clear the importance of LGBTQ representation in Lansing, and the need to expand the .\n\nAfter winning the primary he was elected by a landslide in the general election on November 8, 2022.\n\n\nMcFall is openly gay, and made history as part of the largest LGBTQ+ legislative cohort in Michigan. He lives in Hazel Park with his husband and pets, two dogs and one cat.\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

In 1942, Lee graduated from the . Lee went on to do post graduate work and alumnus at the .\n\n\nIn 1945, Lee started work as a public accountant. In 1950, Lee founded the firm Albert Lee and Co. in Detroit. He served as the senior partner of the firm until January 1965. Lee served as the special consultant of a number of Michigan Auditors General, including , , and . Lee served as the secretary-treasurer of the Michigan State Board of Accountancy from January 1, 1959, to October 15, 1963. Lee served as vice-chairman of Michigan Governor  and 's Special Task Force for state problems from 1959 to 1963. Lee served as Michigan Auditor General from 1965 to 1982. Lee was a member of multiple accounting associations, including the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, the National Associations of Accountants, and the American Accounting Association.\n\n\nLee was married to Delphine Baron. Together, they had two children, Marc and Helaine. Lee was a Freemason, and was awarded the 33° honorary degree. .\n\n\nLee died at the age of 71 on July 10, 1982.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Barbara-Rose Collins''' (née '''Richardson'''; April 13, 1939 – November 4, 2021) was an American  from the  of  and the first black woman from Michigan to be elected to Congress.\n\n\nCollins was born as Barbara-Rose Richardson in , the daughter of Lou Versa (Jones) and Lamar Nathaniel Richardson, a Ford Motor Co. employee. She is an alumnus of  in Detroit, Michigan. She attended Cass Technical High School in 1957. She earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in Political Science and Anthropology from .\n\nIn 1960, Barbara-Rose Collins became divorced and a single mom. Barbara-Rose Collins worked multiple jobs and had public assistance until beginning a position as a Business Manager at . She worked as a Business Manager for the Physics department at Wayne State University for 9 years.\n\nAfter hearing a speech by Black activist  at Detroit's  Church in the late 1960s, Barbara-Rose Collins became inspired by the speech to pursue a career in activism to uplift communities. Later, she was supported by the pastor of the Shrine Church to pursue a career in state legislature. She ran for a seat in 1974.\n\nDuring her early campaign days in 1974, Collins hyphenated her first and middle names, changing from Barbara Rose to Barbara-Rose, to distinguish herself from other candidates.\n\nCollins was a member of the Detroit Public School Board from 1971 to 1973, the  for the  from 1975 to 1981, and the  from 1982 to 1991. During her time on the Detroit Public School Board, she earned recognition for her \"school safety and academic achievement.\"\n\nIn 1988, she lost a primary election to the incumbent  for what was then ,  When he retired, she won the seat, taking 34 percent of the vote in a crowded eight-way Democratic primary. This was  in this heavily Democratic, black-majority district. She won handily in November and was reelected three more times, each time garnering over 80 percent of the vote. Her district was renumbered as the  after the 1990 census.\n\nCollins was a sponsor of several bills that passed into law, including the Food Dating Bill, the Sex Education Bill, and the Pregnancy Insurance Bill. She also introduced the Unrenumerated Work Act in 1991, 1993, and 1994. This bill would have required the  to set value on unwaged work such as housework, care work, agricultural work, volunteer work, and work in a family business, and include that value in the  of the United States. This measure had been called for in the Forward Looking Strategies resolution passed at the . Collins's bill was endorsed by the  and by 1993 had 90 co-sponsors; however, it failed to pass.\n\nCollins was the subject of a  inquiry in 1995, under suspicion of 11 instances of misuse of funds. In 1996, after she lost the Democratic primary for re-election to , the inquiry was dropped. After five years out of politics, Collins returned to the Detroit City Council in 2001. She was re-elected in 2005 and retired in 2009.\n\n\nIn 1996, Collins was the first congressperson to introduce legislation to make  a federal holiday. According to the ACLU of Michigan, \"Michigan's own Congresswoman Barbara Rose Collins introduced a bill in 1996 that petitioned the U.S. government to make Juneteenth a federal holiday.&nbsp; In her congressional remarks, she stated, \"the dehumanizing and degrading conditions of slavery were unnecessarily prolonged for hundreds of thousands of black men, women, and children, because our American government failed to communicate the truth\" (2017).  Juneteenth finally became a  in 2021.\n\n\nCollins died from  at a  hospital, on November 4, 2021, at age 82, during the . According to her son, she had been vaccinated with the . According to one of her grandsons, Collins had health issues that contributed to her COVID-19 death despite her vaccination status.\n\n\nCollins was the aunt of actor and comedian .\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

    "pages": }\n'''Jeremy Allen Moss''' (born June 23, 1986) is an American politician from ,  currently representing the , which includes all of , , , , , , , and parts of , , and . A member of the , he is the  elected to the , as well as the first to serve as President Pro Tempore. Moss previously served in the  from 2014 - 2018, and remains the youngest-ever member of the Southfield City Council.\n\n\nMoss was born on June 23, 1986, in Detroit and is a lifelong resident of . He attended  and graduated from  in the Birmingham Public School District.\n\nHe graduated with high honors from  with a bachelor's degree in  and an additional major in . While attending Michigan State, he participated in several student-led humanitarian aid missions in the US and around the globe, twice traveling to New Orleans in the aftermath of  to assist with cleanup efforts and spending time abroad in Uruguay to build housing in among the most impoverished areas of South America. He graduated from the Michigan Political Leadership Program Fellowship and was also president of the university's .\n\nMoss is currently a member organizations such as the Greater Southfield/Farmington chapter of the  and the Martin Luther King Task Force, and is a board member of Congregation Beth Ahm in .\n\nHe also serves on the 's State Central Committee, as a board member of the Southfield Lathrup Village Democratic Club, and has been a Southfield Democratic Precinct Delegate. He was an alternate delegate from Michigan to the . In 2011, he was selected Young Democrat of the Year by the Oakland County Democratic Party.\n\nMoss is Jewish and openly gay.\n\n\nMoss worked in the offices of Mayor  and State Representative . He worked as District Director for State Representative  after serving as his campaign manager.\n\nIn November 2011, at age 25, he placed first among eight candidates to be elected to serve as the youngest-ever elected official in Southfield. He served as  of the council's Legislative and Urban Affairs Committee, and as a member of the Boards and Commission and Neighborhood Services committees. In 2013, Moss successfully advocated for the creation of a new Economic Development Committee.\n\nHe was elected to serve the  in the Michigan House of Representatives in November 2014. He became the second openly gay member elected to the Michigan legislature.\n\nIn his first term in the Michigan House of Representatives, he served as minority vice chairman of the House Local Government Committee and sat on the House Commerce and Trade and House Regulatory Reform committees.\n\nMoss was re-elected in 2016. He was selected by his colleagues to serve as the House Democratic . In his second term, he served as minority vice chairman of the House Regulatory Reform Committee and sat on the House Elections and Ethics Committee, House Local Government Committee, and the Joint Committee on Administrative Rules.\n\nIn 2018, Moss was elected to represent the 11th Michigan Senate District and was the Assistant Democratic Leader. Moss started his second term in the Michigan Senate in 2023, representing district 7. He currently serves as President Pro Tempore of the Michigan Senate; Chair of the Elections and Ethics Committee; Chair of the Regulatory Affairs Committee; and is a member on the Economic and Community Development, Government Operations, and Local Government committees.\n\n\nMoss holds the distinction of having been the youngest-ever elected official on the Southfield City Council (2011) and has not let up on public service since. After City Council, he was elected to the Michigan House of Representatives, serving as the Democratic Caucus Whip, and then became the Assistant Democratic Leader in his first term in the Michigan Senate.\n\nIn 2014, he defeated Nicole Brown, Darryle Buchanan and Charles Roddis in the Democratic primary for the 35th District of the Michigan House of Representatives on August 5, 2014. He then went on to defeat  candidate Robert Brim in the general election on November 4, 2014. He defeated Brim in a rematch in 2016.\n\nIn 2018, Moss defeated Crystal Bailey, Vanessa Moss, and James Turner in the Democratic primary for the 11th State Senate district. He went on to defeat Republican Boris Tuman and Libertarian James Young in the general election.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Arthur Edson Blair Moody''' (February 13, 1902 – July 20, 1954), known as '''Blair Moody''', was a journalist and   from the  of .\n\n\nMoody was born in , the son of Arthur Edson Blair Moody and Julia Downey Moody. and attended the public schools in . He graduated from  with a degree in economics in 1922. Moody attended the ; he received his A.B. degree in 1949, and his LL.B. degree in 1952. He was an instructor in history at the , a preparatory school in Providence, in 1922-23.\n\nA solid athlete, Moody lettered in football, baseball and track at Brown. He also was the heavyweight boxing champion at Brown at one time. He was offered a contract by the professional baseball team the  to pitch, but declined.\n\n\n\nMoody moved to  and worked from 1923 to 1951 as a reporter covering , for the '''', a newspaper owned by his uncle, . He was a correspondent for '''' from 1934 to 1948 and wrote for the  and the .\n\nMoody was a combat war correspondent in 1944, covering the war in , , the , the , and . He moderated a radio and television program '''' from 1946 to 1952. He was a foreign correspondent during 1947–1948.\n\n\nFollowing the death of U.S. Senator , Moody was appointed by Michigan Governor  on April 22, 1951, as a  to the . He served from April 23, 1951, to November 4, 1952. Moody was appointed to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee and the Committee on Expenditures in the Executive Departments. In July 1951, he was appointed to chair a subcommittee of Senate Small Business Committee, established to \"protect the interests of small business in the defense program.\" The committee's purview included the perceived problem of steel cutbacks and unemployment in the auto industry. Moody also is remembered for his proposal for presidential debates, an idea that did not take hold until the 1960 Kennedy-Nixon televised debates. An unsuccessful candidate for election in 1952 (to the remainder of the unexpired Senate term), Moody lost to Republican  in the  presidential landslide.\n\n\nMoody resumed his newspaper and television career as the host and moderator of the \"Meet Your Congress\" television show.\n\n\nBlair Moody's father Arthur Blair Moody was the son of .\n\nMoody married his first wife Mary Ann in 1930 and they had a son, Blair Jr. They were divorced in 1940 and Blair Sr. married his second wife, Ruth, in 1941; the marriage lasted until his death in 1954. Blair and Ruth Moody had two sons, Christopher and Robin. \n\nFrom 1946 until 1954, Blair Moody is reported to have had an affair with Helen Knowland, the wife of his friend Republican Senator . William Knowland is said to have later begun an affair with Ruth Moody.\n\nMoody died age 52 on July 20, 1954, in , while campaigning for the Democratic nomination for the other U.S. Senate seat from Michigan, of a  following complications of viral . He was buried at .\n\n was a   Judge, and a Justice of the . Christopher S. Moody was founder and President of Moody & Associates, Inc., a nationwide insurance firm. Robert O. (Robin) Moody is the founder and President of , the oldest independent bargain book wholesaler in America, established in 1980.\n\n\nAn elementary school in , was named for Senator Blair Moody. The school is in its original location with its original name and continues to educate students. A second elementary school was built adjacent to it in the 1960s.\n\n\nIn 1941, Moody authored ''Boom or Bust'', a book charting his post-World War II vision for American democracy. His focus was on transitioning to full employment, reducing the national debt, and identifying a strategy for \"how the national budget may actually be balanced.\"\n\n* ''Boom or Bust'' (1941)\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Nancy Cassis''' (born January 26, 1944- July 2024) is an American teacher and psychologist.  As a Michigan Senator who initially ran against , she dropped out of the contest before Michigan's 2006 gubernatorial Republican primary.  In the  she served as the Majority Caucus Chairperson and introduced the Michigan Business Tax, which was eventually repealed by conservative governor .\n\nCassis is a  resident who represented the .\nShe has a B.A. from Ohio University, where she graduated summa cum laude and .  She earned her M.S. and Ed.S. degrees from the  in .  The Senator was a teacher from 1966 to 1968 for the Ohio Public Schools. She also was a psychologist for the  Community Schools from 1980 to 1996.\n\nNancy Cassis waged an unsuccessful write-in campaign to be the Republican nominee for the  in .  Incumbent  was ineligible due to forged signatures. Cassis had pledged to spend at least 200,000 dollars in order to defeat balloted candidate  in the Republican primary. Some Cassis supporters had doubts that Bentivolio would win the general election, while some Bentivolio supporters viewed the Cassis write-in campaign as an effort by establishment Republicans to block the election of a conservative.  Bentivolio was elected to Congress.\n\n\n\n\n\n* 2012 Congressional Campaign\n*\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Andrew B. Dougherty''' (October 17, 1863 – January 8, 1928) was a Canadian-born American politician.\n\n\nDougherty was born on October 17, 1863, in , . His father was . Dougherty's family moved to Michigan when he was five years old.\n\n\nIn 1899, Dougherty was a member of the . In 1904, Dougherty  was a delegate to  from Michigan. In 1912, unsuccessfully ran as a candidate for presidential elector for Michigan. Dougherty was appointed to the position of  in 1923, and he served in that position until 1926.\n\n\nDougherty died on January 8, 1928, in . He was interred at Maple Grove Cemetery in .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Margaret O'Brien''' (born November 20, 1973) is a former member of the  and the . A member of the , she represented a district based in .\n\n\nO'Brien was born in  to Richard and Katheleen (Crawford) Wilson. Her childhood was spent on dairy farms with her three brothers, first in  and then in .\n\nShe attended Fulton and Indian Lake Elementary Schools in  and graduated in 1991 from , where she excelled in  and . The women's track record for the 3200-meter relay, set in 1991, is still held by O'Brien and her teammates. In 1996, she earned a bachelor's degree in international relations from James Madison College at .\n\nFrom 1995 to 2003, O'Brien was a social worker with Catholic Family Services. She then worked as a real estate agent at  Advantage and served on the City Council of  from 2003 to 2010. She lives in Portage with her husband and four children.\n\n\nO'Brien was first elected to the Michigan House in 2010 and became active on private property rights, education reform, adoption, and direct access to physical therapy. She was twice unanimously elected as associate speaker pro tem and often presided over sessions of the House.\n\nIn 2014, she was elected to represent the  in the , defeating  nominee  and  nominee . In the Senate, she was unanimously elected as assistant president pro tem and again frequently presided over sessions. She worked on bills to ensure the rights of people with s, to provide state IDs to the homeless, to protect victims of domestic violence, to enact safe passing distances for vulnerable roadway users, and to train caregivers of seniors and people with disabilities.\n\nO'Brien is known for her work to change Michigan's sexual assault laws in the aftermath of the  scandal, alongside advocates including , , Amanda Thomashow, Sterling Reithman, and Larissa Boyce.\n\nIn 2018, she lost a rematch with McCann. In January 2019, she was elected as secretary of the Michigan Senate, only the second woman to have held that post.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''William Patrick Huizenga''' ( ; born January 31, 1969) is an American politician serving as a  from Michigan since 2011, representing the state's  since 2023. A member of the , Huizenga served in the  from 2003 to 2009. He currently represents much of Southwestern Michigan, including , , and .\n\n\nBorn to a family of , Huizenga is the co-owner and operator of Huizenga Gravel Company, a family business in . In the early 1990s, he worked in real estate. He left real estate in 1996, becoming an aide to U.S. Representative .\n\n\nStarting with his first election in 2002, Huizenga represented the  for three terms, winning reelection in 2004 and 2006. After the 2006 election he was . The district is in  and includes , Zeeland, , , , , and .\n\nHuizenga voted for the initial version of the Michigan Business Tax, but opposed the 2% surcharge and a sales and services tax later in the process.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAfter serving 18 years, Republican incumbent  retired to run for the Republican nomination for governor. Huizenga defeated ,  Wayne Kuipers, businessman Bill Cooper, and three others in the Republican primary electionthe real contest in this heavily Republican districton August 3, 2010. Huizenga defeated Democratic nominee Fred Johnson, 64% to 32%. The district was rated \"Solid Republican\" by ''.'' The district and its predecessors have been in Republican hands for all but four years since 1873, and without interruption since 1935.\n\n\n\nHuizenga was reelected, defeating Democratic nominee Willie German Jr., Mary Buzuma of the Libertarian Party, Ronald Graeser of the U.S. Taxpayers Party and William Opalicky of the Green Party.\n\n\n\nHuizenga was reelected, defeating Democratic nominee Dean Vanderstelt, Ronald Welch of the Libertarian Party and Ronald Graeser of the U.S. Taxpayers Party.\n\n\n\nHuizenga was reelected, defeating Democratic nominee Dennis Murphy, Erwin Haas of the Libertarian Party, and Matthew Brady of the Green Party.\n\n\n\nHuizenga was reelected, defeating Democratic nominee Rob Davison and Ronald Graeser of the U.S. Taxpayers Party.\n\n\n\nHuizenga was reelected, defeating Democratic nominee Bryan Berghoef, Max Riekse of the Libertarian Party, Gerald Van Sickle of the U.S. Taxpayers Party, and Jean-Michel Creviere of the Green Party.\n\n\n\n\nFor his first six terms, Huizenga represented much of 's eastern shore and many of 's suburbs, including , Holland, , and . However, redistricting after the 2020 census saw the district significantly redrawn. It was renumbered as the 4th district and pushed well to the south. It picked up Kalamazoo and Battle Creek while losing Muskegon, all of its share of  and much of its share of . In the process, the district lost its connection to longtime Congressman , who represented the district (then numbered as the 9th) from 1967 to 1993.\n\nThe reconfigured district included much of the territory of the Kalamazoo-based , represented by 18-term incumbent and fellow Republican . Upton opted to retire, effectively handing the Republican nomination to Huizenga. The new 4th was no less Republican than the old 2nd, and Huizenga easily won a seventh term.\n\n\nIn December 2020, Huizenga was one of 126 Republican members of the  to sign an  in support of '''', a lawsuit filed at the  contesting the results of the , in which  defeated incumbent . The Supreme Court declined to hear the case on the basis that Texas lacked  under  to challenge the results of an election held by another state.\n\n  issued a statement that called signing the amicus brief an act of \"election subversion.\" She also reprimanded Huizenga and the other House members who supported the lawsuit: \"The 126 Republican Members that signed onto this lawsuit brought dishonor to the House. Instead of upholding their oath to support and defend the Constitution, they chose to subvert the Constitution and undermine public trust in our sacred democratic institutions.\"\n\nAs of January 2022, Huizenga has voted with  stated position roughly 14% of the time.\n\n\n* \n**\n**  (Chair)\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\nHuizenga voted against the  codifying '''' and '''', recognizing marriages across state lines regardless of \"sex, race, ethnicity, or national origin of those individuals.\"\n\n\nHuizenga and his wife have five children and live in Holland. He attends Haven  in .\n\n\n\n\n\n*  official U.S. House website\n* \n* \n* \n*  at MichiganVotes.org\n** Voting record: , , \n\n;Articles\n* , Jim Harger, ''Grand Rapids Press'', October 12, 2009\n* , Andrew S. Levin, ''Michigan.gov'', June 29, 2010\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Barbara Anne Byrum''' (born November 10, 1977) is a Democratic politician from the State of Michigan. Byrum currently serves as the Ingham County Clerk. Prior to her election to the position of Clerk, Byrum represented the  in the . She succeeded her mother, House  . She owns Byrum Hardware in , and lives in Onondaga with her husband Brad Delaney and their two children.\n\n\nByrum grew up in , a small rural town in southwestern Ingham County. She is the daughter of Jim Byrum, a former Lansing Community College trustee, and Dianne Byrum, a former State Representative. Byrum is a graduate of Leslie High School. She attended Lansing Community College from 1994 to 1997 before attending . Byrum earned a Bachelor of Science degree in  management in 1999. After working in agribusiness for a few years, she returned to MSU College of Law and graduated with her juris doctor in 2004.\n\n\nByrum served as the Representative for the 67th House District in the Michigan House of Representatives from 2007 to 2012. During her first term, Byrum was Chair of the Intergovernmental, Urban and Regional Affairs Committee and a vice-chair of the House Committee on Agriculture. During the 94th Legislature, she was also on the Commerce, Education and Health Policy committees and was caucus vice-chair. She was Chair of the House Committee on Insurance. During her last term in the Michigan House of Representatives Byrum was the ranking Democrat on the House Committee on Redistricting and Elections.\n\n\nByrum is responsible for introducing the bill that later became Public Act 218 of 2008 which allows small distilleries to market and sell their distilled grain-based spirits onsite. Byrum worked closely with Kris Berglund, a Distinguished Professor of forestry and chemical engineering at Michigan State University.\n\n\nOn June 14, 2012, during a contentious debate over a controversial anti-abortion bill, Byrum and her colleague, Representative , found themselves banned from speaking on the House floor for saying \"vasectomy\" and \"vagina,\" respectively.  Byrum tried to introduce an amendment to the proposed bill that would ban men having vasectomies unless the procedure was needed to save their lives – a key clause of the anti-abortion bill. She was ruled out of order after protesting that she had not been allowed to speak on her proposal. Both Byrum and Brown were censured by House leadership and forbidden to speak on the floor.\n\nFollowing the incident on the House floor, playwright  staged a special reading of her play, '','' on the steps of the state Capitol Building.\n\n\nByrum has served as the Clerk of Ingham County since 2013. On November 8, 2016, she was re-elected to the position. On November 3, 2020, she was re-elected to a third term.\n\n\nThe County Clerk is elected for a four-year term and is responsible for keeping records of births, deaths, assumed names, co-partnerships, and issuing and filing marriage licenses.  In addition, the Clerk's office processes gun permits and notary bonds.  The Clerk also serves as the Clerk of the Board of Commissioners, the Board of Canvassers, the Gun Board, and is the Clerk of the Circuit Court.  The Clerk is also a member of the Plat Board and Election Commission. The Clerk also serves as an officiant for wedding ceremonies.\n\nOne of the more prominent responsibilities is the Chief Election Official in the county.  As such, the County Clerk administers all election functions required by law.  Part of those duties include the supervision of all national, state, and local elections and includes the training of all election workers in the county for those communities with a population of under ten thousand.  The Clerk is also responsible for the Administration of the Michigan Campaign Finance Reporting Act for those candidates that file for office at the local level.\n\n\nOn Saturday, March 22, 2014, following a U.S. District Court ruling that Michigan's ban on same sex marriage was unconstitutional, Byrum performed what has been reported as the first same sex marriage in the state of Michigan. At the time of their marriage, the couple, Glenna DeJong, 53, and Marsha Caspar, 51, had been together for 26 years. When asked why she opted to open her office to issue licenses, Byrum said, \"My biggest struggle on that day was -- I can open, yeah, my key will open the door, but how will I actually process those marriage licenses? I couldn't sleep with the thought that I might be standing in the way of loving couples joining together in marriage.\"\n\n\nFollowing the 2016 Presidential Election, Green Party candidate Jill Stein requested a recount of the votes cast in Michigan. On December 5, 2016, the Presidential Recount began in Ingham County. Byrum reportedly hired 75 election workers to recount ballots. On December 7, Byrum announced the recount was finished. Ingham County was the first county to complete their recount.\n\n\n\nReporting from February 2023 named Byrum as one of several potential Democratic candidates who was considering a run for Michigan's 7th Congressional District, which will be open with Rep. Elisa Slotkin announcing her run for U.S. Senate. Byrum confirmed that she was interested and exploring a potential Congressional run in March 2023.\n\nOn June 1, Bryum put out a video/written statement over Twitter saying she wasn't running for Congress and instead opted to run for re-election instead.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

Howell''' (born April 29, 1949) is an American lawyer and politician from .\nHe is a former member of the  who represented a portion of  from 1999 through 2004.\n\nHe attended  and is a 1967 graduate of St. Paul's Seminary in Michigan.\n\nHe graduated from  with an ,  with a , and from  with a .\n\nHowell was an air traffic controller in the  and an officer with the Saginaw County Sheriff's Department and the Saginaw Police Department from 1972 to 1981. He also was an attorney for  from 1981 to 1983, and practiced privately from 1983 until his election to the House in 1998.\n\nHowell is a vocal advocate for Michigan's system of no-fault auto insurance because his son was critically injured in an accident in 2005.\n\nFrom 2005 to 2009 he was an Assistant Attorney General of Michigan.\n\nSince 2010 he has served as President of Sammael, Inc.\n\nHe was a judicial candidate for the 10th Circuit Court in Michigan in 2010.     "pages": }\n'''Richard Henry Austin''' (May 6, 1913 – April 20, 2001) was an American politician. A , he served as the  from 1971 to 1995, the first  elected to the position, the first to win election to any statewide office in  except the , and the longest-serving Secretary of State in the state. Also, the first Black  in Michigan, he previously served from 1967 to 1971 as the first Black  auditor, and ran unsuccessfully for  .\n\n\n\nAustin was born in Stouts Mountain, , . --> His father, a , died when Austin was 11, after which his mother moved with her three sons to ; as a child he worked as a .\n\nAfter graduating first in his class from , he was awarded an athletics scholarship to , but had to leave for financial reasons; working in a shoe store and taking night classes, he earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in  from the  in 1937, --> and in 1941 became the first Black certified public accountant in Michigan.\n\n\n\nIn 1941, Austin founded the accounting firm of Richard H Austin & Co, which later became Austin, Washington & Davenport. After becoming Secretary of State in 1970, he sold the firm, which in 1971 became George Johnson & Company and now operates as GJC CPAs & Advisors.\n\n\n\nAustin served as an elected delegate for the  6th District to the  that produced the 1962 . In 1962 he also served on the  and was elected to the . He was co-chairman of the Michigan Commission on Legislative Apportionment from 1963 to 1965.\n\nIn , he ran for Congress in , but lost to  in the   by 38 votes.\n\nHe was elected the first Black Wayne County auditor in 1966.\n\nIn  he ran for , leading in the nonpartisan primary but lost to fellow Democrat , 49% to 51%.\n\n\n\nIn 1970, Austin was elected as the Michigan Secretary of State, making him the first Black person to hold that position in any U.S. state and also the first elected to any statewide office in Michigan except for the Supreme Court. He became the longest-serving Secretary of State in Michigan history, serving until January 1, 1995, when he lost a  in 1994 to  . \n\nDuring his tenure, Austin emphasized road safety, supporting the enactment of laws mandating use of s and s, and retention of the law requiring s, and also achieving improvements to  and . He also introduced mail-in vehicle registration renewals, license-plate tabs, and in 1975 the first \"\" law, a model for the .\n\nIn  Austin unsuccessfully sought the Democratic nomination for the  seat being vacated by retiring .\n\n\n\nIn 1939 Austin married Ida Dawson; they had a daughter. He died in Detroit on April 20, 2001, at the age of 87, from a  and . His papers are held at .\n\n\n\nIn recognition of his service to traffic safety, Austin was placed on the Michigan Transportation Hall of Honor in 1996, and the annual award of the Michigan Governor's Traffic Safety Advisory Commission was renamed for him. The Treasury Building in  was renamed to the Richard H. Austin building by an act of the state legislature in 2005.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
