    "pages": }\n\n'''Judith Kaczmarczyk Nerat''' (August 12, 1948 – December 23, 2012) was a  politician and member of the . Nerat was elected to represent the  on November 4, 2008. The 108th district is located in the  and includes all of , , and  counties. Nerat previously ran for the same seat in 2006, losing to then incumbent Representative .\n\n\nNerat was born to Leo and Irene Kaczmarczyk in , located in Menominee County, on August 12, 1948. Leo Kaczmarczyk was a marine shipyard worker in , and a member of the International Brotherhood of Boilermakers Union.\n\nNerat graduated from Stephenson High School as well as the College of Beauty Culture in . She owned and operated a hair salon in , for over 34 years. In 2004, Nerat was certified as a nursing assistant and worked at a local assisted living facility.\n\n\nNerat was married and has two children and five grandchildren. She lived in , and belonged to Holy Redeemer Catholic Church.\n\nIn August 2009, Nerat was diagnosed with , a type of cancer which affects . She took time away from the legislature to battle the disease, missing over 100 votes. She returned full-time in November 2009.\n\n\nNerat was elected to the Menominee County Road Commission in 1998. In 2000, she was appointed to the Commissioners’ Committee for the County Road Association of Michigan. In 2002, she was appointed chair of the Commissioners’ Committee. Judy was elected to the County Road Association Self Insurance Fund in 2003, as one of nine directors. She was re-elected to the Road Commission in 2004.\n\nIn 2006 she announced her intention to run as a  against incumbent  State Representative  in the 108th district in Michigan's Upper Peninsula. Nerat easily won the Democratic Primary, but went on to lose to Casperson in the general election.\n\nHowever, in 2008, Casperson was unable to run for re-election due to term limits, choosing instead to run against Congressman . Nerat again declared her intention to run, this time for an open seat. She narrowly defeated Janis Burgess in the Democratic Primary, winning by only 76 votes. In the November General Election, Nerat faced Republican Mike Falcon of . Nerat won the seat with 56% of the vote. She campaigned the last three weeks leading up to the election with a fractured hip before undergoing  surgery in late October.\n\nNerat is quoted in the '''' on February 3, 2009, in regards to Michigan Governor 's announcement that the state will cease subsidizing the Upper Peninsula State Fair as saying, \"I don't know where this rumor started. However, up to this point, the state has not provided any state funding to support the fair.\"\n\n\n*'''2010 election for State House'''\n**Judy Nerat (D), 11,870\n**Ed McBroom (R), 17,734\n*'''2008 election for State House'''\n**Judy Nerat (D), 56%\n**Mike Falcon (R), 44%\n*'''2008 Democratic primary election for State House'''\n**Judy Nerat (D), 37%\n**Janis Burgess (D), 36%\n**Dennis Baldinelli (D), 17%\n**David Polzin (D), 10%\n*'''2006 election for State House'''\n** (R), 55%\n**Judy Nerat (D), 45%\n*'''2006 Democratic primary election for State House'''\n**Judy Nerat (D), 69%\n**David Polzin (D), 31%\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Pamela Louise Pugh''' (born December 20, 1970) is an American  scientist, politician, and the current president of the . She first won election to the board in 2014 and was reelected in 2022. She was a  candidate for  in the  in .\n\n\nPamela Pugh was born on December 20, 1970, in . Her father, John Pugh, is a civil rights activist, professor, and administrator at  and her mother was a paraprofessional. She attended Florida A&M earning a Bachelor of Science and the University of Michigan graduating with a Master of Science and Doctorate of Public Health. Pugh serves on multiple boards including the Healthy Schools Network Board of Directors and the  Board of Directors. She also served as the Chief Public Health Advisor to the city of  during its .\n\nPugh is the first Black woman to serve as the President of the Michigan State Board of Education. She was voted president in a 6–0 vote with two Republican members voting present.\n\n\nOn May 23, 2023, Pugh announced her candidacy as a  for the U.S. Senate in . Pugh withdrew from the race on November 27 to instead run for the  in the , 11 days after incumbent  announced that he was not seeking re-election.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Hansen Hashim Clarke''' (born '''Molik Hashim''', March 2, 1957) is an American politician and former U.S. Congressman. A , he was the  for  from 2011 to 2013. Prior to his election to Congress, he had been a member of the  from 1991 through 1992 and from 1999 through 2002, and represented the  in the  from 2003 to 2011. Clarke was also the first U.S. Congressman of  descent.\n\nClarke entered Congress after defeating incumbent  in the 2010 Democratic primary for the 13th congressional district. In 2012, due to redistricting, fellow incumbent  chose to run against Clarke in the  primary. Clarke finished second in the primary behind Peters, and left Congress in January 2013.\n\nIn April 2014, Clarke attempted a comeback and announced he would again run in the 14th District primary. The seat was to be vacated by Peters, who ran successfully for the U.S. Senate. Clarke was unsuccessful in his bid to regain the seat.\n\n\nMolik Hashim was born in , . His father was an immigrant from  in ,  (now ), and his mother was .  He grew up in the city's . Clarke's father died when he was eight years old and his mother worked as a  to support her family. Clarke is an alumnus of , and later graduated from , a Massachusetts boarding school.\n\nClarke attended , graduating with a degree in fine arts. He is a member of  fraternity. While at Cornell, Clarke became interested in public service and electoral politics. He was elected to the student seat on the Cornell University Board of Trustees, defeating fellow student and future political commentator  in the process.  He earned a J.D. degree from  in 1987.\n\nClarke worked on the 's staff of , during the administration of , and then as chief of staff to U.S. Representative .\n\n\n\n\nClarke was elected to the Michigan House of Representatives in 1990, 1998, and 2000.  After his six years in the Michigan House, Hansen Clarke was elected to the Michigan Senate in 2002.  Senator Clarke was re-elected to his seat in the Senate in 2006. In 2010, Hansen Clarke was elected to represent the 13th District of Michigan in the United States House of Representatives.\n\n\nClarke served on the State Senate Appropriations committee, and later served on the Health Policy committee and Commerce and Tourism committee.\n\n\nClarke ran unsuccessfully in the .\n\n\n\n;2010\n\n\nClarke defeated seven-term incumbent U.S. Rep.  in the Democratic primary for Michigan's 13th Districtthe real contest in this heavily Democratic, black-majority districtin Aug. 3, 2010.\n\nIn the general election, Clarke easily defeated Republican John Hauler, and became the third American of South Asian descent elected to Congress.\n\n;2012\n\nAfter Michigan lost a congressional district in redistricting, most of Clarke's district became the 14th District. It was significantly redrawn to take in large slices of nearby .  Clarke's home was drawn into the 13th District, represented by fellow Democrat , but Clarke opted to follow most of his constituents into the 14th.  Clarke faced fellow Congressman  and  mayor  in the primary.  Peters' 9th district had been eliminated in redistricting, and he chose to run in the 14th; he had represented much of the Oakland County portion of the district in both the state senate and in Congress.  Peters emerged as the winner, and defeated Republican John Hauler in November.\n\n\n;2014\n\nIn May 2013, Peters announced that he would not be running for re-election in 2014. He instead  the U.S. Senate seat being vacated by retiring Democrat . Clarke attempted to win his seat back, but was defeated in the primary by .\n\n\nClarke championed initiatives to increase investment in the City of Detroit, which resulted in millions of dollars of federal assistance being awarded to the city and the region.  He won approval in Congress to increase funding to improve nutrition for low-income families, provide housing for homeless veterans, and better equip and staff local police, fire, and emergency medical providers to bolster homeland security.\n\n;Student Loan Forgiveness Act of 2012 (H.R. 4170)\nClarke led the effort in Congress to cut student loan debt for millions of Americans by authoring the Student Loan Forgiveness Act of 2012.  This bill inspired a national movement, including a petition in support of his legislation that received more than one million signatures that urged Congress to pass H.R. 4170.\n\n;Home foreclosures\nClarke also fought foreclosures to save family homes and neighborhoods.  He established himself as one of the nation's strongest advocates for struggling homeowners and distressed communities with the Save Our Neighborhoods Act, a bill that would allow many homeowners to stay in their homes by suspending the foreclosure process and reducing their mortgage principal.\n\n;Literacy\nClarke worked to reduce crime and restore hope by addressing the urgent crisis of illiteracy among African-American and Hispanic men.  He co-authored a bipartisan resolution initiating national action for literacy. Rep. Clarke also introduced the first federal legislation to \",\" which would prohibit unfair discrimination against job applicants with certain criminal backgrounds.\n\nClarke was a member of the , , and the Congressional Progressive Caucus.\n\n\n* ''''''\n** \n** \n* ''''''\n** \n** \n\n\n http://miboecfr.nicusa.com (website).}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n http://miboecfr.nicusa.com (website).}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n http://miboecfr.nicusa.com (website).}}\n\n\n\n\n\n http://miboecfr.nicusa.com (website).}}\n\n\n\n\n http://miboecfr.nicusa.com (website).}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n http://miboecfr.nicusa.com (website).}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n http://miboecfr.nicusa.com (website).}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nClarke is married to Choi Palms-Cohen. They married in 2007, after meeting at the offices of the  (ICLE) in  where she worked. They live on Detroit's east side where Clarke was born and raised. Clarke was raised as a  but later converted to .\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*  ''official U.S. House website''\n*  ''official campaign website''\n\n*  at MichiganVotes.org\n** Voting record: , , , \n*  campaign finance reports and data\n*  campaign finance reports and data\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Candice Sue Miller''' ( '''McDonald'''; born May 7, 1954) is an American politician serving as the Public Works Commissioner of  since 2017. A member of the , Miller previously served as the  for  from 2003 to 2017, the  from 1995 to 2003, and the Macomb County Treasurer from 1993 to 1995. She also served as the  Supervisor. She was inducted into the  in 2015.\n\n\n\n* '''''' (chairman)\nIn the 113th Congress, Representative Miller was appointed to serve as chairman of the  (CHA), and in the 114th Congress she continued to serve as the committee's chair. CHA was established in 1947 and is charged with the oversight of federal elections and the day-to-day operations of the House of Representatives.The committee ensures that the House of Representatives runs in an effective and efficient manner. It also has jurisdiction over the federal election process.\n\nUnder her leadership as chair, the U.S. House received consecutive \"clean\" audits. She also played a major role in advancing legislation to end the practice of using millions of dollars in taxpayer funding to host political party conventions and, instead, redirected that funding for pediatric research. Working with House officers, she helped to increase the availability of low-cost digital tools used by the House to improve the House's daily functions and reduce operating costs. She also oversaw the , which focused on using local governance over elections and made recommendations to help locals election administrators improve upon their own voting processes.\n* ''''''\n** \nRepresentative Miller has served on the  since March 2008. She is currently serving as vice chair of the full House Committee on Homeland Security and served as chairman of the  from 2011 until February 2016. She is also a member of the . The committee is charged with oversight of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS).\n\nAs chairman of the Subcommittee on Border and Maritime Security, Representative Miller initiated legislative efforts to ensure the nation's borders are adequately secured against international terrorist organizations, illegal immigration, drug and human smuggling, and exploitation of the legitimate visa process.\n\nDuring the 113th Congress, Representative Miller sponsored legislation to formally authorize Customs and Border Protection (CBP) and clarify the security mission of the agency for the first time since the Department of Homeland Security was created in 2002. The legislation passed the House on July 28, 2014. She also advocated for ways to strengthen the Department of Homeland Security's ability to identify and stop terrorists with western passports, authoring legislation in that would allow DHS to suspend a country's participation in the U.S. Visa Waiver Program if it fails to provide the U.S. with pertinent traveler information related to terror threats. Representative Miller also crafted legislation to increase oversight of the maritime security mission of DHS, as well as to strengthen domestic maritime security connected to U.S. trade with its trusted partners.\n\nMichigan's 10th Congressional District is a border district. It is home to the Blue Water Bridge, the second-busiest border crossing on the northern tier; Selfridge Air National Guard Base, which has expanding missions in the area of ; Coast Guard stations at Selfridge, Port Huron, and Harbor Beach; it borders Chemical Valley, which is one of the largest collections of petro-chemical operations in North America; the CN Rail Tunnel, the busiest rail artery in the U.S. Two important trade arteries, interstates I-94 and I-69, also originate in Michigan.\n\nMiller focused her efforts on building a stronger presence of  assets at Selfridge, enhancing the security of airways, roadways, railways, and waterways, and securing domestic food and water supplies by enhancing Northern Border security.\n\nThe Committee on Homeland Security was established in 2002 to provide congressional oversight for the U.S. Department of Homeland Security and better protect the nation against a possible terrorist attack. Many of the programs at Selfridge and the armed service reserves throughout the 10th Congressional District fall under the purview of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security. The Committee on Homeland Security provides oversight for the department and handles issues dealing with transportation security, border and port security, , cyber security, and science and technology, emergency preparedness, emerging threats, intelligence and information sharing, investigations, and management and procurement.\n* ''''''\n** \n** \n** \n\nIn 2007, Representative Miller was appointed to the . She is also a member of the , the , as well as the . Representative Miller is the only member from Michigan serving on this committee.\n\nIn 2014, Representative Miller was appointed to the House Committee on Transportation and  As the only Michigan Member, she focused her involvement on innovative ways that P3s can benefit infrastructure projects in Michigan like the expanded Customs and Border Plaza at the Blue Water Bridge in Port Huron.\n\nThe committee's broad oversight portfolio includes many federal agencies, including the Department of Transportation, the U.S. Coast Guard, Amtrak, the Environmental Protection Agency, the Federal Emergency Management Agency, the General Services Administration, the Army Corps of Engineers, and others.\n\nThroughout her career in public service, protecting the Great Lakes has been one of Representative Miller's priorities. During the 113th Congress, as the only member of the committee from the state of Michigan, Miller advocated for the Great Lakes during House and conference negotiations of the Water Resources Reform and Development Act (WRRDA) which included her provision designating all ports and harbors on the Great Lakes as a single, comprehensive navigation system (the Great Lakes Navigation System) for budgeting purposes. This created a unified front for Great Lakes ports and harbors for purposes of federal funding.\n\nFor the 110th Congress Miller was appointed to continue her service on the  and was added to the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, which has jurisdiction over not only surface transportation but also water quality issues related to the Great Lakes. During the , Miller was a member of the Armed Services committee, and part of a \"war room\" team that relayed information from the Bush administration to Republican members, the news media, and the public.\n\n\nDuring the 108th Congress, Miller was admonished by the House Ethics Committee for improperly attempting to influence the vote of fellow Michigan Congressman Nick Smith on a Medicare vote.\n\n\n\nThe report ... admonished Rep. Candice S. Miller (R-Mich.) for making comments about Brad Smith during the Nov 22 roll call that appeared to be \"a threat of retaliation\" for Nick Smith's vote against the bill.\n\nRepresentative Miller told the Investigative Subcommittee that the first time she spoke to Representative Smith about his vote on the Medicare legislation was on the House floor while the vote was open, after Representative Smith had cast his vote. She estimated that she spoke with him during the first hour of the time that the vote was held open. Representative Miller saw Representative Smith's no vote on the board and she \"didn't like the way that he voted.\" Representative Miller testified that, on her own initiative, she approached Representative Smith and said words to the effect of: \"Is this how you're going to vote; or, This is how you're going to vote? And he said, Obviously.\"\n\nRepresentative Miller recalled that she responded by saying words to the effect of: \"Well, I hope your son doesn't come to Congress, or I'm not going to support your son, or something to that effect.\" Representative Smith then \"rose up out of his seat and said, You get out of here.\" That was the end of the interaction between the two Members. Representative Miller estimated that the exchange lasted for about ten seconds. She told the Investigative Subcommittee that she did not at any point ask Representative Smith to change his vote on the Medicare legislation.\n\nRepresentative Smith told the Investigative Subcommittee that Representative Miller specifically threatened to work against his son if he did not change his vote. Representative Smith's recollection was that Representative Miller \"came up and said something like, I haven't been involved in this campaign before, but if you don't change your vote, I'll get involved, and I'll make sure Brad isn't elected.\"}}\n\n\nMiller is a signatory of 's , which commits her to oppose tax increases.\n\nMiller sat on the  and has praised President Obama for his stance on off-shore oil exploration. She supports selling oil and gas leases to help fund the research and development of alternative energy projects.\n\nIn December 2010, Miller complained about the , and called  a terrorist organisation.\n\nOn April 26, 2012, Miller voted for the controversial . It passed the House of Representatives, but did not become law.\n\n\nIn June 2013, Miller introduced legislation, the  (), to redefine how the  are treated in competing for United States government harbor maintenance funding, and to create an opportunity for recreational harbors to vie for federal funding.\n\nMiller, along with Congresswoman , introduced , the . The bill would implement a  exit system that would monitor the exit of foreign visitors. The bill would require the  to implement a biometric exit system for ten airports and ten seaports, test the system for two years, and then implement the system nationwide.\n\nMiller also introduced, on November 14, 2013, , . The bill would allow the FEC to continue to use a fee schedule to impose small fines on things such as late filings.\n\nOn January 10, 2014, Miller introduced the , a bill that would authorize the  (CBP) and its mission and direct the CBP in the  to establish standard procedures for addressing complaints made against CBP employees and to enhance training for CBP officers and agents. Miller said that \"Today, the House passed legislation that provides the necessary statutory authorization that will protect the agency's mission by providing our officers and agents proper authorities to carry out their important work.\"\n\nMiller also introduced a bill, the Visa Waiver Program Improvement Act of 2015 which has been criticized for casting US citizens of Arab, Iranian, and Muslim descent as second-class citizens in their own country – a \"legislation that will effectively create two classes of Americans – Americans with Middle Eastern or Muslim background, and Americans without that background\".\n\nMiller was ranked as the 71st most bipartisan member of the U.S. House of Representatives during the  (and the most bipartisan member of the U.S. House of Representatives from Michigan) in the Bipartisan Index created by  and the  that ranks members of the United States Congress by their degree of bipartisanship (by measuring the frequency each member's bills attract co-sponsors from the opposite party and each member's co-sponsorship of bills by members of the opposite party).\n\n\nThe bill  passed in the House on March 4, 2014. The bill delayed indefinitely some of the reforms to the deeply indebted . The primary issue what the premiums should be on home and business owners located in flood zones. Miller opposed the bill and argued that the state of Michigan should opt out of the National Flood Insurance Program entirely and urged the governor to do so. According to Miller, Michigan residents subsidize other, more flood prone parts of the country, by paying higher premiums than they should. Miller suggested insurance premiums of being decided by politics rather than actuarial costs. She said that \"too many Americans across this nation are paying rates far below what actual risk would dictate in the marketplace while others, including many who I represent, are being forced to pay into a program that they do not need or want to help subsidize lower rates for other favored groups whose risk is far greater.\"\n\n\n\nMiller was elected  Supervisor in 1980, becoming the first woman and the youngest person ever to be elected to the position. In her first bid for federal office, Miller lost to 5-term incumbent Democrat  for .\n\n\nShe was the first woman ever elected to the positions of Macomb County Treasurer and Secretary of State. Her 1992 upset of Democratic incumbent County Treasurer Adam Nowakowski was the first win for a Republican county-wide in Macomb County in more than 60 years.\n\n\nMiller was elected Michigan Secretary of State, unseating 6-term incumbent . She was the first Republican to serve as secretary of state in Michigan in 40 years since  left office in 1955.\n\n\nMiller carried every county in Michigan (including , home to Detroit) and beat both Democrat Mary Parks and the  Perry Spencer by 1 million votes, the largest margin of victory for a candidate running statewide in Michigan.\n\n\nFollowing her re-election it was reported in June 1999 that Miller, who was term-limited as Secretary of State, was considering running for Congress again, seeking a probable re-match against Bonior. She was also rumored to be considering running for the Republican nomination for , to succeed three-term Republican Gov. , who was term-limited. She ultimately passed on both races.\n\n\nAfter the , the  reconfigured the state's congressional map. In the process, they redrew the 10th District, represented by 13-term  David Bonior. The old 10th had been a fairly compact district taking in most of Macomb and St. Clair counties. However, the reconfigured 10th was pushed all the way to the . In the process, the legislature moved Miller's home in Harrison Township into the district, while shifting Bonior's home in  to the neighboring 12th District. Bonior subsequently opted to run for the  rather than run for re-election to the USA House of Representatives. Miller won the Republican primary unopposed, and later in the general election in November she handily beat Democrat Carl Marlinga, the Macomb County Prosecutor since 1982. Marlinga called himself a \" Democrat\", and Miller called herself a \" Republican.\" She outraised Marlinga, and secured the  (but not ) endorsement.\n\n\nMiller faced no opposition in the Republican primary, and was  as the Republican candidate on August 8, 2006. In the general election Miller was challenged by Democrat  and three third-party candidates. Miller defeated Denison 178,843 to 84,574 votes.\n\n\n\nMiller was reelected against Democratic candidate Robert Denison,  candidate , and  candidate Candace Caveny.\n\nDuring the , Miller endorsed Former   for president. At the Michigan Republican convention, she explained, \"When deciding what candidate I wanted to be our next President of the United States I knew we needed someone who would continue the fight against terrorism, who has proven leadership and who has the record and experience of managing government and improving the economy. Again and again on the most important issues facing America I came to the same conclusion, that former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani is the man we need to lead our nation.\"\n\nMiller spoke on behalf of Senator  and was a vocal supporter of Governor . She was a member of Gov. Palin's \"truth squad\" leading up to the 2008 presidential election.\n\n\n\nMiller was challenged by Democratic nominee , a Sterling Heights firefighter and paramedic. He is currently the chairman of the 10th District Democrats and was a delegate to the  and s. Miller won reelection November 3, 2010 with nearly 72% of the vote, beating Yanez, two minor party candidates, and a write-in.\n\n\n\nMiller's choice for chairman of Michigan's 10th congressional district Republican committee lost to her former assistant secretary of state, Stanley Grot, a local . Grot is chairman of the district committee, clerk of , and formerly a constituent relations representative in the 's office. He has been president of the American Polish Cultural Center.\n\n\n\nMiller was challenged by Democratic nominee Chuck Stadler and Green nominee Harley Mikkelson, but she won reelection with 68.7% of the vote.\n\n\n\nIn March 2015, Miller announced she would not seek re-election to Congress, and resigned at the end of the . Even though she was leaving Congress, Miller insisted that her career in public service was not over.\n\nIn March 2016, Miller announced she would seek the Republican nomination for the position of Macomb County Public Works Commissioner, challenging six-term incumbent Democrat Anthony Marrocco.\n\nMiller defeated Marrocco in the general election, taking 55 percent of the vote. Marrocco is the third 24-year incumbent that Miller has defeated in her political career, after Nowakowski and Austin. She resigned her seat in the House on December 31, 2016, in order to take office as Public Works Commissioner the next day.\n\nOn January 1, 2017, her first day as Public Works Commissioner, Miller held a press conference at the site of a  in . Miller, alongside County Executive , announced she had spoken with Gov. Rick Snyder about obtaining emergency funds from the state and said that she believed Snyder would tour the site.\n\nMiller's first act upon taking office was placing Dino Bucci, who was a top deputy to Marrocco, on administrative leave, as he became the subject of a federal investigation along with Marrocco.\n\nIn May 2017, Miller confirmed that 10 employees from the public works department had been subpoenaed by the FBI to testify before a grand jury in a wide-ranging investigation into public corruption in Macomb County. Miller said the corruption that occurred under Marrocco was pervasive and widespread and that people used the office's resources for personal use. In November 2017, Bucci was indicted on 18 felony counts including bribery, extortion, mail fraud, money laundering and embezzlement for his role in a decade-long conspiracy alleging a \"pay-to-play\" scheme under Marrocco. Bucci faced up to 20 years in prison if convicted On May 27, 2020, Marrocco was indicted on two counts of extortion and one count of attempted extortion for allegedly using Bucci and other county employees to force contractors and business people who wished to do business with the Public Works Department to buy tickets to his fundraisers. Bucci pleaded guilty the next day in the , admitting his role in Marrocco's corrupt acts.\n\nMiller announced plans to run for re-election in June 2018 and won the GOP nomination uncontested in August 2020 and faced Democratic nominee, Toni Moceri, a former Macomb County Commissioner in the general election. Miller won re-election in a landslide, taking more than 61 percent of the vote.\n\nShe received 1 vote in the second ballot of the  from . Miller, along with Texas Republican Representative , is the first woman to receive a vote from a Republican during a \n\n\nMiller has long been courted by the Michigan Republican Party to run for governor, with speculation on her gubernatorial aspirations dating back to 1999. Miller was considered one of the leading contenders for the Republican nomination in  to succeed term-limited Republican incumbent  She ultimately passed on the race and announced on September 23, 2017, that she was endorsing  , saying \"...I think he's actually going to be the next governor.\"\n\nFollowing her re-election as Public Works Commissioner, Miller was again at the top of the Michigan GOP to run for governor in  to challenge Democratic incumbent Gov. . In December 2020, former Republican   said Miller was the \"dream candidate\" for many in the Republican Party. In January 2021, Miller announced that she would not run for governor.\n\n\nShe is a graduate of  of , Michigan.\n\nMiller's husband Donald Miller served as Circuit Court judge in the 16th Circuit Court for Macomb County. He was a , flew combat missions in , commanded the  and retired from the  as a . He died in January 2019 at the age of 80. Their daughter is a member of the .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Gabriel Leland''' (born September 28, 1982) is a former  politician from the state of .  In 2004, Leland was elected to the , representing the , which is located in  and includes the farwest and partial northwest corner of the city of . Leland has served on the  from 2013 to 2021, when he resigned and pleaded guilty to misconduct in office.\n\n\nLeland attended Kehillat Israel Congregation in Lansing, MI while growing up.\n\n\nOn November 5, 2013, Leland won the newly created Detroit City Council seat in District 7. It was the narrowest victory in any of the council races, winning by only 50 votes. In 2017, Leland was re-elected with 56% of the vote. He resigned in 2021.\n\n\nOn October 4, 2018, Leland was indicted on charges of two counts of bribery and one count of conspiracy to commit bribery. He was accused of soliciting $15,000 worth of bribes from a local business owner, Robert Carmack. In March 2018, Robert Carmack filed a lawsuit against Leland in federal court for extortion.\n\nIn May 2021, Leland pled guilty to felony misconduct and resigned from the city council.\n\n\n* '''2017 campaign for Detroit City Council District 7'''\n** Gabe Leland, 56%\n** Regina Ross, 44%\n* '''2013 campaign for Detroit City Council District 7'''\n** Gabe Leland, 49.11%\n** John K. Bennett, 48.81%\n*'''2008 campaign for State House'''\n**Gabe Leland (D), 95%\n**Marc Sosnowski (UST), 5%\n*'''2008 campaign for State House, Democratic Primary'''\n**Gabe Leland (D), 68%\n**LaTanya Garrett (D), 27%\n**Brian Sylvester (D), 6%\n*'''2006 campaign for State House'''\n**Gabe Leland (D), 94%\n**Thomas Shaut (R), 6%\n*'''2006 campaign for State House, Democratic Primary'''\n**Gabe Leland (D), 53%\n**Stephanie Young (D), 28%\n**Barbra Long (D), 8%\n**Ron Johnson (D), 4%\n**Thomas Jackson (D), 3%\n*'''2004 campaign for State House'''\n**Gabe Leland (D), 91%\n**Reuben Myers (R), 9%\n*'''2004 campaign for State House, Democratic Primary'''\n**Gabe Leland (D), 21%\n**Jim Edmondson, Jr. (D), 18%\n**Barbra Long (D), 17%\n**Shanelle Jackson (D), 17%\n**Carolyn Chambers (D), 10%\n**Ron Johnson (D), 6%\n**Michael Grundy (D), 5%\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    ],
    "pages": }\n'''William Lucas''' (January 15, 1928 – May 30, 2022) was an American politician.\n\nWhen he was orphaned in his early teens (his West Indian immigrant parents died within a year of each other), he went to live with and was raised by an aunt. He attended  in , and starred on the school track team. Because of his track skill he was offered a number of collegiate , and accepted one from . He was the first in his family to go to college, and graduated with honors in 1952 with a .\n\nAfter graduation, Lucas spent several years as a teacher and welfare case worker in . In 1953 he joined , where he remained for nine years, often working undercover in Harlem. From his experiences with the city legal system he decided to become a lawyer, and attended  at night. He received his  degree in 1962, and at the graduation ceremony, he was an escort for the speaker, Robert Kennedy, who offered him a job in the Justice Department. Lucas accepted and spent two years as an investigator in the civil rights division. He then joined the  as a special agent, stationed first in , and later in . He left the Bureau in 1967 to become Wayne County undersheriff, and two years later was appointed Wayne County sheriff when Roman Gribbs vacated the position after winning election as mayor of Detroit. Lucas was elected Wayne County sheriff in his own right in 1970 and reelected twice thereafter, serving in that capacity for thirteen years. In 1982, he ran successfully for the newly created office of Wayne County Executive. He served for four years as the chief executive officer of the third largest county in the United States.\n\nExplaining that he was dismayed by the influence of special interests in the Democratic party, Lucas switched political affiliation to the Republican party in May 1985. He won the Republican gubernatorial primary in , only the second Black person in American history to win a major party nomination for governor. He ran on a platform that stressed the historic nature of his candidacy, , and law and order, but lost by a large margin in the general election to the incumbent Democrat, . Lucas only carried one county in the state.\n\nLucas made an unsuccessful run for Wayne County Sheriff in 2004.\n\nLucas died in Detroit on May 30, 2022, at the age of 94.\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n* \n*\n*\n* Emergence of William Lucas, Republican\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n\n'''Doug Spade''' (born February 11, 1951) is a  politician and radio personality.\n\n\nSpade was born on February 11, 1951.\n\n\nSpade attended the  for four years. Spade graduated from Camden-Frontier High School before moving to his current residence, , where he graduated from .\n\n\nSpade hosted the  talk show ''Party Line'' for 25 years. On November 3, 1998, Spade became the second blind person to be elected to the , where he represented the . He served in this position from January 13, 1999, to 2004. Spade was succeeded by his brother, . In , Spade was the  nominee for the 's , but was defeated by his  opponent. Spade was nominated by the Democratic Party in  for the Michigan Senate's , but was again defeated.\n\n\nSpade is married to JoAnn. Spade has had multiple . During his time in the legislature, Spade's Leader Dog was named Toby. Toby was the first seeing eye dog used by a member of the . Spade's most recent Leader Dog is Lucky.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''William Van Regenmorter''' (January 29, 1939 &ndash; June 18, 2012) was a  politician from the  of , representing . He served as the representative of  from 1982 to 1990 and the  from 2002 to 2006. Between those terms, from 1990 to 2002, he served as senator of the 22nd district. He authored Michigan's Crime Victims Rights Act, which has served as the national model for . He also authored and passed two successful amendments to the Michigan Constitution (art. I, sec. 20 and art. I, sec. 24).\n\n\nVan Regenmorter attended . He was a businessman, prior to running for political office, he owned a furniture retail store and served as an analyst at . He also served as the  Commissioner.\n\n\nVan Regenmorter's political career started with his election into the Michigan State House of Representatives in 1982. He served as the representative of Ottawa County through 1990. Van Regenmorter served several terms in the  (1990-2002) before being elected to the  in 2002. VanRegenmorter announced that he would not seek election in 2006 for health reasons. He is most widely known for authoring Michigan's Crime Victims Rights Amendment and had been seen as a national leader on this issue.\n\nHe served and headed various committees during his time in office, including the chair of the Judiciary Committee for 16 years.Grand Rapids Press, The. \"William J. Van Regenmorter: Obituary.\" \nhttp://obits.mlive.com/obituaries/grandrapids/obituary.aspx?pid=158136483.\n Other committee positions include Corrections (M.V.C.), Economic Development & Energy, and House Oversight.Michigan Independent News and Information Service. Capitol Profiles 1987-1988: A \nDirectory of Michigan's Elected Officials in Lansing and Washington. Lansing: \nCapitol Publications, 1987. 76. Print.\n\n\nHis work included initiating several reforms in the criminal justice system, revisions of the juvenile code, changes in sentencing procedures for dangerous felons and enactment of community placement provisions. He stressed the need for improving the cost-efficiency of the state's own budget operations. Another major accomplishment was his work with State Representative Michael Nye in sponsoring and passing legislation to create the family division of Michigan's circuit court in the mid-1990's. The family division is a specialized court with jurisdiction over a wide range of family-related litigation including domestic relations, child abuse/neglect, and delinquency. The goal was to create a system of \"one family, one judge\" where a single judge would preside over all issues of a single family in the court system. \n\n\nHe died at age 73, after a battle with Parkinson's Disease. Flags across the state were lowered to half-mast in his honor.\n\n\nThe problem with attempting to collect scholarly research on former Michigan legislator, William Van Regenmorter, is that there is none. The only information to be found about the man is located in various Michigan government documents, obituaries, website biographies, and his collection of papers in Calvin College's Heritage Hall. \n\t\nThere is little information written about the life of Van Regenmorter prior to his political career. The biographical sketches published by the state of Michigan contain what little is written about his life before his election to the State House of Representatives in 1982. These include The Michigan Manual of 1983–84, 1987–88, and 2001–2002. All of which state his date of birth, January 29, 1939, in Jamestown Michigan. His obituary in the Grand Rapids Press also contains this information along with the names of his parents, William Sr. and Zora (Van Oss) Van Regenmorter. Following his birth no other information is provided until mention of his schooling, which took place at Calvin College. There is another lapse in biographical information between his time at Calvin College and his professional career. Capitol Profiles states that William was a financial analyst for Dun & Bradstreet and at one point he was the owner of a retail furniture store. It is documented in the 1983-84 edition of the Michigan Manual that Van Regenmorter was a member of the Christian Reformed Church. \n\t\nThe political career of Van Regenmorter is the most detailed portion of his life. In comparing the three manuals one can see some subtle changes throughout the years. The 1983-84 edition coincided with Van Regenmorter's second year in office and states that before the 1982 election he served as Ottawa County Commissioner. In his first term as Representative of Michigan's 55th district he served on the National Association of Criminal Justice Planners. His biographical sketch in the 1987-88 edition showed that Van Regenmorter was the director of the Michigan Victim Alliance as well as the Chairman of Michigan's Republican Caucus. The 2001-2002 edition of the Michigan Manual contains the info of his final term as a Michigan senator. At this time he served on both the Gaming and Casino Oversight committee and the Joint Committee on Administrative Rules. This edition also recognized that he was the author of the Crime Victim's Rights Act and two successful amendments to the Michigan Constitution.\n\t\nThe majority of the writing found on William Van Regenmorter is concerned with his work with crime victims' rights, specifically his authorship of the William Van Regenmorter Crime Victims Rights Act and the subsequent amendment to Michigan's constitution. In a tribute following Van Regenmorter's death the Office for Victims of Crime (OVC) stated that his influence over the development of victims' rights policy has spread across the country, and that the Michigan Victims Bill of Rights has served as the model in drafting Arizona's law, that in turn, served as the model for many other states' amendments.Office for Victims of Crime. \"Tribute to William Van Regenmorter.\" \nhttp://www.ovc.gov/news/William_VanRegenmorter.html.\n A copy of the act and amendment can be found on Michigan Legislature's digital government publications website.\n\t\nThe policy reforms and amendments were so influential that in 1989 Pepperdine Law Review conducted a study of the history of Michigan's reforms on crime victims' rights, focusing on the Crime Victims Rights Act and Van Regenmorter's authorship. Van Regenmorter, in an article published by the Grand Rapids Business Journal, described how the federal Crime Victims Rights Act was approved using language from Michigan's constitutional amendment.\n\t\nBy far the most informative piece concerning William Van Regenmorter, other than his own personal collection, is the University of Akron's Oral History interview. In the 2003 interview Van Regenmorter stated his reasons of interest in crime victims' rights. The interview discusses the context in which Van Regenmorter started his policy making concerning victims' rights, the challenges involved, successes, failures, and future plans concerning the same subject.\n\t\nThroughout his years as both a representative and senator in the Michigan state legislature Van Regenmorter has won a considerable number of awards. In an online publication of the Michigan Manual of 2003-04 it is stated that William was the recipient of Michigan \"Legislator of the Year\" eleven times and the \"National Legislator of the Year\" by the National Victim Center. Van Regenmorter's obituary stated that his death was on June 18, 2012, after having struggled with Parkinson's Disease for nine years. The Office of Victims of Crime's tribute to Van Regenmorter described how on June 20, 2012, Governor  ordered that flags were to be lowered at half-staff in honor of Senator Van Regenmorter.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }
  }

    "pages": }\n'''Cindy Gamrat''' (; born June 15, 1973) is a former  member of the , representing the . She was first elected in 2014, after playing a leading role in organizing the  in Michigan. She engaged in an  with fellow Representative , and was expelled from the House in September 2015 for using taxpayer resources in an attempt to cover up the affair.\n\n\n\n\nGamrat became a Tea Party organizer after moving to Michigan in 2010.\n Shortly after moving, she founded ''Plainwell Patriots Tea Party'' and in 2011 founded ''Michigan 4 Conservative Senate''.\n\nIn 2011, Gamrat was leader of the ''Plainwell Patriots Tea Party'' which hosted a United States Senate candidate forum on November 22 of that year. The event featured  executive , former Kent County Judge Randy Hekman, libertarian activist  of Detroit,  of Midland, president of the ''American Family Association of Michigan'', and Roscommon businessman Peter Konetchy.\n\n''Michigan 4 Conservative Senate'', also founded by Gamrat, was patterned after successful efforts by Indiana tea party groups that rallied behind  as the tea party challenger to Republican U.S. Sen. . In Michigan, she organized more than 50 tea party groups, under the name ''Michigan 4 Conservative Senate (MI4CS)'', to try to avoid dispersing tea party clout in a field crowded with conservatives. In addition to coordinating forums by tea party groups around the state, ''MI4CS'' organized a candidate forum at  in Mount Pleasant Michigan on January 14, 2012. The forum preceded a convention of Michigan tea party groups that would decide which of the participating candidates they would support. Clark Durant, Randy Hekman, Scotty Boman, Chuck Marino and Gary Glenn participated, while Peter Konetchy, Rick Wilson, and former Congressman  chose not to.\n\n\nWith   unable to run for reelection due to s, Gamrat ran for election to the  for the 80th district in the 2014 elections on a platform focused on leadership and self-described \"family values\", while identifying as part of the . Gamrat defeated Geoff Parker of the  and Arnis Davidsons of the  in the .\n\nIn April 2015, Gamrat was permanently removed from the Michigan House's Republican Party caucus for violating their confidentiality rules with a  post. '''' published audio recordings on August 7, 2015, in which fellow Michigan Representative  asked staff to create a rumor that he had sex with a  in order to distract from the affair he was having with Gamrat. , the  of the Michigan House, initiated an investigation into their use of public funds to cover up their affair. She was found guilty of inappropriate behavior and expelled from the Michigan House on September 11, becoming the fourth lawmaker to be expelled from the legislature in Michigan history. Courser resigned before the House could pass a resolution to expel him.\n\nGamrat filed paperwork with the  Clerk to become a candidate in the  to fill her former seat. She received 9% of the vote in the primary election, finishing in third place.\n\nGamrat was charged with two felony counts of official misconduct for her role in the scandal on February 26, 2016, by  , which comes with a maximum penalty of five years in prison. On June 14, 2016, Lansing District Judge Hugh Clarke Jr. ruled that there is not enough probable cause for Gamrat to face felony misconduct in office charges.\n\n\nGamrat is a nurse from . She and her ex-husband, Joe, have three children, Paige, Joseph, and Meghan, whom they have homeschooled. Joe was accused of sending Cindy and Courser mysterious text messages during their affair, but was later cleared of any wrongdoing with no charges filed. She filed for divorce on August 3, 2016.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''David Lee Camp''' (born July 9, 1953) is a former American politician who served as a member of the  from 1991 to 2015. Camp represented  since 1993, and previously served one term representing . A member of the , Camp was chairman of the , serving from 2011 to 2015. In March 2014, he announced that he would not run for re-election.\n\n\nCamp was born in , the son of Norma L. (Nehil) and Robert D. Camp. He graduated from  in 1971. He attended the , , 1973–1974 and earned his , magna cum laude, in 1975 from  in . He earned a  from the  School of Law in 1978. From 1979 to 1991, he was a partner with the law firm Riecker, Van Dam & Barker in Midland, Michigan.\n\nCamp was diagnosed with early-stage non-Hodgkin's  in 2012. After several months of chemotherapy, Camp announced he was cancer-free in December 2012.\n\n\nCamp worked as a member of the  board of canvassers and a member of the Midland County  executive committee. For 4 years he was special assistant to the  from 1980 to 1984. He served another 4 years on the staff of his boyhood friend   (R-MI) from 1984 to 1987, before running and winning the  of the  in 1988 and serving one term.\n\n\n\n\nWhen U.S. Congressman Schuette of  decided in 1990 to run for the U.S. Senate against incumbent U.S. Senator , Camp ran to replace him and won the endorsement of his former boss. In the Republican primary he faced former U.S. Congressman  and former State Senator . Despite trailing Dunn in early polls, Camp won the Republican primary with a plurality of 33%. He defeated Cropsey (30%), Allen (19%), Dunn (18%), and Simcox (1%). He won the general election with 65% of the vote.\n\nAfter redistricting, he decided to run in . He won the general election with 62% of the vote. He never won re-election with less than 61% of the vote and never had a primary challenge.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCamp served on the House Committee on Agriculture.  For his work on behalf of Michigan agriculture, Camp received the Golden Plow Award in 1998, the American Farm Bureau Federation's highest honor given to only one Member of the House in each Congress.\n\n\n\nIn the , he served as a deputy  and served on the . Speaker  chose Camp to serve on the Select , which had been created by the House of Representatives on January 7, 2003. While on the committee Camp was the Chairman of the Subcommittee on Infrastructure and Border Security, where he helped develop policies to secure U.S. land and maritime borders in the wake of the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks.\n\n\n\nCamp was the Ranking Member of the Subcommittee on Health, and Chairman of the Subcommittee on Select Revenue Measures, respectively.  He served seven terms as a Member of the Subcommittee on Human Resources, and six terms as a Member of the Subcommittee on Trade. As a junior Member of the committee in 1996, Camp played a role in the passage of the .\n\n\n\nCamp served as Ranking Member of the full committee on Ways and Means. Camp was one of three House Republicans appointed by then-Minority Leader  (R-OH) to serve on the ,  known as the Bowles-Simpson Commission, formed in February 2010. It was charged with identifying policies to improve the U.S. fiscal situation in the medium term, and to achieve  over the long term. While on the Commission, which failed to achieve its aims and did not see enactment of any of its proposals, Camp co-led the Tax Reform Working Group and was a member of the Mandatory Spending Working Group.\n\n\n\nCamp was involved in the House Republicans' January 2011 attempt to repeal the .\n\n\n\nCamp introduced the  into the House on September 27, 2013.  The bill reauthorized the Adoption Incentives Program that focuses on helping states to find adoptive parents for foster children and passed the House on October 22, 2013. Camp later introduced the  which passed the House on July 23, 2014.\n\nOn June 26, 2014, Camp introduced the , a bill intended to change and improve 's post-acute care (PAC) services and how they are reported on.\n\n\n.]]\n* '''''' (Chairman)\n* '''''' (Chairman)\n* ''''''\n\n\n* Building a Better America Caucus\n* \n* Life Insurance Caucus\n* Sportsmen's Caucus\n* Zero Capital Gains Tax Caucus\n* Congressional Cement Caucus\n\n\n\"I'm a conservative on fiscal policy, but I'm a moderate on some other issues,\" he told Congressional Quarterly in 2006. He told National Review in 2007 that he feels \"more at home\" with the conservative Republican Steering Committee. Camp is part of the moderate bloc through his participation in the Main Street Partnership. He generally voted along party lines in the House, siding with Republicans 93.7 percent of the time during the 111th Congress. The  gave him a lifetime rating of 89 percent, his score with the  is considerably lower. Camp voted for both the  and the . Camp opposes abortion and same-sex marriage. He voted twice for President George W. Bush's tax cuts, and supports their full extension. He pushed for private accounts for Social Security and he supports drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. Camp supported the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, and he backed President Bush's decision to send more troops to Iraq in 2007 with some reservations. In August 2013 Camp announced his support for cutting benefits to the  (TANF) program.\n\nCamp introduced the Tax Reform Act of 2014 on February 26, 2014. The congressional nonpartisan  calculated the bill would allow 95 percent of filers to get the lowest tax rate possible by claiming the standard deduction, would create up to 1.8 million jobs and increase gross domestic product by up to 1.4% in 2023.\n\nWhen the Chicago office of the  took action against  regarding dioxin pollution of waterways leading into the Saginaw River, he had regional EPA director Mary Gade fired in 2008.  The resulting reluctance of that EPA regional office to take action regarding major environmental issues led to their inaction in the .  Camp's wife was Dow's attorney.\n\n\nApproximately one year after announcing his decision not to run for re-election to Congress, it was announced that Camp would be joining prominent accounting firm  as a senior policy advisor.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Matt Koleszar''' (born September 21, 1981) is an American politician serving as a member of the  from the 22nd district (formerly District 20). He was first elected in November 2018, defeating incumbent  , and was re-elected in 2020. Due to decennial re-districting, in 2022 Koleszar ran for the 22nd district, which includes  and parts of , , , and ; he was elected as the first representative for the new district.\n\n\nKoleszar was born in . He earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in secondary education with a focus on social studies and English from  in 2006, and a Master of Arts degree in English studies for teachers from  in 2011.\n\n\nBefore his election as a state representative, Koleszar had taught middle school and high school social studies and English for 12 years in the  in , coached cross country and baseball, and served as president of the Airport Education Association.\n\n\nKoleszar served as assistant Democratic leader in 2019 and 2020, and as Democratic whip in 2021 and 2022. He has introduced legislation on issues ranging from air quality to school libraries, as well as tuition assistance for the children of fallen Police Officers and Firefighters. He has served on the House committees for education, higher education, health policy, education policy, elections and ethics, labor, and school aid. After the Democrats won control of the state legislature in the 2022 elections, he was appointed chair of the education committee.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nKoleszar is married to Kimberly Bush-Koleszar.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Horace Sheffield III''' (born December 28, 1954) is an American pastor and media personality. Sheffield is the Pastor of New Destiny Christian Fellowship.\n\nSheffield as of 2018 serves as the Co-Chair of the  Community Democratic Caucus.\n\n\nSheffield was born in Detroit, Michigan. He is the son of Mary (née Otto), and Rev. Horace Sheffield, Jr., a supervisor at . The elder Sheffield fought to create the UAW's Inter-Racial Committee. Later, he was instrumental in helping stage the legendary April 1941 workers strike at Ford.\n\nSheffield is the father of Detroit City Council President Pro Tem Mary Sheffield.\n\n\nAfter graduating Cass Tech High School, Sheffield attended Wayne State University, where he received his B.A. in History & English In 1995, Sheffield earned a  Masters in Public Administration from the . In 2000, the University of Michigan awarded Sheffield its \"African American Alumni Affiliate Alumnus of the Year\" award. In 2016, the University of Michigan awarded Sheffield its \"Making A Difference (M.A.D.)\" Award.\n\n\nSheffield is the CEO of the Detroit Association of Black Organizations, Chairman of the Detroit Ecumenical Ministers Alliance and Founder/Former President of both the Detroit and Michigan Chapters of the . He is also the pastor of the New Destiny Christian Fellowship.\n\nSheffield also founded the Detroit Cares Alternative Academy.\n\nIn 2003, Sheffield co-wrote a letter with  to American Honda, complaining that the company did not hire enough African-Americans in management. \"We support those that support us,\" the letter said. \"We cannot be silent while African-Americans spend hard-earned dollars with a company that does not hire, promote or do business with us in a statistically significant manner.\"\n\nIn 2009, Sheffield led the National Black Leadership Commission, a conference by African-American clergy about the spread of .\n\nSheffield served as a member of the organizing committee for the 2009 , that was hosted at  in Detroit.\n\nIn 2016, Sheffield started the \"Bust the Ball\" campaign, which held protests August 17 in Detroit, and on August 29 in New York over his concerns that the  was engaging in \"Green-lining\", or being exclusionary of non-white agents and staff.\n\nOn Christmas morning 2016, a man left a message on a New Destiny Christian Fellowship prayer hotline, using racial slurs and threatening to firebomb Sheffield's church.\n\n\nIn 1979, Sheffield was a founding co-chair of The Commission for the Advancement of Policy Affecting Youth, the Disadvantaged and the Poor.\n\nIn 2014, Sheffield was called by a federal grand jury to talk about what he knew regarding efforts to influence the selection of  leaders. The  was investigating rumors that Thomas Hardiman, President and CEO of A&H Contractors, was reportedly trying to bribe Detroit City Council members, in an attempt to influence the outcome of the vote for Council President. Sheffield said he was angry because Hardiman approached his daughter, Councilwoman Mary Sheffield, about the vote.\n\n\nIn April 2014, Sheffield filed to run in the Democratic Primary Election for Michigan's 13th Congressional District, against incumbent John Conyers. During the election, Sheffield challenged the signatures Conyers had gathered after it was discovered that the signature collectors were not registered to vote in the district. Wayne County Clerk Cathy Garrett ruled that the signatures were invalid, which would have made Conyers ineligible. Conyers and the ACLU filed a successful lawsuit claiming that the law was unconstitutional, and Conyers was allowed to run. On August 5, 2014, John Conyers won the primary election, receiving 86% of the vote.\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n'''John D. Cherry Jr.''' (born May 5, 1951) is an American politician who served as the 62nd  from 2003 to 2011. A , Cherry also served as a  appointee to the , and was the immediate past chair of the international  (of which he is still a member).\n\nCherry was an announced candidate for  in . However, on January 5, he announced his withdrawal from the race, citing an inability to \"secure enough money to make my candidacy fully viable.\"\n\n\nCherry grew up in , and graduated from  1969. Cherry earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in  from the  in 1973 and a  from the  in 1984. He is of Polish and Scots-Irish descent.\n\n\nA former staff member to  Gary Corbin, Cherry served as the state political director for the , until 1982. He was then elected to the  as a  (1983–1986),  (1987–2002) and Senate .\n\nCherry was elected in 2002 as the  of  , passing on his state senate seat to his sister . As the lieutenant governor, John Cherry presided over the State Senate, casting votes there in the event of a tie.\n\nAs lieutenant governor, John Cherry was elected chairman of the  (NLGA) in July 2006. John Cherry also chaired the Lt. Governor’s Commission on Higher Education & Economic Growth, with the commission making recommendations on  and the need to expand Michigan's job base. The Cherry Commission report led to the ''Michigan Promise'' scholarship, the ''No Worker Left Behind'' program, and Michigan replacing the high school  exam with the . Michigan also increased standards in the K-12 curriculum and graduation requirements consistent with the Commission's recommendations.\n\nCherry has been awarded  degree from  and an Honorary Doctor of Public Service degree from . He has earned several awards including being recognized as \"one of Michigan’s Most Effective Legislators\" by '''' and the 2005  of the Year by the Michigan United Conservation Clubs.Cherry serves as the Chairman of the St. Andrew's Society of Detroit's Board of Trustees 2016 to present. Cherry serves as the Vice-President of the Council of Scottish Clans and Associations 2016 to present, and as President of the Clan MacLachlan Association of North America 2014 to present.\n\n\nCherry is married to former State Representative . They have two adult children, Meghan and , and four grandchildren.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Rose Mary Robinson''' (born December 12, 1939) is an American lawyer and a former  member of the .\n\n\n\nRose Mary Robinson was born on December 12, 1939. In 1972, Robinson earned a  degree from  in , .\n\n\nRobinson started her legal career as a Legal Council for  for Council 25. In 1970, with the help from , Robinson was one of the first women elected as a  in . Robinson served as the County Commissioner until 1982. In 2006, 2008, and 2010, Robinson was a delegate for the Democratic Precinct.\n\nOn November 6, 2012, Robinson won the election and became a member of the  for  and won reelection two more times being term limits prevented her from seeking another. In February 2015, Robinson cosponsored HB 4209, a bill that establishes regulations for  facilities. In September 2017, Robinson cosponsored HB 4991, a bill that appropriates $1.3 billion for fiscal year 2019. Due to term limits, Robinson did not campaign in the 2018 election.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* ()\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''David M. Knezek Jr.''' (born August 13, 1986) is an American politician who represents the 8th district on the . He is a member of the . Prior to his appointment to the Wayne County Commission in 2020, he served as a member of the  from 2015 to 2018 and as a member of the  from 2013 to 2014.\nKnezek was defeated in the August 2018 Michigan Senate District  5 Democratic Primary by dark horse candidate  who reported spending nothing on the campaign.\n\n\nKnezek has a bachelor's degree in political science from the .  He then served in the U.S. military as a  platoon member in the , completing two tours of duty in . He was honorably discharged in 2014, having risen to the rank of sergeant.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*  \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Elizabeth Brater''' (born April 12, 1951) is a  former member of the , who represented the  from 2003 to 2010, and served as the Assistant Minority Leader. Her district included the cities of  and . She was previously a member of the  from 1995 to 2000.\n\n\nBrater was born in . After graduating high school in 1969, she enrolled at the , where she remained for two years, but transferred to the , completing her  in English in 1973. She continued to receive an  in History, '''', in 1976, and was a member of . She moved to  in 1975, when her husband, Enoch Brater, took a job as an English professor at the . In Ann Arbor, she worked as an editor and writer, also teaching courses on local government and writing at the university.\n\n\nBrater won election as a  to the  city council from the city's Third Ward in 1988. She then ran for mayor of Ann Arbor in April 1991, defeating two-term incumbent  mayor . Brater was the first woman to be elected mayor of Ann Arbor. As mayor, Brater established the city's extensive  program. \nAfter serving one two-year term, she was defeated in her mayoral reelection campaign, losing in April 1993 to the  challenger, former city council member , who went on to serve four two-year terms as mayor.\n\nAfter her mayoral defeat, Brater ran successfully for the  in November 1994. She served in the House from 1995 to 2000, representing . Term limits prevented Brater from running for a fourth term.\n\nBrater was honored by the Michigan Sierra Club as its 1996 Environmentalist of the Year and by the Alliance for the Mentally Ill of Michigan as its 1998 Legislator of the Year.\n\nIn November 2002, Brater won election to the . In the Democratic primary, she defeated a fellow member of the Michigan House, John Hansen of . In the general election, she triumphed easily over  candidate Gordon Darr, a  Trustee, and  candidate Elliott Smith. In 2006, she was re-elected with more than 71% of the vote, but in 2010 was term-limited and thus barred from seeking re-election.\n\n\nIn the , Brater was a member of the Judiciary and Finance committees, the vice-chair of the Natural Resources and Environmental Affairs and the Agriculture, Forestry and Tourism committees. Brater also served as a member of the Governor's Land Use Leadership Council.\n\n\n*'''2006 Election for the Michigan State Senate - 18th District'''\n\n\n*'''2002 Election for the Michigan State Senate - 18th District'''\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* '''official government website'''\n** video clips\n* profile\n*''Follow the Money'' - Liz Brater\n**    Senate campaign contributions\n**   House campaign contributions\n* \n*\n* at ''PoliticalGraveyard.com''\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Todd Anthony Courser''' (born August 2, 1972) is an American lawyer,   politician, and former member of the  who resigned his seat when it became clear that he would be expelled for misconduct and the misuse of taxpayer resources in an attempt to cover up his extramarital affair with fellow Representative .\n\n\nHe graduated from the  with a  in 1995 and from the  with a  in 2003.\n\nCourser was admitted to the  in 2006 and continues to practice law in his firm, Todd A. Courser & Associates, PLLC.\n\n\nCourser ran unsuccessfully for a seat in the  in 2008, for the  in 2010, and for the state Board of Education in 2012. In 2013, Courser unsuccessfully challenged incumbent Chairman of the Michigan Republican Party, .\n\n\nIn 2014, Courser again ran for a seat in the Michigan House of Representatives. A primary election was held on August 5, 2014, and a general election was held on November 4, 2014. The signature-filing deadline for candidates wishing to run in this election was April 22, 2014. Margaret Guerrero-DeLuca defeated Immanuel Eickholdt in the Democratic primary. Todd Courser defeated Jacob Hunsanger, Jan Peabody and Sharna Smith in the Republican primary. Courser defeated DeLuca in the general election.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n'''' published audio recordings on August 7, 2015, in which Courser asked staff to create a rumor that he had sex with a  in order to distract from the affair he was having with , also a member of the Michigan House of Representatives. , the  of the Michigan House, initiated an investigation into their use of public funds to cover up their affair. Despite calls to resign from office, Courser claimed he was being blackmailed by mainstream Michigan Republicans and would not resign.\n\nIn the pre-dawn hours of September 11, 2015, Courser resigned after several hours of a stalemate on his expulsion vote. Gamrat was subsequently expelled from the House. Courser announced that he would run in the  to fill his vacated seat. Courser finished in fifth place in the primary election, with less than 4% of the vote.\n\nCourser was charged with four felonies over his role in the scandal on February 26, 2016, by  . He was charged with three separate counts of official misconduct, which carries a maximum penalty of five years in prison and one count of , which carries a maximum penalty of 15 years in prison. Courser is represented by Portage-based attorney Matthew S. DePerno.\n\nIn April 2016, Courser announced his candidacy for Lapeer County Prosecutor. He was unsuccessful in the August Republican primary, garnering about 4% of the vote.\n\nBoth Courser and Gamrat launched their own independent radio programs on WFDF-AM (910) in April, and then May respectively, of 2016.\n\nIn  2016, Lansing District Court Judge Hugh B. Clarke Jr. ordered Courser to stand trial on two felony counts (one count of perjury and one count of misconduct in office), while dismissing both felony counts against Gamrat.\n\nIn 2019, Courser pleaded no contest to willful neglect of duty by a public officer, a misdemeanor. He received probation.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Garfield attended the .\n\n\nGarfield worked as a carpenter and an electrical estimator. Garfield served on the  Board of Commissioners. On November 5, 2002, Garfield was elected to the  where he represented the  from January 8, 2003 to December 31, 2008. During his time in the legislature, Garfield resided in .\n\n\nIn September 2005, Garfield was arrested for . In the Oakland County 52-4 District Court in , Garfield entered a guilty plea, and entered himself into rehabilitation for alcoholism and pain medication misuse.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Michael Charles Mueller''' (born September 30, 1974) is a  member of the .\n\n\nMueller was born on September 30, 1974, in . Mueller graduated from  in 1992. He served in the United States Navy from 1993 to 1997. In 1999, Mueller earned a BS in criminology from . Mueller then graduated from police academy.\n\n\nMueller was employed as sheriff deputy in  and , beginning in 2000. Mueller also owned Mueller’s Orchard and Cider Mill, a family business, and operated Birchview Outdoor Wedding & Event Center.\n\nMueller entered politics in 2018, when he began his campaign for Michigan state representative in the , to fill the seat of the term limited State Representative . Mueller campaigned on auto insurance reform and reducing taxes for retirees. He faced a four way challenge in the Republican primary. Drew Shapiro, who had served as Genesee County commissioner, was the only one in the primary who had previous experience in elected office. The other candidates were Matthew Anderton and Ian Shetron. Before the primary election, a political action committee called the Michigan Freedom Network, which endorsed Mueller's candidacy, made a website featuring references Shapiro's criminal record, including marijuana possession and domestic violence, as well as his mugshot. Mueller claimed his campaign was not involved with the Michigan Freedom Network's website. Mueller ultimately won the primary with 65% of the vote, with Shapiro in second place.\n\nAfter winning the Republican nomination, Mueller faced the Democratic nominee David Lossing in the general election. Lossing previously served as mayor of Linden, and had also worked as an adjunct professor for the  in Ann Arbor and Flint. Mueller's won the November 6 election with 62% of the vote. On November 28, while state representative-elect, shortly before retiring as Livingston County deputy sheriff, Mueller was patrolling , when another vehicle struck his patrol car. Mueller testified in June 2019 that the driver, Alfred Smith, then attempted to flee, with Mueller eventually catching up to Smith and getting into a scuffle with him.\n\nIn Mueller's first term, he served on the following legislative committees: Agriculture, Health Policy, and Energy. He also serve as vice chair of the Committee on Military, Veterans' Affairs and Homeland Security. As vice chair of said committee, in April 2019, Mueller voted with the rest of the Republicans in the committee to pass two bills which sought to ban  in Michigan, which was criticized by the  as well as the sheriff's departments of  and Washtenaw County. Later in his first term, in March 2020, Mueller introduced bill which sought to ban excessively increasing the price of temporary accommodations in during emergencies, with Democratic State Senator  proposing a Senate counterpart bill.\n\nIn 2020, Mueller was unopposed in the Republican primary. In the general election, he faced Democratic nominee Brad May. May was a mental health clinician who dealt both general mental health and substance abuse. In October 2020, it was revealed by the Michigan Republican Party that May had a criminal history, including robbery and drug use, which May confirmed had been in response to the death of his daughter. Mueller defeated May in the November general election with 64% of the vote.\n\nIn his second term, Mueller served on the following legislative committees: Regulatory Reform, Judiciary, Health Policy, and Government Operations. Mueller serves as the Chair of the Committee on Government Operations and the Majority Vice-chair of the Committee on Judiciary. In March 2021, Mueller collaborated with Democratic State Representative  and Republican State Representative  to introduce a set of three bills banning hand-based cellphone usage while driving. Specifically, the bills banned the use of social media while driving, as previous laws only prevented texting. Mueller explained that the bills would not stop all distracted driving, but says that they will “give closure to some of the victims that have been killed by people who have done it.” In June 2021, Mueller joined a bipartisan coalition of state legislators to introduce a package of four bills designed to increase the legal ramifications for drive-by shootings, in response to the murder of 3-year old Messiah Williams.\n\nIn December 2021, the state house passed a spending bill of $368.5 million for public safety and police funding, an increase from the $80 million dollar plan proposed earlier in May. A sponsor of the bill, Mueller cited the  as a reason for increased funding. Mueller was named one of the 2021 \"Legislators of the Year\" by the Police Officers Association of Michigan for securing funding for the police, and received similar awards from the Michigan Association of Chiefs of Police. In May 2022, Mueller proposed a bill, which would allow $10 million dollars to be a located to creating critical incident mapping, with the use of satellite imagery, of every private and public school in Michigan for first responders, including police and medical staff, to use during emergencies. The bill passed through the state house unanimously in June 2022.\n\nIn the 2022 Republican primary, redistricting moved Mueller from the 51st district to the . On August 2, Mueller won a three-way primary election against Dylan Pescarolo in second place and Brandy Bush. In November 2022, Mueller defeated Stacy Taylor of . Mueller received 58.1% of the vote.\n\n\nSometime after 2015, Mueller married Angela Acox. Together, they have four children.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Fred Maltby Warner''' (July 21, 1865 – April 17, 1923) was an American politician who served as the 26th  from 1905 to 1911. He also served as the 24th  from 1901 to 1905.\n\n\nBorn in , England, Warner spent most of his life in Michigan. Warner was orphaned at three months of age and adopted by a family in . His adoptive father, , served in both chambers of the state legislature during periods from 1852 to 1870.\n\nHe attended the common schools there and later attended the Michigan Agricultural College (now ). He worked at his father's store and later, as a Farmington businessman and , he established thirteen cheese factories.\n\n\nAs a prominent citizen he rose quickly in politics in 1894. From 1895 to 1898 he served in the  just as his father did. From 1901 until 1904 he served as the  under .\n\nIn 1904, Warner was elected  and served three terms, 1905–1911. He was known as a  governor advocating such policies as regulation of railroad and insurance, ,  and . Also during his six years in office, a factory inspection bill was authorized, a direct primary election law was sanctioned and there was a promotion of highway construction.\n\n\nImage:GovWarnerMansion.jpg|Warner Mansion in Farmington, Michigan was the Governor's residence and is now a historical site\nImage:GovWarnerMansionSign.jpg|\nImage:Fred M Warner.jpg|Portrait of Warner\n\n\n\nAfter leaving office, he stayed politically active. Warner was a member of the , , , , and . In 1920, he began serving as a man until his death three years later. He died at the age of 57 from kidney failure and is interred at Oakwood Cemetery in Farmington, Michigan.\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n* via web.archive.org.
